<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiation-physics">Radiation physics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-physics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-contents">CHAPTER CONTENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-contents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1.1 Structure of the atom 1
1.2 Electromagnetic radiation 3
1.3 Production of X-rays 5
1.4 The interaction of X- and gamma rays with matter 9</p>
<p>1.4.1 Attenuation 9
1.4.2 Compton effect 11
1.4.3 Photoelectric effect 12
1.4.4 Relative importance of Compton and photoelectric effects 14
1.4.5 Secondary electrons and ionization 14</p>
<p>1.5 Filtration 15
1.6 Radiation dosimetry 16</p>
<p>1.6.1 Absorbed dose 16
1.6.2 Kerma 17
1.6.3 Measurement of X- and gamma ray dose 17
1.6.4 Radiation quantity and quality 19</p>
<p>1.7 Luminescence 19
1.8 Summary 20</p>
<p>Diagnostic imaging employs radiations - X, gamma, radiofrequency and sound - to which the body is partly but not completely transparent, and it exploits the special properties of a number of elements and compounds. As ionizing radiations (X-rays and gamma rays) are used most, it is best to start by discussing the structure of the atom and the production of X-rays. Some properties of the particles making up the atom and described elsewhere in this text are given in Table 1.1.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-1-structure-of-the-atom">1.1 STRUCTURE OF THE ATOM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-1-structure-of-the-atom" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An atom consists mainly of empty space. Its mass is concentrated in a central nucleus that contains a number  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span></span></span>  of nucleons (protons and neutrons), where  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span></span></span>  is called the mass number. The nucleus comprises  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span></span></span></span></span>  protons, where  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span></span></span></span></span>  is the atomic number of the element, and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(A - Z)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  neutrons. A nuclide is a species of nucleus characterized by the two numbers  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span></span></span> . The atomic number is synonymous with the name of the element. Thus,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>12</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{12}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">12</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  refers to a carbon atom with</p>
<p>Table 1.1 Some fundamental particles</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Relative mass</th><th>Relative charge</th><th>Symbol</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Nucleons</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Neutron</td><td>1</td><td>0</td><td>n</td></tr><tr><td>Proton</td><td>1</td><td>+1</td><td>p</td></tr><tr><td>Extranuclear</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Electron</td><td>0.00054</td><td>-1</td><td>e-,β-</td></tr><tr><td>Other</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Positron</td><td>0.00054</td><td>+1</td><td>e+,β+</td></tr><tr><td>Alpha particle</td><td>4</td><td>+2</td><td>α</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Radiation physics 3</p>
<p>Silver bromide is an example of an ionic crystal, and consists of equal numbers of positive silver ions (silver atoms that have each lost their single valence electron) and negative bromine ions (bromine atoms that have each gained an outer shell electron). The two kinds of ion hold each other, by electrostatic attraction, in a highly regular three-dimensional lattice. This accounts for the well-known properties of such crystals. Other examples encountered in imaging equipment are sodium iodide and caesium iodide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="binding-energy">Binding energy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#binding-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An atom is described as ionized when one of its electrons has been completely removed. The detached electron is a negative ion and the remnant atom a positive ion. Together, they form an ion pair.</p>
<p>The binding energy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(E)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> of an electron in an atom is the energy expended in completely removing the electron from the atom against the attractive force of the positive nucleus. This energy is expressed in electronvolts (eV), explained in Box 1.1.</p>
<p>The binding energy depends on the shell <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 17: …E_{\mathrm{K}} &amp;̲gt; E_{\mathrm{…" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">(E_{\mathrm{K}} &amp;gt; E_{\mathrm{L}} &amp;gt; E_{\mathrm{M}} \dots)</span></span> and on the element, increasing as the atomic number increases. For example, for tungsten <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>W</mi><mo separator="true">;</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>74</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(W; Z = 74)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">W</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">74</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> the binding energies of different shells are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>70</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_{\mathrm{K}} = 70</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_{\mathrm{L}} = 11</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">L</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_{\mathrm{M}} = 2\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">M</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>The K-shell binding energies of various elements encountered in X-ray imaging are given in Table 1.2.</p>
<p>An atom is excited when an electron is raised from one shell to another further out. This involves the expenditure of energy; the atom as a whole has more energy than normal and so is said to be excited. For example, a valence electron can be raised to one of the unoccupied shells further out, shown dashed in Figure 1.1. When it falls back, the energy is re-emitted as a single 'packet' of energy or photon of light (visible or ultraviolet). This is an example of the quantum aspects of electromagnetic radiation.</p>
<p>Table 1.2 Atomic number <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(Z)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> and K-shell binding energy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(E_{\mathrm{K}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> of various elements</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Element</th><th>Z</th><th><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_{\mathrm{K}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> (keV)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Aluminium</td><td>13</td><td>1.6</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium</td><td>20</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>Molybdenum</td><td>42</td><td>20</td></tr><tr><td>Iodine</td><td>53</td><td>33</td></tr><tr><td>Barium</td><td>56</td><td>37</td></tr><tr><td>Gadolinium</td><td>64</td><td>50</td></tr><tr><td>Tungsten</td><td>74</td><td>70</td></tr><tr><td>Lead</td><td>82</td><td>88</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-2-electromagnetic-radiation">1.2 ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-2-electromagnetic-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the term given to energy travelling across empty space. All forms of electromagnetic radiation travel with the same velocity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(c)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> as light when in vacuo, very close to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>8</mn></msup><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">8</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">ms</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and not significantly less in air. They are named according to the way in which they are produced and the special properties they possess. X-rays (emitted by X-ray tubes) and gamma rays (emitted by radioactive nuclei) have essentially the same properties and differ only in their origin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quantum-aspects">Quantum aspects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quantum-aspects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Electromagnetic radiation can be regarded as having particle-like properties. But rather than being composed of particles, the radiation is represented as a stream of packets or quanta of energy, called photons, that travel in straight lines.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wave-aspects">Wave aspects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wave-aspects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Electromagnetic radiation can also be regarded as sinusoidally varying electric and magnetic fields, travelling with velocity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> when in vacuo. They are transverse waves: the electric and magnetic field vectors point at right angles to each other and to the direction of travel of the wave.</p>
<p>At any point, the graph of field strength against time is a sine wave, depicted as a solid curve in Figure 1.2a. The peak field strength is called the amplitude <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(A)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. The interval between successive crests of the wave is called the period <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>T</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(T)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. The frequency <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(f)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is the number of crests passing a point in a second, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f = 1 / T</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span></span></span></span></span>. The dashed curve refers to a later instant, showing how the wave has travelled forwards with velocity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-5771a24d.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-565768c0.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 1.2 Electromagnetic wave. Field strength versus (a) time and (b) distance.</p>
<p>Copyrighted material</p>
<p>FARR'S PHYSICS FOR MEDICAL IMAGING</p>
<p>Table 1.3 Electromagnetic spectrum</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Radiation</th><th>Wavelength</th><th>Frequency</th><th>Energy</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Radiowaves</td><td>1000–0.1 m</td><td>0.3–3000 MHz</td><td>0.001–10 μeV</td></tr><tr><td>Microwaves</td><td>100–1 mm</td><td>3–300 GHz</td><td>10–1000 μeV</td></tr><tr><td>Infrared</td><td>100–1 μm</td><td>3–300 THz</td><td>10–1000 meV</td></tr><tr><td>Visible light</td><td>700–400 nm</td><td>430–750 THz</td><td>1.8–3 eV</td></tr><tr><td>Ultraviolet</td><td>400–10 nm</td><td>750–30000 THz</td><td>1.8–100 eV</td></tr><tr><td>X- and gamma rays</td><td>1 nm–0.1 pm</td><td>3 × 10⁵ – 3 × 10⁹ THz</td><td>1 keV–10 MeV</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>At any instant, the graph of field strength against distance is also a sine wave, as shown in Figure 1.2b. The distance between successive crests of the wave is called the wavelength <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\lambda)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Wavelength and frequency are inversely proportional to each other:</p>
<p>wavelength × frequency = constant.</p>
<p>Their product is equal to the velocity <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>λ</mi><mi>f</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\lambda f = c)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. This relation is true of all kinds of wave motion, including sound, although for sound the velocity is about a million times less.</p>
<p>The types of electromagnetic radiation are listed in Table 1.3, in order of increasing photon energy, increasing frequency, and decreasing wavelength. The values are rounded and the boundaries between the types of radiation are not well defined, other than for visible light, for which the boundaries are defined by the properties of the receptor, i.e. the human eye. The nomenclature that is most commonly used in practice is emphasized in bold in the table.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wave-and-quantum-theories-combined">Wave and quantum theories combined<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wave-and-quantum-theories-combined" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Photon energy is proportional to the frequency. The constant of proportionality is called Planck's constant <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(h)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Thus <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>h</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E = hf</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>More usefully, because frequency is inversely proportional to wavelength, so also is photon energy:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;keV</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>1.24</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>λ</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>in&nbsp;nm</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E (\text{in keV}) = 1.24 / \lambda (\text{in nm}).</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;keV</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1.24/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">in&nbsp;nm</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>For example:</p>
<p>Blue light <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>400</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda = 400\,\mathrm{nm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">nm</span></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>≈</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E \approx 3\,\mathrm{eV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">eV</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Typical X- and gamma rays <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>140</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E = 140\,\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">140</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>≈</mo><mn>0.1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda \approx 0.1\,\mathrm{nm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">nm</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intensity">Intensity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intensity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Radiation travels in straight lines called rays that radiate in all directions from a point source. A collimated set of rays is called a beam. A beam of radiation can be visualized by taking at some point a cross-section at right angles to the beam (Fig. 1.3a).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a28b8cb0.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg">
Figure 1.3 (a) Photon fluence and energy fluence. (b) The inverse square law applying to a point source S.</p>
<p>Suppose the beam is switched on for a given (exposure) time. Simply counting the photons allows the number per unit area passing through the cross-section in the time to be determined, and is called the photon fluence at the point. A beam may contain photons of different energies. Adding up the energies of all the individual photons gives the total amount of energy per unit area passing through the cross-section in the time, and is called the energy fluence at the point.</p>
<p>Copyrighted material</p>
<p>Radiation physics 5</p>
<p>The total amount of energy per unit area passing through the cross-section per unit time (watts per square millimetre) is called the energy fluence rate at the point, and is also referred to as the beam intensity. In wave theory, intensity is proportional to the square of the amplitude (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span></span></span></span></span>, see Fig. 1.2), measured from the peak of the wave to the axis.</p>
<p>Energy fluence and intensity are not easy to measure directly. As explained in section 1.6.2, in the case of X- and gamma rays an easier indirect measurement of energy fluence is usually made, namely air kerma, and, instead of intensity, air kerma rate. The relationship between these quantities is discussed later in section 1.6.4.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inverse-square-law">Inverse square law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inverse-square-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because electromagnetic radiation travels in straight lines, it follows that the dimensions of the beam are proportional to the distance from a point source S, as is shown in Figure 1.3b. As a result, the area of the beam is proportional to the square of the distance from a point source. Therefore the air kerma is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.</p>
<p>With reference to Figure 1.3b:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;at&nbsp;B</mtext><mtext>air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;at&nbsp;A</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>distance&nbsp;to&nbsp;A</mtext><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>distance&nbsp;to&nbsp;B</mtext><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{air kerma at B}}{\text{air kerma at A}} = \frac{(\text{distance to A})^2}{(\text{distance to B})^2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;at&nbsp;A</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;at&nbsp;B</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.4271em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.4911em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">distance&nbsp;to&nbsp;B</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7401em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">distance&nbsp;to&nbsp;A</span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>For the inverse square law to hold, it is essential that the radiation comes from a point source and that there is no absorption or scatter of radiation between the source and the points of measurement. Figure 1.3b has been drawn such that the distance from the source doubles in going from A to B. In this instance, the air kerma reduces by a factor of 4.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-3-production-of-x-rays">1.3 PRODUCTION OF X-RAYS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-3-production-of-x-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-x-ray-tube">The X-ray tube<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-x-ray-tube" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>X-rays are produced when fast-moving electrons are suddenly stopped by impact on a metal target. The kinetic energy of the electrons is converted into X-rays (no more than 1%) and into heat (≥99%).</p>
<p>An X-ray tube, depicted in Figure 1.4, consists of two electrodes sealed into an evacuated glass envelope:</p>
<ul>
<li>a negative electrode (cathode) that incorporates a fine tungsten coil or filament</li>
<li>a positive electrode (anode) that incorporates a smooth flat metal target, usually of tungsten.</li>
</ul>
<p>The filament is heated by passing an electrical current through it to a temperature at which it is white hot (incandescent). In this state, it emits electrons by the process of thermionic emission. At such high</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-2c2fa494.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg">
Figure 1.4 An X-ray tube and its power supplies.</p>
<p>temperatures (∼2200°C), the atomic and electronic motion in a metal is sufficiently violent to enable a fraction of the free electrons to leave the surface despite the net attractive pull of the lattice of positive ions.</p>
<p>The electrons are then repelled by the negative cathode and attracted by the positive anode. Because of the vacuum, they are not hindered in any way and bombard the target with a velocity around half the speed of light.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kilovoltage-and-milliamperage">Kilovoltage and milliamperage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kilovoltage-and-milliamperage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Two sources of electrical energy are required and are derived from the alternating current (AC) mains by means of transformers. Figure 1.4 shows:</p>
<ul>
<li>the filament heating voltage (about 10 V) and current (about 10 A)</li>
<li>the accelerating voltage (typically 30–150 kV) between the anode and cathode (referred to as tube potential, high voltage, kilovoltage or kV); this drives the current of electrons (typically 0.5–1000 mA) flowing between the anode and cathode (referred to as tube current, milliamperage or mA).</li>
</ul>
<p>The mA is controlled by adjusting the filament voltage and current and thus filament temperature. A small increase in temperature produces a large increase in tube current.</p>
<p>An X-ray set is designed so that, unlike most electrical components, increasing or decreasing the tube voltage does not affect the tube current. It is also designed so that the kV is unaffected by changes in the mA. The two factors can therefore be varied independently.</p>
<p>The waveform of a high-voltage generator can be described graphically to demonstrate how voltage varies with time. Figure 1.5 depicts the waveforms of four types of high-tension voltage supply. These are explained in Box 1.2.</p>
<p>Copyrighted material</p>
<p>FARR'S PHYSICS FOR MEDICAL IMAGING</p>
<p>The dashed line (B) in Figure 1.8 shows the spectrum of bremsstrahlung produced near the target nuclei. In fact, the target itself, the glass wall of the tube, and other materials collectively referred to as the filtration, substantially absorb the lower-energy photons. There is therefore a low-energy cut-off, at about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>, as well as a maximum energy. The latter depends only on the kV and the former on the filtration added to the tube (see section 1.5).</p>
<p>For the X-rays emerging from an X-ray tube operated at constant potential, the peak of the continuous spectrum (i.e. the most common photon energy) is typically between one-third and one-half of the kV. The average or effective energy is greater, between 50 and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span> of the maximum. Thus an X-ray tube operated at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">90</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span> can be thought of as emitting, effectively, 45-keV X-rays. As the operating kV is greater than the K-shell binding energy, characteristic X-rays are also produced. They are shown in Figure 1.8 as lines superimposed on the continuous spectrum.</p>
<p>The area of the spectrum represents the total output of all X-ray photons emitted. Figure 1.9 compares the spectrum from a tube with a tungsten target, operating at three different kV values. As the tube voltage is increased, both the width and height of the spectrum increase.</p>
<p>In the range <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>120</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 - 120\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">120</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>, the intensity of the emitted X-rays is approximately proportional to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{kV}^2\times \mathrm{mA}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9818em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8984em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mA</span></span></span></span></span></span>, the exact exponent being dependent on the filtration. This may be compared with the electrical power supplied, which is proportional to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{kV}\times \mathrm{mA}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mA</span></span></span></span></span></span>. The efficiency of X-ray production is the ratio</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>X-ray&nbsp;output</mtext><mtext>electrical&nbsp;power&nbsp;supplied</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{X-ray output}}{\text{electrical power supplied}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2408em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">electrical&nbsp;power&nbsp;supplied</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">X-ray&nbsp;output</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>and increases with the kV. The efficiency is also greater than the higher the atomic number of the target.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-cdd96497.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg">
Figure 1.8 An X-ray spectrum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controlling-the-x-ray-spectrum">Controlling the X-ray spectrum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controlling-the-x-ray-spectrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To summarize, there are five factors that affect the X-ray spectrum. The following are the effects of altering each in turn, the other four remaining constant.</p>
<ul>
<li>Increasing the kV shifts the spectrum upwards and to the right, as shown in Figure 1.9. It increases the maximum and effective energies and the total number of X-ray photons. Below a certain kV (70 kV for a tungsten target), the characteristic K-radiation is not produced.</li>
<li>Increasing the mA does not affect the shape of the spectrum but increases the output of both bremsstrahlung and characteristic radiation proportionately.</li>
<li>Changing the target to one of lower atomic number reduces the output of bremsstrahlung but does not otherwise affect its spectrum, unless the filtration is also changed. The photon energy of the characteristic lines will also be less.</li>
<li>Whatever the kV waveform (see Fig. 1.5), the maximum and minimum photon energies are unchanged. However, a constant potential or three-phase generator produces more X-rays and at higher energies than those produced by a single-phase pulsating potential generator when operated with the same values of kV and mA. Both the output and the effective energy of the beam are therefore greater. This is because in Figure 1.5c,d the tube voltage is at the same peak value throughout the exposure. In Figure 1.5a,b, it is below peak value during the greater part of each half cycle.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-03280bd0.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg">
Figure 1.9 Effect of tube kilovoltage (kV) on X-ray spectra for three tube potentials: A, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>; B, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>; and C, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>120</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">120\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">120</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Copyrighted material</p>
<p>Radiation physics 9</p>
<p>A half wave-rectified, single-phase generator (Fig. 1.5a) produces useful X-rays in pulses, each lasting about 3ms during the middle of each 20-ms cycle of the mains.</p>
<p>For the effect of the fifth factor, filtration, see section 1.5.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-4-the-interaction-of-x-and-gamma-rays-with-matter">1.4 THE INTERACTION OF X- AND GAMMA RAYS WITH MATTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-4-the-interaction-of-x-and-gamma-rays-with-matter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Where the following refers to X-rays, it applies equally well to gamma rays. Figure 1.10 illustrates the three possible fates of the individual photons when a beam of X- or gamma rays travels through matter. They may be any of the following.</p>
<ul>
<li>Transmitted: pass through unaffected, as primary or direct radiation.</li>
<li>Absorbed: transferring to the matter all of their energy (the photon disappearing completely).</li>
<li>Scattered: diverted in a new direction, with or without loss of energy transferring to the matter, and so may leave the material as scattered or secondary radiation.</li>
</ul>
<p>X-ray absorption and scattering processes are stochastic processes governed by the statistical laws of chance. It is impossible to predict which of the individual photons in a beam will be transmitted by 1mm of a material, but it is possible to be quite precise about the fraction of them that will be, on account of the large numbers of photons the beam contains.</p>
<p>The X-ray image is formed by the transmitted photons. Those that are absorbed or scattered represent attenuation by matter. An understanding of how the properties of X-rays and the materials through which they travel affect the relative amounts of attenuation and transmission gives an understanding of how the X-ray image is formed.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-0a627a6d.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg">
Figure 1.10 Interaction of X- or gamma rays with matter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-4-1-attenuation">1.4.1 Attenuation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-4-1-attenuation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Attenuation refers to the fact that there are fewer photons in the emerging beam than in the beam entering the material. It is represented by the photons that are completely absorbed and those that are scattered.</p>
<p>It is helpful to consider first the attenuation in a simple case.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-narrow-monoenergetic-beam-of-x-rays">A narrow, monoenergetic beam of X-rays<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-narrow-monoenergetic-beam-of-x-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The fundamental law of X-ray attenuation states that, for a monoenergetic beam, equal thicknesses of an absorber transmit equal fractions (percentages) of the radiation entering them. This is illustrated in Figure 1.11a, where each sheet reduces the beam by 20%.</p>
<p>In particular, the half-value layer (HVL) is the thickness of stated material that will reduce the intensity of a narrow beam of X-radiation to one-half of its original value. For example, as is shown in Figure 1.11b, two successive HVLs reduce the intensity of the beam by a factor <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{2} = 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span> from 1024 to 256. Ten HVLs would reduce the intensity of the beam by a factor <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>10</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1024</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{10} = 1024</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1024</span></span></span></span></span>, i.e. down to 1 in this example.</p>
<p>The HVL is a measure of the penetrating power or effective energy of the beam. It is useful to have a parameter that quantifies the attenuating properties of the material. This is the linear attenuation coefficient <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mu)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, which is inversely proportional to the HVL:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.693</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu = 0.693 / \mathrm{HVL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">0.693/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HVL</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>More precisely, the linear attenuation coefficient measures the probability that a photon interacts (i.e. is absorbed or scattered) per unit length of the path it travels in a specified material.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-661c4013.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<p>Copyrighted material</p>
<p>FARR'S PHYSICS FOR MEDICAL IMAGING</p>
<p>However, the linear attenuation coefficient applies only to narrow monoenergetic beams. The HVL can be used for beams that are not monoenergetic but applies only to narrow beams.</p>
<p>The HVL decreases and the linear attenuation coefficient therefore increases as:</p>
<ul>
<li>the density of the material increases</li>
<li>the atomic number of the material increases</li>
<li>the photon energy of the radiation decreases.</li>
</ul>
<p>For example, lead is more effective than either aluminium or tissue at absorbing X-rays, because of its higher density and atomic number. X-rays of 140 keV are more penetrating and are said to be 'harder' than those of 20 keV.</p>
<p>The mass attenuation coefficient <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mu/\rho)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">ρ</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is obtained by dividing the linear coefficient by the density of the material. It is therefore independent of density and depends only on the atomic number of the material and photon energy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exponential-graph">Exponential graph<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exponential-graph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>However thick the absorber, it is never possible to absorb an X-ray beam completely. This is shown, in Figure 1.12a, by the shape of the graph of percentage transmission versus thickness <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>, both being plotted on</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-e06948ab.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-825f1ebd.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg">
Figure 1.12 Exponential attenuation, half-value layers: (a) linear scale, (b) logarithmic scale. HVL, half-value layer.</p>
<p>linear scales. This is an exponential curve described by the equation</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>μ</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></msup><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I = I _ {0} e ^ {- \mu d},</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0935em;
