<li>Focal spot size is expressed in terms of the apparent or projected focal spot; sizes of 0.3, 0.6, 1.0, and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.2\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1.2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  are commonly employed.</li>
<li>Usually, an X-ray tube has two filaments and two focal spots of different sizes which are selected from the control panel.</li>
</ul>
<p>The smaller focal spot is selected where small fields are needed &amp; for better resolution "in mammography and in cineradiography with a small field image intensifier" and the larger one for thicker parts of the body where a greater intensity of X-rays is needed "in general radiography using large films" (Table 2.1).</p>
<p>Table 2.1 Typical effective focal sizes (mm)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Macromammography</th><th>0.1</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Mammography</td><td>0.3</td></tr><tr><td>Macroradiography</td><td>0.3</td></tr><tr><td>Radiography</td><td>0.6-1.2</td></tr><tr><td>Fluoroscopy</td><td>0.6</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>MCQ X-ray output: DOES NOT depend on focal size, only sharpness and effective field of view do.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measurement-of-the-effective-focal-spot">MEASUREMENT OF THE EFFECTIVE FOCAL SPOT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-the-effective-focal-spot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two principal methods of measuring the effective focal spot.</p>
<p>14</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pinhole-camera">'PINHOLE CAMERA'<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pinhole-camera" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-726869df.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>This consists of a hole drilled in a disk of heavy metal, such as gold, incorporated in a lead sheet.</li>
<li>Must be positioned <strong>half way</strong> between the focal spot and the film.</li>
</ul>
<p>The pinhole is may be positioned closer to the tube anode than to the cassette → magnified image of the effective focal spot → knowing the magnification enables the true size of the effective focal spot to be calculated.</p>
<ul>
<li>It is important to <strong>align the pinhole to central beam of the X-ray tube accurately</strong>.</li>
<li>The pinhole must be <strong>several times smaller than the focal spot</strong> (e.g. pinhole of <strong>0.03 mm</strong> for focal spots below 1mm, and <strong>0.08 mm</strong> for focal spots from 1 to 2.5 mm).</li>
<li>Although X-rays diverge in all directions from each point on the target, only one of them passes through the pinhole, and it produces a dot of blackening on the film.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="notice-the-following">Notice the following:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#notice-the-following" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pinhole size of 0.03mm is very small, so special equipments are needed for accurate measurement.</li>
<li>Intensity is <strong>more towards periphery of the focal spot</strong> (edge band distribution → commonest pattern, though undesired).</li>
<li>The resulting image (Fig. 2.12b) shows:
a. <strong>The size &amp; shape</strong> of the <strong>effective focal spot</strong>.
b. Density pattern represents <strong>intensity distribution</strong> &amp; any lack of uniformity is shown.
c. Reveals any <strong>extra-focal X-radiation</strong> "which degrades image".</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-2579c6d5.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="star-test-tool">STAR TEST TOOL:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#star-test-tool" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>This technique is <strong>used in measuring focal spots less than 0.3 mm</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A 'star test' tool comprises a number of tapered 'spokes' of lead mounted on a Perspex disk (Figure).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This is mounted partway between the film and the tube (not in contact with film).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exposure produces a magnified and unsharp image of the star (Fig. 2.13b), shows following features:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>RING OF BLURRING  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Diameter of ring is used to calculate the effective focal spot size.</li>
<li>Outside this ring a sharp NEGATIVE image is produced.</li>
<li>Paradoxically, inside the ring there is a POSITIVE and sharp image of the spokes.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9c9b38e8.jpeg" alt="img-40.jpeg">
(a)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-33aba13f.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg">
(b)
Fig. 2.13: Measurement of the effective focal spot with a 'star test' tool, (a) The star test tool, (b) Image with a blurring diameter</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blooming">Blooming<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blooming" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Blooming = unwanted increase in focal spot size which occurs when the tube is operated at high milliamperage.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Occurs because the negative charge of the focusing cup is less effective, so electrons emitted from the filament are not well focused in a regular beam  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  hit a larger area  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 1: &amp;̲gt;" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">&amp;gt;</span></span>  actual focal spot.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  It occurs particularly at low  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">kV</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span>  values and with small focal spots.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="regarding-focal-spot">Regarding focal spot:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regarding-focal-spot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The focal spot size can limit the spatial resolution "geometric unsharpness", depends on the location of the object in the source-to-detector direction.</li>
<li>The resolution impact of the focal spot increases with geometric magnification, i.e. increasing distance between the object and the film or detector if FFD is fixed.</li>
</ul>
<p>Thus, a small focal spot is desired in order to optimize spatial resolution.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The focal spot size also sets the upper limit on X-ray tube current or output rate (heat loading).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If an X-ray tube is operating at its instantaneous power limit, decreasing the size of the focal spot will require a decrease in the tube current (radiation output).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>:: There is a trade-off between spatial resolution due to the size of the focal spot &amp; image noise in a fixed exposure time due to the decreased X-ray intensity and imaging time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-7-4-uniformity-of-the-x-ray-beam">2.7.4 UNIFORMITY OF THE X-RAY BEAM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-7-4-uniformity-of-the-x-ray-beam" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The useful X-ray beam is taken in a direction perpendicular to the electron stream "at right angles to the tube axis from the center of the focal spot". (B in Fig. 2.15).</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  It is usually pointed toward the center of the area of interest in the body.</p>
<p>" Toward the anode edge of the field, the beam A is cut off by the face of the target.</p>
<p>Toward the cathode edge, the beam C is cut-off by the edge aperture in the lead shield.</p>
<p>Thus, the X-ray field is made symmetrical around the central ray  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{B}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">B</span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>  are the limits of the useful beam.</p>
<p>In fact the useful beam is narrower than suggested because of THE HEEL EFFECT.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b6324aee.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg">
Fig. 2.15 Heel effect.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-heel-effect">THE HEEL EFFECT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-heel-effect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The intensity of the x-ray beam that leaves the x-ray tube is not uniform but depends on the angle at which the x rays are emitted from the focal spot.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-mechanisms">2. Mechanisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Electrons penetrate a few micrometers into the target before being stopped by a nucleus  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  so; the X-rays produced are attenuated and filtered by the target material on their way out.
X-rays traveling toward the anode edge of the field have more target material to cross  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  :attenuated more than those traveling toward the cathode edge  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the intensity of the beam decreases toward the anode end of the fields (Less importantly, the HVL increases because of the filtration effect).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-589daa07.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-for-the-one-time-life-cycle-effect">3. For the one-time life cycle effect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-for-the-one-time-life-cycle-effect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Anode angle: the steeper the target  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  heel effect.</li>
<li>FFD:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  FFD  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓↓</span></span></span></span></span>  heel effect "with fixed film size".</li>
<li>Film size:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓↓</span></span></span></span></span>  film size  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓↓</span></span></span></span></span>  heel effect "with fixed FFD".</li>
<li>Roughening of the target surface  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓↓</span></span></span></span></span>  X-rays output &amp;  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  the heel effect.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>In radiographs of body parts of different thicknesses  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the thicker parts should be placed toward the cathode (filament) side of the x-ray tube.</li>
</ul>
<p>e.g. AP film of the thoracic spine  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  anode end over the upper thoracic spine where the body is less thick &amp; the cathode end of the tube is over the lower thoracic spine where thicker body structures will receive the increased exposure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-7-3-heat-rating">2.7.3 HEAT RATING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-7-3-heat-rating" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The heat loading of an X-ray tube (calculated in joules)</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= \mathrm{kV} \times \mathrm{mAs}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mAs</span></span></span></span></span></span>  for a constant potential (three phase).
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>×</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= 0.7 \times \mathrm{kV} \times \mathrm{mAs}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.7</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mAs</span></span></span></span></span></span>  for a pulsating single-phase generator.</p>
<p>17</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="single-radiographic-exposure">Single radiographic exposure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#single-radiographic-exposure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In order to 'freeze' and display movement, individual exposures should be as short as the heating of the X-ray tube permits.</li>
<li>The allowable mAs at a particular kV increase as the exposure time is lengthened (MCQ).</li>
<li>Any combination of kV, mA, and exposure time should be such that, at end of the exposure, the temperature of the anode does not exceed its safe value, i.e. there should be no risk of the target melting, vaporizing or roughening.</li>
<li>The rating is usually stated as the allowable mA, and this:</li>
<li>☑ Decreases as the exposure time is increased.</li>
<li>☑ Decreases as the kV is increased.</li>
<li>☑ Increases with the effective focal spot size (because increase effective focal spot means increase actual focal spot for a fixed anode angle)...and,</li>
<li>Increases with smaller target angles for a fixed effective focal spot, (Drawing above explain it, because the actual focal spot then larger).</li>
<li>☑ Is greater for a rotating than a stationary anode.</li>
<li>☑ Is greater for a 10 cm disk than a 7 cm disk.</li>
<li>☑ Is greater for a high-speed anode.</li>
<li>☑ Is greater for a three-phase constant potential than for a single-phase pulsating potential - because the former produces heat more evenly throughout the exposure.</li>
<li>The foregoing information is stored on a microprocessor in the control circuit which prevents any exposure being made which would exceed the rating of the tube.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="repeated-radiographic-exposures">Repeated radiographic exposures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#repeated-radiographic-exposures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>To display movement, e.g. angio- or cineradiography, a rapid series of exposures is made.</li>
<li>Each exposure must be sufficiently short &amp; within the rating of the focal area.</li>
<li>For repeated exposures → depends also on the ability of the anode assembly and the oil to accumulate heat → both not allowed to exceed its maximum safe temperature.</li>
<li>The rapidity with which a series of such exposures can be made depends on:</li>
<li>a) سعة التخزين The maximum amount of heat that can be temporarily stored in the anode in particular &amp; the tube housing as a whole; and</li>
<li>b) سرعة التوزيع The rate at which they lose heat by cooling.</li>
<li>The heat storage capacity of the anode may be increased by soldering to the back of the tungsten plate a disk of molybdenum and/or solid graphite (both have a higher heat capacity per unit mass than tungsten).</li>
<li>Microprocessor in control circuit calculates the max. total number of exposures allowed.</li>
<li>If the anode heat capacity (typically 0.2 MJ) has been reached → need at least 15 min to cool down completely;</li>
<li>&amp; the entire assembly (typical heat capacity 1.0 MJ) may need an hour.</li>
</ul>
<p>18</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="continuous-operation-fluoroscopy">Continuous operation: fluoroscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#continuous-operation-fluoroscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Heat must be removed at the same rate as it's produced from the housing "not allowed to accumulate in the oil".</li>
</ul>
<p>∴ The rating depends only on the cooling rate (and whether or not the fan is on) and NOT at all on the focal spot size or the type of generator.</p>
<ul>
<li>In fluoroscopy the anode is stationary or rotating at reduced speed, to ↓ bearing wear.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-ratings">Other ratings:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-ratings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Maximum kV also depends on the insulation of the tube, cables, etc.</li>
<li>Maximum mA → is low at a low kV than at a high kV (d.t. 'space charge effect'). N.B. allowable mA (tube rating) is low at high kV.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-7-5-quality-assurance-of-exposure-parameters">2.7.5 QUALITY ASSURANCE OF EXPOSURE PARAMETERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-7-5-quality-assurance-of-exposure-parameters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>~ At installation; each X-ray tube and generator should be checked for compliance to a certain specification.
~ X-ray generators need to be checked periodically → for exposure parameters (e.g. kV and mAs), and tube parameters (e.g. focal spot and filtration). More details in Section 3.8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="focal-spot-and-filtration">Focal spot and filtration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#focal-spot-and-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Focal spot should be measured at installation.</li>
<li>If the HVL and the kV measured carefully → the total filtration can be deduced from a set of published graphs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="kilovoltage-and-output">Kilovoltage and output<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kilovoltage-and-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The kV can either be measured:</li>
</ul>
<p>✓ Directly (invasively) by potential divider applied across the high tension leads
✓ Indirectly (non-invasively) by a penetrameter method.</p>
<p>A calibrated electronic penetrameter is placed in the beam → compares the differentially filtered response of detectors contained within it → gives equivalent kV.</p>
<ul>
<li>The tube output → measured by a dosemeter, often an ionization chamber.</li>
<li>For constant mAs, the output is a function of kV⁰. "X ≈ 2".</li>
<li>For a constant kV, the output is a linear function of mA and exposure time.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="field-definition-and-uniformity">Field definition and uniformity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#field-definition-and-uniformity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The size of the X-ray field is delineated using lead diaphragms + a light beam incorporated in overcouch tube.</li>
<li>Regular checks should be made to ensure that:</li>
</ul>
<p>a. The light beam and field outline match.
b. The center of the field, on the cross wires of the light beam diaphragm, coincides with the center of the X-ray field.</p>
<ul>
<li>The extent of the heel effect and field non uniformity can be measured by exposing a large, plain film and measuring the density differences across the field.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="processes-occurring-in-the-target-of-an-x-ray-tube">PROCESSES OCCURRING IN THE TARGET OF AN X-RAY TUBE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#processes-occurring-in-the-target-of-an-x-ray-tube" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Each electron arrives at the surface of the target with a kinetic energy (in kiloelectronvolts "keV") = the kV between the anode and cathode.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="interaction-with-the-k-shell-line-spectrum">INTERACTION WITH THE K-SHELL: LINE SPECTRUM,<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interaction-with-the-k-shell-line-spectrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristic-radiation">CHARACTERISTIC RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristic-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Electron (a) from the filament collides with an electron (b) in the K-shell of an atom  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  ejected from the atom, provided that the energy of the bombarding electron is greater than the binding energy of the shell.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The remaining energy is shared between the initial electron &amp; the ejected electron  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  both leave the atom
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The hole created in the K-shell is most likely to be filled by an electron (c) falling from the L-shell  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  emission of a single X-ray photon (d) of energy equal to the difference in the binding energies of the two shells,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_K - E_L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">L</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>The photon is referred to as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>α</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K_{\alpha}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  radiation.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-8430ca6d.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg">
Fig. 1.6 Production of characteristic radiation.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Alternatively, but less likely, the hole may be filled by an electron falling from the M-shell  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  emission of a single X-ray photon of energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_K - K_M}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">M</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> . ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>β</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K_{\beta}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9694em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0715em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  radiation)</p>
<p>In the case of the usual target material, Tungsten "W"  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>74</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(Z = 74)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">74</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> ,</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>70</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_K} = 70 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_L} = 12 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">L</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> , and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_M} = 2 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">M</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>α</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore \mathrm{K}_{\alpha}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  radiation has photon energy of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>58</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">58 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">58</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>&amp; K <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>  radiation has photon energy of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>68</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">68 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">68</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<ul>
<li>The x-ray photon energy is a "characteristic" of the K shell of a tungsten atom regardless of the energy of the electron that ejected the K-shell electron</li>
</ul>
<p>20</p>
<p>L-radiation → if hole created in the L-shell is filled by an electron from farther shell.</p>
<p>Even in the case of tungsten, L-radiation photons have only energy = 10 keV → insufficient to leave the X-ray tube assembly "no part in radiology".</p>
<ul>
<li>Characteristic X-ray photons have discrete photon energies → line spectrum.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the case of another target material, Molybdenum (Z = 42),</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm {E} _ {\mathrm {K}} = 2 0 \mathrm {K e V}, \mathrm {E} _ {\mathrm {L}} = 2. 5 \mathrm {k e V}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">KeV</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">L</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>α</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore \mathrm{K}_{\alpha}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> radiation has a photon energy of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>17.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">17.5 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">17.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>&amp; Kβ radiation has a photon energy of 20 keV.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="18f5e2cf">∴ The energy of the K-radiation photons:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#18f5e2cf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Increases → with ↑ atomic number of the target.</li>
<li>It is characteristic of the target material.</li>
<li>Not affected by the tube voltage, except that:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A K-electron cannot be ejected if the peak tube voltage is less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>The rate of production of the characteristic radiation increases as the kV is increased above this value.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contribution-of-characteristic-radiation-to-the-total-production-of-x-rays">Contribution of characteristic radiation to the total production of x rays?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contribution-of-characteristic-radiation-to-the-total-production-of-x-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Below <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70\mathrm{kVp}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kVp</span></span></span></span></span></span> → no K-shell characteristic radiation.</li>
<li>Between 80 and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150\mathrm{kVp}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kVp</span></span></span></span></span></span> → K-shell characteristic radiation contributes about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> (80 kVp) to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>28</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">28\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">28%</span></span></span></span></span> (150 kVp) of the useful x-ray beam.</li>
<li>Above <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150\mathrm{kVp}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kVp</span></span></span></span></span></span> the contribution of characteristic radiation decreases, and it becomes negligible above <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300\mathrm{kVp}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kVp</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interaction-with-the-nucleus-bremsstrahlung-continuous-spectrum">INTERACTION WITH THE NUCLEUS: BREMSSTRAHLUNG, CONTINUOUS SPECTRUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interaction-with-the-nucleus-bremsstrahlung-continuous-spectrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ff76ad06.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When an electron penetrates K shell &amp; passes near the nucleus of a tungsten atom → the +ve charge of the nucleus acts on the -ve charge of the electron.
∴ The electron is deflected from its original direction &amp; slowed down</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The kinetic energy lost by the electron is emitted directly in the form of a photon of radiation called general radiation or bremsstrahlung ("braking radiation" in German)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Except in mammography, 80% or more of the X-rays emitted by a diagnostic X-ray tube are bremsstrahlung.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most electrons that strike the target:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Make interactions with a number of atoms &amp; loses only part of its energy at each interaction which appear in the form of radiation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Penetrate many atomic layers before giving up all their energy; therefore, not all x-rays are produced on the surface of the target.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occasionally, the electron will collide head-on with a nucleus → single photon of energy = kVp. "the largest photon energy that can be produced at this kilovoltage"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most of the radiation will have little energy, and will appear as heat "over  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">99\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">99%</span></span></span></span></span>  of all reactions" + few x rays will appear.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The energy of a photon of radiation is related to the kinetic energy (keV) of the electron, which is related to the potential difference (kVp) across the x-ray tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Remember, Energy of photon of radiation is inversely related to wavelength.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In case of a head-on collision between the electron and nucleus. All the energy of the electron is given to the resulting x-ray photon. The minimum wavelength (in angstroms) of this x-ray photon can be calculated:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="d5ca77e6"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>12.4</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>k</mi><mi>V</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\lambda_{min} = 12.4 / kVp</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">λ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3117em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">min</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">12.4/</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">kV</span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d5ca77e6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="for-example">For example,<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>0.124 Å is the shortest wavelength (highest energy) x-ray photon that can be produced with an x-ray tube potential of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\mathrm{kVp}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kVp</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
<li>Most of the x rays produced will have wavelengths longer than 0.124 Å.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-50363752.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 2-14 is a graph of continuous spectrum of the wavelengths of x rays. Notice that:</p>
<ol>
