<p>This arrangement, referred to as 'good geometry'  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  minimizes the amount of scattered radiation SS entering the detector</p>
<p>The beam is restricted by means of a lead diaphragm to just cover a small detector.</p>
<ul>
<li>The diaphragm b and sheets of the absorbing material c are positioned halfway between the source a and detector d.
A second collimator may be placed in front of the detector.</li>
</ul>
<p>28</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-affecting-attenuation">FACTORS AFFECTING ATTENUATION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-affecting-attenuation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-energy">I- Energy:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>↑ beam energy → ↓ attenuation (μ) → ↑ percentage of transmitted photons.</li>
<li>↑ beam energy → ↑ HVL.</li>
<li><strong>Beam energy determines the dominant interaction type:</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>With low radiation energy → photoelectric effect is dominant → ↓ transmitted photons.</li>
<li>With increasing the energy → ↑ Compton scattering &amp; ↓ PEE → ↑ transmitted photons.</li>
<li>With high energy → most interactions are Compton interaction.
&amp; with increasing the energy within high ranges → ↑ % transmitted photons but with small differences (both within Compton interaction)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-atomic-number-a">II- Atomic number (A):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-atomic-number-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Generally, ↑ atomic no. → ↑ attenuation.</li>
<li>The only exception is with high atomic no. absorber, if the beam energy exceeded the binding energy of an inner shell electron (see absorption edge).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-density">III- Density:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-density" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Density determines the no. of electrons in a given thickness.</li>
</ul>
<p>So, ↑ density → ↑ attenuation in a linear relationship
∴ Doubling the density for the same thickness → doubles attenuation of that thickness</p>
<ul>
<li>The difference in tissue densities is responsible for the X-ray film contrast.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-electrons-per-gram">IV- Electrons per gram:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-electrons-per-gram" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Mass unit → depends on the no. of neutrons in the absorber atoms.</li>
<li>Actually, the no. of electrons \ cm³ "which is a volume unit" is more important.</li>
<li>We obtain the e \ cm³ by multiplying e \ gm in density.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\mathrm{e}}{\mathrm{gm}} \times \frac{\mathrm{gm}}{\mathrm{cm}^3} = \frac{\mathrm{e}}{\mathrm{cm}^3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.988em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1076em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">gm</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">e</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.7936em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1076em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7401em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">gm</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.7936em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1076em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7401em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">e</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>When Compton interactions predominate, the no. of e \ cm³ becomes the most important factor in attenuation.</li>
<li>Example: bone has fewer e \ gm than water, but attenuates radiation more because it has more e \ cm³.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="attenuation-of-a-wide-beam">ATTENUATION OF A WIDE BEAM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#attenuation-of-a-wide-beam" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The percentage transmission by the same object of a wide beam of X- or gamma rays is greater than that of a narrow beam of photons of the same energy because a wide beam produces more scatter SS and much of it stays within the beam. Fig. 1.13b</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="attenuation-of-a-heterogeneous-beam">Attenuation of a heterogeneous beam<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#attenuation-of-a-heterogeneous-beam" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The beams produced by X-ray tubes are <strong>Heterogeneous (Polyenergetic)</strong>, i.e. they comprise photons of a wide range of energies (spectrum of energies).</li>
<li>The max. energy of the beam = peak kVp.
The mean energy is between 1/2 – 1/3 of peak energy.</li>
<li>As the beam travels through an attenuating material,
“ ↓ Beam quantity → same as monochromatic radiation.
“ ↑ Beam quality as, the lower-energy photons are attenuated proportionally more</li>
</ul>
<p>29</p>
<p>than the higher-energy photons &amp; as the lower energy photons are removed from the beam → ↑ mean energy of the remaining photons.</p>
<ul>
<li>The exponential law does not apply for a heterogenous beam. However, it is still correct to refer to the HVL of the beam.</li>
<li>As the beam penetrates the material: a process of FILTRATION occurs</li>
<li>The beam becomes progressively more homogeneous.</li>
<li>↑↑ Proportion of higher-energy photons in beam → ↑↑ average energy → the beam becomes 'harder' or more penetrating.</li>
<li>The 'second HVL' which would reduce the beam intensity from 50 to 25% &gt; the 'first HVL', which reduces it from 100 to 50%.</li>
<li>When the transmission % of polyenergetic radiation plotted on logarithmic scale → Curved line.</li>
</ul>
<p>The HVL of a typical diagnostic beam is</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>30 mm in tissue</th><th>12 mm in bone</th><th>0.15 mm in lead</th></tr></thead></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interaction-processes">INTERACTION PROCESSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interaction-processes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>5 processes of interaction between X-rays and matter contribute to attenuation</p>
<ol>
<li>Interaction with a loosely bound or 'free' electron → Compton process "modified scatter"</li>
<li>Interaction with inner shell or 'bound' electron → Photoelectric absorption.</li>
<li>Interaction with a bound electron → Unmodified scatter.</li>
<li>Pair production.</li>
<li>Photodisintegration.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="unmodified-scatter">Unmodified scatter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#unmodified-scatter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is also known variously as coherent, classical, elastic, or Thomson scattering</li>
<li>The photon bounces off an electron which is firmly bound to its parent atom → the photon is scattered with no loss of energy.
∴ No secondary electron - No ionization.</li>
<li>This process occurs with low-energy photons and at very small angles of scattering
∴ The scattered radiation does not leave the beam → little significance in radiology.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pair-production-photodisintegration">PAIR PRODUCTION &amp; PHOTODISINTEGRATION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pair-production-photodisintegration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Both interactions don't occur within the diagnostic energy range (which rarely use energies &gt; 150 keV).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-5-compton-process-modified-scatter">1.5 COMPTON PROCESS (MODIFIED SCATTER)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-5-compton-process-modified-scatter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="responsible-for-almost-all-the-scatter-radiation-in-diagnostic-radiology">Responsible for almost all the scatter radiation in diagnostic radiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsible-for-almost-all-the-scatter-radiation-in-diagnostic-radiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-c99d0bb2.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The photon bounces off a free electron which recoils, taking away some of the energy of the photon as kinetic energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the photon is scattered with reduced energy.
: The energy of the incident photon is distributed between:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Kinetic energy of the recoil electron.</li>
<li>Energy retained by deflected photon</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="compton-photon-never-gives-up-all-its-energy-unlike-in-photoelectric-interaction">Compton photon never gives up all its energy unlike in photoelectric interaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compton-photon-never-gives-up-all-its-energy-unlike-in-photoelectric-interaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The reaction produces:</p>
<p>Ion pair "+ve ion &amp; -ve electron - called recoil electron"
Scattered photon.</p>
<ul>
<li>The energy carried off by the recoil electron is said to be absorbed by the material, and the remainder, carried by the photon, to have been scattered.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the diagnostic range of energies no more than  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span>  of the energy is absorbed, the rest being scattered.</p>
<p>: The Compton process is partial absorption.</p>
<p>The angle of scatter  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\theta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">θ</span></span></span></span></span>  is the angle between the scattered ray and the incident ray.</p>
<p>Photons may be scattered in all directions.</p>
<p>The electrons are projected only in sideways and forward directions.</p>
<ul>
<li>Unlike PEE in which most of photon's energy is expended to free electron bond  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Recoil electron is already free (so no energy needed for this).
2 factors determine the amount of energy retained by scattered photon:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Initial photon energy.</li>
<li>Angle of scatter  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\theta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">θ</span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effect-of-the-angle-of-scattering">EFFECT OF THE ANGLE OF SCATTERING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-the-angle-of-scattering" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It will be seen that The greater the angle of scatter</p>
<ol>
<li>The greater the energy and range of the recoil electron</li>
<li>The lower the energy of the scattered photon (i.e. the greater the loss of energy).</li>
</ol>
<p>31</p>
<p>∴ Scattered photons at small angles retain most of original energy:</p>
<ol>
<li>As they scatter at small angle → they remain within the 1ry beam → film fogging.</li>
<li>They are too energetic → can't be removed by filters.</li>
<li>Scattered radiation - even those scattered at large angles - still have much energy → safety hazards to medical staff especially in fluoroscopy.</li>
</ol>
<p>∴ A back-scattered photon (θ = 180°) is less energetic 'softer' than a side-scattered photon (θ = 90°), which in turn is softer than a forward-scattered photon (θ = 0°).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effect-of-initial-photon-energy">EFFECT OF INITIAL PHOTON ENERGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-initial-photon-energy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Higher energy photons are more difficult to deflect (more momentum).</li>
<li>↑↑ initial photon energy</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>↑↑ the remaining photon energy of the scattered radiation → more penetrating. However, ↑ photon energy → ↓ no. of reactions → ↑ probability to pass through body than low energy photons</li>
<li>↑↑ the kinetic energy of the recoil electron and ↑↑ its range.</li>
</ol>
<p>This is seen in the following examples:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Incident photon</th><th>Back-scattered photon</th><th>Recoil electron</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>25 keV</td><td>22 keV</td><td>3 keV</td></tr><tr><td>150 keV</td><td>100 keV</td><td>50 keV</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>∴ The softening effect of Compton scatter is greatest with large scattering angles &amp; high energy X-rays.</p>
<p>The Compton process contributes to the total linear attenuation coefficient μ, an amount σ which is called the Compton linear attenuation coefficient.</p>
<ul>
<li>In diagnostic energy range (up to 150 keV):
Photon retains most of its original energy (i.e. very little transferred to recoil electron)</li>
<li>The probability σ that the Compton process will occur</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Proportional to the physical density, as with all attenuation processes.</li>
<li>Proportional to electron density.</li>
<li>Independent of the atomic number, as it concerns only 'free' electrons.</li>
<li>Approximately proportional to 1 / E.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="to-summarize">To summarize<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-summarize" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>σ is proportional to ρ / E and is independent of Z.</p>
<p>The mass Compton attenuation coefficient σ / ρ is the same within 10% for such materials as air, tissue, bone, contrast media, and lead → represented by a single curve in Fig. 1.16, which shows how σ/ρ varies with photon energy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="free-electron">Free electron:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#free-electron" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An electron which binding energy is much less than energy of incident photon.</li>
<li>In diagnostic radiology range (10 – 150 keV):</li>
</ul>
<p>“ In high atomic no. elements → outer shell electrons are free.
“ In low atomic no. elements (as in soft tissue) → all electrons are free.</p>
<p>32</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-6-photoelectric-absorption">1.6 PHOTOELECTRIC ABSORPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-6-photoelectric-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When a photon (a) 'collides' with an electron (b) in the K-shell of an atom &amp; if its energy &gt; the binding energy of the shell → it can eject the electron b from the atom.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-photon-disappears">The photon disappears:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-photon-disappears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Part of its energy, equal to the binding energy of the K-shell, is expended in removing the electron from the atom.</li>
<li>The remainder becomes the kinetic energy (KE) of that electron.</li>
</ol>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi><mi>E</mi><mtext>&nbsp;of&nbsp;the&nbsp;electron</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>photon&nbsp;energy</mtext><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">KE \text{ of the electron} = \text{photon energy} - E_K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;of&nbsp;the&nbsp;electron</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">photon&nbsp;energy</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-64944012.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<p>Less often, the X- or gamma ray photon may interact with an electron in the L-shell of an atom → ejected from the atom with KE = photon energy - KL.</p>
<ul>
<li>The electrons so ejected are called <strong>photoelectrons</strong>.</li>
<li>The 'holes' created in the atomic shell are filled by electrons falling in from a shell farther out, with the emission of a series of <strong>photons of characteristic radiation</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-photoelectric-interaction-yields-3-end-products">The photoelectric interaction yields 3 end products:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-photoelectric-interaction-yields-3-end-products" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>-ve Ion (photoelectron).</li>
<li>+ve ion (atom deficient by one electron).</li>
<li>Characteristic radiation</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-the-case-of-air-tissue-bone-light-atom-materials">In the case of air, tissue &amp; bone (light-atom materials):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-case-of-air-tissue-bone-light-atom-materials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Calcium which has highest atomic no. of all body elements, emits <strong>only 4 keV</strong> max. energy of characteristic radiation</p>
<p>∴ The characteristic radiation is so soft → absorbed immediately with the ejection of a further, low-energy, photoelectron or 'AUGER' ELECTRON.
∴ All the original photon energy is converted into the energy of electronic motion.
∴ Photoelectric absorption in such materials is complete absorption.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-the-case-of-barium-and-iodine-in-cm-high-atomic-number-materials">In the case of barium and iodine in CM (high atomic number materials):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-case-of-barium-and-iodine-in-cm-high-atomic-number-materials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Characteristic radiation is sufficiently energetic to leave the patient &amp; fog x-ray film → only partial absorption "like Compton effect".</p>
<p>Photoelectric absorption contributes to the total linear attenuation coefficient in an amount <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><munder accentunder="true"><mi mathvariant="bold">r</mi><mo stretchy="true">‾</mo></munder></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\underline{\mathbf{r}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em; vertical-align: -0.2em;"></span><span class="mord underline"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.4444em;"><span style="top: -2.84em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="underline-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">r</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> which is called the photoelectric linear-attenuation coefficient.</p>
<p>33
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 + D = H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> :</p>
<ul>
<li>The more tightly the electron is bound to the atom and the nearer the photon energy is to its binding energy, the more likely photoelectric absorption is to happen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2a44a067">The probability  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mstyle style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><mi>τ</mi></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pmb{\tau}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord" style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.1132em;">τ</span></span></span></span></span></span>  that photoelectric absorption:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2a44a067" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mstyle style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><mi>τ</mi></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pmb{\tau}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord" style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.1132em;">τ</span></span></span></span></span></span>  is inversely proportional to the cube of the photon energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="bold">E</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{E}^3\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  decreases markedly as the photon energy of the radiation increases.</li>
</ol>
<p>(Provided that photon energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 1: &amp;̲gt;" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">&amp;gt;</span></span>  binding energy)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mstyle style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><mi>τ</mi></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pmb{\tau}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord" style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.1132em;">τ</span></span></span></span></span></span>  is proportional to the cube of the atomic number  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="bold">Z</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{Z}^3\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  increases markedly as the atomic number of the material increases.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mstyle style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><mi>τ</mi></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pmb{\tau}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord" style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.1132em;">τ</span></span></span></span></span></span>  is proportional to the density of the material, as with all attenuation processes.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Photoelectric effect can't take place with free electron  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  called forbidden interaction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="to-summarize">To summarize:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-summarize" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-d79bb25d.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg">
Fig. 1.16 shows how the mass photoelectric attenuation coefficient  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mstyle style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><mi>τ</mi></mstyle><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mstyle style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><mi>ρ</mi></mstyle></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pmb{\tau} / \pmb{\rho}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord" style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.1132em;">τ</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord" style="text-shadow: 0.02em 0.01em 0.04px;"><span class="mord mathnormal">ρ</span></span></span></span></span></span>  varies with photon energy in the case of soft tissue with  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7.4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z = 7.4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">7.4</span></span></span></span></span> , bone with  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z = 13</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">13</span></span></span></span></span> , and iodine with  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>53</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z = 53</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">53</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>The graphs are straight lines because logarithmic scales are used on both axes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applications-of-photoelectric-effect-in-diagnostic-radiology">Applications of photoelectric effect in diagnostic radiology:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applications-of-photoelectric-effect-in-diagnostic-radiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="good-role">Good role<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#good-role" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Photoelectric effect produces radiographic images of excellent quality due to:</p>
<ol>
<li>No scattered radiation.</li>
<li>Enhancement of natural tissue contrast (i.e. PEE interaction depends on  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3^{\mathrm{rd}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">3</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">rd</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  power of atomic no.  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  magnify contrast between tissues)</li>
</ol>
<p>: PEE is desirable from point of view of film quality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bad-role">Bad role:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bad-role" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>PEE increase patient exposure, as all the incident photon is absorbed by the pt. while in Compton reaction, only part of the incident photon's energy is absorbed.</p>
<p>: PEE is undesirable from point of view of patient exposure.</p>
<p>:We should use highest energy (kVp) techniques which not distort the diagnostic quality of X-ray ray films.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mcq">MCQ:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mcq" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Radiographic image contrast is less with Compton reaction than with PEE.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristic-radiation-in-photoelectric-interactions">Characteristic radiation in photoelectric interactions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristic-radiation-in-photoelectric-interactions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Same principle as characteristic radiation production either in the X-ray target or in photoelectric effect, the only difference is the method used to eject the inner shell electron (high speed electron in the x-ray tube &amp; x-ray photon in PEE)</p>
<ul>
<li>Characteristic radiation is usually referred to as 2ry radiation, to differentiate from Scatter radiation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effective-atomic-number">EFFECTIVE ATOMIC NUMBER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effective-atomic-number" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Effective atomic number = a (weighted) average of the atomic numbers of the constituent elements.</p>
<p>= the cube root of the average of the cube roots of the atomic numbers of the constituents  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mtext>一一一一一一一一一一一一</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一} \text{一}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord cjk_fallback">一</span></span></span></span></span></span>  co3</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Fat</th><th>Air</th><th>Water, muscle</th><th>Bone</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>6</td><td>7.6</td><td>7.4</td><td>13</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="absorption-edges">ABSORPTION EDGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#absorption-edges" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-k-absorption-edge">The K-absorption edge:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-k-absorption-edge" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>i.e. as the photon energy is increased, photoelectric attenuation decreases until the binding energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_{K}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  of the material is reached → the photoelectric absorption jumps to a higher value and start to decrease again as the photon energy further increases.</p>
<ul>
<li>The reason is that photons with less energy than  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_K}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  can only eject L-electrons and can only be absorbed in that shell. Photons with greater energy than  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E_K}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  can eject K-electrons as well, and can therefore be absorbed in both shells.
This is an exception to the general rule that attenuation decreases with increasing energy</li>
<li>K-absorption edge occurs at different photon energies with different materials.</li>
</ul>
<p>Fig. 1.16 illustrated  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></span> -absorption edge for iodine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="for-example">For example,<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the case of iodine,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>K</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>33</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>keV</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_K = 33 \, \text{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">33</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  and photons of energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>31</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>keV</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">31 \, \text{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">31</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  are attenuated much less than photons of energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>keV</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35 \, \text{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>The  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span></span> -edges of low atomic number materials such as air, water, tissue, and aluminum have no significance as they occur at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>K</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_K = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>  keV or less.</p>
<ul>
<li>The higher the atomic number of the material, the greater is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{K}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">K</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and the greater is the photon energy at which the edge occurs.</li>
<li>When max. X-ray absorption is desired, the K-edge of an absorber should be close to the energy of the X-ray beam</li>
</ul>
<p>e.g. In Xeroradiography, Selenium is used for low energy radiation (30-35 kVp) like mammography. While, Tungsten is used for high energy radiation (350 kVp) like CXR.</p>
<p>The absorption edge is important in:</p>
<ol>
<li>Choosing materials for 'K-edge filters'.</li>
<li>Contrast media.</li>
<li>Imaging phosphors.</li>
</ol>
<p>36</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="relative-importance-of-compton-and-photoelectric-attenuation">Relative Importance of Compton and photoelectric attenuation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#relative-importance-of-compton-and-photoelectric-attenuation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The photoelectric coefficient is proportional to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>Z</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z^3 / E^3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, and is particularly high when the photon energy is just greater than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>K</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E_K</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">K</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>The Compton coefficient is independent of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span></span></span></span></span> and little affected by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Accordingly,</p>
<ol>
<li>Photoelectric absorption is more important with high-Z materials &amp; low-energy photons.</li>
<li>Compton process is more important with low-Z materials &amp; high-energy photons.</li>
</ol>
<p>The photon energy at which the two processes happen to be equally important depends on the atomic number of the material:</p>
<p>30 keV for air, water, and tissue
50 keV for aluminum and bone
300 keV for iodine and barium
500 keV for lead</p>
<ul>
<li>As regards diagnostic imaging with X-rays (20-140 keV), therefore:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The Compton process is the predominant process for air, water, and soft tissues (except at very low photon energy "20 – 30 keV" → PEE reaction predominate)</li>
<li>Photoelectric absorption predominates for contrast media, lead, and the materials used in films, screens, and other imaging devices;</li>
<li>While both are important for bone (intermediate atomic no.).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>PEE is more common at low energies.</li>
<li>Compton scattering in dominant at high energies.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Coherent scattering play only a minor role throughout diagnostic energy range.</li>
<li>Attenuation is greater when the PEE predominates (complete absorption).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="secondary-electrons">SECONDARY ELECTRONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-electrons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>'Secondary radiation' refers to Compton scattered radiation;</li>
<li>'Secondary electrons' to the recoil electrons and photoelectrons</li>
<li>As they travel through the material, the secondary electrons interact with the outer shells of the atoms they pass nearby, and excite or ionize them → the track of the electron is tortuous &amp; dotted with ion pairs.</li>
<li>When traveling through air the electron loses an average of 34 eV per ion pair.
3 eV needed to excite an atom &amp; 10 eV to ionize it, and there
&amp; there about 8 times as many excitations as ionizations.</li>
<li>When it loses the whole of its initial energy → the electron comes to the end of its range.
The greater the initial energy of the electron, the greater its range
The range is inversely proportional to the density of the material.</li>
</ul>
<p>The ranges in air are some 800 times greater than in tissue</p>
<p>For example, when 140 keV photons are absorbed in soft tissue,</p>
<p>Some of the secondary electrons are photoelectrons having energy of 140 keV, able to produce some 4000 ion pairs and having a range of about 0.2 mm.</p>
<p>Most of the secondary electrons are recoil electrons with a spectrum of energies averaging 25 keV and an average range of about 0.02 mm.</p>
<p>37</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-9-filtration">1.9 FILTRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-9-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The lower-energy photons in the X-ray beam are mainly absorbed by and deposit dose in the patient → so, don't reach the film or contribute to the image.</li>
<li>Filtration removes a large proportion of the lower-energy photons before they reach the skin "so, reduces the patient dose" while hardly affecting the radiation producing image.</li>
<li>Filtration is the process of shaping the X-ray beam to increase the ratio of useful photons to the photons that increase the patient dose or decrease image contrast.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inherent-filtration">INHERENT Filtration:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inherent-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The X-ray photons produced in the target are first filtered by:</li>
<li>Principally, the target material itself. The window of the tube housing.</li>
<li>The glass envelope. The light beam diaphragm mirror</li>
<li>The insulating oil.</li>
<li>Inherent filtration is measured in <strong>Aluminum Equivalent</strong>: = the thickness of Al that would produce the same degree of attenuation as the inherent filtration.</li>
<li>Typically, inherent filtration = 0.5-1 mm Al equivalent.</li>
</ul>
<p>In few cases, unfiltered radiation is desirable
As filtration ↑↑ the mean energy of an X-ray beam → it ↓↓ tissue contrast</p>
<ul>
<li>With lower energy radiation (&lt; 30 kVp) this loss of contrast affects image quality</li>
<li>When inherent filtration must be minimized, a tube with a window of <strong>beryllium (Z = 4)</strong> instead of glass is used e.g. Mammography.</li>
</ul>
