<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="added-or-additional-filtration">ADDED "or Additional" Filtration:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#added-or-additional-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Uniform flat sheet of metal, usually <strong>Aluminum</strong> placed between the X-ray tube &amp; patient</li>
<li><strong>Ideal filter material</strong> → the one which absorbs all low energy photons &amp; transmit all high energy photons (such material doesn't exist).</li>
<li>The predominant attenuation process should be <strong>photoelectric absorption</strong>, which varies inversely as the cube of the photon energy. The filter will therefore attenuate the lower-energy photons much more than it does the higher-energy photons.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>The total filtration</strong> is the sum of the added filtration and the inherent filtration.</p>
<p>For general diagnostic radiology it should be at least 2.5 mm Al equivalent.
(This will produce a beam with effective energy of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{BVL} = 2.5\mathrm{mmAl}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">BVL</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mmAl</span></span></span></span></span></span> at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>, and 4.0 mm at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>120</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">120\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">120</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="choice-of-filter-material">CHOICE OF FILTER MATERIAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#choice-of-filter-material" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>The Atomic Number</strong> should be sufficiently high to make the energy-dependent attenuating process, photoelectric absorption, predominate.</p>
<p>It should <strong>not be too high</strong>, since the whole of the useful X-ray spectrum should lie on the high-energy side of the absorption edge. If not, the filter might soften the beam.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Aluminum (Z = 13)</strong> is generally used: has sufficiently high atomic number to be suitable for low energy radiation &amp; most diagnostic X-ray beams (general purpose filter).</li>
<li>With the higher kV values, <strong>Copper (Z = 29)</strong> is used, being a more efficient filter.</li>
</ul>
<p>Disadv.: Copper filters can't be used alone because photoelectric interaction with the copper emits  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>9</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  characteristic X-rays  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  if reaches patient skin, will increase the skin dose  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  must be absorbed by a 'backing filter' of aluminum on the patient side of the 'compound filter'.</p>
<ul>
<li>Molybdenum or Palladium filters have absorption edges (20 or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>24</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">24\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">24</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> , respectively) favorable for mammography.</li>
<li>Erbium (58 keV) has been used at moderate kV values, called 'K-edge filter'.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="filter-thickness">FILTER THICKNESS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#filter-thickness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The total filtration for diagnostic radiology as recommended by The national council of radiation protection and measurements:</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>kVp</th><th>Total filtration</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Below 50 kVp</td><td>0.5 mm Al</td></tr><tr><td>50 – 70 kVp</td><td>1.5 mm Al</td></tr><tr><td>Above 70 kVp</td><td>2.5 mm Al</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Increased filtration has definite disadvantage;</li>
</ul>
<p>Excessive filtration  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  absorption of high energy photons  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the quality of the beam is not altered significantly but the intensity is greatly diminished  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  needs  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  exposure time which may  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  movement blurring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effects-of-filtration">EFFECTS OF FILTRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effects-of-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Figure 1.18 shows the spectrum of X-rays generated at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  after passing through 1, 2, and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  aluminum.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-0b5c88c3.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Filters attenuates lower-energy X-rays more in proportion than higher-energy X-rays  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  ↑↑ the penetrating power (HVL) of the beam but ↓↓ intensity
It is responsible for the low-energy cut-off of the X-ray spectrum.</li>
<li>Increasing the filtration has the following effects:</li>
</ul>
<p>It causes the continuous  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> -ray spectrum to shrink and move to the right, Fig. 1.18.</p>
<ol>
<li>It selectively reduces the total number of photons "the area of the spectrum" and the total output of X-rays  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  removes much more low energy photons than high energy.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  Minimum &amp; Effective photon energies but not affect maximum photon energy</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  the exit dose/entry dose ratio, or film dose/skin dose ratio.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="compensating-or-wedge-filler">COMPENSATING OR WEDGE FILLER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compensating-or-wedge-filler" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A wedge-shaped filter may be attached to the tube to make the exposure across the film more uniform and compensate for the large difference in transmission, for example, between the upper and lower thorax, neck and shoulder, or foot and ankle.</li>
<li>Similarly, a compensating filter may sometimes be used in mammography.</li>
</ul>
<p>39</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-7-properties-of-x-and-gamma-rays">1.7 PROPERTIES OF X-AND GAMMA RAYS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-7-properties-of-x-and-gamma-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The excitations and ionizations produced by the secondary electrons which account for the various properties of X- and gamma rays:</p>
<ol>
<li>The ionization of air and other gases → makes them electrically conducting: used in the measurement of X- and gamma rays.</li>
<li>The ionization of atoms in the constituents of living cells cause biological damage &amp; the hazards of radiation exposure.</li>
<li>The excitation of atoms of certain materials (phosphors) → makes them emit light (luminescence, scintillation, or fluorescence): used in the measurement of X- and gamma rays and as a basis of radiological imaging.</li>
<li>The effect on the atoms of silver and bromine in a photographic film → leads to blackening (photographic effect): used in the measurement of X- and gamma rays and as a basis of radiography.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="luminescence">LUMINESCENCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#luminescence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>When a phosphor absorbs X-rays, the secondary electrons set in motion raise valence electrons to a higher energy level.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The electrons stay in energy 'traps' and the absorbed energy is stored in the phosphor until the electrons return to the valence shells, with the emission of photons of light.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This may happen spontaneously, either:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>☑ Instantaneously → fluorescence</li>
<li>☑ After a noticeable interval of time → phosphorescence.</li>
</ul>
<p>The latter is called afterglow or lag, and is generally to be avoided in imaging.</p>
<p>OR</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>The emission of the light may require stimulation:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>☑ By heat → thermoluminescence.</li>
<li>☑ By intense light from a laser → photostimulation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-ionizing-radiations">Other ionizing radiations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-ionizing-radiations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Some ultraviolet radiation has a sufficiently high photon energy to ionize air.
Beta particles, emitted by many radioactive substances and other moving electrons (in a television monitor, for example) also possess the above properties.
Alpha rays (helium nuclei <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>4</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>He), (which are particularly stable combinations of two neutrons and two protons) are also emitted by some radioactive substances.</p>
<p>Both alpha and beta rays are charged particles and are directly ionizing.</p>
<p>X- and gamma rays are indirectly ionizing, through their secondary electrons; the 'secondary' ions produced along the track of a secondary electron being many times more than the single 'primary' ionization caused by the initial Compton or photoelectric interaction.
Neutrons also ionize tissue indirectly through the hydrogen nuclei they collide with.</p>
<p>40</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-8-absorbed-dose">1.8 ABSORBED DOSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-8-absorbed-dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The SI unit of absorbed dose is <strong>GRAY (Gy)</strong>; 1 Gy = 1 J \ kg.</li>
<li>The absorbed dose is <strong>the energy absorbed as ionization or excitation per unit mass of the material irradiated</strong> (in joules per kilogram).</li>
<li><strong>Dose rate</strong> is measured in <strong>Grays per Second</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>The concept of absorbed dose applies to all kinds of direct and indirect ionizing radiations and to any material.</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Before 1980 the international unit of absorbed dose was the <strong>RAD</strong>,
1 Gy = 100 rad &amp; 1 rad = 1 cGy = 10 mGy.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="kerma">KERMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kerma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>Kerma</strong> is the kinetic energy (of the secondary electrons) released per unit mass of irradiated material.</li>
<li><strong>Absorbed Dose</strong> is energy deposited (as ionization &amp; excitation) by those 2ry electrons</li>
<li>Kerma is measured in <strong>GRAY</strong> &amp; is synonymous with absorbed dose.</li>
<li>In most radiodiagnostic situations they are equal and can be used interchangeably.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="measurement-of-x-and-gamma-ray-dose">MEASUREMENT OF X- AND GAMMA RAY DOSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#measurement-of-x-and-gamma-ray-dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is extremely difficult to measure dose in solids or liquids directly.
First we <strong>measure the dose delivered to air ('air kerma')</strong> under same conditions &amp; then multiply it by a <strong>conversion factor</strong> to obtain the dose in the material.</li>
<li>The conversion factor:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dose-in-stated-material">Dose in stated material<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose-in-stated-material" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="dose-in-air">Dose in air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose-in-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Depends on the relative amounts of energy absorbed in air and the material.</li>
<li>Like the mass absorption coefficients, the factor depends on:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The effective atomic number of the material.</li>
<li>The effective energy of the X- or gamma rays.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>For X-rays used in radiology, approximate values of the conversion factors are:</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>For muscle</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Muscle atomic number nearly equal that of air &amp; <strong>Compton process predominates</strong></li>
<li>The ratio is close to unity and only varies between <strong>1.0 - 1.1</strong> over the kilovoltage range</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>For compact bone</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>With higher atomic number and <strong>Photoelectric absorption</strong> is important.</li>
<li>The ratio varies from about <strong>4.5 at low keV energies</strong> to <strong>1.2 at high keV</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li><strong>For fat</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>With lower atomic number → the ratio varies in the opposite direction, from about <strong>0.6 at low keV energies</strong> to <strong>1.1 at high keV energies</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li><strong>For the soft tissue elements in cavities within bone</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The ratio lies between bone and muscle → depends on the size of cavity &amp; photon energy.</li>
</ul>
<p>41</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thimble-or-cavity-chamber">THIMBLE OR CAVITY CHAMBER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thimble-or-cavity-chamber" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The air dose or kerma can be measured by placing at the point in question a plastic 'thimble' (a) containing a small mass of air (b), which is indirectly ionized by the X-radiation. Each X-ray photon (X) absorbed in the wall liberates a secondary electron (e), which produces ion pairs along its tortuous track.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For each ion pair, 34 eV of energy will have been deposited. Therefore,</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>For each coulomb of charge (either positive or negative) carried by the ions, 34 J of energy will have been deposited.</p>
<ul>
<li>To measure the charge, the ions are separated before they can recombine by applying a polarizing voltage between the</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-6b9d31f4.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg"></p>
<p>outer thimble wall and a thin central electrode (c) → Ionization current (I) flows, proportional to the dose rate of the radiation &amp; the mass of air in the chamber.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Charge can be collected → Air Kerma indicated on a meter or digital read-out; or Current can be measured → Air Kerma Rate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A polarizing voltage of 100 V is usually sufficient to collect all the ions and produce SATURATION CURRENT.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If the voltage is too low, some of the positive and negative ions recombine, and the ionization current measured is too low.</p>
<p>Above a certain 'saturation' voltage, all the ions are separated, and ionization current is constant.</p>
<ul>
<li>Air has been chosen as the standard material for dosimetry because:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Effective atomic number of air (7.6) is close to that of tissue (7.4)
→ ∴ the conversion factor is close to unity</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Applicable to the measurement of a wide range of X- and γ ray photon energies.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Large &amp; small doses and large &amp; small dose rates are easily and accurately measured.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Air is available, cheap, universal with invariable composition.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="wall-material">WALL MATERIAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wall-material" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The chamber wall must be made of a suitable material.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The material of wall and electrode must be indistinguishable from air, except in density. They must be made of air-equivalent material (specially compounded plastic is used).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An air-equivalent material matches air as regards Effective atomic number
→ absorbs energy from an X-ray beam to the same extent as the same mass of air.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Density is not important; it can conveniently be a solid.</p>
<ul>
<li>The thimble wall is made of plastic (Z = 6), made conducting by an internal coat of graphite, and the inner electrode made of thin aluminum wire (Z = 13).</li>
</ul>
<p>By adjusting the length of the wire, the average or effective atomic number of</p>
<p>42</p>
<p>the combination can be made equal to that of air.</p>
<p>The chamber is said to be <strong>air wall</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Air thimble measures the air dose whatever the photon energy of the radiation → <strong>energy-independent</strong> "However, corrections are needed, as discussed below".</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wall-thickness">WALL THICKNESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wall-thickness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-chamber-wall-must-be-sufficiently-thick">The chamber wall must be sufficiently thick<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-chamber-wall-must-be-sufficiently-thick" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The dosemeter is designed to measure the air dose at the center of the thimble → the overall dimensions should be small.</li>
<li>Typical values are length 17 mm, diameter 7 mm, and wall thickness 0.7 mm.</li>
<li>If the wall is too thin, electrons which have been set moving by the X-rays at points in the surroundings can penetrate into the air cavity and contribute to the ionization, giving a false reading.</li>
</ul>
<p>∴ The wall thickness should be greater than the maximum range of the secondary electrons set in motion by the hardest X-rays to be measured (For example, 0.2 mm for the photoelectrons from 140 keV X-rays)</p>
<p>So, the ionization is unaffected by the X- and gamma dose rate at points outside thimble</p>
<ul>
<li>However, if the wall is too thick it attenuates unduly the radiation being measured.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="air-volume">AIR VOLUME:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#air-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The larger the air volume, the more sensitive the dosemeter.</li>
</ul>
<p>A 30 ml chamber is often used to check the output of an X-ray set</p>
<p>A larger one to measure the low-intensity stray radiation near an X-ray set or in a radionuclide calibrator to assess radioactivity (see Section 5.6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="energy-dependence-correction-factors">ENERGY DEPENDENCE: CORRECTION FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#energy-dependence-correction-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In practice, the dosemeter is likely to give an incorrect measure of the air dose for two reasons:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>It is not possible to make the wall and electrode exactly air-equivalent.</li>
<li>The X- or gamma rays being measured are attenuated by the walls of the chamber, thus reducing the reading, particularly when measuring low-energy X-rays.</li>
</ol>
<p>✓ Accordingly, the dosemeter reading has to be multiplied by a correction factor, N, which varies with the photon energy, i.e. the dosemeter is 'energy-dependent'.</p>
<ul>
<li>Another correction has to be applied if the ambient temperature or pressure differ from standard values. If the pressure is too high or if the temperature is too low, air will leak out of the chamber, and the reading will be too low; and vice versa. Such a correction is not needed with sealed chambers.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="standard-free-air-chamber">STANDARD, FREE AIR CHAMBER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#standard-free-air-chamber" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The correction factor N is measured at a national standards laboratory (such as the National Physical Laboratory in the UK), where the thimble dosemeter is compared with a standard instrument, The Free Air Chamber.</li>
<li>This is designed to measure air dose exactly, whatever the energy of the radiation.</li>
<li>The 'wall' of the chamber is ordinary air, and so its 'thickness' has to be some 800 times that appropriate for a thimble chamber. This makes it a very large chamber which is inconvenient for departmental use.</li>
</ul>
<p>43</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sealed-parallel-plate-chambers">SEALED PARALLEL PLATE CHAMBERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sealed-parallel-plate-chambers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These are mounted on the light beam diaphragm for measuring the product (air kerma x area of beam).</li>
<li>It effectively measures the total energy entering the patient, most of which is deposited in the tissues, although some re-emerges as scatter.</li>
<li>It is referred to as <strong>a kerma-area</strong> or <strong>Jose-area product monitor</strong>.</li>
<li>This is easier to measure than the skin dose and is also a better index of the risk to the patient.</li>
<li>This chamber must be:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Transparent to light and to X-rays.</li>
<li>It must be broader than the widest beam of X-rays used.</li>
<li>It must not cast a shadow on the film, and is made of Perspex. The electrodes are made conducting by a transparent layer, a few atoms thick, of a metal such as gold.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Another type of sealed parallel plate chamber can be inserted between the patient and the film cassette for <strong>automatic exposure control</strong> (see Section 3.8).</li>
</ul>
<p>44</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exposure">EXPOSURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exposure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Not all dosemeters in current use are calibrated to read air kerma in grays. Some are calibrated to read exposure, which is defined as</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stMarkdownPre" class="st-emotion-cache-acwcvw e1icttdg5"><div class="stCode st-emotion-cache-6ml83 e1xss9yb4" data-testid="stCode"><pre class="st-emotion-cache-1nqbjoj e1xss9yb2"><div style="background-color: transparent;"><code style="white-space: pre;"><span>ionization charge collected
</span>mass of air in the thimble chamber</code></div></pre><div class="st-emotion-cache-chk1w8 e1xss9yb3"><button data-testid="stCodeCopyButton" title="Copy to clipboard" data-clipboard-text="ionization charge collected
mass of air in the thimble chamber" style="top: 0px; right: 0px;" class="st-emotion-cache-1lyayqq e1xss9yb5"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><rect x="9" y="9" width="13" height="13" rx="2" ry="2"></rect><path d="M5 15H4a2 2 0 0 1-2-2V4a2 2 0 0 1 2-2h9a2 2 0 0 1 2 2v1"></path></svg></button></div></div></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The obsolescent quantity 'exposure' only applies to X- and gamma rays and not to alpha particles, beta particles, or neutrons
Whereas, air kerma applies to them all.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The SI unit of exposure is coulombs per kilogram:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stMarkdownPre" class="st-emotion-cache-acwcvw e1icttdg5"><div class="stCode st-emotion-cache-6ml83 e1xss9yb4" data-testid="stCode"><pre class="st-emotion-cache-1nqbjoj e1xss9yb2"><div style="background-color: transparent;"><code style="white-space: pre;"><span>absorbed dose to air (Gy) = 34 x exposure (C kg⁻¹)</span></code></div></pre><div class="st-emotion-cache-chk1w8 e1xss9yb3"><button data-testid="stCodeCopyButton" title="Copy to clipboard" data-clipboard-text="absorbed dose to air (Gy) = 34 x exposure (C kg⁻¹)" style="top: 0px; right: 0px;" class="st-emotion-cache-1lyayqq e1xss9yb5"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><rect x="9" y="9" width="13" height="13" rx="2" ry="2"></rect><path d="M5 15H4a2 2 0 0 1-2-2V4a2 2 0 0 1 2-2h9a2 2 0 0 1 2 2v1"></path></svg></button></div></div></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The factor 34 is numerically equal to the energy in electronvolts expended per ion pair.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An older unit of exposure is the roentgen (R).
In reading the earlier literature, 'roentgen' can be taken as roughly synonymous with 'rad' or 10 mGy.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-dosemeters">OTHER DOSEMETERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-dosemeters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is often convenient to measure radiation dose by means of:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The photographic effect in silver bromide, used in a film badge (see-Section 6.9.1).</li>
<li>The fluorescent effect in sodium iodide, used in a scintillation counter (see also the gamma camera, Section 5.3).</li>
<li>The thermoluminescence in lithium fluoride, used in a 'TLD' (see Section 6.9.2).</li>
<li>The photoconductivity in germanium or silicon, used in an 'electronic' dosemeter.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The first two employ materials having a high atomic number, are highly energy dependent, and need calibration against an air wall thimble chamber. Lithium fluoride is sufficiently air or tissue equivalent to be adequate for the measurement of patient and staff doses.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An electronic dosemeter consists of a small semiconducting crystal in series with a battery and a digital measuring device. X-rays absorbed by the crystal make it conduct an electric current which is proportional to the dose rate.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="phantoms">PHANTOMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phantoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When measuring the dose delivered to a patient, the latter is often substituted by a phantom of the same general size and shape as the relevant part of the body and made of tissue-equivalent material.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tissue-equivalent material = a material which matches tissue as regards density and effective atomic number. It therefore absorbs and scatters an X-ray beam, whatever its energy, in the same manner and to the same extent as the same volume of tissue.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These conditions are most easily met by water in a thin-walled plastic container.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ Alternatively, specially compounded rubber or waxes may be used.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ Phantoms used in mammography are often based on Ferspex, which attenuates the X-ray beam more than the same thickness of tissue, for which allowance must be made.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>45</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quantity-and-quality">QUANTITY AND QUALITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quantity-and-quality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The intensity or air kerma rate of an X-ray beam is:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>proportional to the square of the kV;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>greater for a constant potential than a pulsating potential,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>proportional to the mA;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>decreases as the filtration is increased;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>inversely proportional to the square of the distance F from the target;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>greater for high rather than low atomic number targets</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The energy fluence or air kerma is, in addition, proportional to the exposure time:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>e</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>r</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mo>∝</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Dose\ rate\ \propto kV^2 \times mA / F^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Dose</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9474em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1141em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>e</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mo>∝</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Dose\ \propto kV^2 \times mAs / F^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">Dose</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9474em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03148em;">k</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1141em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal">s</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The Quality (i.e. penetrating power of an X-ray beam) may be specified as the HVL of the beam in a stated material, usually aluminum with diagnostic X-rays.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Alternatively, the quality may be described by the average or effective energy of the X-ray spectrum.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>This may be deduced from the measured HVL. The greater the HVL the greater the effective energy.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The effective energy can be defined as the photon energy of monoenergetic X-rays which have the same HVL as the polyenergetic beam being assessed. For example, 100 kV X-rays filtered with 2 mm Al have the same HVL (3 mm Al) as 30 keV photons. When filtered with 10 mm Al the effective energy is increased to 50 keV.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The HVL and effective energy of an X-ray beam:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increase as the applied kV is increased;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>are greater for constant potential than pulsating potential;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>are unaffected by the mA or exposure time;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>increase as the filtration is increased;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>are unaffected by the distance from the target</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A 'hard' X-ray beam is produced by a high kV and a thick filter; a 'soft' beam by a low kV and a thin filter.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Since the two principal factors affecting HVL or effective energy are kV and filtration, and since the latter is normally not changed, it is common in radiography to describe the quality of X-rays simply by stating the tube kV.</p>
<p>46</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-10-appendix">1.10 APPENDIX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-10-appendix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="units">UNITS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#units" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The SI units of energy and power are the joule (J) and the watt (W):</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \mathrm {W} = 1 \mathrm {J} / \mathrm {s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">W</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">J</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The SI units of electric charge and current are the coulomb (C) and ampere (A):</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \mathrm {A} = 1 \mathrm {C} / \mathrm {s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \mathrm {C} = 1 \mathrm {A s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">As</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>A smaller unit of current is the milliampere (mA).</p>
<p>A smaller unit of charge is the milliampere-second (mAs).</p>
<p>The SI unit of electrical potential difference (PD) and electromotive force (EMF) is the volt (V).</p>
<p>When a charge of 1 C passes through an EMF of 1 V it acquires 1 J of energy.</p>
<p>A smaller unit of energy is the electronvolt (eV), which is the energy acquired by a single electron when it passes through an EMF of 1 V.</p>
<p>There are as many electronvolts in a joule as there are electrons in a coulomb (= 6.25 x <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>18</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{18}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">18</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="multiplying-factors">MULTIPLYING FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiplying-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tera-</th><th>Giga-</th><th>Mega-</th><th>Kilo-</th><th>Milli-</th><th>Micro-</th><th>Nano-</th><th>Pico-</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Γ</td><td>G</td><td>M</td><td>k</td><td>m</td><td>μ</td><td>n</td><td>p</td></tr><tr><td>10^{12}</td><td>10^{9}</td><td>10^{6}</td><td>10^{3}</td><td>10^{-3}</td><td>10^{-6}</td><td>10^{-9}</td><td>10^{-12}</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electron-density">ELECTRON DENSITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electron-density" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In point of fact, the probability of the Compton process depends on the number of electrons per unit volume while being otherwise independent of atomic number. It therefore depends upon</li>
</ul>
<p>Mass per unit volume <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span> No. of electrons per unit mass</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The former is the usual 'physical density' and the latter is called the 'electron density'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Since the number of atoms per unit mass is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∝</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\propto 1 / \mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span>, and the number of electrons per atom is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∝</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\propto \mathrm{Z}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">Z</span></span></span></span></span></p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span></span></span></span></span> The number of electrons per unit mass must be <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∝</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\propto \mathrm{Z} / \mathrm{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">Z</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ul>
<li>Apart, from hydrogen (for which <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Z / A} = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Z/A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>), almost all light elements relevant to radiology have <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0.5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Z / A} = 0.5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Z/A</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<p>As a result, hydrogenous materials have slightly more electrons per gram than materials without hydrogen content.</p>
<p>The electron density of bone, air, fat, muscle, and water does not vary by more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span>. On account of this small variation we often simply say that Compton attenuation is proportional to physical density.</p>
<ul>
<li>Air-equivalent materials and tissue-equivalent materials must have the same electron density as air and soft tissue, respectively; as well as having the properties stated in Section 1.8.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="photon-and-energy-fluence-and-air-kerma">Photon and energy fluence and air kerma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#photon-and-energy-fluence-and-air-kerma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The relative (spectral) distributions of these three quantities are shown in Fig. 1.19 for a typical  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  X-ray beam. By way of example, consider a beam of photons of energy 30 keV. An air kerma of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{mGy}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mGy</span></span></span></span></span></span>  at a poi.'it is produced by an energy fluence of about  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mu \mathrm{J}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">J</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">m</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{mm}^{-2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , which corresponds to a photon fluence of 300 million photons  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{mm}^{-2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-6a3be22b.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg">
Fig 1.19 Photon fluence, energy fluence, and air kerma distributions.</p>
<p>48</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="imaging-with-x-rays">IMAGING WITH X-RAYS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#imaging-with-x-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-1-attenuation-of-x-rays-by-the-patient">2.1 ATTENUATION OF X-RAYS BY THE PATIENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-1-attenuation-of-x-rays-by-the-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In conventional projection radiography, a fairly uniform, featureless beam of X-radiation falls on the patient → differentially absorbed by the tissues of the body → the X-ray beam emerging from the patient carries a pattern of intensity which is dependent on the thickness and composition of the organs in the body.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Superimposed on the absorption pattern is an overall pattern of scattered radiation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The X-rays emerging from the patient are captured on a large flat phosphor screen → converts the invisible X-ray image into a visible image of light, which then is either:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Recorded as a negative image on film, to be viewed on a light box (illuminator); or</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Displayed as a positive image on a video monitor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In this chapter, we consider the invisible X-ray image and some consequences of the properties of X-rays described in the previous chapter, namely:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>They travel in straight lines; and</li>
<li>They are absorbed and scattered when traveling through matter.</li>
</ol>
<p>49</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="limiting-patient-dose">LIMITING PATIENT DOSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#limiting-patient-dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>&gt; The film-screen or any other imaging system used to convert the X-rays into light requires a specific or minimum dose to produce a satisfactory image. (About 1 µGy per radiograph when using sensitive rare-earth screens; 1 µGy per second of fluoroscopy). This is THE EXIT DOSE emerging from the patient.</p>
<p>&gt; THE ENTRANCE DOSE "that to the skin proximal to the tube" has to be much higher because of the high attenuation of X-rays by the patient.</p>
<ul>
<li>10 times greater for a posteroanterior chest,</li>
<li>100 for an anteroposterior abdomen or skull,</li>
<li>1000 for a lateral pelvis.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; THE AVERAGE DOSE lies somewhere between the entrance and exit doses.</p>
<p>&gt; THE EFFECTIVE DOSE, for reasons given in Chapter 6, is smaller.</p>
<p>&gt; One of the limiting factors in X-ray imaging is THE ACCEPTABLE DOSE of radiation that can be delivered to the patient. Patient dose should be as small as possible, consistent with producing an image satisfactory for clinical purposes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effect-of-tube-kilovoltage-on-patient-dose">Effect of tube kilovoltage on patient dose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-tube-kilovoltage-on-patient-dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; ↑↑ Kilovoltage (kV) → beam is more penetrating → ↑↑ the proportion of high-energy photons which reach the film-screen &amp; ↓↓ no. of low-energy photons absorbed in skin &amp; body soft tissue.</p>
<p>:: A lower entrance dose is needed for the same exit dose.</p>
<p>:: ↑↑ kV → ↓↓ the skin dose and, to a lesser extent, the dose to deeper tissues.</p>
<p>&gt; N.B.:
Whereas the output of the X-ray tube (Intensity) and the skin dose rate are proportional to kV², the film-screen dose is nearly proportional to kV⁴ (The exponent is 3-5, dependent on patient thickness and field size). (See Section 1.3)</p>
