<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="speed-and-selectivity">SPEED AND SELECTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#speed-and-selectivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The two tasks of a grid - to transmit primary radiation and absorb scattered radiation - may be judged by its <strong>SELECTIVITY &amp; SPEED</strong>:</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Selectivity</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>fraction&nbsp;of&nbsp;primary&nbsp;radiation&nbsp;transmitted</mtext><mtext>fraction&nbsp;of&nbsp;scattered&nbsp;radiation&nbsp;transmitted</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Selectivity} = \frac{\text{fraction of primary radiation transmitted}}{\text{fraction of scattered radiation transmitted}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Selectivity</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">fraction&nbsp;of&nbsp;scattered&nbsp;radiation&nbsp;transmitted</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">fraction&nbsp;of&nbsp;primary&nbsp;radiation&nbsp;transmitted</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Typical figures range from 6 - 12, depending on the grid ratio and tube kV.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Speed&nbsp;or&nbsp;exposure&nbsp;factor</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>total&nbsp;incident&nbsp;radiation</mtext><mtext>total&nbsp;emergent&nbsp;radiation</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>exposure&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;with&nbsp;a&nbsp;grid</mtext><mtext>exposure&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;without&nbsp;a&nbsp;grid</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Speed or exposure factor} = \frac{\text{total incident radiation}}{\text{total emergent radiation}} = \frac{\text{exposure necessary with a grid}}{\text{exposure necessary without a grid}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Speed&nbsp;or&nbsp;exposure&nbsp;factor</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">total&nbsp;emergent&nbsp;radiation</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">total&nbsp;incident&nbsp;radiation</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">exposure&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;without&nbsp;a&nbsp;grid</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">exposure&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;with&nbsp;a&nbsp;grid</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>It is also called 'Bucky factor' &amp; typically equals 3 - 5.</p>
<ul>
<li>Bucky factor is a practical measure which indicates how much the exposure factors must be increased when we change from non-grid to a grid technique → so, it also shows how much the patient exposure is increased.</li>
<li>Bucky factor is a measure of the total quantity of radiation absorbed from an X-ray beam by a grid &amp; so, in part, the ability of the grid to absorb scatter radiation.</li>
<li>Factors affecting the grid factor:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>High-ratio grids</strong> absorb more scatter radiation &amp; have larger bucky factor than low-ratio grids.</li>
<li>↑↑ beam energy "i.e. ↑ kV" → ↑ scatter radiation → needs a higher-ratio grids.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The high bucky factor have desirable &amp; undesirable aspect:</li>
<li>“Desirable as regarding the film quality.”</li>
<li>Undesirable as regards the exposure factor &amp; patient dose.</li>
</ul>
<p>Both GRID FACTOR and CONTRAST IMPROVEMENT FACTOR depends on kV → both decrease as kV increases</p>
<p>While, THE GRID RATIO doesn't have anything to do with Kv.</p>
<p>N.B.:</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∼</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sim</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">∼</span></span></span></span></span>  1ry transmission indicates only the amount of 1ry radiation absorbed by a grid.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∼</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sim</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">∼</span></span></span></span></span>  Bucky factor indicates the absorption of both 1ry &amp; 2ry radiation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-3-2-effect-on-direct-rays">2.3.2 EFFECT ON DIRECT RAYS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-3-2-effect-on-direct-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="precautions-of-using-grids-grid-cut-off">PRECAUTIONS OF USING GRIDS &amp; GRID CUT-OFF:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#precautions-of-using-grids-grid-cut-off" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>(a) The primary disadvantage of grids is that they increase the amount of radiation needed for an exposure &amp; so increase the amount of radiation to the patient.
(b) The grid must be used at a specified distance from the anode.</p>
<ul>
<li>Unfocused grids, in which the strips are completely parallel, may be used at any focus distance but suffer severely from cut-off.</li>
<li>The effect can be reduced by using a longer FFD or a grid with a lower grid ratio.</li>
</ul>
<p>(c) The tube must be accurately centered over the grid.
(d) The grid must not be tilted; otherwise CUT-OFF of the primary rays will occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="grid-cut-off">GRID CUT-OFF:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#grid-cut-off" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Grid cut off occurs due to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Focused grid placed upside down (by mistake)</li>
<li>Lateral decentering (grid angulation)</li>
<li>Focus-grid distance decentering</li>
<li>Combined lateral and focus-grid distance decentering.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9275bd6d.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg">
Figure 8-11 Cutoff from an upside down focused grid (A) and radiograph resulting from an upside down focused grid (B)
Figure 8-12 Cutoff from lateral decentering. (A) and series of radiographs resulting from increasing amounts of lateral decentering (B)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-c74b6d72.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg">
Figure 8-15 Cutoff from far focus-grid distance decentering</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-f7746e4b.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg">
Figure 8-17 Cutoff from combined lateral and far focus-grid distance decentering</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-004f8279.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-f626cc03.jpeg" alt="img-76.jpeg">
Figure 8-14 Cutoff from near focus-grid distance decentering
Figure 8-18 Cutoff from combined lateral and near focus-grid distance decentering</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="grid-front-cassette">Grid-front cassette<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#grid-front-cassette" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Special X-ray cassette with a grid build into the front of the cassette.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Used for portable radiography.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Most are focused with a low grid ratio (4:1 or 8:1) &amp; long focal distance "focusing range"</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="moving-slot">MOVING SLOT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#moving-slot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>An alternative to a grid  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  consists of two metal plates each with a slot,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  wide, aligned with the beam in front of and behind the patient.</li>
<li>They are arranged to move steadily across the field during the exposure. With only a slice of the patient being irradiated at any instant, little scatter is produced.</li>
<li>An increase of exposure time is necessary, but this can be mitigated by employing several slits well spaced apart.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-4-magnification-and-distortion">2.4 MAGNIFICATION AND DISTORTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-4-magnification-and-distortion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Some important aspects of a radiological image arise simply from the fact that  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span> -rays travel in straight lines.
Figure- 2.8a .shows how the imago  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span></span></span></span></span>  of structure  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span>  produced by a diverging X-ray beam is larger than the structure itself.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b77707cb.jpeg" alt="img-77.jpeg">
(a)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-41143376.jpeg" alt="img-78.jpeg">
(b)
Fig. 2.8 Magnification and blurring, (a) Formation of magnified image, (b) A plot of film density along a line across the film.</p>
<ul>
<li>If the diagram is redrawn with larger or smaller values for  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">h</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span></span></span></span></span> , it will be seen that magnification is reduced by using a longer FFD "F" or by decreasing the object-film distance "h", (It will be shown in Section 2.5 that this also reduces the blurring  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span></span></span></span></span> .)</li>
</ul>
<p>Also to decrease Magnification:</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  When positioning the patient, the film is placed close to the structures of interest.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  tissues compression  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  this will also reduce patient dose.</p>
<ul>
<li>On the other hand, advantage is taken of increased magnification in macroradiography (see Section 3.9).</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>T&nbsp;h&nbsp;e&nbsp;m&nbsp;a&nbsp;g&nbsp;n&nbsp;i&nbsp;f&nbsp;i&nbsp;c&nbsp;a&nbsp;t&nbsp;i&nbsp;o&nbsp;n</mtext><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>l&nbsp;e&nbsp;n&nbsp;g&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;o&nbsp;f&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;e&nbsp;i&nbsp;m&nbsp;a&nbsp;g&nbsp;e</mtext><mtext>l&nbsp;e&nbsp;n&nbsp;g&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;o&nbsp;f&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;e&nbsp;s&nbsp;t&nbsp;r&nbsp;u&nbsp;c&nbsp;t&nbsp;u&nbsp;r&nbsp;e</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text {T h e m a g n i f i c a t i o n} M = \frac {\text {l e n g t h o f t h e i m a g e}}{\text {l e n g t h o f t h e s t r u c t u r e}} = \frac {F}{F - h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">T&nbsp;h&nbsp;e&nbsp;m&nbsp;a&nbsp;g&nbsp;n&nbsp;i&nbsp;f&nbsp;i&nbsp;c&nbsp;a&nbsp;t&nbsp;i&nbsp;o&nbsp;n</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">M</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">l&nbsp;e&nbsp;n&nbsp;g&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;o&nbsp;f&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;e&nbsp;s&nbsp;t&nbsp;r&nbsp;u&nbsp;c&nbsp;t&nbsp;u&nbsp;r&nbsp;e</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">l&nbsp;e&nbsp;n&nbsp;g&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;o&nbsp;f&nbsp;t&nbsp;h&nbsp;e&nbsp;i&nbsp;m&nbsp;a&nbsp;g&nbsp;e</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1297em; vertical-align: -0.7693em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7693em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="distortion">DISTORTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distortion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Distortion = difference between the shape of a structure in the image and in the subject.</li>
<li>Causes:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>It may be due to foreshortening of the shadow of a tilted object, e.g. a tilted circle projects as an ellipse.</li>
<li>It may also be caused by differential magnification of the parts of a structure nearer to and farther away from the film-screen, an effect which is familiar to photographers.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Distortion can be reduced by using a longer FFD.</li>
</ul>
<p>62</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-5-unsharpness-and-blurring">2.5 UNSHARPNESS AND BLURRING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-5-unsharpness-and-blurring" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In practice, three types of unsharpness combine to limit the resolution achievable (see Section 3.6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="geometrical-unsharpness">GEOMETRICAL UNSHARPNESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#geometrical-unsharpness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The image of a stationary structure produced by the beam from an ideal point source would be perfectly sharp. At the edge of the shadow, the intensity of X-rays would change suddenly from a high to a low value.</li>
<li>Figure 2.8a shows that, in the case of effective focal spot <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f \, \mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the intensity changes gradually over a distance <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span></span></span></span></span>, variously called the penumbra, blurring or unsharpness.</li>
<li>If the diagram is redrawn with larger or smaller values for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f, F</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">h</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span></span></span></span></span>, it will be seen that <strong>blurring is reduced by</strong>:</li>
<li>☑ using a smaller focal spot;</li>
<li>☑ decreasing the object-film distance; or</li>
<li>☑ using a longer FFD → this also reduces magnification and distortion</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span></span></span></span></span> is usually and conveniently <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \, \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>, but it may be smaller in some techniques, such as fluoroscopy, while <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \, \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> is used with a chest stand.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="geometrical-blurring">Geometrical blurring<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#geometrical-blurring" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The geometrical blurring <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mi>h</mi></mrow><mi>F</mi></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B(g) = \frac{fh}{F}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">g</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2772em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9322em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.4461em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">h</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>If <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f = 2 \, \mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F = 1 \, \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">h = 100 \, \mathrm{mm} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> then <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B(g) = 0.2 \, \mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">g</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Usually the geometrical blurring is less than this as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">h</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">h</span></span></span></span></span> are smaller.</p>
<ul>
<li>Figure 2.8b plots the intensity of X-rays (or film density) along a line across the film. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span></span></span></span></span> is the geometrical blurring and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> the contrast.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="movement-unsharpness">MOVEMENT UNSHARPNESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#movement-unsharpness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>One of the problems in radiography is the imaging of moving structures.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If, during an exposure of duration <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span> seconds, the structure moves parallel to the film with an average speed <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">v</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span></span></span></span></span>, the edge of the shadow moves a distance slightly greater than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">vt</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>∴ movement blurring <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>v</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B(m) = vt</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span> (approximately).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">v = 4 \, \mathrm{mm} \, \mathrm{s}^{-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03588em;">v</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">s</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.05</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t = 0.05 \, \mathrm{s} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.05</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> then <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">B(m) = 0.2 \, \mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>N.B.:</strong> Movement strictly perpendicular to the film does not produce blurring.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Movement blurring may be reduced to a satisfactory degree by:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Immobilization.</li>
<li>Using short exposure time, made possible by a rotating anode tube (see Section 2.7.2) and intensifying screens (see Section 3.4).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>It is, on the other hand, made use of in mechanical tomography (see Section 2.6).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="absorption-unsharpness">ABSORPTION UNSHARPNESS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#absorption-unsharpness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A gradual change in absorption near the edge of a tapered or rounded structure, e.g. a blood vessel, produces absorption blurring.</li>
<li>This is inherent in the objects being imaged, though the effect can sometimes be reduced by careful patient positioning.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-6-tomography">2.6 TOMOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-6-tomography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>So far we have considered conventional projection radiography, in which the shadows of structures farther from the film are superimposed on those closer to the film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  there is lack of depth.</li>
</ul>
<p>This lack of depth resolution is overcome in biplane angiography by taking two crossed projections.</p>
<p>In tomography,</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Only structures in a selected slice of the patient, parallel to the film, are imaged sharply.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Those above and below are deliberately blurred  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  unrecognizable. This blurring is produced by simultaneous movement, during the exposure, of two of the three following: tube, film, and patient.</p>
<p>In linear tomography, depicted in Fig. 2.9a:</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  The tube T and cassette carrier C are linked by an extensible rod TC which is hinged about a fulcrum or pivot P which, in turn, is attached via a vertical arm to the table top.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  During the exposure, the cassette tray moves horizontally, for example from right to left, along rails under the couch top, while the tube stand moves along floor rails in the other direction, from left to right.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b7c304ac.jpeg" alt="img-79.jpeg">
Fig. 2.9 Linear tomography (a) the thickness of cut t is related to swing angle  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\theta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">θ</span></span></span></span></span> . (b) Structures outside the focal plane are blurred.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-e77354c4.jpeg" alt="img-80.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Figure 2.9b depicts two positions  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  of the focal spot and the corresponding positions of the film. It shows that the plane of interest within the patient is at the level of fulcrum, all points (&amp; levels) above and below are blurred.</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Shadow of a structure P at the level of the pivot moves from  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P_1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{P_2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  at the same speed as the cassette  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  remains stationary on the film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  sharp image. This is true of any structure in the plane through P (sometimes called the 'focal plane').
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  However, the shadow of a structure R above the pivot moves further, from  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{R}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{R}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , sweeping across the film, and is blurred out. A structure S below the pivot is similarly blurred.</p>
<p>The farther the structure from the pivot plane, the greater the movement blurring. Structures lying within a slice of thickness  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span>  are sufficiently sharp to be recognizable, whereas those lying outside that slice are too blurred and of too low contrast (see below).</p>
<p>The level of cut (focal plane) is adjusted by raising or lowering the pivot.</p>
<p>64</p>
<ul>
<li>The <strong>thickness of cut (t)</strong> is controlled by:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Adjusting the <em>tomographic angle θ</em> (i.e. the angle of tube swing or the amplitude of tube travel expressed in degrees)</li>
</ol>
<p>“The greater tomographic angle → the thinner the cut, because even structures vertically close to P are blurred.</p>
<p>“If θ were zero → t would be very large, i.e. a conventional radiograph results.”</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>if the fulcrum (level of cut) is raised → smaller thickness of cut,</li>
</ol>
<p>As this increases the movement of the cassette and the tomographic effect.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Decreasing the FFD has a similar effect.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Typically, in tomography θ is around 40° and t about 3 mm.</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Since such a thin slice of each structure is being imaged, and the shadows of off-focus anatomy are spread over the film → ∴ contrast is low → ∴ a reasonably low kilovoltage must be used, consistent with penetrating the patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The technique has been most useful when imaging structures of <em>high inherent contrast</em>, e.g. bony structures in the inner ear and iodine-filled vessels in pyelography.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In Tomography, high patient dose is needed</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Since for much of the exposure the beam is passing obliquely through the patient, attenuation is higher and patient dose is greater than in conventional radiography.</p>
<p><strong>Narrow- versus Wide-Angle Tomography:</strong></p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Wide-angle Tomography</th><th>Narrow-angle Tomography "Zonography"</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Use</strong></td><td>To obtain the max. blurring of obscuring shadows</td><td>To view a whole object "undistorted &amp; sharply defined"</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Aim</strong></td><td>To enable imaging of an object completely obscured by overlying shadows.</td><td>Produce undistorted sharply defined image of an entire structure in focal plane, against a background of slight blurring.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Tomographic angle</strong></td><td>Wide (&gt; 10°, usually 35-50°)</td><td>Narrow (&lt; 10°)</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Exposure time</strong></td><td>Long</td><td>Short</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Effect</strong></td><td>~ Considerable unsharpness of focal plane images (i.e. low contrast)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>~ Maximum blurring of objects outside focal plane.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>~ Less section thickness.</td><td>~ Little unsharpness of focal plane images.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>i.e. retain the natural contrast</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>~ Minimum blurring of objects outside focal plane.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>~ Greater section thickness.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Choice</strong></td><td>Best for tissues with high contrast</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e.g. bone, inner ear</td><td>Best for tissues with low contrast</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>e.g. lung, soft tissue</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Tomographic motion</strong></td><td>Can be done with both linear or circular motion</td><td>Done with circular motion.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Unlikely to cause phantom images</td><td>frequently cause phantom images</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>65</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blurring">Blurring:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blurring" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The purpose of tomography is to distort the object that might interfere with the radiographic image of structures of interest (in the focal plane).</li>
<li><strong>Width of the Blur</strong> = the distance over which the image of an object is spread out on film.</li>
<li><strong>Width of blurring is determined by 4 factors:</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>↑ Amplitude of tube travel → ↑ width of blur (linear relation)</li>
<li>↑ Distance from focal spot → ↑ blurring. However, the distance inside pt. body is uncontrollable.</li>
<li><strong>Distance from film</strong>: objects far away from the film are blurred more than objects closer to the film (assuming they are both the same distance from the focal plane). So, position patient so that the objects we want to blur are as far from the film.</li>
<li><strong>Orientation of tube travel</strong>: long &amp; narrow objects which have longitudinal axis oriented in the same direction as the axis of tube travel → not blurred, even though it's outside the focal plane, while maximum blurring is when the long axis of the object is ⊥ direction of tube travel.</li>
</ol>
<p>To overcome this problem with linear tomography and increase blurring outside the pivot plane, other tomographic movements may be used:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>☑ <strong>Circular movement</strong>, which produces the tomographic effect in all directions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ <strong>Elliptical movement</strong>, similar to the above but more appropriate to the elongated human body.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Spiral and hypocycloidal movements</strong>, on the principle that the more complex the movement the better!</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Blur margin = the edge of the blurred image.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>~ Linear tomography → uniform blurring with gradual fade-off at the blur margin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>~ Circular tomography → non-uniform blurring with sharp blur margin → important in phantom image formation.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="phantom-image-formation">Phantom Image Formation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#phantom-image-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Phantom images appear on tomograms, but they don't actually exist.</li>
<li>It is produced by blurred margins of structures outside the focal plane.</li>
<li>These unreal images are less dense &amp; less sharp than real image, but still may add difficulty to film interpretation.</li>
<li>Occur mostly with circular tomography &amp; zonography → object outside focal plane are only minimally blurred.</li>
<li>Bony trabeculae, teeth, ribs &amp; dye-filled vessels are anatomic parts that are apt to cause phantom images.</li>
</ul>
<p>66</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quality-assurance">QUALITY ASSURANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-assurance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Commercial test tools are used to check the performance of tomographic equipment for height of cut and slice thickness.</li>
<li>The simplest test → Pinhole camera technique (Figure 16-17 Christensen's)</li>
<li>By placing a lead sheet with a hole 1 mm in diameter between the fulcrum and the table top (at the level of the focal plane).</li>
<li>× 2 exposures,</li>
<li>One using the tomographic movement → produce an image of the swing (a straight line of uniform density for linear tomography)</li>
<li>The other with a vertical beam → a dense spot superimposed on swing which should be at the center of the line</li>
<li>Any elongation of the tomographic image of the hole indicates lack of coincidence between the movement of the tube and the film cassette.</li>
<li>The of dots produced by the Pin-hole technique provides the following information:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Tube motion (e.g. linear, circular, etc.).</li>
<li>The angle of swing of tube (exposure angle).</li>
<li>Symmetry of exposure angle → exposed dots have to be equal in length on either side of the central dot.</li>
</ol>
<p>RADIOGRAPHY WITH FILMS AND SCREENS</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="x-ray-cassette">X-ray cassette:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-ray-cassette" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A flat, light-tight box with spring clips.</li>
<li>Contain internal pressure pads → keep film between a pair of screens in close contact.</li>
<li>The front of the cassette is made of aluminum (Z = 13) or carbon fiber (Z = 6) → to minimize the attenuation of the beam → reduce the patient exposure.
Carbon fiber is effective at the lower kV values → in mammography &amp; orthopedics.</li>
<li>The cassette back incorporates a thin lead sheet (absorb the remnant radiation).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-1-intensifying-screens">3.1 INTENSIFYING SCREENS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-1-intensifying-screens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="function">Function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Absorb the energy in the x-ray beam 'penetrated the patient' → convert into a light pattern with the same pattern as original x-ray beam → recorded as latent image on x-ray film.</p>
<ul>
<li>They decrease the x-ray dose to the patient, yet still afford a properly exposed x-ray film.</li>
<li>↓↓ exposure allows use of short exposure times → necessary to minimize patient motion</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="construction">Construction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#construction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>An intensifying screen consists of 4 layers:</li>
<li>A base 'for support' - polyester "plastic" or cardboard - 0.25 mm thick.</li>
<li>A phosphor layer:</li>
<li>× 0.1-0.5 mm thick.</li>
<li>× Dense layer of fine phosphor crystals (3-10 μm) bound by a transparent resin.</li>
<li>A reflecting layer "not in all screens":</li>
<li>× Thin white reflective layer - between the base &amp; phosphor (Titanium dioxide TiO₂)</li>
<li>× Reflect light directed toward back of screen again toward the film "otherwise lost"</li>
<li>Very thin protective layer (outermost) → Physical protection to phosphor layer.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-13041f91.jpeg" alt="img-81.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The most frequently used phosphors are:
a) Calcium Tungstate
b) Various rare earths:</li>
<li>i- Lanthanum oxybromide.</li>
<li>iv- Yttrium oxysulfide.</li>
<li>ii- Lanthanum oxysulfide.</li>
<li>v- Barium lead sulfate.</li>
<li>iii- Gadolinium oxysulfide.</li>
<li>vi- Barium fluorochloride.</li>
</ul>
