<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="matching-film-and-phosphor">Matching film and phosphor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#matching-film-and-phosphor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The intensity of light emitted by a screen depends on the phosphor, but its color depends on activator.</li>
<li>Spectral sensitivity of the film should match Spectral emission of the screen to ensure maximum radiographic effect.</li>
</ul>
<p>1- Calcium tungstate, which emits a continuous spectrum of violet and blue light, and Lanthanum oxybromide activated with terbium, which emits a blue light</p>
<ul>
<li>Can be used with ordinary X-ray film "sensitive only to ultraviolet and blue light".</li>
<li>Film doesn't exhibit photosensitivity to red light → Amber red safelight for darkroom.</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Gadolinium and lanthanum oxysulfides activated with terbium → green light.</p>
<ul>
<li>Used only with an orthochromatic film "its sensitivity include green light".</li>
<li>A red safelight is necessary.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="to-maximize-the-absorption-of-x-rays">To maximize the absorption of X-rays.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-maximize-the-absorption-of-x-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Phosphor should have a sufficiently high atomic number</li>
<li>The absorption edge of tungsten (W, 70 keV) is less favorably placed in relation to the X-ray spectrum than those of gadolinium (Gd, 50 keV) or lanthanum (La, 39 keV).</li>
<li>Rare earth screens are also more efficient than tungstate in converting absorbed X-ray energy into emitted light (conversion efficiency of tungstate is 5% compared to 20% for rare earths, see later).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-6f4f6765.jpeg" alt="img-82.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>All these factors make rare earth screens more sensitive ('faster') than calcium tungstate screens, so allows:</li>
<li>Lower exposure.</li>
<li>2-3 times lower patient dose "for same quality".</li>
<li>Lower kV.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="afterglow">Afterglow<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#afterglow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In afterglow, the screen retains a 'memory' of an exposure → superimposed on the image of a subsequent exposure → must be avoided in intensifying screens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intensification-factor-speed">Intensification factor 'SPEED'<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intensification-factor-speed" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the reduction in patient dose and tube loading when the screens are used.</li>
<li>It is the ratio</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mtext>air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;D</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;with&nbsp;film&nbsp;alone</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;D</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;with&nbsp;film&nbsp;plus&nbsp;screens</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{air kerma necessary to produce D} = 1 \text{ with film alone}}{\text{air kerma necessary to produce D} = 1 \text{ with film plus screens}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;D</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;with&nbsp;film&nbsp;plus&nbsp;screens</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">air&nbsp;kerma&nbsp;necessary&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;D</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;with&nbsp;film&nbsp;alone</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Typical values are 30-100</p>
<ul>
<li>Factors ↑↑ IF:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>↑↑ kV → because the K-absorption edges of silver and bromine in the film are 26 keV and 13 keV, respectively, while the K-absorption edge of tungsten = 70 keV.</li>
<li>Heavily filtered x-ray beam (same reason).</li>
<li>↑↑ Thickness of the phosphor 'coating weight' or using larger crystals.</li>
<li>Rare earth screens have a larger IF than tungstate.</li>
<li>The use of a white reflecting layer, e.g. titanium dioxide.</li>
</ol>
<p>3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-4-use-of-screens">3.4 USE OF SCREENS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-4-use-of-screens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="film-exposed-directly-to-x-rays">Film exposed directly to X-rays<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#film-exposed-directly-to-x-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>More exposure (mAs) is required if no screens are used.</li>
</ul>
<p>Films exposed with par speed intensifying screens will require an x-ray exposure of approximately 1 mR to produce a density of 1; this value will rise to 30 mR with direct x-ray exposure.</p>
<ul>
<li>At the same density, contrast is always lower for a film exposed to x rays only than for the same film exposed by light from intensifying screens.</li>
</ul>
<p>Intensifying screens are less sensitive than film to lower energy x-rays → ↓ effect of 'lower energy' scattered radiation → ↑ contrast</p>
<p>Stated another way.</p>
<p>The gradient "gamma" of x-ray film is greatest when the film is exposed with intensifying screens than with direct x-ray exposure.</p>
<ul>
<li>When does direct exposure to X-ray needed?</li>
</ul>
<p>To produce a sharp image → used in thin parts and where fine detail is required, e.g. teeth &amp; bone fractures of the extremities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="film-exposed-with-screens">Film exposed with screens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#film-exposed-with-screens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A film exposed with screens is more sensitive than film exposed alone for 2 reasons:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The screen phosphor layer is thicker → absorbing X-rays &gt; film emulsion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each X-ray photon absorbed by phosphor produces hundreds of small light photons.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Film and screen</th><th>Film only</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Absorbed by phosphor, 30</td><td>Absorbed by film, 2</td></tr><tr><td>Light photons produced, 18000</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Light photons reaching film, 9000</td><td>—</td></tr><tr><td>Latent images produced, 90</td><td>Latent images produced, 2</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Accordingly, the use of screens reduces the air kerma or exposure necessary to produce a properly exposed film</li>
</ul>
<p>→ reduces the dose to the patient
→ reduces the loading of the tube and generator
→ allow the use of shorter exposure time → reducing movement blurring.
→ allow the use of a smaller focal spot → ↓ geometrical blurring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="front-and-back-screens">Front and back screens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#front-and-back-screens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To equalize the densities of the two emulsions, the rear screen coating is thicker than that of the front screen since the back screen relies on X-rays which have not been absorbed by the front screen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reciprocity-law">Reciprocity law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reciprocity-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The density of blackening of a film depends only on the quantity of radiation (or mAs) whatever the particular combination of intensity (mA) and exposure time (s).</p>
<ul>
<li>It holds only for X-rays, i.e. film exposed without screens. It does not hold for light;</li>
</ul>
<p>3.2 FILMS</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-1de1a558.jpeg" alt="img-83.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>A film consists of:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>A polyester base (typically 0.2 mm thick) → support fragile emulsion.</li>
<li>On which is coated a thin photographic emulsion (10 μm thick).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The emulsion is a suspension of fine silver halide crystals (iodobromide: 90-99% silver bromide, 1-10% silver iodide) in gelatine.</li>
<li>Each crystal is about 1 μm in size and containing a million or more silver atoms.</li>
<li>A photographic emulsion is:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Sensitive to X-rays and ultraviolet &amp; visible light.</li>
<li>Also, affected by mechanical, electrical &amp; chemical factors.</li>
</ol>
<p>All of which have implications for storage and handling.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Thin transparent antistatic supercoat → protect against abrasion &amp; curling.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>An X-ray film is usually double coated with an emulsion on each side of the base, and is used with a pair of screens.</li>
<li>About a 1/3 of the X-radiation falling on the front screen (nearer the patient) is absorbed</li>
<li>About 1/2 the light so produced travels forward and exposes the nearer (front) emulsion 'the rest is absorbed in the screen'.</li>
<li>About 1/2 the X-radiation transmitted by the front screen is absorbed by the rear screen → the produced light exposes the rear-facing emulsion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exposure-to-light">Exposure to light<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exposure-to-light" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Two features of the silver iodobromide crystal account for the photographic process</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-c6f6314e.jpeg" alt="img-84.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>The small proportion of iodide ions distort the lattice.</li>
</ol>
<p>There are several types of crystal defects.</p>
<ul>
<li>Point defect → a silver ion moved out of its normal position in the crystal lattice "interstitial silver ions" → can move in the crystal (Fig. 10-4).</li>
<li>Dislocation is a line imperfection in the crystal.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>The silver halide crystals are manufactured to possess sensitivity specks.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Chemical sensitization is produced by adding a sulfur-containing compound to the emulsion → reacts with silver halide to form silver sulfide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The silver sulfide is located on the surface of the crystal and is referred to as the sensitivity speck.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>How exposure of sensitized silver iodobromide grains in the film emulsion to light or direct x rays, initiates the formation of atomic silver to form a pattern?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-560c5151.jpeg" alt="img-85.jpeg"></p>
<ol>
<li>The energy absorbed from a light photon gives an electron in the bromine ion enough energy to escape.</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mtext>light&nbsp;photon</mtext><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>electron</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Br}^{-} + \text{light photon} \rightarrow \mathrm{Br} + \text{electron}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9279em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Br</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">light&nbsp;photon</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Br</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">electron</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>AgS sensitivity speck act as an electron trap.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The electron gives the sensitivity speck a negative charge → attracts the mobile interstitial <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ag^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9658em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ions in the crystal → form a single silver atom:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mtext>electron</mtext><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ag}^{+} + \text{electron} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ag}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.039em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Ag</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">electron</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Ag</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>This single atom of silver then acts as an electron trap for a second electron. → get negative charge → causes a second silver ion to migrate to the trap to form a two-atom silver nucleus.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The negative bromine ions that have lost electrons are converted into neutral bromine atoms → leave the crystal &amp; taken up by the gelatin of the emulsion.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The submicroscopic speck of silver metal form A LATENT IMAGE in the film, awaiting development.</li>
<li>Metallic silver is black.</li>
</ul>
<p>It is silver that produces the dark areas seen on a developed radiograph.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="processing">Processing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#processing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The invisible pattern of latent images is made visible by PROCESSING.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-film-is-processed-in-three-stages">The film is processed in three stages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-film-is-processed-in-three-stages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-development">I- Development:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Reduction of the silver ions (addition of an electron) by alkaline solution → black metallic silver: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><mtext>electron</mtext><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ag}^{+} + \text{electron} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ag}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.039em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Ag</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">electron</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Ag</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ul>
<li>N.B.: The development process is initiated at the site of a latent image speck on the surface of the grain → then, progress to development of the entire grain.</li>
</ul>
<p>The unexposed crystals, which carry no latent images, are unaffected by the developer.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Because, the silver atoms in the latent image accelerate the reduction of the silver ions in the grain → the silver in a grain that does not contain a latent image are reduced at a much slower rate. Thus, time is a fundamental factor in the developing process.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>∴ Development should be discontinued when the differential between exposed developed grains and unexposed undeveloped grains is at a maximum.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the developer attack unexposed crystals → Fog formation or wholly opaque film.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>To inhibit this, Potassium Bromide (Restrainer) is incorporated in the initial charge of developer (but not in the replenisher since the reduction of silver itself liberates bromine ions into the developer, which also decreases the rate of development).</p>
<ul>
<li>The bromide ions released by the reduction of silver ions to silver atoms pass into the developing solution. It is mainly this increase in bromide concentration that limits the life</li>
</ul>
<p>of developing solutions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-fixation">II- Fixation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-fixation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The film is now fixed by an acid solution of thiosulfate ('hypo').</li>
<li>It dissolves unaffected silver ions → the image becomes stable "unaffected further by light"</li>
<li>Incomplete fixation → 'milky' radiograph.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-washing">III- Washing:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-washing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After stages (1) and (2) the film is washed in water, and finally it is dried by hot air.</li>
<li>With inadequate washing → retained hypo will turn brown/yellow.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="automatic-processing">Automatic processing:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automatic-processing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Automatic processors use a roller feed system to transport the film through different solutions.</li>
<li>Processor performance is maintained through a comprehensive quality assurance program, described in Section 3.3.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="photographic-characteristics-of-x-ray-film">Photographic Characteristics of X-Ray Film<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#photographic-characteristics-of-x-ray-film" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="photographic-density">PHOTOGRAPHIC DENSITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#photographic-density" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The measurement of film blackness is called "photographic density".</li>
<li>The degree of film blackening is:</li>
<li>☑ Directly related to the intensity of radiation reaching the film.</li>
<li>☑ Directly related to silver grains \ unit area.</li>
<li>☑ Inversely related to the light transmission.</li>
<li>X-ray image is a negative image</li>
</ul>
<p>The film is darkest where the X-rays have been most intense, and vice versa.</p>
<ul>
<li>Photographic density is measured using a densitometer as log the ratio of the intensities of the incident to the transmitted light through the film.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msub><mi>I</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D = \log \frac{I_0}{I_t}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.1963em; vertical-align: -0.836em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2806em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">t</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.836em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>D = density I₀ = incident light on film Iₜ = transmitted light by the film</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-dee47004.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg"></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>DENSITY</mtext><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><mn>10</mn></msub><mfrac><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msub><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msub></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{DENSITY} = \log_{10} \frac{I_0}{I_+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">DENSITY</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2547em; vertical-align: -0.8943em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.207em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2583em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2083em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8943em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><msub><mi>I</mi><mo>+</mo></msub></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{I_0}{I_+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.3752em; vertical-align: -0.4868em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8884em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2737em;"><span style="top: -2.357em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.0714em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.5em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size3 size1 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2025em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.4101em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3173em;"><span style="top: -2.357em; margin-left: -0.0785em; margin-right: 0.0714em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.5em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size3 size1 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.143em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.4868em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span> alone measures the opacity of the film (the ability of film to stop light).</li>
<li>Useful densities in diagnostic radiology range from about 0.3 (50% of light transmitted) to about 2 (1% of light transmitted).</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span></span></span></span></span> Density increase of 0.3 → the opacity is doubled.</p>
<p>→ transmitted light is halved.</p>
<ul>
<li>The average density of the area of interest on a properly exposed film =</li>
</ul>
<p>6</p>
<p>1.0; of the lung field in a chest film 2.0; while viewing an area of density of 3.0 needs a bright lamp.</p>
<p>7</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If an unexposed x-ray film is processed, it will demonstrate a density of about 0.12.
This density refers to base density and fog.
Base density = 0.07
Caused by the plastic material &amp; the blue dye used to make film base.
Fog: "the density resulting from developed unexposed silver grains" = 0.05 "see later"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Why is density expressed as a logarithm?</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Logarithms express large differences in numbers on a small scale.</li>
<li>The physiologic response of the eye to differences in light intensities is logarithmic.</li>
<li>Superimposition of densities is best described on logarithmic base.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Densities are additive → either 2 films or 2 emulsions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-3-characteristic-curve">3.3 CHARACTERISTIC CURVE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-3-characteristic-curve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The relationship between log air kerma "or log exposure" and the density produced by the exposure → "characteristic curve".</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9dcb0359.jpeg" alt="img-87.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The most important parts of the characteristic curve:
a) The region of correct exposure:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ Straight-line portion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ Steepest.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ The densities within the area of diagnostic interest should lie within this range.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ Density is proportional to the log exposure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Other features of curve are:
b) The toe, shallow slope.
c) the shoulder, shallow slope, and
d) saturation density,
In both c &amp; d, the film is too dark to be readable on an ordinary illuminator;
e) reversal or solarization,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ ↑ E → ↓ D "producing a positive image".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>☑ Used for film copying, by exposure of reversal films to ultraviolet light.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="four-properties-of-the-film-screen-combination-can-be-derived-from-the-characteristic-curve">Four properties of the film-screen combination can be derived from the characteristic curve:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#four-properties-of-the-film-screen-combination-can-be-derived-from-the-characteristic-curve" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-fog-level-fff-in-fig-3-2">(1) Fog level <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">f</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10764em;">f</span></span></span></span></span> in Fig. 3.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-fog-level-fff-in-fig-3-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Fog → ↓↓ image contrast.</li>
<li>Types:</li>
<li>Inherent fog has typically <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.12</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D = 0.12</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.12</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Additional fog may arise during storage due to:</li>
<li>☑ Temperature &amp; humidity</li>
<li>☑ Accidental X-rays exposure.</li>
<li>☑ Light exposure.</li>
<li>Assessment → by measuring the density of processed but unexposed film (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E = 0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0</span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="29747abf">(2) Gamma (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#29747abf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>= the slope of the straight-line portion of the characteristic curve.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Gamma</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>D</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>−</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Gamma} = \frac{D_2 - D_1}{\log E_2 - \log E_1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Gamma</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2408em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3603em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0278em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The steeper slope → ↑ <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> → ↑ contrast</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-2c06f943.jpeg" alt="img-88.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> generally refers to the average slope between densities 0.25 and 2.0 (or 2.25).</li>
<li>In Fig. 3.3, film-screen A has a higher <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> than B (has a steeper slope → more 'contrasty').</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> depends on the range of crystal sizes (not their average sizes).</li>
</ul>
<p>The more uniform the crystals → the higher is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-film-speed-iii-in-fig-3-3">(3) Film Speed <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">I</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span></span></span></span></span> in Fig. 3.3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-film-speed-iii-in-fig-3-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>= The reciprocal of the exposure (measured in Roentgen) needed to produce <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Speed</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mtext>Exposure&nbsp;"in&nbsp;Roentgens"&nbsp;needed&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;</mtext><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Speed} = \frac{1}{\text{Exposure "in Roentgens" needed to produce } D=1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Speed</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2019em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Exposure&nbsp;"in&nbsp;Roentgens"&nbsp;needed&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>Factors ↑↑ film speed:</li>
<li>↑↑ Grain size.</li>
<li>Modern emulsions with flat crystals.</li>
<li>X-ray photon energy = 30-40 keV.</li>
<li>The relative speed of two films or film-screen combinations is the ratio</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>exposure&nbsp;needed&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;</mtext><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;on&nbsp;film&nbsp;A</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{exposure needed to produce } D = 1 \text{ on film A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">exposure&nbsp;needed&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;on&nbsp;film&nbsp;A</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>exposure&nbsp;needed&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;</mtext><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>&nbsp;on&nbsp;film&nbsp;B</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{exposure needed to produce } D = 1 \text{ on film B}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">exposure&nbsp;needed&nbsp;to&nbsp;produce&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;on&nbsp;film&nbsp;B</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>Speed "with fixed  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  " means that the film needs less exposure to produce same density.</li>
<li>But with films of different  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  relative speed change with change  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '}' at position 38: …~h~d~l~l~e~s~}}}̲" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{~s~h~d~l~l~e~s~}}}</span></span>  D</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-cd5bfd2a.jpeg" alt="img-89.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ae2aa303.jpeg" alt="img-90.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-film-latitude-or-dynamic-range">(4) Film latitude or dynamic range<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-film-latitude-or-dynamic-range" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>L is the range of air kerma E which produce densities D lying in the useful density range  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  between 0.25 "below which the gradient is too low" and 2.0 "above which the film is too dark for details to be seen using a normal illuminator".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Typically the dynamic range is 40:1.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Figure 3.3 shows that film contrast  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  and latitude are inversely related.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Film A has the steeper slope and higher  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> . It also has the narrower latitude L(A).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are two practical aspects to this concept of film latitude.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For the technologist:
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  latitude  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  more room for error in his choice of exposure (mAs).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For the radiologist  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  interested in high contrast "less latitude".
But if a wide range of subject contrast (such as in the chest) must be recorded  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  higher latitude can record small changes in film exposures.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Typically, wide latitude is needed in chest radiography and a high  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  in mammography.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="l-in-fig-3-2">L in Fig. 3.2.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#l-in-fig-3-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3721e226.jpeg" alt="img-91.jpeg">
LOG RELATIVE EXPOSURE</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-62b397f6.jpeg" alt="img-92.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exposure-latitude">EXPOSURE LATITUDE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exposure-latitude" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>= The range of EXPOSURE FACTORS (kV and mAs) which will give a correct exposure of a subject.</p>
<ul>
<li>If the exposure latitude is too small  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  misjudgment of the machine settings appropriate to individual patients will necessitate repeating radiographs &amp;  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  patient dose.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ddbea055.jpeg" alt="img-93.jpeg">
Fig 3.4 Exposure latitude with films of (a) high and (b) low gamma</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7a709535.jpeg" alt="img-94.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-which-increase-the-exposure-latitude">Factors which increase the exposure latitude:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-which-increase-the-exposure-latitude" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span>  Film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  Film latitude.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span>  subject contrast; which in turn depends on:</li>
</ol>
<p>a) Tissue densities.
b) Atomic numbers.
c) Thicknesses of the structures.
d) Tube kV.</p>
<p>If a higher kV is used and the mAs  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span>  subject contrast  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span>  range of air kerma within the image  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↑</span></span></span></span></span>  latitude of exposure</p>
<p>In conclusion, exposure latitude for a particular radiograph of a patient can be increased by using a higher kV or a film of lower  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
