<li>The actual tube kilovoltage should be within <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pm 5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">±</span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of the set value.</li>
<li>The kV can either be measured:</li>
</ul>
<p>☑ Directly (invasively) by <strong>potential divider</strong> applied across the high tension leads
☑ Indirectly (non-invasively) by <strong>a penetrameter</strong> method.</p>
<ul>
<li>Penetrameter method:</li>
</ul>
<p>× Employs <strong>2 copper absorbers</strong> of different thicknesses, beneath each of which is a <strong>photodiode</strong>.
× The unit is positioned in the middle of the X-ray field, some <strong>50-75 cm</strong> from the tube.
× Attached to the tube is a <strong>0.5 mm copper filter</strong> which transmits mainly X-rays near to the peak kiloelectronvolt value.
× Tube kV, mA, and exposure time are selected, and an exposure made.
× Each detector produces a different current, proportional to the X-ray intensity falling on it. The higher the tube kV, the smaller the ratio of the two currents.
× The current ratio is displayed, as <strong>the equivalent kV</strong>, on a digital read-out. The <strong>type of the waveform</strong> (pulsating or constant) can also be displayed.
× The kV is checked at several settings of the kV control.
× The kV meter itself needs to have the accuracy of its readings checked periodically at a national or secondary standards laboratory.</p>
<ul>
<li>In the same meter, the current from a single diode may be used to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Monitor X-ray output.</li>
<li>Used to start and stop a built-in digital timer to measure pulse length or check timer accuracy.</li>
<li>Displayed on an external storage oscilloscope → showing the waveform more precisely, how quickly the X-rays switch on and off, and the exposure time.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-total-filtration">THE TOTAL FILTRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-total-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Checked by measuring the kV (as above) and the half value layer (HVL) (see Section 1.4) and referring to a set of published graphs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-focal-spot">THE FOCAL SPOT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-focal-spot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>May also be checked when a new tube is installed, as described in Section 2.7.1.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="automatic-exposure-controls">AUTOMATIC EXPOSURE CONTROLS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automatic-exposure-controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Checked by measuring the radiation front and back of a water phantom with a dosemeter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-9-macroradiography">3.9 MACRORADIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-9-macroradiography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Where a magnified image is required  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the anode-object distance is decreased &amp; the object-film distance is increased.</li>
<li>Figure 3.8 shows that the image of a structure S is larger when the film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{F}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  is away from the patient than when it is at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{F}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , close to the patient.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-eb902f8d.jpeg" alt="img-99.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="this-has-the-following-implications-for-technique">This has the following implications for technique:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#this-has-the-following-implications-for-technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="focal-spot">Focal spot.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#focal-spot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A very small focal spot must be used (e.g.  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1 \, \mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) otherwise geometric blurring would be unacceptable.
The heat rating is reduced as a result of using small focal spot.</p>
<p>Exposure time  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  increased to several seconds, to keep within the rating of the focal spot</p>
<p>. Movement blurring  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  increased
. Immobilization is therefore important.</p>
<p>Patient dose  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  increased because of the increased exposure needed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contrast">Contrast<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contrast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>No grid is needed.
The air gap reduces the scatter reaching the film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  reduce the additional exposure needed (because the use of grids would necessitate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  exposure &amp; this didn't happen).</p>
<p>Screen blurring  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  not magnified although the image of the structure is magnified.</p>
<p>: The relative effect of screen blurring is reduced.
: Fast screens may be used, which again helps to reduce additional exposure needed.</p>
<p>Geometrical blurring  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  increased, relative to the size of the image.
Quantum mottle  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  not increased, since the same number of X-ray photons are absorbed in the screen, for the same film blackening.</p>
<p>23</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-10-mammography">3.10 MAMMOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-10-mammography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mammography aims to demonstrate on the same film both:</p>
<p>☑ Microcalcifications → small "100 μm in size" but of high inherent contrast.
☑ Other tissues → much lower contrast but large.</p>
<p>N.B. both subject contrast &amp; geometrical unsharpness are important factors in mammography</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contrast">CONTRAST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contrast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The breast does not attenuate the beam greatly, allowing the use of the low kV that is needed to obtain sufficient photoelectric absorption in order to differentiate between normal and abnormal breast tissues.</li>
<li>Ideally, monoenergetic X-rays of about 18-20 keV would produce optimal contrast and penetration in the case of a small breast.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tube-requirements-for-mammography">Tube requirements for mammography:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tube-requirements-for-mammography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tube voltage at 28 kV (constant potential) → the usual range is 25 – 30 kV.
At low kV, x-ray output is approximately proportional to the kV³; in contrast to general radiology with higher kV → x-ray output is proportional to the kV²</li>
<li>Relatively long exposure times are required to produce enough film blackening at such low kV without exceeding tube rating.</li>
<li>Beryllium window</li>
<li>Molybdenum target (produce more effective spectrum of energies for breast imaging).</li>
<li>Molybdenum filter (0.03 mm) → has an absorption edge at 20 keV → transmits most of the characteristic radiation (17.9 and 19.5 keV) but removes most of the continuous spectrum.</li>
</ul>
<p>This filter is known as a K-edge filter, because the filter strongly absorbs the radiation with energy above the k edge of molybdenum &amp; also the low energy photons. While it is relatively transparent to the characteristic radiation peaks (17.5 keV &amp; 19.6 keV).</p>
<p>In case of thicker breast, higher-energy radiation is preferred</p>
<p>Better results, with a significant decrease in absorbed dose to the breast tissue, are obtained with:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Rhodium target, giving 20.2 and 22.7 keV characteristic rays.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rhodium or Palladium filter, having absorption edges at 25 &amp; 25 keV, respectively.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Tungsten targets can be used with a Rhodium k-edge filter (k-edge = 23 keV) to remove the high energy photons.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-32254150.jpeg" alt="img-100.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 3.9 compares (A) the spectrum produced in this way by a molybdenum-molybdenum combination with (B) the spectrum that would be produced by operating a tube with a tungsten target at 30 kV and using a 0.5 mm Al filter.</p>
<ul>
<li>N.B.: modern mammography tubes allow the selection of both the filter &amp; the target, for example:</li>
<li>Mo target with either Mo or Rh filter</li>
<li>Rh or W target with a Rh filter.</li>
</ul>
<p>24</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-requirements-to-increase-contrast">Other Requirements to increase contrast:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-requirements-to-increase-contrast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Films <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma = 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span> to overcome the low subject contrast.</li>
<li>As gamma &amp; latitude are inversely related → films therefore have low latitude
The narrow exposure latitude make automatic exposure control, carefully controlled processing, and daily quality assurance checks desirable for consistent films and to avoid repeats.</li>
<li>The use of a grid or air gap → but the exposure and patient dose are increased.</li>
<li>A very fine high-resolution moving grid is the preferred option.</li>
<li>The grid moves continuously during the exposure → to blur the grid lines.</li>
<li>Standard grid ratio for mammography is 1:5.</li>
<li>Grids increase glandular dose by a factor between 2:3.</li>
<li>Compression of the breast:</li>
<li><strong>Importance</strong>: the main purpose of compression is to improve image quality</li>
<li>Vital for immobilization as exposure times are relatively long → so, ↓ movement blurring</li>
<li>Reduce the object-film distance → so reduce geometric blurring;</li>
<li>Equalize tissue thickness.</li>
<li>Compression also reduce patient dose (lower thickness allows reducing exposure).</li>
<li>The Max. Compression permitted to the breast is a force of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>200</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">200\,\mathrm{N}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">N</span></span></span></span></span> (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≈</mo><mn>20</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\approx 20\,\mathrm{kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4831em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span></span></span></span></span> force).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="image-definition">IMAGE DEFINITION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#image-definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Imaging microcalcifications needs high image definition</p>
<ul>
<li>It is necessary to use a single coated film to avoid parallax and crossover, together with a single, rare earth, rear screen.</li>
<li>A vacuum cassette improves the film-screen contact.</li>
<li>A small focal spot (0.3 mm or less) must be used.
For magnification of suspected lesions (by factors of 1.5 or 2, using an air gap of 15-30 cm) → 0.1 mm focal spots are used "to limit the geometric unsharpness".</li>
<li>On account of the small field of view, a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> target can be used, or a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>0</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> target with the tube tilted away from the chest wall.</li>
<li>A metal (not glass) tube is often used → ↓↓ extrafocal radiation.</li>
<li>The small focal spot and the inefficient production of X-rays consequent on the low kV and target atomic number → problems of tube loading.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-requirements">Other requirements:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The focal film distance is commonly <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60\,\mathrm{cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> → longer FFD would result in problems in achieving sufficiently high exposures.</li>
<li>The anode heel effect is utilized in mammography:</li>
<li>The axial ray "produced from the center of the focal spot → more intense beam" is directed to the chest wall "the thickest part of the breast" &amp; the anode side of the beam is not used.</li>
<li>MCQ: the axial ray is directed to the center of the x-ray field → "F"</li>
<li>A rotating anode is essential to improve the heat rating → as the small focal spot &amp; the long exposure time significantly increase the heat loading on the tube.</li>
<li>The optimum film density for viewing is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5 - 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> assuming optimized ambient viewing conditions.</li>
</ul>
<p>25</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dose">DOSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Breast tissue is relatively sensitive to radiation.</li>
<li>The requirements of contrast &amp; of sharpness or spatial resolution → ↑↑ patient dose.</li>
<li>The beam is <strong>tightly collimated</strong> and the collimator is designed to protect the chest wall from irradiation, and the rest of the body is protected by absorbing the remnant radiation immediately behind the cassette.</li>
<li>Ironically, while the objective of mammography is the early detection of breast tumors → <strong>irradiation of breast tissue is itself carcinogenic</strong>.</li>
<li>The average dose to glandular tissue in the breast is <strong>2 mGy per mammogram</strong> → carries a risk of inducing fatal cancer of about <strong>-0 / million at age 30-50 years</strong> and <strong>10 / million at age 50-65 year</strong> (see Section 6.3).</li>
</ul>
<p>This has implications for routine mammography of 'well women' outside recognized breast-screening programs.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Mammography equipment is subject to strict Quality Assurance procedures.</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Tube and generator tests for the low kV and filtration.</li>
<li>In addition, image quality and patient dose are crucial factors.</li>
<li>Collimation and field alignment are particularly important.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A <strong>mammography phantom</strong> capable of producing an anthropomorphic image, in addition to quantifiable data (for contrast and resolution), is ideal for routine use.</li>
<li>The mean glandular dose is also measured periodically, using a special <strong>thin-window ionization chamber</strong> and a <strong>standard Perspex mammographic phantom</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dose-limits">Dose limits:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose-limits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The dose limit for the UK breast screening programme for a standard breast → the mean glandular dose to the breast is <strong>2 mGy</strong>.</li>
<li>The diagnostic reference level for the breast screening programme for a 55 mm thick compressed breast → the mean glandular dose = <strong>0.5 mGy</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="silver-recovery">SILVER RECOVERY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#silver-recovery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Silver is an <strong>expensive</strong> and <strong>relatively scarce</strong> material which also causes <strong>pollution</strong> if disposed of in the environment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>As large amounts of silver are left behind in film processing, it is important to recover as much as possible for recycling.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are a number of ways to reclaim the silver:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>The electrolytic method.</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 90-95% of the silver in fixer can be deposited on a rotating cathode.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× The fixer can be reused.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× To avoid sulfiding (formation of silver sulfide) the pH must be kept low.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Metallic displacement with iron wool.</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× Silver is precipitated as sludge, and needs refining.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× The fixer cannot be reused.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Silver may be recovered from scrap film by burning or by chemical treatment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-11-xeroradiography">3.11 XERORADIOGRAPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-11-xeroradiography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Xeroradiography employs the same principle as a photocopier.</li>
<li>Instead of a film and screen, the light-tight cassette contains a rigid aluminum sheet (A in Fig. 3.10) on which is coated a thin layer (S) of selenium.</li>
<li>Before exposure to X-rays its surface is sprayed with a uniform positive charge.</li>
<li>In the dark, this material is an insulator but, when exposed to X rays (or light), electrons are liberated within the material  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  progressively discharge the positive surface charge.</li>
<li>The charge remaining at any point on the surface is related to the exposure of X-rays it has received  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  thus the X-ray pattern is converted into a pattern of positive charge.</li>
<li>Figure 3.10b shows the distribution of charge left after radiographing a stepped structure</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3b34150c.jpeg" alt="img-101.jpeg">
Fig. 3.10 Xeroradiography (a) Cross section through charged selenium plate, (b) Exposure to X-rays with a step-wedge, (c) Plot of density of toner deposit along a line across the plate</p>
<ul>
<li>Processing is rapid and 'dry'.</li>
<li>The image is developed, in the dark, in a closed development chamber by an aerosol of fine particles of carbon or dark blue thermoplastic toner material.</li>
<li>These are negatively charged and so are attracted to the remaining charge on the plate.</li>
<li>The image is then transferred to a paper sheet which is heated to bond the toner particles permanently.</li>
<li>The selenium plate is reused after cleaning and recharging.</li>
<li>Figure 3.10c shows the distribution of toner resulting from the exposure of Fig. 3.10b. More toner is accumulated for denser body structures, so the image produced is a reversal of a normal X-ray film.</li>
<li>The image generally has a very low contrast as the density of the carbon deposit does not vary greatly over the image. However, the boundaries of structures are well delineated by 'edge enhancement'.</li>
<li>Figure 3.10c shows that the toner piles up along one side of a boundary and is correspondingly depleted along the other side.</li>
</ul>
<p>As a result,</p>
<p>Structures of about 1 mm in size show a much higher contrast than larger structures.</p>
<ul>
<li>For this reason xeroradiography has sometimes been used in mammography, in which case a tungsten anode gives better results than a molybdenum one.</li>
</ul>
<p>However, as it generally incurs a higher dose than with films and screens  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  no longer favored as an imaging technique.</p>
<p>FLUOROSCOPY</p>
<p>Fluoroscopy is a real time X-ray imaging</p>
<p>☑ Phosphor screen → converts pattern of X-rays into a similar pattern of light for real time imaging.
☑ Intensity of light is proportional to the intensity of X-rays &amp; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma=1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-vision-fluoroscopy-early-days">Direct vision fluoroscopy (early days)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-vision-fluoroscopy-early-days" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>☑ The fluorescent material → copper-activated zinc cadmium sulfide → emitted light in yellow-green spectrum.
☑ The radiologist's eyes was protected by a sheet of lead glass.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>~ High doses.
~ Low brightness, even with examination carried out in a dark room &amp; with dark-adaptation of eyes by wearing red goggles for 20 to 30 minutes.</p>
<p>So, was dependent only on the Rods "scotopic" vision &amp; couldn't stimulate the cones "photopic" vision.</p>
<p>☑ The use of direct-vision fluoroscopy is now BANNED.</p>
<p>N.B. IRR99 states that no one can do fluoroscopic examination without image intensifier or similar device.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-1-1-the-image-intensifier">4.1.1 THE IMAGE INTENSIFIER:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-1-1-the-image-intensifier" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Used to increase the brightness of the image, while maintaining its proportionality with the X-ray beam intensity</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="as-fig-12-3-shows">As Fig. 12-3 shows,<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#as-fig-12-3-shows" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The tube itself is an evacuated glass envelope, a vacuum tube, which contains four basic elements:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>input phosphor &amp; photocathode</li>
<li>electrostatic focusing lens</li>
<li>accelerating anode</li>
<li>output phosphor</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="glass-tube">Glass Tube:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glass-tube" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>2 - 4 mm thick.</li>
<li>Enclosed in a lead-lined metal container → shielding.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="input-phosphor-screen">Input Phosphor Screen:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#input-phosphor-screen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>230 mm in diameter, 0.2 mm thick.</li>
<li>Coated on the inside of glass tube.</li>
<li>The input fluorescent phosphor → Cesium iodide (Csi).
→ deposited on a thin aluminum substrate by a process called "vapor deposition" → tiny needles perpendicular to substrate surface.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-46a63acc.jpeg" alt="img-102.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Phosphor absorbs about  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span>  of the X-ray energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  converted into light.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-cb316047.jpeg" alt="img-103.jpeg">
INPUT PHOSPHOR
and
PHOTOCATHODE</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-e0959004.jpeg" alt="img-104.jpeg">
OUTPUT PHOSPHOR
A
B</p>
<ul>
<li>Image quality is better with CsI screens than ZnCdS due to:</li>
</ul>
<p>1- Vertical orientation of the crystals:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span>  lateral light diffusion  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span>  blurring &amp;  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  resolution
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↑</span></span></span></span></span>  screen efficiency  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span>  patient dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The resolution of a CsI image intensifier = 1 line pairs per millimeter (3 - 5).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Greater packing density:</p>
<ul>
<li>Since cesium iodide can be vacuum-deposited "requires no inert binder"  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  ↑ packing density.</li>
<li>The packing density of cesium iodide is three times greater than that of zinc-cadmium sulfide  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Phosphor thicknesses have been reduced comparably from approximately  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.3</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.3\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  with ZnCd sulfide to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  with CsI.</li>
</ul>
<p>3- A more favorable effective atomic number.</p>
<ul>
<li>The more appropriate atomic numbers of cesium and iodine give these screens a substantial advantage over those made of zinc-cadmium sulfide.</li>
<li>Ideally, for maximum photoelectric absorption, the K-absorption edge of a phosphor should be as close to the energy of the x-ray beam as possible, provided the energy of the edge does not exceed that of the beam.</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The absorption edges of Cesium (at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>36</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">36\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">36</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) &amp; Iodine (at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>33</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">33\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">33</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) are favorably placed in relation to the effective energy of the X-ray</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b0e8e048.jpeg" alt="img-105.jpeg">
Fig. 4.2 Mass attenuation coefficient of cesium iodide (CsI) and zinc-cadmium sulfide (ZnCdS) versus photon energy with the X-ray spectrum superimposed  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  shows that the greater part of the spectrum of X-rays leaving the patient lies on the high absorption side of the absorption edge of cesium iodide.</p>
<p>Cesium iodide input screens absorb approximately 2/3 of the incident beam as opposed to less than 1/3 for zinc-cadmium sulfide, even though the cesium iodide screen is only one third as thick.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="photocathode">Photocathode<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#photocathode" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>Photoemissive metal</strong> "Cesium-Antimony photoelectric screen".</li>
<li>It is coated directly over the phosphor screen → so, the light from the CsI input phosphor passes directly &amp; strike the photocathode → emit <strong>Photoelectrons</strong> in numbers proportional to the brightness of the screen.</li>
<li><strong>MCQ</strong>: the max. fluoroscopic tube current is mainly limited by <strong>Patient Dose</strong></li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="n-b">N.B.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Older tubes had a <strong>thin light transparent barrier</strong> between the input phosphor and the photocathode. Light diffusion in this barrier reduced resolution.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrostatic-focusing-lens">Electrostatic Focusing Lens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrostatic-focusing-lens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The lens is a series of +ve cylindrical electrodes "usually plated onto the inside surface of the glass envelope".</li>
<li>These electrodes focus the electron beam as it flows from the photocathode toward the output phosphor "so called <strong>electron lens</strong>".</li>
<li>Each point on the input phosphor is focused to a specific point on the opposite side of the output phosphor.</li>
<li>The image on the output phosphor is:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>Inverted and reversed</strong> due to electron focusing by <strong>point inversion</strong> "all electrons pass through a common focal point on their way to the output phosphor" (Fig. 12-3)</li>
<li><strong>Reduced in size</strong>, which is one of the principal reasons why it is brighter.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>For undistorted focusing, <strong>all photoelectrons must travel the same distance</strong> → so, <strong>input phosphor is curved</strong> to ensure that electrons emitted at the peripheral regions of the photocathode travel the same distance as those emitted from the central region.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="accelerating-anode">Accelerating Anode<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accelerating-anode" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Located in the neck of the image tube (Fig. 12-3).</li>
<li>Has a <strong>positive potential of 25 to 35 kV</strong> relative to the photocathode</li>
<li>Accelerate electrons emitted from the photocathode to a tremendous velocity toward the output screen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="output-phosphor-screen">Output Phosphor Screen:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#output-phosphor-screen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Typically <strong>25 mm in diameter</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The output fluorescent screen of image intensifiers is <strong>silver-activated zinc-cadmium sulfide</strong>, the same material used in first-generation input phosphors</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Output phosphor converts the electron pattern back into one of light.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Crystal size and layer thickness are reduced</strong> "since it absorb electrons, not X-rays, need only be a few micrometers thick" → maintain resolution in the minified image.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The number of light photons from output screen is increased approximately 50-fold than light produced at the input screen due greatly accelerated electrons.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>4</p>
<p>The phosphor is covered with Thin Aluminum Film, through which the accelerated electrons penetrate to fall on the phosphor screen.</p>
<p>BUT, prevents light from the output phosphor to travel backward to the input photoelectric screen and cause further emission of electrons &amp; ultimately of light. Otherwise, reduce the image contrast.</p>
<p>The metal housing provides some shielding against external magnetic fields as well as X-ray protection (protection against X-ray that might penetrate the glass envelop into the detector tube, causing false signals).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-summary">In summary:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A uniform x-ray beam passes through and attenuated by the patient  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  passes through the glass front of the image intensifier tube &amp; enters the image intensifier tube  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  The input fluorescent screen absorbs x-ray photons  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  converts their energy into light photons in proportion to the intensity of incident x-ray beam  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  strike the photocathode  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  emit photoelectrons  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  immediately accelerated away from the photocathode by the high potential difference between it and the accelerating anode  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  as the electrons flow from the cathode toward the anode, they are focused by an electrostatic lens  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  guides them to the output fluorescent screen without distorting their geometric configuration  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  electrons strike the output screen  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  emits the light photons that carry the fluoroscopic image to the eye of the observer.</li>
<li>In the intensifier tube, the image is carried first by x-ray photons, then by light photons, next by electrons, and finally by light photons.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-f6238972.jpeg" alt="img-106.jpeg">
OPERATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The output phosphor image is viewed either directly through a series of lenses and mirrors, or indirectly through closed-circuit television "in modern systems".</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mirror-optical-system-shown-in-figure-12-4">Mirror optical system "shown in Figure 12-4"<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mirror-optical-system-shown-in-figure-12-4" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disadv">Disadv.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Light travels a long distance.</p>
<ul>
<li>Small viewing angle  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  difficult to palpate patient.</li>
<li>One observer can view the image  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  a serious disadvantage in training.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ff8b1290.jpeg" alt="img-107.jpeg"></p>
<p>6</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="recording-image">RECORDING IMAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recording-image" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>On <strong>photospot</strong> or <strong>cine film</strong>.</li>
<li>From <strong>the TV camera signal</strong> "image degraded by the television chain" or by <strong>directly exposing the film to the output phosphor</strong> "better".</li>
<li><strong>Beam Splitter</strong> allows continuous TV viewing while exposing the film → by splitting the light from the II output into two paths at the time of film exposure using a <strong>36" semitransparent "partially silvered" mirror</strong> positioned in the light beam:</li>
<li>90% of light is reflected to the film camera.</li>
<li>10% pass through the mirror to TV camera "still produce a satisfactory TV image since the exposure level has been increased"</li>
<li>the image may be coupled to the TV camera by a <strong>fiberoptic bundle</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a529d1b2.jpeg" alt="img-108.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gain">Gain:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The image is <strong>intensified, minified &amp; inverted</strong> by the electron lens.</li>
<li>For <strong>each X-ray photon</strong> absorbed by the input phosphor → about <strong>400 light photons</strong> are emitted → producing <strong>400 photoelectrons</strong> → which cause the output phosphor to emit nearly <strong>400000 light photons</strong>.</li>
<li>Intensification can be measured in two ways:</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Brightness gain</th><th>Conversion factor</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Equals the ratio</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>brightness of the output phosphor</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>brightness of the input phosphor</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Also called intensification factor.</td><td>is a ratio of the luminance of the output phosphor to the input exposure rate</td></tr><tr><td>Equals the ratio</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>brightness of the output phosphor (candela/m2)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>dose rate in air on the input surface of the intensifier (μGy/s)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>not directly measurable</td><td>Measured with a photometer and a dosemeter employing a flat circular ionization chamber, respectively</td></tr><tr><td>The overall brightness gain is typically 5000-10000</td><td>Typical figures are in the range 15-25, but it decreases with age and use.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>The brightness gain of an image intensifier comes from two completely unrelated sources, called "<strong>minification gain</strong>" and "<strong>flux gain</strong>".</li>
</ul>
<p>7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="minification-gain">Minification Gain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#minification-gain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Produced by a reduction in image size.</li>
<li>The quantity of the gain depends on the relative areas of the input and output screens.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Minification&nbsp;gain</mtext><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Minification gain} = \left(\frac{d_1}{d_0}\right)^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Minification&nbsp;gain</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.604em; vertical-align: -0.95em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size3">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.836em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size3">)</span></span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.654em;"><span style="top: -3.9029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>where <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>l</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d_l</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.01968em;">l</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the diameter of input screen, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>d</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d_0</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8444em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em;
