margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is the diameter of output screen</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="minification-gain-increase-overall-gain-by-about-100-times">Minification gain increase overall gain by about 100 times<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#minification-gain-increase-overall-gain-by-about-100-times" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>With a 1-in. output screen, the minification gain is simply the square of the diameter of the input screen; that is, a 9-in. intensifier has a gain of 81.</li>
<li>The brightness gain from minification does not improve the statistical quality of the fluoroscopic image as the same number of light photons make up the image regardless of the size of the output screen.</li>
<li>Theoretically, brightness can be increased indefinitely by minification, but also the picture becomes more grainy → due to magnification of the fluoroscopic crystals in the output screen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="flux-gain">Flux Gain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#flux-gain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the increase in the number of light photons due to acceleration of electrons.</li>
<li>It increases the brightness by a factor of approximately 50-100.</li>
<li>For each light photon from the input screen, as ejecting one electron from the photocathode. The electron is accelerated to the opposite end of the tube, gaining enough energy to produce 50 light photons at the output screen.</li>
</ul>
<p>The total brightness gain of an image intensifier is the product of the minification and flux gains:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Brightness&nbsp;gain</mtext><mo>=</mo><mtext>minification&nbsp;gain</mtext><mo>×</mo><mtext>flux&nbsp;gain</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Brightness gain} = \text{minification gain} \times \text{flux gain}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Brightness&nbsp;gain</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">minification&nbsp;gain</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">flux&nbsp;gain</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dual-and-triple-field-intensifiers-zooming">Dual- And Triple-field Intensifiers (Zooming)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dual-and-triple-field-intensifiers-zooming" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Image quality increase as the size of the input field is decreased.</li>
<li>Dual-field or triple-field image intensifiers can be operated in several modes, including a 4.5-in., a 6-in., or 9-in. mode "or even larger image intensifiers (12- to 16-in.)" → resolve the conflicts between image size and quality</li>
<li>The 9-in. mode is used when it is necessary to view large anatomic areas.</li>
<li>When size is unimportant, the 4.5- or 6-in. mode is used "better image quality".</li>
<li>Field size is changed by applying a simple electronic principle: the higher the voltage on the electrostatic focusing lens, the more the electron beam is focused; In figure 12-7</li>
<li>In the 9-in. mode, the electrostatic focusing voltage is decreased → the electrons crossover point move close to the output phosphor → smaller final image.</li>
<li>In the 6-in. mode, the electrostatic focusing voltage is increased → the electrons focus farther away from the output phosphor →</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-cfadc712.jpeg" alt="img-109.jpeg"></p>
<p>diverge to form larger image on the output phosphor than in the 9-in. mode.</p>
<p>The central part of the input image (6-in in diameter) then fills the whole of the output phosphor.</p>
<ul>
<li>Effect of Zooming (adv. &amp; Disadv.)</li>
<li>Magnifies the image.</li>
<li>Improves the sharpness "resolution"</li>
<li>But, makes the image less bright "less minification gain" → exposure factors are automatically increased to compensate for the decreased brightness → increases the patient's skin dose (↑ scatter).</li>
</ul>
<p>BUT the X-ray beam is automatically recollimated → ↓↓ volume of irradiated tissue → ↓↓ scatter &amp; improve contrast</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viewing-and-recording-the-fluoroscopic-image">Viewing and Recording the Fluoroscopic Image<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viewing-and-recording-the-fluoroscopic-image" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The development of the image intensifies allowed displaying the fluoroscopic image on television.</li>
<li>Its small output phosphor simplifies optical coupling,</li>
<li>Its bright image produces a strong video signal.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="closed-circuit-television">CLOSED-CIRCUIT TELEVISION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#closed-circuit-television" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Components of a TV system are a camera, camera control unit, and monitor.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-6686ea8a.jpeg" alt="img-110.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Fluoroscopic television systems are always closed-circuit systems; "i.e. the video signal is transmitted from one component to the next through cables rather than through the air, as in broadcast television".</li>
<li>A lens system or a fiberoptic system conveys the fluoroscopic image from the output phosphor of II to the video camera → image is converted into a series of electrical pulses called the video signal → transmitted through a cable to the camera control unit → amplified → forwarded through another cable to the television monitor → converts the video signal back into the original image for direct viewing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nature-of-the-video-picture">Nature of the video picture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nature-of-the-video-picture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The television image is made up of a mosaic of hundreds of thousands of tiny dots of different brightness → each contributing a minute bit to the total picture.</p>
<ul>
<li>The individual dots are clearly visible at close range &amp; with magnification.</li>
<li>The lines are close together in a small picture tube and spread apart in a large tube, but in both</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a97cd9bd.jpeg" alt="img-111.jpeg"></p>
<p>the total number is the same.</p>
<p>9</p>
<ul>
<li>The dots are arranged in a specific pattern along horizontal lines, called horizontal scan lines.</li>
<li>The number of lines varies from one television system to another but, in the United States, most fluoroscopy and all commercial television systems use 525 scan lines. The UK TV systems uses 625 scan lines</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="television-camera">Television Camera<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#television-camera" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The vidicon camera is the one usually employed for fluoroscopy "relatively inexpensive, compact unit"</li>
<li>There are several types of vidicons; one is the plumbicon.</li>
<li>The essential parts of a vidicon camera are shown in Figure 13-3.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-06b5e5ef.jpeg" alt="img-112.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The most important part is the vidicon tube, a small electronic vacuum tube that measures only 1 in. (25 mm) in diameter and 6 in. in length.</li>
<li>The tube is surrounded by coils: An electromagnetic focusing coil and 2 pairs of electrostatic deflecting coils</li>
<li>The fluoroscopic image from the image intensifier is focused onto the target assembly, which consists of three layers:</li>
</ul>
<p>(1) Glass face plate;</p>
<p>(2) Signal plate;</p>
<p>(3) Target.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-glass-face-plate">The glass face plate:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-glass-face-plate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It's only function is to maintain the vacuum in the tube.</li>
<li>Light merely passes through the face plate on its way to the target.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-signal-plate">The signal plate:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-signal-plate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A thin transparent film of graphite located on the inner surface of glass face plate.</li>
<li>It is an electrical conductor with a positive potential of approximately 25 V.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-vidicon-target">The vidicon target:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-vidicon-target" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is functionally the most important element in the tube.</li>
<li>It is a thin film of photoconductive material, usually antimony sulfide <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{Sb}_{2}\mathrm{S}_{3})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Sb</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">S</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> suspended as globules in a mica matrix.
In a plumbicon the photoconductive material is lead monoxide (PbO),</li>
<li>Each globule is about 0.001 in. in diameter and is insulated from its neighbors and from the signal plate by the mica matrix.</li>
<li>The globules behave like tiny capacitors, which converts the light</li>
</ul>
<p>10</p>
<p>pattern focused on it into pattern of electrical resistance (see later).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-cathode">The cathode<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cathode" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Located at the opposite end of the vidicon tube from the target.</li>
<li>Heated indirectly by an <strong>internal electric coil</strong>.</li>
<li>The heating coil boils electrons from the cathode (thermionic emission), creating an electron cloud.</li>
<li>These electrons are immediately formed into a beam by <strong>The Control Grid</strong>, which also initiates their acceleration toward the target.</li>
<li>The <strong>cathode-heating coil assembly</strong> with <strong>the control grid</strong> are called <strong>"electron gun"</strong> because it shoots electrons out of the end of the control grid.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-anode">The anode<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-anode" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The electron beam progresses down the tube → moves beyond the influence of the control grid into the electrostatic field of the anode.</li>
<li>The anode has a positive potential of <strong>approximately 250 V</strong> relative to the cathode.</li>
<li>The anode extends across the target end of the tube as <strong>a fine wire mesh</strong>.</li>
<li>The wire mesh and signal plate form a <strong>uniform decelerating field</strong> adjacent to the target.</li>
</ul>
<p>The signal plate (+ 25 V) has a potential of 225 V less than that of the wire mesh (+ 250 V), so electrons should flow from the signal plate to the wire mesh.</p>
<ul>
<li>The electrons from the cathode are accelerated to <strong>high velocity</strong>, but they are still <strong>low energy electrons</strong> (about 250 eV).</li>
<li>Then they coast through the decelerating field → by the time they reach the target, they have been slowed to <strong>near standstill</strong> (they are now 25-eV electrons).</li>
<li>The decelerating field also performs a second function: <strong>it straightens the final path of the electron beam</strong> → so it strikes the target perpendicularly.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electromagnetic-focusing-coil">Electromagnetic Focusing Coil<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electromagnetic-focusing-coil" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Wraps around almost the entire length of the vidicon tube → creates a constant magnetic field parallel to the long axis of the tube → keeps electron beam in a narrow bundle essential to scans the fine mosaic of photoconductive globules.</li>
<li>The electrons progress down the tube in a series of oscillating spirals.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9cd525d4.jpeg" alt="img-113.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-2cd89242.jpeg" alt="img-114.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrostatic-deflecting-coils">Electrostatic deflecting coils<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrostatic-deflecting-coils" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The electron beam is steered by variable electrostatic fields produced by two pairs of deflecting coils that wrap around the vidicon tube. "<strong>Time-varying voltages from a 'sweep generator'"</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Vertical deflecting coils are shown in Figure 13-4B.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By alternating the voltage on the coils, the focused electron beam is moved up and down to scan the target.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The other pair of coils moves the beam from side to side along a horizontal line.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All four coils, working together, move the electron beam over the target in a repetitive scanning motion.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="video-signal">Video Signal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#video-signal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>When a globule absorbs light, photoelectrons are emitted (Fig. 13-5B).</li>
<li>The electrons are immediately attracted to the anode and removed from the tube.</li>
<li>The globule, having lost electrons, becomes positively charged.</li>
<li>Since the globule is insulated from its surroundings it behaves like half of a tiny capacitor, and draws a current onto the conductive signal plate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  this current that flows onto the signal plate is ignored, or clipped, and is not recorded (Fig. 13-5C).</li>
<li>Similar events occur over the entire surface of the target.</li>
<li>A brighter area in the light image emits more photoelectrons than a dim area, and produces a stronger charge on the tiny capacitors.</li>
<li>The result is a mosaic of charged globules that store an electrical image that is an exact replica of the light image focused onto the target.</li>
<li>The electron beam scans the electrical image stored on the target and fills in the holes left by the emitted photoelectrons (i.e. discharging the tiny globule capacitors).</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-80c9ca10.jpeg" alt="img-115.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>After the capacitors are fully discharged (no more positive charges are left), no additional electrons can be deposited in the globules.</li>
<li>Excess electrons from the scanning beam drift back to the anode and are removed from the tube.</li>
<li>When the electrons in the scan beam neutralize the positive charge in the globules, the electrons on the signal plate (Fig. 13-5D) no longer have an electrostatic force to hold them on the plate. They will leave the plate via the resistor.</li>
<li>These moving electrons form a current flowing through a resistor  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  a voltage appears across the resistor which constitutes the video signal (Fig. 13-5E).
It was indicated earlier that the electrons in the electron beam were reduced to low energy electrons before they entered the target. There are two reasons for this.</li>
<li>The first Reason is that we want no electrons to enter the target after the positive</li>
</ul>
<p>charge has been neutralized.</p>
<ul>
<li>The second reason is that the electrons should not have sufficient energy to produce secondary electrons when they do enter the globules. "high energy secondary electrons would be able to neutralize the positive charge in other globules and degrade the image".</li>
</ul>
<p>The globules are not all discharged at the same time.</p>
<ul>
<li>Only a small cluster, a dot, is discharged each instant in time. Then the electron beam moves on to the next dot in an orderly sequence, discharging all the globules on the target.</li>
<li>The result is a series of video pulses, all originating from the same signal plate but separated in time.
Each pulse corresponds to an exact location on the target.</li>
<li>Reassembling these pulses back into a visible image is done by the camera control unit and the television monitor.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="television-monitor">Television Monitor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#television-monitor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The last link in the television chain is the monitor.</li>
</ul>
<p>It contains the picture tube and the controls for regulating brightness and contrast.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-deb296b8.jpeg" alt="img-116.jpeg">
Figure 13-6 Television monitor</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A picture tube is similar to a vidicon camera tube (Fig. 13-6).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Both are vacuum tubes and both contain an electron gun, control grid, anode, focusing coil, and deflecting coils.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A picture tube, however, is much larger.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This evacuated glass envelope contains:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>at the narrow end, an electron gun (c), which projects a pencil of electrons, shown as a dashed line in the figure,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A phosphor screen (e) coated on the inside of the wide end of the envelope, where the pencil produces a small dot of light.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The focusing and deflecting coils are wrapped around the neck of the tube, and they control the electron beam in exact synchrony with the camera tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brightness of the individual dots in the picture is regulated by the control grid  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  modulate the brightness of spot of light on the monitor screen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The control grid receives the video signal from the camera control unit, and uses</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>this signal to regulate the number of electrons in the electron beam.</p>
<ul>
<li>To produce a bright area in the television picture, the grid allows a large number of electrons to reach the fluorescent screen. To produce a dark area, the grid cuts off the electron flow almost completely.</li>
<li>The anode is plated onto the inside surface of the picture tube near the fluorescent screen. It carries a much higher positive potential (10,000 V) than the anode of the camera tube (250 V), so it accelerates the electron beam to a much higher velocity.</li>
<li>The electrons strike the fluorescent screen at the flared end of the tube, which makes the screen emit a large number of light photons. The generation of light photons over the entire surface of the tube is the visible television image.</li>
<li>Many secondary electrons are set free by the impact of the electron beam with the screen, and they are attracted to the anode and conducted out of the picture tube.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="television-scanning">TELEVISION SCANNING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#television-scanning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The television image is stored as an electrical image on the target of the vidicon tube, and it is scanned along 525 lines by a narrow electron beam 30 times per second.</li>
<li>Each scan of the entire target is called a "frame".</li>
<li>The electron beam scans the target in much the same manner that we read a page in a book, only it does not have to turn pages. Instead, as the beam reads, it also erases. As the electron beam discharges the globule capacitors, it erases their image.</li>
<li>As soon as a line is read and erased, it is ready to record a new image, and it begins immediately.</li>
<li>Because the electron beam scans the target 30 times each second → our eyes perceive a continuous motion as in a cine film.</li>
<li>But, the eye can detect individual flashes of light, or flicker, up to 50 pulses per second. A television monitor only displays 30 frames per second, so an electronic trick, called interlaced horizontal scanning, is employed to avoid flicker.</li>
<li>Instead of scanning all 525 lines consequently, only the even-numbered lines are scanned in the first half of the frame, and only the odd-numbered lines are scanned during the second half (Fig. 13-7).</li>
<li>Each pass of the electron beam over the video target is called a field, and consists of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>262</mn><mn>1</mn></msup><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">262^{1}/_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">26</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">/</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> lines.</li>
</ul>
<p>∴ Although only 30 frames are displayed each second, they are displayed in 60 flashes of light (fields), and flicker disappears.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-838f6de8.jpeg" alt="img-117.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 13-7 Interlaced horizontal scanning</p>
<p>Synchronization</p>
<ul>
<li>It is necessary to synchronize the video signal between the camera and monitor to keep them in phase with each other.</li>
<li>The camera control unit adds synchronization pulses to the video signal at the end of each scan line &amp; scan field "horizontal and vertical synchronization pulses".</li>
<li>They are generated during the retrace time of the electron beam, while no video signal is being transmitted.</li>
<li>First, the picture screen is blackened by a blanking pulse, and the synchronization signal is added to the blanking pulse.</li>
<li>If the synchronization pulses were added to the video signal while the screen was white → white streaks of noise.</li>
</ul>
<p>15</p>
<p>TELEVISION IMAGE QUALITY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-resolution">I- RESOLUTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Spatial resolution is the ability to detect a single small structure against its background or to distinguish two separate structures close together.</li>
<li>It is tested by imaging a bar 'test tool' or 'resolution grid' (Fig. 4.5a).</li>
<li>The bars are strips of lead affixed to a Perspex plate.</li>
<li>The bars are equally spaced &amp; each space = the width of a bar.</li>
<li>A bar and a space together make up a line pair.</li>
<li>The spatial frequency = the number of such line pairs per millimeter (lp\mm).</li>
<li>Figure 4.5a also plots the brightness of the screen image (or the video signal) along a scan line.</li>
<li>The higher the spatial frequency → ↑ blurring &amp; ↓ contrast.
∴ if the blurring is too large or the bars too narrow and too close together → the blur of the edges of each bar merges with that of the adjacent one → the gap between them cannot be distinguished.</li>
<li>The effect of blurring is to worsen resolution</li>
</ul>
<p>So, the smaller the blurring → the better the resolution.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-5e00dcc4.jpeg" alt="img-118.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-d6672a42.jpeg" alt="img-119.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-23d729de.jpeg" alt="img-120.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The spatial resolution of the system is defined as the spatial frequency of the finest pattern that can still be resolved.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="video-signal-frequency-bandpass">Video Signal Frequency (Bandpass)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#video-signal-frequency-bandpass" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Bandpass "bandwidth", is the frequency range that the electronic components of the video system must be designed to transmit without distortion.</li>
<li>The frequency of the video signal fluctuate from moment to moment, depending on the nature of the television image "that's why we need to set range for frequencies"</li>
</ul>
<p>16</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ec22a06a.jpeg" alt="img-121.jpeg">
Figure 13-9 The video signal from one scan line of a line pair phantom</p>
<ul>
<li>Figure 13-9 shows one scan line of an image containing 4 line pairs  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>4</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(4\mathrm{lp})\rightarrow \mathrm{So}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">lp</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">So</span></span></span></span></span></span> , video signal for this scan line consists of 4 cycles.</li>
<li>We can calculate the frequency "number of cycles per second" of the video signal generated by the four-line-pair image by multiplying the number of cycles per scan line (four in this case) by the number of scan lines per frame by the number of frames per second:</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mtable rowspacing="0.16em" columnalign="left" columnspacing="1em"><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mfrac><mtext>c&nbsp;y&nbsp;c&nbsp;l&nbsp;e&nbsp;s</mtext><mtext>s&nbsp;c&nbsp;a&nbsp;n&nbsp;l&nbsp;i&nbsp;n&nbsp;e</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mtext>s&nbsp;c&nbsp;a&nbsp;n&nbsp;l&nbsp;i&nbsp;n&nbsp;e&nbsp;s</mtext><mtext>F&nbsp;r&nbsp;a&nbsp;m&nbsp;e</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mtext>f&nbsp;r&nbsp;a&nbsp;m&nbsp;e&nbsp;s</mtext><mtext>s&nbsp;e&nbsp;c&nbsp;o&nbsp;n&nbsp;d&nbsp;s</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mtext>c&nbsp;y&nbsp;c&nbsp;l&nbsp;e&nbsp;s&nbsp;/&nbsp;s&nbsp;e&nbsp;c</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mstyle scriptlevel="0" displaystyle="false"><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>525</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>63</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>000</mn></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\begin{array}{l} \frac {\text {c y c l e s}}{\text {s c a n l i n e}} \times \frac {\text {s c a n l i n e s}}{\text {F r a m e}} \times \frac {\text {f r a m e s}}{\text {s e c o n d s}} = \text {c y c l e s / s e c} \\ 4 \times 5 2 5 \times 3 0 = 6 3, 0 0 0 \\ \end{array}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.4922em; vertical-align: -0.9961em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mtable"><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span><span class="col-align-l"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.4961em;"><span style="top: -3.5639em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9322em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">s&nbsp;c&nbsp;a&nbsp;n&nbsp;l&nbsp;i&nbsp;n&nbsp;e</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.4461em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">c&nbsp;y&nbsp;c&nbsp;l&nbsp;e&nbsp;s</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">F&nbsp;r&nbsp;a&nbsp;m&nbsp;e</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">s&nbsp;c&nbsp;a&nbsp;n&nbsp;l&nbsp;i&nbsp;n&nbsp;e&nbsp;s</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8801em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">s&nbsp;e&nbsp;c&nbsp;o&nbsp;n&nbsp;d&nbsp;s</span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">f&nbsp;r&nbsp;a&nbsp;m&nbsp;e&nbsp;s</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">c&nbsp;y&nbsp;c&nbsp;l&nbsp;e&nbsp;s&nbsp;/&nbsp;s&nbsp;e&nbsp;c</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -2.3639em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">525</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">63</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">000</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9961em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="arraycolsep" style="width: 0.5em;"></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>When the number of line pairs in the image changes, the frequency of the video signal also changes.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="resolution-of-the-tv-system">Resolution of the TV system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#resolution-of-the-tv-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The TV system degrades the resolution further due to:</p>
<p>" Mosaic structure of the TV camera image plate.
The two aspects of the way in which the image is scanned:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-line-structure">1- Line structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-line-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-bandwidth">2- Bandwidth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-bandwidth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vertical-resolution-depending-on-the-line-structure">VERTICAL RESOLUTION (depending on the line structure)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vertical-resolution-depending-on-the-line-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>VERTICAL RESOLUTION is determined by the number of vertical scan lines (525 in our illustration)  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the test pattern positioned with the bars horizontal.</li>
<li>For a 525-vertical-line system, the maximum line-pair structure that can be resolved on the TV monitor is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>262</mn><mn>1</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">262^{1}/2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">26</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/2</span></span></span></span></span>  line pairs per TV monitor image.</li>
<li>Factors affecting vertical resolution:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The smaller fields, in magnification mode  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  resolution.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  monitor size with fixed number of horizontal scan line  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span>  resolution</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo><mn>525</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore 525</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">525</span></span></span></span></span> -line system displayed on a 6-in. monitor has better resolution than a 13- or 19-in. monitor. So, the image on a small TV screen will look better than that on a large screen.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  Scan lines  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↑</span></span></span></span></span>  vertical resolution.</li>
</ol>
<p>18</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="horizontal-resolution-depending-on-the-bandpass">HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION (depending on the bandpass)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#horizontal-resolution-depending-on-the-bandpass" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>HORIZONTAL RESOLUTION depends on the bandwidth of the TV monitor electronics → to test it; the test pattern is turned with the bars vertical.</li>
<li>For a 525-line system, lowest and highest frequency signals will be as follows:</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mtext>cycles</mtext><mtext>scan&nbsp;line</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mtext>scan&nbsp;lines</mtext><mtext>frame</mtext></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mfrac><mtext>frames</mtext><mtext>second</mtext></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mtext>cycles/sec</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{\text{cycles}}{\text{scan line}} \times \frac{\text{scan lines}}{\text{frame}} \times \frac{\text{frames}}{\text{second}} = \text{cycles/sec}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">scan&nbsp;line</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">cycles</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">frame</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">scan&nbsp;lines</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0574em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">second</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">frames</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">cycles/sec</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Minimum:
1 × 525 × 30 = 15,750</p>
<p>Maximum:
262¼ × 525 × 30 = 4,130,000</p>
<p>∴ The frequency of the video signal will fluctuate between a minimum of 15,750 Hz and a maximum of 4,130,000 Hz (i.e. bandpass = 4.1 MHz).</p>
<ul>
<li>Actually, a somewhat <strong>higher</strong> bandpass is required, because about 10% of the scan time is lost in retracing from one line to another.</li>
<li>This additional 10% increases the required bandpass to approximately 4.5 MHz for a 525-line system.</li>
<li>At this bandpass, vertical and horizontal resolutions are equal.</li>
</ul>
<p>Remember,</p>
<p>☑ Vertical resolution depends on the number of vertical lines (such as 525), whereas horizontal resolution is determined by the bandpass.</p>
<ul>
<li>Most X-ray TV systems have a bandpass of 5 MHz with a 525-line system. Interlacing is not entirely satisfactory; resolution may be impaired if tissues move between the two halves of a 1/25 s frame.</li>
<li>A high-resolution image intensifier (II) TV system employs 1250 lines, <strong>non-interlaced</strong> ('progressive') scan, can resolve 2 lp/mm, but requires a bandwidth of at least 25 MHz.</li>
<li>Digital photospot imaging produces high resolution with the normal bandwidth.</li>
<li>In film-screen radiography, the film can resolve 100 lp/mm whereas a slow ('detail') intensifying screen can only resolve 10 lp/mm, and a fast screen 5 lp/mm.</li>
</ul>
<p>Resolution of different imaging modalities:</p>
<ol>
<li>Radiographic film ALONE 100 lp/mm. (but needs very high dose)</li>
<li>Film-screen with Slow screens 10 lp/mm.</li>
<li>Film-screen with Fast screens 5 lp/mm</li>
<li>Image intensifier 4-5 lp/mm</li>
<li>TV system 1 lp/mm</li>
<li>High resolution non interlaced TV system (II-TV system) 2 lp/mm</li>
<li>Photo spot cut film 100mm 4-5 lp/mm</li>
<li>Photo spot cut film 35mm 2 lp/mm</li>
<li>CT 1 lp/mm</li>
<li>Gamma camera 1-2 lp/cm Very poor resolution!!!</li>
<li>Mammography 10-20 lp/mm (or 5-20)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>We assumed that a 525-line TV system actually uses all 525 lines to form an image → absolute maximum resolution (but, we never attain maximum values).</li>
<li>In fact, significantly fewer than 525 lines are available for image formation → some lines are lost to prevent the retrace and blanking signals from showing on the TV screen.</li>
<li>Resolution of 370 lines (185 line pairs) is typical in a 525-line system. N.B. 200 line pairs are typical in the UK 625-lines TV system</li>
<li>The overall resolution of the imaging system depends on the size of the input image.</li>
</ul>
<p>↑↑ size of II input image → ↓↓ resolution.</p>
<p>Table 13-1 Resolution of a TV Imaging System for Various-Sized Image Intensifiers</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>SIZE OF IMAGE INTENSIFIER</th><th></th><th>TELEVISION RESOLUTION (lp/mm)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>in.</td><td>mm</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4.5</td><td>114</td><td>1.6</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td>152</td><td>1.2</td></tr><tr><td>9</td><td>229</td><td>0.8</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>'Based on a 525-line TV system with a total resolution of 185 lp.</p>
<ul>
<li>Even though a resolution of 1.6 lp/mm is a considerable improvement, it falls far short of displaying the entire resolution of cesium iodide image intensifiers.
→ The only way that this resolution can be adequately displayed is with a film system such as a 35 mm cine, or spot film cameras.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="resolution-of-the-image-intensifier">Resolution of the image intensifier<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#resolution-of-the-image-intensifier" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The image intensifier itself has a spatial resolution of about 4-5 lp/mm (or better in the magnification mode).</li>
<li>It is principally affected by</li>
<li>The blurring caused by light spread in the input phosphor.</li>
<li>Less significantly in the much thinner output phosphor.</li>
<li>Due to defects in the electron lens, the periphery of the image has</li>
<li>Worse resolution than the center.</li>
<li>Greater magnification → 'pincushion' distortion.</li>
<li>The resolution is always stated in relation to the size of the X-ray image on the face of the intensifier.</li>
<li>Resolution with 100 mm cut film is nearly as good as that of intensifier itself. but, resolution on 35 mm film is only about half that of intensifier.</li>
</ul>
<p>19</p>
<p>20</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contrast">CONTRAST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contrast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contrast-of-image-intensifier">CONTRAST OF IMAGE INTENSIFIER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contrast-of-image-intensifier" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Tested using a lead disc (¹/₄-in. thickness &amp; its diameter = 10% of the input screen)</li>
<li>The disc is placed over the center of the input screen → exposed to radiation → brightness is measured at the output phosphor.</li>
<li>Contrast is the brightness ratio of the periphery to the brightness in the center of the output screen "representing area under lead disc".</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Contrast ratios range from 20:1 to 30:1</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Two factors tend to diminish contrast in image intensifiers.</li>
</ul>
<p>1- The input screen does not absorb all the photons in the x-ray beam.</p>
<ul>
<li>Some transmitted through the intensifier tube &amp; few absorbed by output screen.</li>
<li>These transmitted photons contribute to the illumination of the output phosphor but not to image formation → produce a background of fog "↓↓ image contrast".</li>
</ul>
<p>2- Retrograde light flow from the output screen.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Not all retrograde light photons blocked by the thin layer of aluminum → some penetrate through it → pass back to activate the photocathode to emits photoelectrons</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>These electrons produce "fog" → ↓↓ image contrast.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contrast tends to deteriorate as an image intensifier ages.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="veiling-glare">Veiling glare<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#veiling-glare" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is due to scattering of light in the output window of the image intensifier, and to a lesser extent in the TV camera tube → ↓ contrast of the image.</li>
<li>It is worse with the larger sizes of intensifier.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contrast-of-tv-camera-monitor">CONTRAST OF TV CAMERA &amp; MONITOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contrast-of-tv-camera-monitor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Both the camera and monitor affect the contrast of a television image.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A vidicon camera → ↓↓ contrast by a factor of approximately 0.8.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>A plumbicon camera → does not cause any decrease in image contrast.</p>
<p>A Vidicon camera has γ = 0.8 while a Plumbicon tube has γ = 1.0.</p>
<p>Remember: ↑ γ → ↑ contrast</p>
<ul>
<li>The monitor enhances contrast by a factor of 2.</li>
<li>The net result is a definite improvement in contrast &gt; the image intensifier alone.</li>
<li>Furthermore, both brightness &amp; contrast levels can be regulated with the monitor → the optimum combination can be selected to best show a point of interest.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dynamic-range-latitude-of-the-television-monitor">Dynamic range (latitude) of the television monitor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dynamic-range-latitude-of-the-television-monitor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the ratio</p>
<p>maximum acceptable brightness of the TV monitor screen smallest detectable brightness above black</p>
<p>Typically = 1000:1, which is usually expressed as 30 dB, as explained in Section 7.16. The choice of kV and the TV contrast are made so that the range of tissues being imaged fall within the dynamic range.</p>
<p>LAG</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lag-of-image-intensifiers">Lag of image intensifiers:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lag-of-image-intensifiers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>= persistence of luminescence after x-ray stimulation has been terminated.</li>
<li>With old image tubes → lag times were 30 to 40 ms.
With CsI tubes → lag times are about 1 ms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lag-of-tv-camera-monitor">Lag of TV camera &amp; monitor:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lag-of-tv-camera-monitor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An undesirable property of most vidicon tubes is lag or stickiness.</li>
<li>Lag becomes apparent when the camera is moved rapidly during fluoroscopy (i.e., the image blurs).</li>
<li>Lag occurs because it takes a certain amount of time for the image to build up and decay on the vidicon target.</li>
<li>Plumbicon tubes demonstrate significantly less lag than vidicon tubes.</li>
<li>The lag of a vidicon is usually not a problem with routine fluoroscopy, but may become a problem in cardiovascular fluoroscopy.</li>
<li>In one respect a certain amount of lag is actually advantageous.</li>
</ul>
<p>It averages out the statistical fluctuations that occur with low-dose fluoroscopy → minimizes quantum mottle.</p>
<p>The image generated by a plumbicon tube will show more quantum mottle than a standard vidicon image الحلو ما يكملش.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="automatic-brightness-control">AUTOMATIC BRIGHTNESS CONTROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automatic-brightness-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Problem: ↑↑ X-ray intensity when moving from a high-attenuation to a low-attenuation area "e.g. from the abdomen to the chest" → sudden increase of brightness → the image becomes chalky, and all detail is lost.</li>
<li>Solution: A 'feedback' system to control the brightness of the TV monitor automatically → used in cineradiography &amp; also in fluoroscopy.</li>
<li>The brightness of the image is monitored either by:
(a) Measuring the (average) video signal or
(b) By a sensor 'watching' the brightness of the output phosphor.</li>
</ul>
<p>Then sending orders back to the X-ray tube &amp; generator to modulate exposure factors (feedback system)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="there-are-three-ways-to-change-the-radiation-input-to-the-ii-input-phosphor">There are three ways to change the radiation input to the II input phosphor:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#there-are-three-ways-to-change-the-radiation-input-to-the-ii-input-phosphor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>kVp variability</li>
<li>mA variability</li>
<li>pulse width variability</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kvp-variability">kVp Variability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kvp-variability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>kVp will vary while mA stays constant.</li>
<li>Advantages:</li>
<li>Fast response times.</li>
<li>Satisfactory images over a wide dynamic range.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ma-variability">mA Variability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ma-variability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The best general purpose automatic brightness control system.</li>
<li>Varies the mA as needed with a convenient kVp control → offers the operator to control of kVp.</li>
<li>Advantages: relatively simple and inexpensive method.</li>
<li>Disadvantages:</li>
</ul>
<p>21</p>
<ul>
<li>Slow response time "changes in mA require change the temperature of the x-ray tube filament".</li>
<li>The dynamic range of this control is less than the kVp-variable units  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  operator must choose appropriate kVp.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="combined-control">Combined Control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#combined-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A number of systems vary both kVp and mA to control brightness  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  wide dynamic range.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-width-variability">Pulse Width Variability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-width-variability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Advantage: very fast response times - very broad dynamic range - allows the operator to choose the mA and kVp levels best suited for the examination.</li>
<li>The length of each exposure is controlled with a grid-controlled x-ray tube or a constant potential generator with secondary switching.</li>
</ul>
