<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="automatic-gain-control">AUTOMATIC GAIN CONTROL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#automatic-gain-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a simple and inexpensive way to control image brightness.</li>
<li>It varies the brightness of the TV system by 1) varying the sensitivity of the TV cameras or 2) varying the gain of the TV amplification system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disadvantages">- Disadvantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It does not change the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span> -ray dose rate to the patient  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  unnecessary patient exposure.</li>
<li>Not improve quantum mottle and will increase electronic noise.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="noise">Noise<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#noise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Quantum mottle is noticeable in fluoroscopy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex-error" title="ParseError: KaTeX parse error: Expected 'EOF', got '&amp;' at position 1: &amp;̲gt;" style="color: rgb(204, 0, 0);">&amp;gt;</span></span>  radiography.</li>
<li>Noise is due to the statistical fluctuations in the number of X-ray photons absorbed in the input phosphor  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  similar fluctuations in the brightness of the image, the density recorded on a spot film and the video signal voltage from the camera tube.</li>
<li>Noise reduces the perceptibility of a structure having low contrast.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-00ff1120.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg">
Fig. 4.6 Resolution tests grids (a), (b) and (c) having different inherent contrasts and the corresponding plots of video signal or image brightness along a scan line, showing the effect of noise on perceptibility.</p>
<ul>
<li>Figure 4.6 depicts part of each of three resolution grids having (a) high, (b) medium, and (c) low contrast, made perhaps with strips of lead, aluminum, and Perspex, respectively.</li>
<li>The bars can easily be resolved in Fig. 4.6a. They can still be resolved in Fig. 4.6b, but they would not be if the noise were greater. In Fig. 4.6c the contrast is</li>
</ul>
<p>completely obscured &amp; the bars can't be distinguished from spaces between them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thus-the-structures-cannot-be-distinguished-if">- Thus the structures cannot be distinguished, if :<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thus-the-structures-cannot-be-distinguished-if" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The noise is too great.
The contrast difference is too small.
The structures are too small, or too close together.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>With a typical average dose rate in air of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 - 2\mu \mathrm{Gy}\mathrm{s}^{-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Gy</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">s</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  on the surface of the image intensifier, during the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/6</span></span></span></span></span>  s time constant (lag) of a Vidicon camera tube, an average of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3000\mathrm{X}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3000</span><span class="mord mathrm">X</span></span></span></span></span> -ray photons might be absorbed in each square millimeter of the input phosphor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>As a result, when trying to see a structure  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  in size, the noise is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msqrt><mn>3000</mn></msqrt></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\sqrt{3000}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.04em; vertical-align: -0.1328em;"></span><span class="mord sqrt"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9072em;"><span class="svg-align" style="top: -3em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord" style="padding-left: 0.833em;"><span class="mord">3000</span></span></span><span style="top: -2.8672em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="min-width: 0.853em; height: 1.08em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="1.08em" viewBox="0 0 400000 1080" preserveAspectRatio="xMinYMin slice"><path d="M95,702
c-2.7,0,-7.17,-2.7,-13.5,-8c-5.8,-5.3,-9.5,-10,-9.5,-14
c0,-2,0.3,-3.3,1,-4c1.3,-2.7,23.83,-20.7,67.5,-54
c44.2,-33.3,65.8,-50.3,66.5,-51c1.3,-1.3,3,-2,5,-2c4.7,0,8.7,3.3,12,10
s173,378,173,378c0.7,0,35.3,-71,104,-213c68.7,-142,137.5,-285,206.5,-429
c69,-144,104.5,-217.7,106.5,-221
l0 -0
c5.3,-9.3,12,-14,20,-14
H400000v40H845.2724
s-225.272,467,-225.272,467s-235,486,-235,486c-2.7,4.7,-9,7,-19,7
c-6,0,-10,-1,-12,-3s-194,-422,-194,-422s-65,47,-65,47z
M834 80h400000v40h-400000z"></path></svg></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1328em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , which is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span>  of the signal.
The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is 50:1.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For a structure to be detectable, the contrast must be at least 2-5 times the noise relative to signal.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>So, a structure  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  in size will be seen against its background provided its contrast is at least  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<ul>
<li>The image of a small structure is produced by the absorption of relatively few photons and is noisy, and to see it requires a high contrast.</li>
</ul>
<p>Either a high dose rate is used to increase the SNR, or the inherent contrast of the object has to be increased, e.g. by changing the kV or using a contrast medium.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-ab7dc8d6.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Fig. 4.7, the solid curve plots on a logarithmic scale the min. contrast needed to see structures of different diameters.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obtained using a special test object (e.g. Leeds TO 10) with 11.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Details having a size and contrast falling in region A can be resolved; those falling in region B cannot.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The dashed line shows the improvement in perceptibility produced by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  dose rate &amp;  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span>  noise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="to-summarize">To summarize:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-summarize" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>the contrast resolution (= smallest detectable contrast) improves with larger details;
the spatial resolution improves with higher contrast;
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span>  the dose rate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓↓</span></span></span></span></span>  noise &amp; improves the inherent detectability of all structures.</p>
<ul>
<li>This relationship (or 'trade-off') between spatial resolution, contrast and noise or dose applies to all forms of imaging (digital, CT, gamma, etc.).</li>
</ul>
<p>In film-screen radiography, noise is too small to affect the details.</p>
<ul>
<li>The lag in a Vidicon camera tube smooths out the statistical fluctuations and reduces noise or mottle.</li>
</ul>
<p>A Plumbicon tube shows less lag and less movement blurring but more noise.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The noise is worse in the areas of the image where the brightness is low.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Improved by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  the tube current &amp; X-ray intensity  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  so, the quality of the image</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>is dose limited or photon limited</p>
<p>But, increase patient dose.</p>
<ul>
<li>Full advantage cannot be taken of the brightness gain of an II in the reduction of patient dose.</li>
<li>The mA cannot be reduced much below that formerly used in direct vision fluoroscopy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  otherwise, increase noise.</li>
<li>The real advantage of the image intensifier  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the contrast and definition of the image can be seen in ambient lighting and by more than one viewer "due to the brighter image".</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="typical-doses-and-dose-rates">Typical doses and dose rates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#typical-doses-and-dose-rates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Images with acceptable noise are produced by the following approximate doses and dose rates on the input surface of the image intensifier:</li>
</ul>
<p>Fluoroscopy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mu \mathrm{Gy}\backslash \mathrm{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Gy</span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Photospot film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mu \mathrm{Gy}\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Gy</span></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span>  frame</p>
<p>Cine  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\mu \mathrm{Gy}\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Gy</span></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span>  frame</p>
<p>Digital  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mu \mathrm{Gy}\backslash</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Gy</span></span><span class="mord">\</span></span></span></span></span>  frame</p>
<ul>
<li>Due to attenuation by the patient, grid, and couch top, the skin proximal to the tube will receive doses around 300x greater. See also Section 6.7.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quantum-sink">Quantum Sink<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quantum-sink" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The information in the image also suffers from statistical fluctuations in all the other discrete 'events' occurring in the image chain:</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Light photons emitted by the input phosphor
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Photoelectrons emitted by the photocathode
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Light photons emitted by the output phosphor
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Electrons constituting the video signal, etc.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The noise produced in each of the above stages is relatively low since the number of light photons and electrons involved is very large.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Quantum Sink is It is the weakest link in the imaging chain</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The part of the system where the number of photons or electrons/mm <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  of the image field is lowest  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the relative noise the largest and the SNR the lowest.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In an II-TV system, it lies in the absorption of X-rays in the input phosphor.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In radiography, it lies in the absorption of X-rays in the intensifying screens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vignetting">Vignetting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vignetting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-63726437.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Vignetting means that the center of the final image is brighter than its edges.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Figure 4.3b shows that all the light from the center A of the output phosphor (2) that is collected by the first lens (3) is collected and focused by the second lens (4) onto the image plane (5) at A'.
However, some (perhaps  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> ) of the light from the edge B of the phosphor that is collected by the first lens misses the second</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>lens so that the image at B' is less bright.</p>
<p>This occurs in the electron lens system also.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="distortion">DISTORTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distortion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The electric fields that accurately control electrons in the center of the image are not able to control peripheral electrons to the same degree.</li>
<li>Peripheral electrons tend to flare out from an ideal course  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  do not strike the output phosphor where they ideally should &amp; are not well-focused.</li>
<li>The result is unequal magnification  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  peripheral distortion.</li>
<li>The amount of distortion is always greater with large intensifiers "the further an electron is from the center of the intensifier, the more difficult it is to control".</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-cb9565db.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg">
Figure 12-6 Test film of a wire screen (35 mm cine frame) from a 9-in. image intensifier</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Figure 12-6 shows a cine image of a coarse wire screen taken with a 9-in. intensifier. As you can see, the wires curve out at the periphery; this effect is most noticeable at the corners.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This same effect has been observed in optical lenses and termed the "pincushion effect," and the term is carried over to image tubes. The distortion looked like a pincushion to the guy who named it.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Generally this distortion does not hamper routine fluoroscopy, but it may make it difficult to evaluate straight lines (for example, in the reduction of a fracture).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Unequal magnification also causes unequal illumination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The center of the output screen is brighter than the periphery (Fig. 12-6).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The peripheral image is displayed over a larger area of the output screen, and thus its brightness gain from minification is less than that in the center.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A fall-off in brightness at the periphery of an image is called vignetting.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Unequal focusing has another effect on image quality; that is, resolution is better in the center of the screen.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In summary, the center of the image intensifier screen has better resolution, a brighter image, and less geometric distortion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fluoroscopic-image-recorders">FLUOROSCOPIC IMAGE RECORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluoroscopic-image-recorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>There are two modes of recording the fluoroscopic image.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="first-light-image-recorders">First, Light Image Recorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#first-light-image-recorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The light image from the output phosphor of the image intensifier may be recorded on film with a photospot camera or cine camera.</li>
<li>Routine spot films are made directly with x rays.</li>
</ul>
<p>26</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="second-tv-image-recorders">Second, TV Image Recorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#second-tv-image-recorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It makes use of the electrical signal generated by the TV camera.</li>
<li>This group includes magnetic tape, magnetic discs, and optical discs.</li>
<li>The three recorders may employ either analog or digital signals.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="light-image-recorders">LIGHT IMAGE RECORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#light-image-recorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conventional-spot-film-recorder">Conventional Spot Film Recorder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conventional-spot-film-recorder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Spot film devices interpose an x-ray film cassette between the x-ray beam and the image intensifier tube.</li>
<li>The standard <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>9</mn><mn>1</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9^{1}/2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">9</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/2</span></span></span></span></span>-in. square cassette is now replaced with several sized cassettes.</li>
<li>During fluoroscopy, the radiologist can at any time move the cassette from its park position (shielded by lead) to a position ready for exposure → But, there is a delay before a film moved into position and an exposure made (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{3}/4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/4</span></span></span></span></span> - 1 sec).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="several-factors-make-this-delay-necessary">Several factors make this delay necessary:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#several-factors-make-this-delay-necessary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>First, Heavy cassette.</li>
<li>Some changes at the x-ray factors are required.</li>
<li>☐ Fluoroscopy is conducted at about 80-90 kVp and 1-3 mA of tube current.</li>
<li>☐ Spot film uses fluoroscopic kVp, but requires much higher mA (300-400 mA)</li>
<li>☐ So, time is required to increase x-ray tube filament heating, and the x-ray tube anode rotation speed.</li>
<li>A phototimer controls the length of exposure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spot-or-photospot-film-cameras">Spot "or Photospot" Film Cameras<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spot-or-photospot-film-cameras" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Records the image output of an image intensifier on a film.</li>
<li>Produce reduced size images: typically, the film is roll film of size 70 or 105 mm, or cut film 100 mm in size.</li>
</ul>
<p>&gt; Recall that the light from the output phosphor of the image intensifier is converted into a parallel beam image by a lens placed close to the output phosphor (refer back to Fig. 12-5). A semitransparent mirror placed in this parallel beam will allow about 10% of the light to travel on to the TV camera, and reflect the remainder to a photospot camera or a cine camera</p>
<ul>
<li>Originally, it was confined to gastrointestinal fluoroscopy → now used for all fluoroscopic images, including angiography.</li>
</ul>
<p>This has been made possible by the improved resolution of cesium iodide image intensifier tubes.</p>
<p>Large input phosphor diameters up to 16 in. allow large areas of the body to be imaged without moving the image intensifier → a single photospot film can cover almost the entire abdomen (this could not be done with a 9-in. tube).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advantages">Advantages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Most significant → Marked reduction in patient exposure.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The recommended per-frame exposure for photospot film cameras is 100 µR. The exposure for a comparable spot film is 300 µR, three times as much.</li>
<li>Generally, the dose to the patient is 3-5 times smaller than with full-size (cassette-loaded) film.</li>
</ul>
<p>N.B. 100 mm film requires a greater patient dose than 70 mm.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>For gastroenterology, cameras are more convenient than conventional spot</li>
</ol>
<p>27</p>
<p><strong>films.</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The film does not have to be changed between exposures.</li>
<li>The delay between initiation and completion of an exposure is shorter.</li>
<li>Exposure times are shorter (in the 50-ms range) → ↓↓ motion.</li>
<li>High framing frequency = 12 frames/second.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>it is possible to record and view the image at the same time → since the camera is recording directly from the output phosphor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The resolution of the resulting films is that of the image intensifier, <em>about 4 line pairs per mm</em> (a range of 3 to 5 Ip/mm).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Resolution of routine spot films is theoretically greater than that of spot film camera films → but longer exposure times required for spot films may degrade the image because of motion unsharpness.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Savings in film costs of greater than 80%.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Disadvantages:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The little films are a nuisance to process and store.</li>
<li>It needs practice to feel comfortable looking at angiograms on small format.</li>
<li>The sharpness or resolution, being that of the image intensifier, is less good.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>CINEFLUOROGRAPHY</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Cinefluorography is the process of recording fluoroscopic images on cine film.</li>
<li>Records from <em>the output phosphor of the image intensifier</em>.</li>
<li>A beam splitting mirror allows simultaneous cine recording and television viewing, just as with spot film camera recording.</li>
<li>Two film sizes: 16 mm and 35 mm.</li>
<li>In the United States, 98% of all cine is done on 35 mm film, and 95% of all cine studies involve the heart. Therefore, our major emphasis will be on 35 mm cardiac cinefluorography.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Cine Camera</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The basic components of the camera are:</li>
<li>Lens.</li>
<li>Shutter.</li>
<li>Pressure plate.</li>
<li>Aperture</li>
<li>Pulldown arm.</li>
<li>Film transport mechanism.</li>
<li>Light enters the camera through <em>the lens</em> and is restricted by <em>the aperture</em>.</li>
<li><em>The shutter</em> is a rotating disc located in front of the aperture with a sector cut out of its periphery.</li>
</ul>
<p>As the shutter rotates → it interrupts light flow into the camera.</p>
<ul>
<li>While the shutter is closed, <em>the pulldown arm</em> advances the film to the correct position for the next exposure (Fig. 13-13).</li>
<li>The x-ray pulses and shutter opening are synchronized.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-8ff97c43.jpeg" alt="img-126.jpeg">
Figure 13-13 Cine camera</p>
<ul>
<li>The framing frequency  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= 60</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span></span>  "divided or multiplied by a whole number (e.g.,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>7</mn><mn>1</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7^{1}/2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/2</span></span></span></span></span> , 15, 30, 60, or 120)".</li>
<li>The combination of the framing frequency and shutter opening determines the amount of time available for both the exposure and pulldown.</li>
</ul>
<p>For example, with a  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>180</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">180^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  shutter opening and 60 frames per second, the time available for both the exposure and pulldown is 1/120 sec.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="framing">Framing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#framing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Framing is controlled by the lens of the cine camera.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exact framing means that the entire image (the output phosphor of the II) just fits on the cine film.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Over-framing means that only a portion of the image is recorded on the film  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  so, some of the output image is not recorded.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The film image with overframing is larger than the film image for exact framing, and this increased size is usually desirable.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extremes of overframing are generally avoided because patient exposure in areas not recorded is undesirable.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Framing characteristics are established when the cine system is installed.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="x-ray-exposure">X-Ray Exposure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-ray-exposure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The timing and intensity of the x-ray exposure are controlled during cinefluorography by two electrical signals that originate from within the cine system.</li>
<li>One signal coordinates the x-ray exposure with the open time of the camera shutter (synchronization).</li>
<li>The other maintains a constant level of intensifier illumination by varying the exposure factors for areas of different thickness or density (automatic brightness control, mentioned before).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="synchronization">Synchronization<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synchronization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In old cinefluorographic equipment,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">x</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">x</span></span></span></span></span>  rays were generated continuously</li>
</ul>
<p>throughout a filming sequence → the patient was needlessly irradiated when the camera shutter was closed.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>These continuous exposures had two serious disadvantages:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Large patient exposures.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased life expectancy of the x-ray tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In all modern cinefluorographic systems → the x-ray output is intermittent &amp; the synchronized with the open time of the camera shutter.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The shutter of the camera is timed by 60 Hz power → permits shutter speeds that are fractions or multiples of the number 60 (e.g., 7 ½, 15, 30, 60, and 120 frames exposed per second).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>At low framing frequencies the image flickers because the x rays are pulsed, but flicker does not interfere with monitoring.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tv-image-recorders">TV IMAGE RECORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tv-image-recorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The second method of recording the fluoroscopic image involves recording the electrical signal from the TV camera.</li>
<li>This includes: magnetic tape, magnetic disc, and optional disc recorders.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="video-tape-recorders">Video Tape Recorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#video-tape-recorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The 'write' head of the recorder is a small coil which has a narrow gap in its closed iron core.</li>
<li>The video signal is applied to the 'write' head → translates the video signal into a time-varying magnetic field → the signal is recorded as variations in the magnetism of the ferrous oxide coating of a plastic tape which travels at a high speed across the narrow gap.</li>
<li>Switching from the 'write' or recording mode to the 'read' or playback mode → the traveling magnetic tape induces in the coil a voltage signal which, after amplification, reproduces the image on the TV monitor. Alternatively a video disk may be used.</li>
<li>Contrast and brightness can be varied as with any TV image.</li>
<li>The dose to the patient is less than with cineradiography but the quality of the image is worse.</li>
<li>No processing is needed; instant replay and frame freeze are possible.</li>
<li>Magnetic tape is low in cost and widely used.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="but-it-has-significant-limitations">But it has significant limitations:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#but-it-has-significant-limitations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The rate of data recording is limited by the speed of tape movement.</li>
<li>Long time is needed to retrieve a stored image.</li>
<li>Not a good permanent recording medium due to tape wear and degradation of the recorded data → so, needs proper storage.</li>
<li>Shelf life of magnetic tape is about 2 years.</li>
</ul>
<p>29</p>
<p>30</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-2-digital-imaging">4.2 DIGITAL IMAGING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-2-digital-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>"The radiological images considered so far are analog images. In particular, the video signal from the TV camera tube is an analog signal, a voltage which varies smoothly as the image brightness is scanned in the raster of horizontal lines.</p>
<p>"If it is converted to digital form, the image can be enhanced in various ways - and if necessary stored - using a computer, before it is displayed on a video monitor or printed via a laser camera.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-2-1-equipment">4.2.1 EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-2-1-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="digitizer">Digitizer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digitizer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The video signal from the TV camera → applied to an analog-digital converter (ADC) or digitizer.</li>
</ul>
<p>This samples the signal at equally spaced intervals (say) 512 times along each of 512 scan lines.</p>
<ul>
<li>Figure 4.8 shows how the video signal varies during the time it takes to scan a single line and how it is sampled at regular intervals.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3f343c5b.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg">
Fig. 4.8 Sampling and digitization of a video signal along a scan line.</p>
<ul>
<li>The voltage at each data point, which gives the grey level, is expressed as the nearest 10-bit binary number between 00000 00000 = (0) &amp; 11111 11111 (= 1023)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="computer">Computer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#computer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The image has in effect been divided into a matrix of 512 x 512 pixels (Fig. 4.9a). Each pixel is roughly a square of side 0.5 mm. This permits a resolution of 1 mm (= two pixels).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The same diagram can be taken to represent a corresponding 'frame' of 512 x 512 memory locations in the core memory of a computer (microprocessor).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-45cf57a3.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg">
Fig. 4.9 Three successive image frames of a digital image, each a matrix of pixels or memory locations.</p>
<p>31</p>
<ul>
<li>The binary numbers representing the image brightness or 'grey level' of each pixel are stored in a frame of 512 x 512 memory locations.</li>
<li>Each location has an 'address', expressed as two binary numbers and is '10 bits deep'. This requires a storage capacity of 10 x 512 x 512 bits = 320 kilobytes (where 1 byte = 8 bits).</li>
<li>Thus a 40 megabyte RAM (random access memory) can store 128 separate images.</li>
<li>If the sampling frequency were to be doubled, to 1024 per scan line → the pixel size would be halved → the matrix size doubled, and → the resolution improved by a factor of 2.</li>
</ul>
<p>However, the 40 megabyte RAM could then only store 30 separate images.</p>
<p>For further remarks about sampling frequency, see Section 9.2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="image-display">Image display<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#image-display" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The image is displayed by reading out of the computer memory the brightness or grey scale values of the pixels in sequence, in synchronism with the electron pencil scanning the monitor (cathode ray tube).</li>
<li>The data from the computer are converted into an analog voltage signal (by a digital-analog converter, DAC) which modulates the brightness of the spot of light on the screen.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lost-frame-hold">Lost frame hold<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lost-frame-hold" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A simple application is to store the last image of a fluoroscopic examination so that it can continue to be observed on the monitor without continuing to expose the patient ('freeze frame').</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="digital-photospot-high-resolution-slow-television-scan">Digital photospot high-resolution, slow television scan<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digital-photospot-high-resolution-slow-television-scan" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A very short exposure at high mA is made, thus freezing movement → the video system is made inoperative ('blanked') during the actual exposure → the camera then scans the image → writes it into the computer memory with a 1024 line progressive (non-interlaced) raster at 6.25 frames /sec "four times more slowly than normal" → thus allowing the usual bandwidth to be used.</li>
<li>The stored image is read out of the memory at the usual 25 frames /sec for flicker-free display on a monitor or is recorded with a laser camera.</li>
<li>The spatial resolution is typically 2 lp/mm, compared with 4 lp/mm for an ordinary photospot, but with the advantages of digital imaging.</li>
</ul>
<p>32</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-2-2-image-processing-storage-and-recording">4.2.2 Image Processing, Storage, And Recording<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-2-2-image-processing-storage-and-recording" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The below methods of processing, storing, and recording a digital image all find general application in CT, gamma imaging, digital ultrasound, and MRI.</p>
<p>Before reading out the stored image from memory, the grey scale numbers in each address can be processed and manipulated in a number of ways.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-0a50d08c.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg">
Fig. 4.10 Windowing</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="windowing">Windowing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#windowing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Windowing is sometimes called 'grey level mapping'.</li>
<li>The digitized image contains more information than can be seen at once on the monitor screen.</li>
<li>The image stored in a 10-bit computer contains 1024 discrete intensity levels, represented by scale  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>  in Fig. 4.10 → but the eye can only distinguish about 32 gradations of brightness on a TV screen.</li>
<li>A small range of values b, the window width, centered on the window level c, is selected for display on the monitor as (say) 32 distinct shades of grey f in the range from black to maximum white.</li>
<li>Intensities in the range d are not differentiated, being all displayed as white, while those in the range e are all displayed as black.</li>
<li>It is possible to visualize subject contrast only in the structures or tissues whose image lies within the window width.</li>
<li>The window level is the mid-range value of the window, and it and the window width can be independently set at the controls.</li>
</ul>
<p>By moving the window level into the image areas  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">d</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">e</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span></span></span></span></span> , these parts of the image then become differentiated and can be visualized.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="value">- Value:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#value" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It allows the contrast and the average brightness of the image to be optimized within the tissues and region of interest.</li>
<li>It allows the speed and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  or latitude of the imaging system to be altered at will, subsequent to a single X-ray exposure  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  cannot be done in film-screen radiography.</li>
<li>This feature can outweigh the poorer resolution of digital compared with film-screen radiography.</li>
</ul>
<p>34</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="background-subtraction">Background subtraction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#background-subtraction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A technique used to reduce the effect of X-ray scattering and veiling glare.</li>
<li>Subtraction of the same number from each of the stored pixel values will increase contrast. (This is the opposite of the effect of scatter or fog reducing contrast on a radiograph.)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="noise-reduction-by-frame-addition-or-averaging">Noise reduction by frame addition or averaging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#noise-reduction-by-frame-addition-or-averaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Several successive images of the same subject, stored in memory, are added together and averaged, pixel by pixel.</li>
<li>The useful signals are in the same locations in all frames and so will add up.</li>
<li>The noise varies randomly from frame to frame &amp; therefore partially averaged out.</li>
<li>As a result, the SNR is improved by a factor = the square root of the number of frames so averaged.</li>
<li>This is sometimes called 'digital temporal altering'.</li>
<li>It depends on the patient being immobile while the several images are acquired.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="noise-reduction-by-low-pass-spatial-filtering">Noise reduction by 'low-pass spatial filtering'<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#noise-reduction-by-low-pass-spatial-filtering" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>To the grey scale value of each pixel is added a proportion of the pixel values of the eight surrounding pixels and an average taken → reduces noise but can impair spatial resolution.</li>
<li>Small bright or dark areas are removed whether they are noise or real images, while leaving the images of larger objects.</li>
<li>It can be compared to turning up the bass control of a hi-fi system.</li>
</ul>
<p>Digital filtering is further explained in Section 9.1.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="edge-enhancement-by-high-pass-spatial-filtering">Edge enhancement by 'high-pass spatial filtering'<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#edge-enhancement-by-high-pass-spatial-filtering" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Where the pixel values change at an edge or boundary in the image, the gradient can be enhanced mathematically (It achieves digitally the edge enhancement feature inherent in xerography - see section 3.11)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adv-disadv">ADV. &amp; DISADV.:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adv-disadv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Reduce the effect of blurring in the imaging system. → enhance those parts of the image with fine structure detail</li>
<li>But, increases noise.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>It can be compared with turning up the treble control of a hi-fi system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="data-shifting">Data shifting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#data-shifting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The pixel values can be moved horizontally and/or vertically within a frame, and the image can be shifted, inverted, rotated, or even stretched.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="image-storage">Image storage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#image-storage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>A number of separate images can be stored in real time, usually in a solid state memory (RAM).</li>
<li>Access to stored images is rapid (microseconds) but the storage capacity is limited by cost.</li>
<li>To make the RAM available for further images → the stored data are transferred to</li>
</ul>
<p>a magnetic disk "medium-term store" → access is reasonably fast (milliseconds), and may be either:</p>
<ol>
<li>A floppy disk, which is portable but has a storage capacity of only about 1 megabyte, or</li>
<li>A hard (Winchester) disk able to store several thousand images.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>For long-term storage (archiving), the images are transferred to optical disks which have a capacity of many gigabytes.</li>
</ul>
<p>The digital information is burnt by a laser into a specially coated disk "the cheapest form of storage".</p>
<p>Digital magnetic tape storage is also used, and has a very high storage capacity (optical tape is even better), but again access is relatively slow.</p>
<ul>
