<li>When required, digitally stored images can be played back into the solid state memory and, after any necessary manipulation, displayed on the screen.</li>
<li>A series of still images can be presented in rapid sequence ('cine' mode).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cameras">CAMERAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cameras" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The image on the monitor screen can be recorded on single-coated photographic film (formulated so that its spectral sensitivity matches the light emitted by the cathode ray tube phosphor), and it can be processed in the normal X-ray film automatic processor.</li>
</ul>
<p>To obtain good images:</p>
<ol>
<li>The cathode ray tube must be of a high grade; and</li>
<li>The film correctly exposed.</li>
</ol>
<p>This is achieved by a light sensor attached to a corner of the screen which feeds back to the modulator grid of the electron gun and controls the brightness of the screen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laser-camera">Laser Camera:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laser-camera" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A laser camera can be connected directly to the digital processor, bypassing the cathode ray tube.</li>
<li>A helium-neon gas laser (for example) emits a beam of light only 70 μm in diameter → scanned in a raster across a moving film by means of a rotating or oscillating mirror → so records the image.</li>
<li>The image is recorded by reading out of the memory the brightness or grey scale values of the pixels in sequence, in synchronism with the laser beam scanning the recording film.</li>
<li>The data from the computer are converted (by a DAC) into an analog voltage signal which modulates the brightness of the laser beam, it takes a total of 20 s to scan a film, which, on account of the narrow laser beam, can record about 4096 x 4096 pixels, with a resolution of 10 lp/mm.</li>
<li>The single-coated film is specially formulated for infrared and the automatic processor. A green safelight may be used.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="multiformat-camera">Multiformat Camera<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiformat-camera" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In a multiformat camera (whether conventional or laser) the whole of the screen image can be made to fill either the whole film or just a part of it, in which latter case a number of images may be recorded, reduced in size, side by side.</li>
</ul>
<p>35</p>
<p>36</p>
<p>37</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-3-computed-tomography-ct">4.3 COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY (CT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-3-computed-tomography-ct" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-ct-scanning">In CT scanning:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-ct-scanning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) A transverse slice of the patient "say 10 mm thick" is imaged → avoiding the superposition of adjacent structures.</p>
<p>(b) The slice is defined by a 'sheet' of X-rays, produced by a narrow fan beam rotated around the patient → ↓ scatter.</p>
<p>(c) The slice is subdivided into a matrix of 512 x 512 volume elements (voxels), each typically 0.5 x 0.5 x 10 mm. The image is reconstructed by a digital computer as a corresponding matrix of 512 x 512 picture elements (pixels).</p>
<p>(d) The computer allows the use of 'windowing' (see Section 4.2.2) to selectively display a restricted range of tissues.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-792e0688.jpeg" alt="img-130.jpeg">
Fig. 4.12 Principle of CT imaging</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-52fc9ad2.jpeg" alt="img-131.jpeg">
Fig. 4.13 Matrix of tissue voxels, corresponding memory locations in the computer or image pixels.</p>
<ul>
<li>From (a), (b), &amp; (d) → contrast resolution is more than conventional radiography
From (c) → the spatial resolution is less good</li>
</ul>
<p>N.B. contrast resolution = the ability to display low contrast structures.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The image is displayed as a matrix of pixels, each 0.5 x 0.5 mm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The brightness or grey scale value of each pixel in the image = the average linear attenuation coefficient μ of the contents of the corresponding voxel.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>38</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-3-1-principle-of-computed-tomography-imaging">4.3.1 PRINCIPLE OF COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY IMAGING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-3-1-principle-of-computed-tomography-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ct-numbers">CT numbers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ct-numbers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The linear attenuation coefficient <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>t</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu_t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2806em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">t</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> of each tissue pixel is compared with that <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu_w</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> of water by the formula:</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>CT&nbsp;number</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>1000</mn><mfrac><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{CT number} = 1000 \frac{(\mu_t - \mu_w)}{\mu_w}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">CT&nbsp;number</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.3074em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2806em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">t</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.02691em;">w</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>Water is used as the reference material because:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Its attenuation coefficient is close to those of soft tissues.</li>
<li>It is a reproducible material for machine calibration.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The multiplier (1000) is used to obtain whole numbers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The CT number (or Hounsfield number) is defined as</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>-1000 for air.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>0 for water.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For tissues CT number is depends on the kV employed, for example;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If, at 80 keV the linear attenuation coefficient of typical bone and water are 0.38 and 0.19 cm⁻¹, respectively → the CT number of the bone is +1000.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>CT number is higher in the case of cortical bone.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="scanning-the-patient">Scanning the patient:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scanning-the-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Commonest CT scanner use <strong>rotating anode tube with a 0.6 mm focal spot.</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It must have a high heat capacity because the examination takes several seconds.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The tube is mounted with its axis perpendicular to the slice → <strong>11 heel effect.</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The X-rays are collimated to leave the tube into <strong>a fan beam</strong> which just covers the body section.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After emerging from the patient, the transmitted beam passes through <strong>a second collimator set</strong>, accurately aligned with the first; both sets being motorized to set the slice thickness.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The beam then falls on a curvilinear array of (say) <strong>700 detectors</strong>, individually collimated and all carefully matched in sensitivity → convert the transmitted beam intensity into a proportional signal current.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The tube &amp; detectors, mounted on opposite sides of a ring, rotate smoothly around the patient.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In the 360° rotation, <strong>X-ray tube is pulsed 300 times. Each pulse lasts 2 - 3 ms, &amp; the scan can take about 1 s.</strong></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="acquiring-the-data">Acquiring the data<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquiring-the-data" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Each time the tube is pulsed, each detector measures the logarithm of the intensity of the radiation falling upon it "these are related to the sum of all the CT numbers of the voxels each ray has passed through" → called <strong>Ray Sum.</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The set of ray sums collected at each position of the tube is called <strong>Projection.</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Each individual voxel is traversed by an X-ray pencil from several different</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>directions during the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>360</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">360^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">36</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  rotation of the ring, to calculate CT number of voxel.</p>
<ul>
<li>If a pencil beam of width  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span>  passes obliquely through a pixel of size  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>×</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t \times t</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6984em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6151em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span></span></span></span></span> , some of the contents of the pixel will be 'missed' → the computer correct that.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reconstructing-the-image">Reconstructing the image<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reconstructing-the-image" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In principle, if we have  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>256</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>256</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">256 \times 256</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">256</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">256</span></span></span></span></span>  voxels &amp; 700 (detectors no.) x 300 (pulses no.) ray sums  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  enough data for the CT numbers of all the voxels.</li>
<li>The arithmetic involved can be performed in a sufficiently short time by a computer and by taking various short cuts, e.g. ('filtered back-projection')  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the CT image can be produced in close to real time.</li>
<li>The CT numbers so computed are stored in the computer memory locations, each of which corresponds to a voxel and therefore to a pixel, as in Fig. 4.13.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="back-projection">Back-projection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#back-projection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3043569f.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg">
Fig. 4.14 Back-projection: schematic, (a) Pencil beam routing around a small dense structure,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(b - d)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  image reconstructed with increasing numbers of projections.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a39d71c5.jpeg" alt="img-133.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-5b05fc96.jpeg" alt="img-134.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-79e9edaa.jpeg" alt="img-135.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Imagine one voxel, the contents of which have a higher  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span></span></span></span></span>  than its surroundings.</li>
<li>As depicted in Fig. 4.14a, an X-ray pencil traverses the voxel and the ray sum is measured. In principle, a stripe of light could now be projected backward along the direction of the X-ray &amp; its intensity being proportional to the ray sum.</li>
<li>Repeating this for each of the rays which traverse the voxel in the course of a scan would build up an image of the structure (Fig. 4.14b).</li>
<li>With a moderate number of stripes the image would be spiky (Fig. 4.14c). With  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span>  number of stripes  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  blurring of edges of the image (Fig. 4.14d).</li>
<li>The blurring could be removed by modifying the brightness near the edges of each back-projected beam or stripe - a process known as 'filtering'.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-c2facd4d.jpeg" alt="img-136.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3dcc7385.jpeg" alt="img-137.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>A simplified mathematical example is given in Fig. 4.15, in which an array of 9 pixels is scanned from 4 successive directions producing the ray sums shown.</li>
<li>The 3 ray sums in Fig. 4.15a are entered (as in Fig. 4.14e) into the memory-locations corresponding to each of the voxels encountered by each ray. Similarly the ray sums shown in Fig. 4.15b-d.</li>
<li>Adding the numbers (Fig. 4.15e-h), results in the totals shown in Fig. 4.15i.</li>
<li>A little further arithmetic manipulation, involving background subtraction and rescaling, finally yields Fig. 4.15k. This is a fair representation of the CT numbers of each pixel.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="filtered-back-projection">Filtered back-projection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#filtered-back-projection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The blurring introduced by the backprojection process can be compensated by a mathematical process carried out by the computer called 'filtering'  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  modifies the brightness near the edge of each backprojected beam.</p>
<p>Filtering algorithms different "filters" can be used</p>
<ul>
<li>'Bone' algorithm  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  enhance fine detail but increase noise.</li>
<li>'Soft tissue' filter  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  improve contrast by smoothing out noise, but impairs the spatial resolution.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="windowing">Windowing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#windowing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Although the scanner can distinguish 2000 different CT numbers, BUT the eye cannot distinguish nearly as many separate shades of grey on the screen.</li>
<li>Soft tissues (excluding fat) only cover a range of about 80 CT numbers.</li>
<li>So a window is chosen which just embraces all the tissues of interest, and only these are displayed as shades of grey within the range black to maximum white on the monitor.</li>
<li>Pixels with CT numbers outside this window are undifferentiated, being displayed as either black or white.</li>
<li>Window level and window width can be set independently at the control panel, for example to differentiate lung tissues.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-d4c8d793.jpeg" alt="img-138.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>They only affect the displayed image; the whole of the data referring to the reconstructed image is retained in the computer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="partial-volume-effect">Partial volume effect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#partial-volume-effect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>CT cannot reveal detail within a voxel.</li>
<li>It measures the average CT number of the contents of each voxel.</li>
<li>A high-contrast object occupying only part of a voxel will raise the CT number for the corresponding pixel and so appear larger than it is → e.g. tiny calcifications and small traces of contrast medium.</li>
<li>The partial volume effect is reduced by using thinner slices &amp; smaller pixels.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="beam-hardening-effect">Beam-hardening effect<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#beam-hardening-effect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The use of a relatively high kV (typically 120 kV constant potential):</li>
<li>Reduces both patient dose and the hardening of the beam by the patient.</li>
<li>Unfortunately, reduces efficiency of the detector and also the image contrast.</li>
<li>It also increases scatter, making necessary the collimation in front of detectors.</li>
</ul>
<p>41</p>
<ul>
<li>Hardening of the beam as it penetrates the patient results in the CT number of the same kind of tissue decreasing along the ray. However, the image reconstruction process assumes that, to the contrary, the CT number of each kind of tissue is constant along each ray.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="correction">Correction:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#correction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Using a 'Beam-Hardening Algorithm' by the computer</li>
<li>The use of a 0.5 mm copper filter mounted on the X-ray tube, which, with the high kV, produces a relatively homogeneous beam.</li>
<li>Recently, improved beam-hardening algorithms have allowed lighter filtration  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  resulting in a greater tube output and a shorter scan time.</li>
</ul>
<p>To compensate for diminishing patient thickness toward the edges of the fan beam  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Bow Tie <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mtext>®</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{\text{®}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9852em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9852em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord accent mtight"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8889em;"><span style="top: -2.7em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord">R</span></span></span><span style="top: -2.8944em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="accent-body accent-full" style="left: 0em; top: 0.2em;"><span class="mord mtight">◯</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  compensating filter is used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-3-2-the-computed-tomography-scanner">4.3.2 THE COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY SCANNER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-3-2-the-computed-tomography-scanner" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="slip-ring-technology">Slip Ring Technology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slip-ring-technology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If the tube kV is supplied by high-tension cables, the gantry ring has to reverse direction after each  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>360</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">360^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">36</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  rotation.</li>
<li>Faster continuous rotation of the tube is achieved in modern scanners by mounting a high-voltage generator, operating at high frequency (up to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">z</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\mathrm{kHz}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kHz</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) on the rotating gantry ring itself and supplying it with power through slip-rings.</li>
<li>Tube can rotate in one direction indefinitely  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  making helical scanning possible.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>1stgeneration</th><th>2ndgeneration</th><th>3rdgenerationMost common</th><th>4thgeneration</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Beam</td><td>Single pencil</td><td>Narrow fan</td><td>Wide fan</td><td>Wide fan</td></tr><tr><td>Translation</td><td>180 steps</td><td>Less</td><td>No</td><td>No</td></tr><tr><td>Detectors</td><td>Single</td><td>Small curved array</td><td>Large array (100s)rotate opposite tube</td><td>Complete ring (1000s) of stationary detectors</td></tr><tr><td>Rotation</td><td>1° at a time through 360°</td><td>Through 360° with less angular steps</td><td>Continuous for 360°</td><td>Tube alone rotate 360°</td></tr><tr><td>Scan time</td><td>3-5 min</td><td>20 sec</td><td>1 sec</td><td>1 sec</td></tr><tr><td>Adv.</td><td></td><td></td><td>Better predetector collimation</td><td>i- avoid ring artifactii- easy detector calibration</td></tr><tr><td>Disadv.</td><td></td><td></td><td>Ring artifact</td><td>Higher pt. dose (Tube is close to pt.)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Further increase of scan speed is possible by simultaneous use of multiple X-ray tubes or by inserting the patient into a huge funnel-shaped X-ray tube in which an electron beam (1000 mA) scans rapidly round a large semicircular target - usually called the fifth-generation scanner.</p>
<ul>
<li>Multiple stationary detector rings allow multiple slices to be scanned simultaneously.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-fafdab19.jpeg" alt="img-139.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7f718313.jpeg" alt="img-140.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-8f5da8ec.jpeg" alt="img-141.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a8639414.jpeg" alt="img-142.jpeg"></p>
<p>(e)</p>
<ul>
<li>A scan time of 50-100 ms → used mainly for cardiac imaging.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="detectors">DETECTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#detectors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The detectors need to have:</p>
<ol>
<li>High-detection efficiency;</li>
<li>Fast response (short afterglow) to keep up with fast scanning;</li>
<li>Wide dynamic range - able to cope with both the high-intensity beam either side of the patient and the highly attenuated beam passing through the patient (intensity ratio 5000:1);</li>
<li>Linearity - signal accurately proportional to the X-ray intensity;</li>
<li>Stability in face of voltage and temperature fluctuations;</li>
<li>Reliability;</li>
<li>Small size to allow close packing, giving better resolution;</li>
<li>Low cost in view of the large number of detectors used.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scintillators">SCINTILLATORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scintillators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Originally: sodium iodide (thallium-activated) crystal, coupled to a photomultiplier which required a highly stabilized high-voltage power supply.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Sodium iodide has been superseded by other scintillators such as cesium iodide, calcium fluoride, cadmium tungstate, and bismuth germinate → shorter afterglow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Photomultipliers have been superseded by silicon photodiodes → المزايا</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Very much smaller</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Very close packing can be achieved with crystals of cadmium tungstate or cesium iodide, with a silicon light sensor embedded in each solid state detector.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Do not need high-voltage supply.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Detector size typically 1.0 x 15 mm (or 1.0 x 1.5 mm for multiple detector arrays)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ionization-chambers">IONIZATION CHAMBERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ionization-chambers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Features:</li>
<li>Less sensitive but more easily matched for sensitivity.</li>
<li>They are very stable → unaffected by voltage fluctuations.</li>
<li>Have a wide linear response with no lag.</li>
<li>They are narrow (and closely packed).</li>
</ul>
<p>To compensate for the lower sensitivity, ionization chambers are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Filled with a high atomic number gas (xenon) rather than air &amp; at high pressure (25 atm, 2.5 MPa).</li>
<li>Made relatively deep &amp; thick (e.g. 6 cm).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scintillators">SCINTILLATORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scintillators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ionization-chambers">IONIZATION CHAMBERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ionization-chambers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>44</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>• Better absorption efficiency than gas detectors because of higher density and higher effective atomic number</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>• A small gap between detector elements is necessary to reduce crosstalk between adjacent detectors → reducing geometric efficiency</td><td>• Thin metal septa separating individual detectors improves geometric efficiency by reducing dead space between detectors</td></tr><tr><td>• Top surface of detector is flat → capable of x-ray detection over a wide range of angles</td><td>• Must be positioned in fixed orientation in respect to x-ray source.</td></tr><tr><td>• The tungsten electrodes, alternately positive and negative (Fig. 4.17e), converge toward the tube (like strips of focused grid) → help to collimate beam and reduce scatter.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Required for 4th generation scanners: particularly as their sensitivity can be checked continuously by the leading or trailing edge of the X-ray fan beam</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• But may be used in 3rd generation scanners as well</td><td>• <strong>Well suited</strong> for 3^{rd} generation scanners, where very stable detectors are needed as their sensitivity cannot be checked or calibrated very often.</td></tr><tr><td>• <strong>Cannot be used</strong> for 4th generation scanners because those detectors must record x-rays as the source moves over a wide angle</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-3-3-image-quality">4.3.3 IMAGE QUALITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-3-3-image-quality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="noise">Noise:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#noise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>This can be tested by imaging a <strong>water phantom</strong>.</li>
<li>The CT numbers of the pixels will not be all the same, due to statistical variations in the number of X-ray photons absorbed in each voxel → the image is not uniform but appears mottled or grainy.</li>
<li>The computer can be asked to compute the mean CT number and also the standard deviation or noise.</li>
<li><strong>The quantum noise</strong> is a fundamental limit to the quality of the CT image since it both 1) reduces contrast resolution of small objects and</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>worsens the spatial resolution of low-contrast objects.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Noise may be reduced by:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Increasing the number of photons absorbed in each voxel, by increasing the slice thickness or the pixel size.
Improving contrast resolution in this way → impair spatial resolution</li>
<li>Increasing either the mA or the scan time.
Both of these involve increasing the patient dose.
To minimize patient dose the radiologist must accept the noisiest picture consistent with good diagnosis.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Other factors increasing noise:</li>
<li>Zoom enlargement; "spreads available ray sum information over pixel matrix"</li>
<li>Narrower window width "each grey level covers a smaller range of CT numbers, i.e. derived from the absorption of fewer X-ray photons in each voxel"</li>
<li>Reducing the scan time or reducing the slice thickness, unless the mA is increased proportionally.</li>
<li>Deficiency of photons →; occurring with:</li>
<li>Thicker patients.</li>
<li>High-attenuation materials such as bone or prostheses in the slice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spatial-resolution-of-high-contrast-objects">Spatial resolution of high-contrast objects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spatial-resolution-of-high-contrast-objects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>High-contrast spatial resolution is good, being determined by Pixel Size.</p>
<ul>
<li>In CT terms 'high contrast' is between water and Perspex (about 12%).</li>
<li>Spatial resolution may be tested with BAR PHANTOM having a range of different line pairs per millimeter.</li>
<li>As CT scanning smooths out the detail within each voxel → detail within a voxel is not imaged → ∴ 2 pixels are needed to define a line pair
∴ Resolution is about 1 lp\mm → much poorer than film-screen radiography.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="high-resolution-imaging">High-resolution imaging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#high-resolution-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>By increasing matrix size or reducing field of view → decreasing pixel size.</li>
<li>Below a certain pixel size, spatial resolution is further limited by:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Size of the focal spot.</li>
<li>Collimators.</li>
<li>Number and size of detectors.</li>
<li>Spacing between detectors.</li>
<li>Patient movement.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spatial-resolution-of-low-contrast-objects">Spatial resolution of low-contrast objects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spatial-resolution-of-low-contrast-objects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Low-contrast spatial resolution is less good and is limited by the NOISE.</p>
<ul>
<li>The larger the structure → the greater the number of pixels over which the</li>
</ul>
<p>45</p>
<p>noise is averaged → the better the SNR.</p>
<ul>
<li>A low-contrast structure may need to be  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 - 10 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  in diameter to be resolved.</li>
<li>Low-contrast spatial resolution is assessed by imaging a slice though a Perspex phantom with water-filled holes of different diameters and different depths → providing different levels of contrast.</li>
</ul>
<p>A graph is plotted "Detail-contrast diagram" showing the minimum contrast needed to see structures of different diameters.
The solid curve in Fig. 4.18 shows how the spatial resolution depends on the contrast of the image.
The dashed curve shows the improvement in low-contrast perceptibility produced by increasing the mA, or dose per slice, and so reducing the noise.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-1d546534.jpeg" alt="img-143.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contrast-resolution">Contrast resolution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contrast-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>'The ability to detect small differences in the attenuation coefficient of adjacent structures'</p>
<p>Contrast resolution is tied to the SNR</p>
<ul>
<li>The contrast between a structure and its surroundings is ONLY detectable if it is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  3-5 times greater than the noise in the image.</li>
</ul>
<p>The more pixels a structure occupy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  ↓ noise  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  better contrast resolution.</p>
<p>With a structure  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  in diameter, differences of 4-5 CT numbers "0.5% difference in attenuation coefficient" can be detected  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  at least 10 times better than can be achieved in film-screen radiography.</p>
<ul>
<li>In CT, soft tissue contrast is superior to that in plain film radiography because:</li>
<li>Not obscured by overlying bone.</li>
<li>Smaller Scatter.</li>
<li>Windowing allows quite small differences of CT number to be selected from the full range and displayed over the whole grey scale.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="resolution-compromise-trade-off">Resolution compromise (trade-off)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#resolution-compromise-trade-off" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Although a spatial resolution of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\,\mathrm{lp}\,\mathrm{mm}^{-1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">lp</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and a contrast resolution of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5%</span></span></span></span></span> are quoted for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CT} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CT</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> they cannot be achieved at the same time, as Fig. 4.18 makes clear.</li>
<li>It is not possible to achieve excellent spatial and contrast resolution simultaneously, except by delivering an unacceptable dose to the patient.</li>
<li>In fact: Well-established relationship among Noise (N), pixel dimensions <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\Delta)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, slice thickness (T), and radiation dose (D):</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>∝</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi>N</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⋅</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">D \propto \frac{1}{T \cdot N^2 \cdot \Delta^3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">T</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7401em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">⋅</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7401em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>slice&nbsp;thickness</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>relative&nbsp;noise</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>pixel&nbsp;size</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>∝</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mtext>dose</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left( \text{slice thickness} \right) \times \left( \text{relative noise} \right)^2 \times \left( \text{pixel size} \right)^3 \propto \frac{1}{\text{dose}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">slice&nbsp;thickness</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">relative&nbsp;noise</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.954em;"><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">pixel&nbsp;size</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.954em;"><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">dose</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>or alternatively,</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>slice&nbsp;thickness</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>minimum&nbsp;detectable&nbsp;contrast</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mtext>minimum&nbsp;detectable&nbsp;size</mtext><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>∝</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mtext>dose</mtext></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left( \text{slice thickness} \right) \times \left( \text{minimum detectable contrast} \right)^2 \times \left( \text{minimum detectable size} \right)^3 \propto \frac{1}{\text{dose}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">slice&nbsp;thickness</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">minimum&nbsp;detectable&nbsp;contrast</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.954em;"><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">minimum&nbsp;detectable&nbsp;size</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.954em;"><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.0074em; vertical-align: -0.686em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3214em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">dose</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.686em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="accordingly">Accordingly,<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accordingly" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>To improve contrast detectability by a factor of 2 involves increasing the dose by a factor of 4.</li>
<li>To improve spatial resolution by a factor of 2 involves increasing the dose by a factor of 8.</li>
<li>To halve the slice thickness without impairing image quality involves increasing the dose by a factor of 2.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-conclusion">In conclusion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-conclusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Compared with x-ray radiography, CT has significantly worse spatial resolution and significantly better contrast resolution</p>
<ul>
<li>Limiting spatial resolution for screen-film radiography is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7\,\mathrm{lp/mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">lp/mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.954em;"><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>; for CT it is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\,\mathrm{lp/mm}^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.204em;
