vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">lp/mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.954em;"><span style="top: -3.2029em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Contrast resolution of screen-film radiography is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span>; for CT it is about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5%</span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dose">Dose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The distribution of absorbed dose in the body section imaged is much more uniform than in conventional radiography.</li>
<li>With a single radiograph of the skull, if the entry skin dose is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">100%</span></span></span></span></span>, the exit skin dose might be <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1%</span></span></span></span></span> and the central dose <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">3%</span></span></span></span></span>;</li>
<li>In CT, the skin dose is more or less uniform all round. The central dose in the</li>
</ul>
<p>47</p>
<p>head is about 100%, and in abdominal CT typically 60%, of the skin dose.</p>
<ul>
<li>Due to scatter from one slice into adjacent slices, the dose increases with the number of slices, but not proportionally.</li>
<li>Although the detector collimators are set to the nominal slice thickness, the actual X-ray beams overlap, as their width is much greater, being determined by the collimation near the tube.</li>
<li>effective dose is directly proportional to the tube current and total scan length (product of the slice thickness and total number of slices)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-ct-dose-index-ctdi">The CT dose index (CTDI):<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ct-dose-index-ctdi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For calculating spread of dose outside a nominal slice.</li>
<li>It is the integral of the dose along the axis of the patient from a single slice divided by the nominal thickness of the slice.</li>
<li>It can be measured by inserting a 10 cm long, thin cylindrical ionization chamber dosemeter along the axis of a cylindrical Perspex phantom and imaging one slice through its middle.</li>
<li>Organ doses from CT examinations estimated by multiplying CTDI by the appropriate conversion factors.</li>
<li>Typical effective doses are in the range 5-10 mSv per examination.</li>
<li>Although CT scans account for only 2% of X-ray examinations, they contribute more than 20% of the radiation dose delivered to the UK population by medical X-rays.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="artefacts">ARTEFACTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#artefacts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-motion-artefacts">I- Motion artefacts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-motion-artefacts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Cardiac motion produces streak artefacts (black and white bands).</li>
<li>The reconstruction process is misled by a moving structure occupying different voxels during the scan.</li>
<li>Mechanical misalignment and movement of the patient have similar effects.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-high-attenuation-objects">II- High-attenuation objects<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-high-attenuation-objects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Neurosurgical clips, dental amalgam, Small areas of bone or contrast medium etc., give rise to star artefacts which may obscure the area of interest.</li>
<li>The effect is accentuated by motion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-defector-malfunction">III- Defector malfunction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-defector-malfunction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In a third-generation scanner even a small imbalance in the sensitivity of the scintillation detectors can produce ring artefacts.</li>
<li>Cause: the X-ray pencil associated with each detector traces out a 'data ring' - a ring of tissue which is 'seen' by that detector alone.</li>
<li>This ring can be seen on the image as an artefact if that detector malfunctions.</li>
<li>The problem is reduced by frequent recalibration of</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-0f8a891a.jpeg" alt="img-144.jpeg"></p>
<p>the detectors, between patients, and is less noticeable with gas detectors, which are more easily matched.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-beam-hardening">IV- Beam hardening<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-beam-hardening" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The reconstruction process assumes a homogeneous X-ray beam, with the result that CT numbers are lower in the center of the patient (known as 'cupping').</li>
<li>This is corrected to some extent by a "beam-hardening algorithm".</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-geometrical-artefacts">V- Geometrical artefacts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-geometrical-artefacts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Because of the diverging beam → CT slices are narrower at the center than at the edge → overlap at the edges or an unscanned region at the center.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-aliasing">VI- Aliasing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-aliasing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A sharp and high contrast boundary (as at a bone edge) may produce a number of parallel streaks nearby in the image, for reasons explained in Section 9.2.</li>
<li>Similarly, at the boundary between the lung and diaphragm, spurious increased density may appear in the base of the lung.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-partial-volume-or-volume-averaging-artefacts">VII- Partial volume or volume averaging artefacts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-partial-volume-or-volume-averaging-artefacts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-assurance-summary">Quality Assurance: summary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-assurance-summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Each department should have a quality control protocol using appropriate test objects to verify the performance of their scanners.</p>
<p>The topics, already mentioned in this chapter include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Noise - the standard deviation of the computed pixel values for the image of a water phantom, or other reference material;</li>
<li>Reproducibility - the consistency of mean CT number for reference material;</li>
<li>Uniformity - the variation of mean CT number over different areas of the scan field for the reference material;</li>
<li>Sensitivity - the smallest detectable object for a series of various materials (different contrasts) (see Fig. 4.18);</li>
<li>Contrast scale - the differences between the mean CT numbers for various test materials;</li>
<li>Resolution - the spatial resolution at a high contrast level;</li>
<li>Alignment - the presence or absence of streak artefacts in the scan of, for example, a high-contrast pin;</li>
<li>Slice thickness and spacing;</li>
<li>Light beam alignment for patient positioning;</li>
<li>Dose measurements - CTDI and dose profile.</li>
</ol>
<p>49</p>
<p>50</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-3-4-other-techniques">4.3.4 OTHER TECHNIQUES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-3-4-other-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="zoom-reconstruction">Zoom reconstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#zoom-reconstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>An area of interest can be delineated and displayed in an enlarged format.</li>
<li>The computed data normally used to set the grey level of one pixel on the monitor is shared between several contiguous pixels.</li>
</ul>
<p>∴ <strong>Noise is increased</strong> but <strong>resolution is effectively improved</strong>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="scanning-in-other-planes">Scanning in other planes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scanning-in-other-planes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="longitudinal-scan">Longitudinal scan<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#longitudinal-scan" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>If the tube and detectors are held stationary and the couch is moved steadily along its length during the exposure → a digital image can be obtained similar to a conventional (anteroposterior, lateral, or oblique) radiographic projection.</li>
<li>Performed at the beginning of an examination, in either the anteroposterior or lateral plane → allows correct positioning &amp; selection of subsequent axial images.</li>
<li>These scout scans are produced with <strong>less patient dose than normal radiograph</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="multiplanar-imaging-sagittal-coronal-and-oblique-sections">Multiplanar imaging (sagittal, coronal, and oblique sections)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiplanar-imaging-sagittal-coronal-and-oblique-sections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ul>
<li>A section can be taken through the three-dimensional array of CT numbers acquired with a series of separate contiguous slices and reconstructed as an image in any plane through the patient.</li>
<li>The image so obtained has a characteristic appearance</li>
</ul>
<p>→ The pixels are rectangular, the longer side = the slice thickness.</p>
<p>This problem has been overcome by spiral scanning.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="spiral-helical-scanning">SPIRAL (HELICAL) SCANNING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spiral-helical-scanning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The couch moves continuously at a steady speed while the tube and detectors make a number of revolutions around the patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The tube receives its power supply through slip-rings, and the detectors send their signals by radio.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Suppose, for example, that the tube makes a complete rotation each second, the couch moves 10 mm/sec, and the collimated slice thickness is 10 mm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In this case the pitch is 1:1.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A block of anatomy 300 mm long will be covered in 30 s, a long breath hold.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The data are <strong>acquired</strong> in the form of <strong>a continuous ribbon of contiguous slices</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The data are <strong>reconstructed</strong> as a series of vertical slices, in this case 10 mm thick.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interpolation allows slices to be imaged at any level and with any incrementation. For example, a series of overlapping slices, each 10 mm thick at increments of 2 mm, could be reconstructed through a volume of interest.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Note that the slice thickness cannot be changed retrospectively.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Compared with sequential CT scanning, in which the tube reverses and the patient couch is indexed between slices with separate breath holds, spiral scanning has the following advantages and</p>
<p>51</p>
<p>disadvantages:</p>
<p>52</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="advantages">Advantages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>It is <strong>faster</strong> → allowing a greater number of patients and also the use of a smaller volume of contrast medium.
(A <strong>double-helical scanner</strong> with two rows of detectors is even faster.)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It <strong>overcomes the problem of slice-to-slice misregistration</strong>, particularly in the region of the diaphragm, caused by variations in inspiration between the separate breath holds needed in sequential scanning.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It <strong>reduces partial volume artefacts</strong> since the reconstructed slices can be incremented in small steps.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Because of the volume acquisition of data, <strong>resolution in the axial direction is good</strong>, and reformatting into other planes is improved.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>No cooling periods between slices</strong> → high heat loading of the tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Even though a high-capacity tube and sensitive detectors are used → a <strong>lower mA must be employed</strong> → ↓ <strong>patient dose</strong> but ↑ <strong>noise</strong>, particularly with thicker patients.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There is some <strong>loss of spatial resolution</strong> due to the interpolation process.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>A high-speed computer</strong> with a large data store is necessary.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pitch">Pitch<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pitch" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>Def.</strong>: <strong>the distance (millimeters)</strong> moved by the table during one rotation of the tube divided by <strong>the slice thickness (millimeters)</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Increasing the pitch</strong>, by increasing the table speed, is like stretching the spring;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>↓ Speeds up scanning.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>↓ Reduces dose,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>BUT resolution may be lost "greater interpolation needed".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Above a pitch of 2:1 there are gaps in the volume being scanned, and artefacts may arise.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="two-dimensional-reformatting">Two-dimensional reformatting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#two-dimensional-reformatting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Imaginary, mathematical, parallel 'rays' may be sent in any chosen direction through the three-dimensional array of CT data in the computer memory, and projected on to a selected image plane.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>As each ray encounters the CT numbers in the voxels it passes through, it may first reject the high numbers corresponding to bone if it is required to remove bone from the image. Then:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>(a) In shaded surface display (SSD)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Any CT number</strong> so encountered in any voxel along each ray is recorded in a corresponding pixel in the image plane, provided it exceeds a set threshold value.</li>
<li>The image is displayed as if illuminated by an imaginary light source.</li>
<li>Particularly useful in <strong>plastic surgery</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p>(b) In maximum intensity projection (MIP)</p>
<ul>
<li>The highest CT number so encountered in any voxel along each ray is recorded in a corresponding pixel in the image plane.</li>
<li>Calcified lesions and contrast media can be distinguished.</li>
<li>Used particularly in CT angiography and arthrography.</li>
</ul>
<p>Three–dimensional reformatting</p>
<ul>
<li>Multiple projections may be made in this way, around an axis of rotation, and displayed in a cine loop as a rotating three-dimensional representation of anatomy, either as a shaded surface image or a volume rendered (see-through) display.</li>
<li>These software manipulations are very computer-hungry and may be time-consuming.</li>
</ul>
<p>Cine computed tomography scanning
A continuously rotating scanner can also be used with the couch stationary to take a sequence of images of a single slice, e.g. to study the passage of contrast medium through the slice and to allow the best image to be selected for interpretation.</p>
<p>1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gamma-imaging">GAMMA IMAGING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gamma-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-1-radioactivity">5.1 RADIOACTIVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-1-radioactivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stable-nuclei">Stable nuclei<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stable-nuclei" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Nearly all the nuclides extant in the world are stable.</li>
<li>Apart from the nucleus of ordinary hydrogen, which consists of a single proton;</li>
<li>All the stable lighter nuclei contain nearly equal numbers of protons and neutrons.</li>
</ul>
<p>For example, the nucleus of a helium atom (alpha particle) is a very stable combination of two neutrons and two protons.</p>
<ul>
<li>The heavier nuclei contain a greater proportion of neutrons.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="isotopes">Isotopes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isotopes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Isotopes of an element are nuclides which</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Similar in</td><td>Different in</td></tr><tr><td>The number of protons.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Atomic number.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Position in the periodic table.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Chemical and metabolic properties.</td><td>The number of neutrons.</td></tr><tr><td>Mass number.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Density</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Other physical properties</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>The nuclei of all carbon atoms contain six protons.</li>
<li>99% of stable carbon nuclei are carbon-12 (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>12</mn></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{12}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">12</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>) with six neutrons;</li>
<li>1% is carbon-13 (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>13</mn></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{13}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">13</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>) with seven neutrons.</li>
<li>Carbon-14 (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>11</mn></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{11}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">11</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>) with only 5 neutrons "neutron deficit", and carbon-14 (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>14</mn></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{14}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">14</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>) with 8 neutrons "neutron excess" → both artificially produced, unstable &amp; radioactive</li>
<li>All 4 nuclides are isotopes of carbon.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="radionuclides">Radionuclides<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radionuclides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Unstable nuclei, having a neutron excess or deficit, are radioactive → 'decay' to become stable nuclei, with the emission of any combination of alpha, beta, and gamma radiation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="production-of-radionuclides">Production of radionuclides:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#production-of-radionuclides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Natural radionuclides: few, sufficiently long lived, e.g. uranium, radium, and radon.</li>
<li>Radionuclides in medical imaging → produced artificially, in the following ways:</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Radionuclides produced by additional neutron forced into a stable nucleus:</th><th>Radionuclides produced by additional proton forced into a stable nucleus → knocking out a neutron:</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>- Nucleus has a neutron excess → unstable.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>In a nuclear reactor, | - Nucleus has a neutron deficit → unstable.</li>
<li>In a cyclotron which accelerates positively charged ions: e.g. protons or alpha particles.  |
|  - e.g. with Molybdenum (Mo):
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>98</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{98}\mathrm{Mo} + \mathrm{n} \rightarrow {}^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">98</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span> | - e.g. with Boron (B):
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>11</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>11</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{11}\mathrm{B} + \mathrm{p} \rightarrow {}^{11}\mathrm{C} + \mathrm{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">11</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">B</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">11</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">n</span></span></span></span></span>  |
|  - Same atomic number. | - Atomic number increased by 1.  |
|  - Mass number increased by 1. | - Same mass number.  |
|  - Radionuclides produced have same chemical properties "an isotope" → cannot be made 'carrier-free'. | - Can be obtained carrier-free.  |
|   | - Short lived → only possible to use them near to the cyclotron.  |</li>
</ul>
<p>2</p>
<table><thead><tr><th><strong>Radioactive fission products</strong> may be extracted from the spent fuel rods of nuclear reactors.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Radionuclides are obtained from generators</strong> (Section 5.5)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-2-radioactive-decay">5.2 RADIOACTIVE DECAY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-2-radioactive-decay" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nuclides-with-a-neutron-excess">Nuclides with a neutron excess:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nuclides-with-a-neutron-excess" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6e51f330">β⁻ Decay<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6e51f330" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Neutron change into a proton &amp; an electron → the electron is ejected from the nucleus with high energy “-ve beta particle”</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">n</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">p</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="bold-italic">β</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{n} \rightarrow \mathbf{p} + \boldsymbol{\beta}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4444em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0501em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord boldsymbol" style="margin-right: 0.03403em;">β</span></span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>For example,</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>I</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>d</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>e</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>131</mn><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>131</mn></msup><mi>I</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>53</mn><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mi>X</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>131</mn><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>131</mn></msup><mi>X</mi><mi>e</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>54</mn><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Iodine-131 \left(^{131}I, Z = 53\right) \rightarrow Xenon-131 \left(^{131}Xe, Z = 54\right).</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mord mathnormal">o</span><span class="mord mathnormal">d</span><span class="mord mathnormal">in</span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2141em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">131</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">131</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">53</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mord mathnormal">o</span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2141em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">131</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">131</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mord mathnormal">e</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">54</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Same mass number.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Atomic number increased by 1 العالى يعلى.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daughter nucleus mostly produced with excess energy → immediate loss with the emission of one or more γ photons → daughter nucleus in ground state'.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="isomeric-transition-it">Isomeric transition (IT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#isomeric-transition-it" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In isomeric transformation: γ ray is not emitted immediately, but after appreciable time from emission of β particle.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example,</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mrow></mrow><mn>42</mn><mn>99</mn></msubsup><mi>M</mi><mi>o</mi><munderover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>67&nbsp;h</mtext></mpadded><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mrow><msup><mi>β</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mpadded></munderover><msubsup><mrow></mrow><mn>43</mn><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></msubsup><mi>T</mi><mi>c</mi><munderover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>6&nbsp;h</mtext></mpadded><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mi>γ</mi></mpadded></munderover><msubsup><mrow></mrow><mn>43</mn><mn>99</mn></msubsup><mi>T</mi><mi>c</mi><munderover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>0.2&nbsp;Ma</mtext></mpadded><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mrow><msup><mi>β</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>γ</mi></mrow></mpadded></munderover><mtext>Stable&nbsp;nuclide</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }_{42}^{99}Mo \xrightarrow[ \text{67 h} ]{\beta^{-}, \gamma} { }_{43}^{99m}Tc \xrightarrow[ \text{6 h} ]{\gamma} { }_{43}^{99}Tc \xrightarrow[ \text{0.2 Ma} ]{\beta^{-}, \gamma} \text{Stable nuclide}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.8235em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">43</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.0714em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.5em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size3 size1 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct mtight">,</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
-16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20
 11 8 0 13.2-.8 15.5-2.5 2.3-1.7 4.2-5.5 5.5-11.5 2-13.3 5.7-27 11-41 14.7-44.7
 39-84.5 73-119.5s73.7-60.2 119-75.5c6-2 9-5.7 9-11s-3-9-9-11c-45.3-15.3-85
-40.5-119-75.5s-58.3-74.8-73-119.5c-4.7-14-8.3-27.3-11-40-1.3-6.7-3.2-10.8-5.5
-12.5-2.3-1.7-7.5-2.5-15.5-2.5-14 0-21 3.7-21 11 0 2 2 10.3 6 25 20.7 83.3 67
 151.7 139 205zm0 0v40h399900v-40z"></path></svg></span></span><span style="top: -2.0997em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">0.2&nbsp;Ma</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6003em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Stable&nbsp;nuclide</span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The daughter nucleus technetium-99 (⁹⁹Tc) remains in the excited state for 6 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is said to be metastable, and is written technetium-99m (⁹⁹ᵐTc).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Technetium-99m decays to the ground state ⁹⁹Tc, with the emission of a γ-ray of energy 140 keV.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Isomeric transition here result in γ rays only "no β ray emission"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>⁹⁹Tc &amp; ⁹⁹ᵐTc are said to be ISOMERS:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Def. of isomers:</strong> nuclei having different energy states but otherwise indistinguishable as regards A number, Z number and other properties.</p>
<ul>
<li>Another isomeric transformation used in nuclear imaging occurs when rubidium-81 (⁸¹Rb) decays to kryplon-81 (⁸¹Kr)</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mrow></mrow><mn>81</mn><mn>81</mn></msubsup><mi>R</mi><mi>b</mi><mo>→</mo><msubsup><mrow></mrow><mn>81</mn><mrow><mn>81</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></msubsup><mi>K</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>→</mo><msubsup><mrow></mrow><mn>81</mn><mn>81</mn></msubsup><mi>K</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }_{81}^{81}Rb \rightarrow { }_{81}^{81m}Kr \rightarrow { }_{81}^{81}Kr</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1111em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1111em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">Kr</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1111em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">Kr</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nuclides-with-a-neutron-deficit">Nuclides with a neutron deficit:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nuclides-with-a-neutron-deficit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="6e51f330">β⁻ Decay<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6e51f330" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A proton change into a neutron and a positive electron → the latter is ejected from the nucleus with high energy “+ve β particle”.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">p</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">n</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="bold-italic">β</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{p} \rightarrow \mathbf{n} + \boldsymbol{\beta}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0501em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord boldsymbol" style="margin-right: 0.03403em;">β</span></span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>For example,</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>11</mn></msup><mi>C</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>11</mn></msup><mi>B</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Carbon-11 \left(^{11}C, Z = 6\right) \rightarrow Boron-11 \left(^{11}B, Z = 5\right).</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">r</span><span class="mord mathnormal">b</span><span class="mord mathnormal">o</span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2141em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">11</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mord mathnormal">oro</span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2141em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">11</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Same Mass and charge.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The atomic number decreased by 1 الناقص يوطى.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daughter nucleus, if excited → loses excess energy by the emission of gamma photons till reaches the ground state.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="k-electron-capture-kc">K-electron capture (KC)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#k-electron-capture-kc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The nucleus capturing an extra-nuclear electron from the nearest (K) shell → increase its number of neutrons relative to the number of protons.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">p</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">e</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{p} + \mathbf{e} \rightarrow \mathbf{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">p</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4444em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">e</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4444em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">n</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>Same Mass and charge.</li>
</ul>
<p>4</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The atomic number decreased by 1, upon the addition of 1. The number of atoms in the K-shell is 160, and the number of atoms in the K-shell is 286. The number of atoms in the K-shell is 160. The number of atoms in the K-shell is 286.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The atomic number decreased by 1, upon the addition of 1. The number of atoms in the K-shell is 160, and the number of atoms in the K-shell is 286. The number of atoms in the K-shell is 160. The number of atoms in the K-shell is 286.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daugher nuclide will emit characteristic X-rays when the hole so created in the K-shell is filled by an electron from an outer shell ± gamma rays if still excited.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daugher nuclide will emit characteristic X-rays when the hole so created in the K-shell is filled by an electron from an outer shell ± gamma rays if still excited.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daugher nuclide will emit characteristic X-rays when the hole so created in the K-shell is filled by an electron from an outer shell ± gamma rays, but no β-particles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gamma Rays:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The gamma rays have identical properties to X-rays.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The gamma rays emitted during radioactive decay have at most a line spectrum which is characteristic of the nucleus.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The gamma rays emitted during radioactive decay have at most a line spectrum which is characteristic of the nucleus.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The gamma rays emitted during radioactive decay have at most a line spectrum which is characteristic of the nucleus.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Interaerage energy is about E_max/3.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When positive and negative beta particles travel through a material → excitation &amp; ionization of atoms "track of the particle is dotted with ion pairs" → till the loss of the whole initial energy → stop "end of its range".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The range of beta particles is greater with ↑↑ initial energy of β particle &amp; ↓↓ density of the material "inversely proportional".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The most energetic beta rays have a range of about 2 mm in tissue.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="positron-emitters">Positron emitters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#positron-emitters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Positron (= positive electrons) is antimatter → very brief existence.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>FATE: When a +ve beta particle comes to the end of its range → it combines with a -ve electron → the charges neutralize each other, and the masses of the two electrons are wholly converted into two photons of annihilation radiation (each of 511 keV) &amp; travel in opposite directions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>According to Einstein's formula</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E = mc^2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8641em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>Positron emitters are used in positron emission tomography (PET) imaging.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="radioactive-decay">RADIOACTIVE DECAY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radioactive-decay" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Radioactive disintegration is a stochastic process.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="activity">Activity:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The rate of disintegration = the number of nuclei disintegrating per second</li>
<li>The SI unit is Becquerel (Bq) = 1 disintegration per second → Bq is a very low activity.</li>
<li>The natural radioactive content of the human body = 2 kBq (2000 Bq).</li>
<li>The activity of radionuclide administrations in imaging are measured in Megabecquerels (1 MBq = 10⁶Bq) and the activity of radionuclide generators in Gegabecquerels (1 GBq = 10⁹Bq)</li>
</ul>
<p>5</p>
<p>☑ The older unit is the Curie “Ci” → 11 mCi – 37 MPa</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Counts  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span>  number of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  rays enter a detector
