<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The count rate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span>  number of counts per second, cps
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Count rate is measured by a detector is less than the activity because the greater proportion of the rays usually miss the detector "undetected".
However,
Count rate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>  activity  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>  number or mass of radioactive atoms in sample</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-fundamental-law-of-radioactive-decay-states-that">The fundamental law of radioactive decay states that:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-fundamental-law-of-radioactive-decay-states-that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The activity of a radioactive sample decreases by equal fractions  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  in equal time intervals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="99d77fad">→ The Exponential Law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#99d77fad" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="physical-half-life">Physical Half-Life:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-half-life" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The half-life  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(t_{1/2})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1052em; vertical-align: -0.3552em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3448em;"><span style="top: -2.5198em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1/2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3552em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  of a radionuclide</p>
<p>= the time taken for its activity to decay to 1/2 of its original value.</p>
<p>For example,</p>
<p>2 successive half-lives reduce the activity of a radionuclide by a factor of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \times 2 = 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>10 half-lives reduce the activity by a factor of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>10</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>1000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{10} = 1000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  This half-life is more properly called the physical half-life.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Characteristic for the radionuclide.
Unaffected by any agency such as heat, pressure, electricity, or chemical reactions.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Examples for the physical half-lives:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Nuclide</th><th>Half-life</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Krypton -81m</td><td>13 s</td></tr><tr><td>Rubidium -62</td><td>1 min</td></tr><tr><td>Nitrogen -13</td><td>10 min</td></tr><tr><td>Carbon -11</td><td>20 min</td></tr><tr><td>Gallium -68</td><td>68 min</td></tr><tr><td>Fluorine -18</td><td>112 min</td></tr><tr><td>Technetium -99m</td><td>6 h</td></tr><tr><td>Iodine -123</td><td>13 h</td></tr><tr><td>Molybdenum-99</td><td>67 h</td></tr><tr><td>Indium -111</td><td>67 h</td></tr><tr><td>Thallium -201</td><td>73 h</td></tr><tr><td>Gallium -67</td><td>78 h</td></tr><tr><td>Xenon -133</td><td>5 days</td></tr><tr><td>Iodine -131</td><td>8 days</td></tr><tr><td>Technetium-99</td><td>200 000 years</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exponential-decay">Exponential Decay:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exponential-decay" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Activity of a radioactive sample never falls to Zero.</li>
<li>The graph of activity versus time, both being plotted on linear scales  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  exponential curve</li>
<li>If, the activity is plotted on a logarithmic scale,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  straight-line (Fig. 5.1).</li>
<li>Such graphs are useful in calculating:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The activity of prepared sample at a particular time; and</li>
<li>Time necessary to store radionuclide waste.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9f0726c6.jpeg" alt="img-145.jpeg"></p>
<p>7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effective-half-life">Effective Half-Life:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effective-half-life" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>For imaging: the pharmaceutical is 'labeled' with the radionuclide forming the radiopharmaceutical</li>
<li>The metabolic properties of the pharmaceutical ensure that it concentrates in the tissues or organ of interest.</li>
<li>The pharmaceutical alone is eliminated from the tissues, organ, and whole body by metabolic processes &amp; excretion → biological half-life “t_biol”</li>
<li>The radionuclide activity alone decays with its physical half-life “t_phys”.</li>
<li>The activity of the radiopharmaceutical administered in body decreases due to the simultaneous effects of:</li>
<li>a) Radioactive decay</li>
<li>b) Metabolic turnover and excretion.</li>
</ul>
<p>The activity can be regarded as having an effective half-life “t_eff”</p>
<ul>
<li>The effective half-life is shorter than either the biological or physical half-lives.</li>
</ul>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msub><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / t_{\mathrm{eff}} = 1 / t_{\mathrm{boil}} + 1 / t_{\mathrm{phys}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07778em;">eff</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">boil</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0361em; vertical-align: -0.2861em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3361em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">phys</span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2861em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<ul>
<li>The effective half-life depends on:</li>
<li>a) The radiopharmaceutical.</li>
<li>b) The organ involved.</li>
<li>c) Personal variations.</li>
<li>d) Health state of the organ.</li>
</ul>
<p>8</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-3-gamma-imaging">5.3 GAMMA IMAGING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-3-gamma-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The patient is given an appropriate radiopharmaceutical, usually by intravenous injection.
(a) The function of the pharmaceutical is to concentrate in the organ or tissues of interest.
(b) The role of the radionuclide is to signal the location of the radiopharmaceutical by the emission of gamma rays.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The radionuclide most commonly used, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99m}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>, emits 140 keV gamma rays.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>-rays are collected by a gamma camera → image of the radioactive distribution on a monitor screen.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Since gamma rays cannot be focused → <strong>Multihole collimator</strong> is used.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A gamma camera has <strong>heavy lead shielding</strong> → attenuate background gamma radiation.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-multihole-collimator">The Multihole Collimator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-multihole-collimator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This consists of:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>Lead disk</strong>: 25 mm thick and 400 mm in diameter.</li>
<li>It is drilled with 20000 circular or hexagonal holes, each 2.5 mm in diameter.</li>
<li>They are <strong>separated by septa</strong> 0.3 mm thick which absorb the rays attempting to pass through them obliquely.
(The half value layer (HVL) of lead for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99m}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> gamma rays is 0.3 mm.)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Each hole only accepts gamma rays from a narrow channel, thus locating any radioactive source along its line of sight.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For example, in Fig. 5.2:
<strong>Ray "a"</strong> is accepted by the collimator, and <strong>Ray "b"</strong> rejected.
<strong>Ray "c"</strong> can be scattered in the body and then pass through the collimator → rejected later by energy discrimination because it have less energy (in 'pulse height analyzer').</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-crystal">The crystal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-crystal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Instead of a large number of tiny detectors, behind the collimator there lies a <strong>single large phosphor crystal</strong> → 500 mm in diameter and 3 - 12 mm thick.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is made of <strong>SODIUM IODIDE</strong> (activated with a trace of thallium).
NaI have a high atomic number (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Z</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>53</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Z = 53</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">53</span></span></span></span></span>) and density → it absorbs about <strong>90% of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{mTc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mTc</span></span></span></span></span></span> gamma rays</strong>, principally by the photoelectric process; but only <strong>30% of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>131</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{131}\mathrm{I}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">131</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> rays</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is fragile, hygroscopic and easily damaged by temperature changes.
To protect → it is encapsulated in an <strong>aluminum cylinder</strong> with one flat Pyrex face.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">Mechanism:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The crystal absorbs <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> photon (photon <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">a</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>) → flash of light "dashed lines".</li>
<li>The flash contains say <strong>5000 light photons</strong> → travel in all directions and last less than a microsecond → about <strong>4000</strong> emerge from the farther flat surface.</li>
<li>The distribution of light leaving the face of the crystal depends upon which collimator hole the gamma ray passed through.</li>
<li>Light photons are <strong>measured by up to 91 matched photomultipliers</strong>, closely packed in a hexagonal array.</li>
<li>A flat transparent plate "light guide" maximizes transfer of light from the crystal to the photomultipliers.</li>
</ul>
<p>9</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-0f89b17c.jpeg" alt="img-146.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="photomultipliers">Photomultipliers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#photomultipliers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-2026ab0f.jpeg" alt="img-147.jpeg"></p>
<p>Each photomultiplier (Fig. 5.3) consists of:</p>
<p>An evacuated glass envelope.</p>
<ul>
<li>Photocathode coated with a material which absorbs light and emits photoelectrons: one electron per 5 or 10 light photons.</li>
<li>Electrons are accelerated toward a positive anode.</li>
<li>En route electrons impinge on a series of dynodes "connected to progressively increasing positive potentials".</li>
<li>When each electron strikes a dynode it knocks out 3-4 electrons  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  accelerated to strike the next dynode.
After 10 stages, the electrons have been multiplied by a factor  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>10</mn></msup><mo>≈</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>6</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4^{10} \approx 10^{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">≈</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  huaen.
Thus each initial flash of light produces a pulse of charge or voltage large enough to be measured electronically.</li>
<li>The amplification factor is very sensitive to changes in the overall voltage across the PMT [about  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  has to be highly stabilized.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-arithmetic-position-logic">Pulse arithmetic (position logic)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-arithmetic-position-logic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In Fig. 5.2, the light pulse illuminates differentially the array of photomultiplier tubes. It produces the largest electrical pulse in photomultiplier (No. 2) nearest to the collimator hole through which  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  ray "a" passed - and smaller pulses in adjacent photomultipliers.</li>
<li>The 'pulse arithmetic circuit' is a microprocessor chip, which combines the pulses from all the photomultipliers according to certain equations  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  yields three voltage pulses (X, Y, Z) which are proportional to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The horizontal "X" and vertical "Y" coordinates of the light flash in the crystal  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the hole through which the gamma ray has passed  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  and so the position in the body of the radioactive atom that has emitted it  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo separator="true">,</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(X, Y)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
<li>The photon energy of the original gamma ray  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>Z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(Z)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">Z</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  The pulses from all the photomultipliers are summed  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  measuring all the light produced by the gamma ray in the phosphor crystal.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  The size or 'height' of the Z-pulse (in volts) is proportional to the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  ray energy absorbed (in keV).
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  The pulse height is generally stated in kiloelectronvolts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-height-spectrum">Pulse height spectrum:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-height-spectrum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The account so far ignores two facts:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Scattered Gamma rays  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  gamma rays originated outside the line of sight of the collimator can enter a collimator hole.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scattered rays will have reduced energy (ray "c" in Fig. 5.2);</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Gamma rays may lose energy through Compton interactions in the crystal before being absorbed photoelectrically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  pulses of reduced height.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-9211236a.jpeg" alt="img-148.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="z-pulses-vary-in-height">Z-pulses vary in height.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#z-pulses-vary-in-height" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>For  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> , Fig. 5.4 illustrates a sequence of such pulses; it plots the height (kiloelectronvolts) of pulses coming in succession from a photomultiplier coupled to a phosphor crystal against time.</li>
</ul>
<p>11</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3ecc4559.jpeg" alt="img-149.jpeg">
Figure 5.5 plots the relative number of pulses having various heights or energies, in a given period of time.</p>
<p>(FWHM, full width at half maximum. PHA, pulse height analyzer.)</p>
<ul>
<li>This pulse height spectrum is made up of:</li>
</ul>
<p>Photopeak: on the right,</p>
<ul>
<li>Comprising pulses produced by complete photoelectric absorption in the crystal of gamma ray photons which have come from within the patient without suffering Compton scattering.
They vary in height, within a 'window' shown by horizontal dashed lines in Fig. 5.4. This range of energies in the photopeak is due to statistical fluctuations in both:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Number of light photons produced in the crystal by each gamma ray photon and</li>
<li>Number of electrons produced in the photomultiplier by each light photon.</li>
</ol>
<p>This also causes the short tail on the right.</p>
<p>Tail on the left,</p>
<p>Containing pulses of lower energy</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  produced by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  rays suffered Compton interactions in the patient or the crystal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="subsidiary-iodine-escape-peak">Subsidiary 'iodine escape peak'<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#subsidiary-iodine-escape-peak" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  below the photopeak.
Due to some of the K-characteristic rays from iodine escaping from the crystal.</p>
<ul>
<li>Only pulses in the photopeak are of use in locating the source of the radioactivity in the patient,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  A pulse height analyzer is used to reject those in the Compton tail</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pulse-height-analyzer">Pulse height analyzer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse-height-analyzer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The Z-pulses enter a pulse height analyzer  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  reject pulses which are (a) lower than a preset value or (b) higher than another preset value.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It allows only pulses which lie within a window of, say,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\pm 10\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">±</span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span>  of the photopeak energy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any high-energy background radiation is also rejected.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The pulses so selected are referred to as 'counts'.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the case of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99m}\mathrm{Te}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Te</span></span></span></span></span></span>  the window might be set at 126-154 keV, centered on 140 keV.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Because a  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>140</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">140 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">140</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  photon will lose only  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  of energy even when scattered through  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>45</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45^{\circ} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  some scattered photons may 'pass through' the window &amp; produce counts  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  degrade the image.</p>
<ul>
<li>For  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>87</mn></msup><mi>G</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{87}Ga</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">87</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal">G</span><span class="mord mathnormal">a</span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>111</mn></msup><mi>I</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{111}In \rightarrow 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">111</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">I</span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span>  or 3 windows must be used  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  each selecting one  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  ray energy.</li>
<li>The X-, Y-, and Z-pulses are next applied:</li>
</ul>
<p>13</p>
<ol>
<li>Directly to a monitor for visual interpretation "in older machines", or</li>
<li>Newer systems → analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) into a computer, enables:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Dynamic and gated studies.</li>
<li>Image processing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-monitor">The monitor<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-monitor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The X- and Y-pulses steer the electron beam in the monitor tube.</li>
<li>If and only if the Z-pulse has passed through the window of the pulse height analyzer → a pinpoint of light appear momentarily on the screen at the X- and Y-coordinates corresponding to <strong>the heights</strong> of the X-and Y-pulses and <strong>the positions</strong> of the radioactive atom emitting each gamma ray.</li>
<li>Thousands of such dots, equally bright, make up the image.</li>
<li>Two types of monitor are used:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>Long persistence screen:</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Each dot of light persists for a sufficiently long time for a visual image to build up of the radioactivity in the patient.</li>
<li>The image quality is not good enough for diagnosis → only helpful for positioning the patient and making sure that the activity has been taken up.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Short persistence screen: of high quality:</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Each dot quickly dies away but can be captured on film, using a film camera.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Types of film camera:</strong></p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>Polaroid film camera:</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>☑ Adv.: high speed – high resolution – processed very quickly.</li>
<li>☑ Disadv: expensive – low contrast – limited dynamic range.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Multiformat film camera:</strong></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>☑ Employs single-coated cut transparency film, formulated for X-ray automatic processor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A number of images can be recorded in sequence side by side on a single film.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the film is exposed for too long, it will be saturated:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>if for too short time, the image will be underexposed, faint, and grainy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Typically, a total of 0.5 million counts is acquired for each image, taking about 5 min.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-computer">The computer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-computer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>After digitization with an ADC → the X-, Y- and Z-pulses pass to a computer → records each Z-pulse as a count in a memory location corresponding to the X- and Y-coordinates.</li>
<li>As the pulses arrive at random, the counts build up in each location → stored as a digital image in a 128 x 128 matrix.</li>
<li>When complete, it is scanned by a television raster and displayed on a monitor screen as a 128 x 128 matrix of 3mm pixels.</li>
<li>The brightness of each pixel depends on the number of counts stored in the corresponding memory location, i.e. to the number of gamma rays which have emanated from the corresponding area of the patient and to the activity therein.</li>
<li>If counts were acquired for too long, the memory locations would become full → more or less uniformly bright monitor screen me.</li>
<li>If they were acquired for too short time → grainy image.</li>
</ul>
<p>14</p>
<p>Typically, a total of 0.5 or 1 million counts are acquired for each image frame</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Stored image can be manipulated and improved, as described in Chapter 4:</strong>
Background suppression - Blurring reduction - Contrast enhancement by windowing - Noise reduction by averaging - Pixel interpolation "to increase matrix" - Extraction of Quantitative data - Image subtraction or addition for two radionuclides.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dynamic-imaging">Dynamic imaging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dynamic-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>The function</strong> of kidney, lungs, heart, etc., can be studied by acquiring <strong>a series of separate images (frames)</strong> in suitably rapid succession. The images can be retrieved from the computer store in sequence and either (a) recorded side by side on a single film in a multiformat camera or (b) repeatedly displayed seriatim on the screen as a cine loop.</li>
<li><strong>Areas of interest (e.g. kidneys)</strong> can be defined by cursors → and the total counts therein measured on each frame and displayed as a function of time (e.g. a renogram).</li>
<li><strong>An area of interest can be defined between the kidneys → used for background subtraction.</strong></li>
<li><strong>In multiple-gated cardiac studies:</strong></li>
<li>☑ Separate frames, each lasting <strong>40 ms</strong>, are acquired at <strong>20–30 different points</strong> in each cardiac cycle. Each sequence is initiated by the R-wave from an ECG.</li>
<li>☑ At each such point, several hundred successive images are added, pixel by pixel, to improve statistics and reduce noise.</li>
<li>☑ The images → multiformat mode or cine loop of the pulsating heart.</li>
<li>☑ Quantitative data about heart function can be extracted.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collimators">COLLIMATORS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collimators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-95079423.jpeg" alt="img-150.jpeg">
(a)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-fae24be6.jpeg" alt="img-151.jpeg">
(b)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-77278d4f.jpeg" alt="img-152.jpeg">
(c)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b14b0e27.jpeg" alt="img-153.jpeg">
(d)</p>
<p>Fig. 5.6 Types of collimator</p>
<p>(a) Parallel hole, (b) divergent hole, (c) convergent, hole, and (d) pinhole.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Parallel hole</th><th>Divergent hole</th><th>Convergent hole</th><th>Pinhole</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Camera</td><td>400 mm</td><td>smaller camera e.g. mobile γ camera</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>FOV</td><td>Same at all distances</td><td>Large</td><td>Small</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>holes</td><td></td><td>Holes diverge toward pt.</td><td>Holes converge toward pt.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Image</td><td>Same size</td><td>Minified</td><td>Magnified</td><td>Magnified &amp; inverted</td></tr><tr><td>Usage</td><td></td><td>Imaging large</td><td>Children</td><td>Superficial small</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>15</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th></th><th>organs e.g. lung</th><th></th><th>organs e.g. Thyroid</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>Characteristics</strong></td><td>Sensitivity is same at any distance</td><td>Both FOV &amp; sensitivity vary with distance. Both have geometrical blurring.</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Resolution ↓ with ↑ collimator-object distance</td><td></td><td>Resolution ↓ toward edge</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-sensitivity-efficiency-of-collimator">The sensitivity "efficiency" of collimator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-sensitivity-efficiency-of-collimator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Measures the proportion of gamma rays, falling on collimator from all directions that pass through the holes.</li>
<li>It is only a fraction of a percent.</li>
<li><strong>The sensitivity is greater with:</strong> <em>The more holes - the wider &amp; shorter they are.</em></li>
<li>↑ Sensitivity → ↓ radionuclide needed to be administered → ↓ patient dose.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spatial-resolution">Spatial resolution:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spatial-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Def.:</strong> the ability of the system to produce distinct images of 2 small radioactive sources close together.</p>
<ul>
<li>Figure 5.7 illustrates one of the holes in a collimator, lying between the crystal and the surface of the patient.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> rays originating between the inner dotted lines → 'illuminate' the whole of the 'visible' crystal surface → produce a maximum signal.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> rays originating outside the outer dashed lines → cut off by the lead septa → produce no signal.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> rays originating from any points along the solid lines illuminate exactly half of the crystal face.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span> is the spatial resolution of the collimator; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathbf">R</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> resolution</li>
<li><strong>Factors affecting the spatial resolution:</strong></li>
<li>↑ Distance from collimator face → ↑ <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span> i.e. worse resolution.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span></span></span></span></span> Resolution is best close to the collimator.</li>
<li>Wider or shorter holes → ↑↑ sensitivity but ↓↓ spatial resolution.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span></span></span></span></span> The better the resolution, the less the sensitivity &amp; a compromise must be made.</li>
<li>This is a major limitation to the performance of a gamma camera.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-collimator">Types of collimator:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-collimator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>|  <strong>Low energy collimators</strong> | • have thin septa (0.3 mm) &amp; more holes.
• can be used with gamma rays of up to 150 keV, e.g. with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>  |
| --- | --- |
