|  <strong>Medium-energy</strong> | • for use up to 400 keV, e.g. with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>111</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{111}\mathrm{In}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">111</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">In</span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>67</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{67}\mathrm{Ga}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">67</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ga</span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>131</mn></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{131}\mathrm{I}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">131</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">I</span></span></span></span></span>.
• have thicker septa (1.4 mm) and consequently fewer holes
• lower sensitivity.  |
|  <strong>General purpose</strong> | • have 20000 holes each 2.5 mm diameter.
• Resolution (@ 10 cm from the face) = 9 mm.
• Sensitivity = 150 cps/MBq.  |
|  <strong>high-resolution</strong> | • have more and smaller holes.
• lower sensitivity → ↑ amount of radioactivity and the imaging times.  |
|  <strong>high-sensitivity</strong> | • have fewer and larger holes.  |</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-3373c739.jpeg" alt="img-154.jpeg"></p>
<p>16</p>
<ul>
<li>poorer resolution.</li>
<li>used in dynamic imaging where short exposure times are necessary.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-gamma-camera">Types of gamma camera:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-gamma-camera" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>General-purpose 400 mm camera → optimized for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>A mobile gamma camera → for cardiac imaging "easy to position, used ICUs" 250 mm field - 5 mm thick crystal → good resolution with 80 keV γ rays from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>201</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{201}\mathrm{T1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">201</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T1</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>A large field of view (500 mm) camera → bone and gallium imaging.</li>
<li>A scanning gamma camera</li>
</ul>
<p>The head translates along the patient → ↑↑ image matrix from 128 x 128 to 128 x 512.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-4-characteristics-and-quality-assurance-of-the-gamma-image">5.4 CHARACTERISTICS AND QUALITY ASSURANCE OF THE GAMMA IMAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-4-characteristics-and-quality-assurance-of-the-gamma-image" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="uniformity-of-field">Uniformity of field<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uniformity-of-field" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Tested by a <strong>blood field phantom</strong> consists of a flat sealed dish, larger than the field of view (FOV), filled with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> or its longer lived analog cotalt-57 (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>57</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{57}\mathrm{Co}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">57</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Co</span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="should-give-a-uniform-image-with-and-without-the-collimator-in-place">Should give a uniform image, with and without the collimator in place<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#should-give-a-uniform-image-with-and-without-the-collimator-in-place" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A defective photomultiplier → seen as a dark area in the image.</li>
<li>A cracked crystal → a linear defect.</li>
<li>Slight differences in the performance of individual photomultipliers → Non-uniformity due to:</li>
<li>Is assessed by instructing the computer to compute a histogram of the counts in individual pixels. (A sufficiently long exposure is necessary to reduce noise).</li>
<li>It calculates the mean &amp; standard deviation → typically the uniformity is 1 - 2%.</li>
<li>Modern gamma cameras can be instructed to compensate subsequent images automatically for minor non-uniformities of the field.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="spatial-resolution">Spatial resolution:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spatial-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>See before</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="intrinsic-resolution">Intrinsic resolution:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intrinsic-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Refers to <strong>THE CAMERA</strong> (crystal, photomultipliers, and position logic circuits) in the absence of the collimator and patient.</li>
<li>When a single γ photon is absorbed at a point in the crystal, the 4000 or so photons of emerging light only eject a total of 400 or so electrons from the photocathodes of all the photomultipliers.</li>
<li>In Fig. 5.2, photomultipliers Nos. 1 and 3 should receive equal numbers of photons and produce identical pulses.</li>
<li>BUT, because of the small numbers of light photons and electrons involved → significant statistical variations in the relative numbers and the heights of the pulses produced → errors in the X and Y coordinates assigned to the event → blurring</li>
<li>Intrinsic resolution can be improved by using a <strong>THINNER CRYSTAL</strong> but with consequent reduction in sensitivity (just as with intensifying screens).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="system-resolution">System resolution:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#system-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-a8ddc8c9.jpeg" alt="img-155.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>Total blurring due to Intrinsic blurring, Collimator &amp; Scattering of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  rays in the patient (according to the same formula as for radiographic blurrings).</li>
<li>Resolution worsens the farther the activity from the collimator. Consequently it is worse for fat patients than for thin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="testing-the-resolution">Testing the resolution:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testing-the-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="resolution-can-be-tested-by-imaging-a-line-source">Resolution can be tested by imaging a line source<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#resolution-can-be-tested-by-imaging-a-line-source" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The computer is instructed to plot the counts along a line of pixels at right angles to a thin tube filled with  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>99</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">99\mathrm{mTc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">99</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mTc</span></span></span></span></span></span> . The graph (Fig. 5.8) is called "line spread function".</li>
<li>The line source can be placed:</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Against the face of the collimator in air (solid curve).</p>
<p>The spread of the curve measured halfway up, called the 'full width to half maximum' or FWHM corresponds to R in Fig. 5.7, and is typically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Against the crystal face after removing the collimator (dotted curve).</p>
<p>The FWHM of this curve measures intrinsic resolution, typically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 - 2\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  At  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mathrm{cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span>  deep in a scattering medium while using the collimator (dashed curve).</p>
<p>(This depth is chosen, as organs being imaged typically lie 5-10 cm deep)</p>
<p>The FWHM of this curve measures system resolution, typically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mathrm{mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>Resolution is not improved by using smaller pixel size than 3 mm in a 128 x 128 matrix.</p>
<ul>
<li>Alternatively, spatial resolution can be tested with a bar test pattern:</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>It is made of either; strips of lead placed on a flood field phantom or evenly spaced parallel line sources.</li>
<li>It is placed against the face of the crystal.</li>
<li>This measures the intrinsic resolution  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  typically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 - 6\mathrm{lp}\backslash \mathrm{cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">lp</span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>In practice the overall system resolution is worse than  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{lp}\backslash \mathrm{cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">lp</span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<p>So, the value of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>  imaging lies in evaluating function rather than anatomy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="linearity">Linearity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#linearity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Linearity (i.e. lack of distortion) can also be checked by imaging a line source.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="energy-resolution">Energy resolution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#energy-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Def.: the ability to distinguish between separate gamma rays of different energies.</p>
<ul>
<li>Importance:</li>
</ul>
<p>Better energy resolution  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  better scatter rejection &amp; better spatial resolution</p>
<ul>
<li>Calculated from FWHM of the photopeak divided by the energy of the photon &amp; expressed as a percentage</li>
</ul>
<p>Typically  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">12%</span></span></span></span></span>  of the peak energy</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b590114a.jpeg" alt="img-156.jpeg"></p>
<p>18</p>
<ul>
<li>The pulse height analyzer - in a sophisticated form called <strong>Multichannel Analyzer</strong> - can be used to plot the photopeak (see Fig. 5.5).</li>
<li>Setting a <strong>narrower pulse height analyzer window</strong> → improves the energy resolution but reduces the sensitivity and increases imaging time.</li>
<li>The energy resolution is better for high-energy gamma photons because they each produce more light photons → it is therefore better with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> than with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>201</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{201}\mathrm{T1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">201</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T1</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="temporal-resolution-dead-time-and-lost-counts">Temporal resolution: dead time and lost counts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#temporal-resolution-dead-time-and-lost-counts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Flash of light produced by a gamma photon in the crystal has a decay time of <strong>0.2 μs</strong>.</li>
<li>About 95% of the light has been emitted in <strong>1 μs</strong> at which point the pulse is cut off electronically. For that period the counting circuit does not recognize other pulses, and is said to be 'dead'.</li>
<li>Due to the stochastic nature of radioactive decay, counts arrive at irregular intervals. If 2 gamma photon enters the camera during the dead time (indicated by vertical dashed lines in the figure) → the two flashes of light overlap, and they are treated as one. → if the combined pulse is too large, it will be rejected by the pulse height analyzer.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lost-counts">Lost counts:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lost-counts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>At high count rates a significant proportion of the gamma photons is missed → underestimated count rate</p>
<ul>
<li>Typically there is <strong>80% loss at 40000 cps</strong> and more at higher count rates</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effect-on-resolution">Effect on resolution:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-on-resolution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If two Compton-scattered photons (60 and 80 keV) enter the system within 1 μs of each other → recorded as a single photon (140 keV) → pass through the pulse height analyzer &amp; produce a spurious image in a false location → deterioration of the spatial resolution</li>
<li>Obvious at the high count rates in cardiac imaging.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sensitivity">Sensitivity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sensitivity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is measured with a <strong>small version of the flood field phantom</strong>.</li>
<li>Expressed as <strong>Total counts per second per megabequerel of activity</strong>.</li>
<li>The <strong>crystal efficiency</strong> is rather high, &amp; the <strong>collimator determines overall efficiency</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Up to a point, using <strong>thicker</strong> crystal increases sensitivity but poorer resolution; more importantly, so does using a collimator with <strong>larger</strong> holes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="noise-quantum-mottle">Noise: Quantum Mottle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#noise-quantum-mottle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Using <strong>shorter exposure</strong> → the flood field phantom shows a characteristic mottled appearance "because the counts fluctuate from pixel to pixel".</li>
<li>The computer can be instructed to draw a histogram of counts per pixel and to calculate the mean and standard deviation. &amp; dividing the mean by the standard deviation gives the signal-to-noise ratio.</li>
<li><strong>Noise in gamma imaging is high</strong> because of the inherently small signal from a limited amount of radioactivity.</li>
<li><strong>Noise could be reduced</strong> by using <strong>more radionuclide</strong> → BUT, ↑↑ patient dose.</li>
</ul>
<p>19</p>
<ul>
<li>The activity is distributed through the body and typically only 20% concentrated in the organ of interest.</li>
<li>The gamma rays are emitted <strong>isotopically</strong> and only a small fraction passes through the collimator holes (cannot be made too wide otherwise resolution is lost).</li>
<li>The gamma rays could be collected for any length of time without further dose to the patient → but imaging time is limited by <strong>ability of the patient to stay still &amp; workload</strong>. The imaging time must be shorter still for dynamic studies, especially cardiac imaging.</li>
<li>The total counts acquired per image are further subdivided among the 128 × 128 pixels → only about 100 counts per pixel → ∴ <strong>pixel to pixel noise = 10%</strong>.</li>
<li>More important is the number of counts acquired over the blur size <strong>R</strong> about 1000, with a noise of 3% → ∴ <strong>hot spots and cold spots of about 10%</strong> can detected against the background activity in the body.</li>
</ul>
<p>This "<strong>Contrast Resolution</strong>" can only be improved at the expense of either increased patient dose or worsened spatial resolution.</p>
<ul>
<li>Noise is the principal factor in determining the quality of gamma images.</li>
</ul>
<p>**Gamma imaging is therefore said to be <strong>noise limited</strong> or <strong>dose limited</strong>.</p>
<ul>
<li>The count rate is maximized and the patient dose minimized by a judicious choice of radiopharmaceutical.</li>
</ul>
<p>20</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-5-radiopharmaceuticals">5.5 RADIOPHARMACEUTICALS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-5-radiopharmaceuticals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="desirable-properties-of-a-radionuclide-for-imaging-are">Desirable properties of a radionuclide for imaging are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#desirable-properties-of-a-radionuclide-for-imaging-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>A <strong>physical half-life of a few hours</strong>, similar to the time from preparation to injection. If the half-life is too short, much more activity must be prepared than is actually injected.</li>
<li><strong>Decay to a stable daughter</strong> or one with a very long half-life (e.g. 200 000 yrs for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>Emit <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> rays (which produce the image) but no <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> particles or very low-energy photons (which have a high linear energy transfer "LET", &amp; only deposit dose in patient)
<strong>Decay by isomeric transition or electron capture is preferred.</strong></li>
<li>Emit gamma rays of energy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>300</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50-300\,\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span> (ideally <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150\,\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>)
→ high enough to exit the patient but low enough to be easily collimated and easily measured, being largely absorbed in the collimator septa and the crystal.</li>
<li>Ideally <strong>emit monoenergetic gamma rays</strong> so that scatter can be eliminated by energy discrimination with the pulse height analyzer.</li>
<li>Be <strong>easily and firmly attached to the pharmaceutical</strong> at room temperature &amp; not affect its metabolism.</li>
<li>Be readily available on the hospital site.</li>
<li>Have a <strong>high specific activity</strong>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-addition-the-radiopharmaceutical-should">In addition, the radiopharmaceutical should:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-addition-the-radiopharmaceutical-should" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>localize</strong> largely and quickly in the 'target';</li>
<li>be <strong>eliminated</strong> from the body with an effective half-life similar to the duration of the examination → patient dose;</li>
<li>have a <strong>low toxicity</strong>;</li>
<li>form a <strong>stable product</strong> both in vitro and in vivo</li>
<li>be readily available and cheap per patient dose.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="technetium-generator">Technetium generator:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technetium-generator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> is used in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of radionuclide imaging as it fulfills most of the above criteria:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>With its <strong>gamma energy of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>140</mn><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">140\,\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">140</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span></strong> → easily collimated and easily absorbed in thin crystal → good spatial resolution.</li>
<li>With its <strong>short half-life</strong> and <strong>pure gamma emission</strong> → a reasonably large activity can be administered → reducing noise.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> is supplied in a generator shielded with lead, Fig. 5.9</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The generator contains an <strong>alumina exchange column</strong> on which has been absorbed a compound of the parent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span> (produced in nuclear reactor &amp; it's half-life = 67 h).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>At the time of arrival, the activity of the 'daughter' <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> has built up to its maximum, equal to that of the parent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daughter is decaying as quickly as it is being formed by the decay of its parent → <strong>transient equilibrium with the parent</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The daughter and parent decay together with the half-life of the parent, 67 h (Fig. 5.10).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-fb1cca01.jpeg" alt="img-157.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The technetium is washed off (eluted) as sodium pertechnetate with sterile saline solution  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  flows under pressure from a reservoir through the column into a rubber-capped sterile container.</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Elution takes few minutes  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  leaves behind Molybdenum "firmly attached to column"
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The eluent decays with its own half-life of 6 h.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>  in the column regrows with the same half-life of 6 h.</p>
<ul>
<li>After  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>24</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">24\mathrm{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">24</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span></span></span></span></span>  → the activity has grown again to a new maximum (equilibrium) value. (After  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6\mathrm{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span></span></span></span></span>  it has reached  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span>  of the maximum; after  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12\mathrm{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span>  and so on.)</li>
<li>Figure 5.10 plots the activity of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span>  (dashed line) and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>  (solid line) against time, following the first elution (1) at time 0.</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-939469e5.jpeg" alt="img-158.jpeg">
Fig. 5.10 Decay of activity of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span>  and growth and regrowth of activity of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>  in a generator which is eluted daily.</p>
<ul>
<li>Elution can be made daily (&amp; if necessary, the column can be eluted twice daily) - though it will be seen that the strength of successive eluents (2, 3, . . .) diminishes in line with the decay of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  after a week, the generator is replaced and the old one is returned for recycling.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="uses-of-technetium-99m">Uses of Technetium-99m<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#uses-of-technetium-99m" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Sodium pertechnetate-99m "have similarity to iodide and chloride ions":</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Thyroid (trapped but not fully metabolized).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gastric emptying studies (mixed with bran porridge)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gastric mucosa (localization of Meckel's diverticulum)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Testicular imaging.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Salivary glands.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cerebral blood flow.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Technetium can easily be labelled to a wide variety of useful compounds:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Hexamethyl propylene amine oxime (HMPAO)  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  cerebral imaging;</li>
<li>Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) - Mercaptoacetyletriglycine (MAG3) → renal study</li>
<li>Iminodiacetic acid (HIDA)  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  biliary studies;</li>
<li>Human serum albumin (HSA) colloidal particles,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5\mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>  in size, phagocytosed in reticulo-endothelial cells  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  imaging of liver, spleen and red bone marrow;</li>
<li>HSA Macroaggregates - 15-100  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span></span></span></span></span> m microspheres  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  temporarily block a small fraction of the capillaries in lung perfusion imaging;</li>
<li>Diethylene Triamine Pentacetic Acid (DTPA) aerosol (5  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span></span></span></span></span> m particles)  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span></li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-ventilation-studies">lung ventilation studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-ventilation-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol start="7">
<li>Diphosphonates  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  bone imaging, being taken up in sites of bone repair;</li>
<li>Autologous red cells  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  cardiac function;</li>
<li>Heat-damaged autologous red cells  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  imaging the spleen;</li>
<li>Sestamibi or tetrofosmin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  cardiac perfusion imaging.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-radionuclides-and-their-uses">Other radionuclides and their uses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-radionuclides-and-their-uses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Iodine</th><th>·Avidly trapped and metabolized by the thyroid, which was the organ first imaged. ·Iodine-131 (131I) the first radionuclide used for imaging: ·Cheap. ·highly reactive. ·excellent label. ·It is produced in a reactor and has a long shelf life (half-life 8 days). Disadv.: emits beta rays as well as rather energetic (mainly 364 keV) γ rays. ·131I has largely been replaced by iodine-123 (123I): ·more expensive. ·cyclotron produced. ·has a half-life of 13 h. ·decays by electron capture, emitting 159 keV gamma rays. ·123I is more expensive than, but otherwise superior to 125I which have: ·long half-life (60 days). ·low photon energy (around 30 keV). ·Iodine may be labeled to hippuran for renal studies, being cleared by both glomerular nitration and tubular secretion.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Xenon-133 (133Xe)</td><td>·Reactor produced. ·Half-life = 5.2 days. ·Emits beta rays and rather low-energy (81 keV) gamma rays. ·It is an inert gas, although somewhat soluble in blood and fat. ·Used, with rebreathing, in lung ventilation imaging.</td></tr><tr><td>Krypton-81m (81mKr)</td><td>·Another inert gas. ·Generator produced → the generator is eluted with compressed air. ·Half-life = 13 s. ·Emits 190 keV gamma rays. ·The patient inhales the air-81mKr mixture in pulmonary ventilation studies. ·The short life of the parent (81Rb, 4.7 h) presents transport difficulties and means it must be used the day it is delivered</td></tr><tr><td>Gallium-67 (67Ga)</td><td>·Cyclotron produced. ·Half-life = 78 h. ·Decays by electron capture, emitting gamma rays of three main energies. ·Gallium citrate is used to detect tumors and abscesses as it binds to plasma proteins.</td></tr><tr><td>Indium-111 (111In)</td><td>·Cyclotron produced. ·Half-life = 67 h. ·Decays by electron capture, emitting 173 and 247 keV gamma rays. ·used to label white blood cells and platelets for locating abscesses and thromboses, respectively.</td></tr><tr><td>Indium-113m (113mIn)</td><td>·sometimes used instead of 111In. ·Generator produced. ·Half-life = 100 min.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>• Emits only gamma rays, but they have a high energy (390 keV).</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Thallium-201 (201Th)</td><td>• Cyclotron produced. • Half-life = 73 h. • Decays by electron capture, emitting 80 keV X-rays. • As an analog of potassium → used as Thallous chloride in myocardial perfusion imaging, where its half-life is well suited to repeated imaging over a few hours</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>24</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="preparation-of-radiopharmaceuticals">Preparation of radiopharmaceuticals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preparation-of-radiopharmaceuticals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>By <strong>simple mixing</strong> at room temperature:
Radionuclide (e.g. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi>m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99m}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>) + Pharmaceutical (e.g. MDP) + other necessary chemicals</li>
<li><strong>Shielded syringes</strong> transfer the components between sterile vials.</li>
