<li>Manipulations <strong>under sterile conditions</strong> in a 'workstation' → <strong>glove box</strong> or <strong>laminar downflow cabinet</strong>.</li>
<li>Room is under a <strong>positive pressure of filtered sterile air</strong>.</li>
<li><strong>Impervious surfaces</strong>: continuous floors- gloss-painted walls- Formica-topped benches.</li>
<li><strong>Entry</strong> is via an air lock and changing room.</li>
<li><strong>The pharmacy</strong> must meet the conditions of both the Medicines Act and the Ionising Radiations Regulations in the UK.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quality-control-includes-testing-for">Quality control includes testing for:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-control-includes-testing-for" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Radionuclide purity</strong>:
Testing for contamination with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>99</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99}\mathrm{Mo}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Mo</span></span></span></span></span></span>, which give unnecessary dose to the patient
By measuring <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> radiation after blocking off the gamma rays from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> with <strong>5mm lead</strong>;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Radiochemical purity</strong>:
Testing for <strong>free pertechnetate</strong> in a labeled compound by <strong>chromatography</strong>;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Chemical purity</strong>:
<strong>Spot colour test</strong> for <strong>alumina</strong>, "which would interfere with labeling";</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Sterility testing and pyrogens testing</strong>: → available only retrospectively;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Response of the radionuclide calibrator</strong>: (see Section 5.6).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-6-dose-to-the-patient">5.6 DOSE TO THE PATIENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-6-dose-to-the-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dose-to-an-organ">Dose to an organ<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose-to-an-organ" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>The absorbed dose delivered to an organ</strong> by the activity it has taken up increases in proportion to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>the activity</strong> administered to the patient and <strong>the fraction</strong> taken up by the organ;</li>
<li><strong>the effective half-life</strong> of the activity in the organ;</li>
<li><strong>the energy (MeV)</strong> of beta and gamma radiation emitted in each disintegration;</li>
<li>Also depends on <strong>how much of that energy escapes from the organ</strong> &amp; not contribute to the absorbed dose.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>All the energy of a <strong>beta ray</strong> is deposited inside the organ and none escapes.</li>
<li>Some of the energy of a <strong>gamma ray</strong> is deposited in the organ and some leaves it, → depending on the size of the organ and how energetic the gamma ray is.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li><strong>the additional dose</strong> from activity in surrounding tissues.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effective-dose-to-the-body">Effective dose to the body<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effective-dose-to-the-body" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Unlike imaging with X-rays, the dose delivered by a radionuclide examination is <strong>unaffected by the number of images taken</strong></li>
<li>After an intravenous injection most tissues may receive some dose, but <strong>the target organ and the organs of excretion generally receive the highest doses</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p>25</p>
<ul>
<li>The distribution of a dose is non-uniform and specific to the examination, but an average dose to the body as a whole can be calculated → <strong>the effective dose (ED)</strong>, "Section 6.3"</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="typical-activities-and-doses">Typical activities and doses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#typical-activities-and-doses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Most investigations deliver an ED of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{mSv}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mSv</span></span></span></span></span></span>  or less  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  no greater than the variation, from place to place and individual to individual, in the annual dose of natural radiation.</li>
<li>Some, such as bone or static brain imaging, deliver doses in the region of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\mathrm{mSv}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mSv</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
<li>Few examinations, such as tumor or abscess imaging with  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>67</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{67}\mathrm{Ga}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">67</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ga</span></span></span></span></span></span> , deliver higher doses  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  undertaken only when other imaging modalities are inappropriate (Table 5.2).</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 5.2 Typical activities and doses</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Site</th><th>Agent</th><th>Activity (MBq)</th><th>Effective dose (mSv)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Bone</td><td>99mTc phosphonate</td><td>600</td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>Lung ventilation</td><td>99mT DTPA aerosol</td><td>80</td><td>0.6</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>81mKr gas</td><td>6000</td><td>0.1</td></tr><tr><td>Lung perfusion</td><td>99mT HA Macroaggregates</td><td>100</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>Kidney</td><td>99mT DTPA gluconate</td><td>80</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>99mT MAG3</td><td>100</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>Tumor</td><td>67GaGa3+</td><td>150</td><td>18</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In order to minimize patient dose, patients should drink a good deal of water and empty the bladder frequently to reduce the dose to the gonads and pelvic bone marrow.
The activity of each administration of radiopharmaceutical is kept within the limits set by the Administration of Radioactive Substances Advisory Committee (ARSAC) of the UK Department of Health (Section 6.6), and checked &amp; recorded before administration.
The phial is placed in the "well' of a large re-entrant ionization chamber, know as:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-radionuclide-or-dose-calibrator">The radionuclide or dose calibrator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-radionuclide-or-dose-calibrator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The ionization current produced by the gamma rays is:</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Proportional to the activity of the sample.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  Depends on the gamma energy and half-life of the radionuclide.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  The radionuclide is entered on the control panel and the activity in MBq is displayed on a digital read-out.</p>
<p>The accuracy of the radionuclide calibrator must be checked regularly using a reasonably long-lived source, such as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>57</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{57}\mathrm{Co}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">57</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Co</span></span></span></span></span></span> .
The calibrator can also be used with a lead sleeve to check for the higher-energy gamma rays from molybdenum impurity.</p>
<p>27</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5-7-precautions-taken-in-the-handling-of-radionuclides">5.7 PRECAUTIONS TAKEN IN THE HANDLING OF RADIONUCLIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-7-precautions-taken-in-the-handling-of-radionuclides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>When handling radionuclides, in addition to the hazard from external radiation there is also a potential hazard from internal radiation due to accidental ingestion or inhalation of the radionuclide or its entry through wounds.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Generally, the risk from contamination is greater than that from external radiation. It is therefore important to avoid contamination of the environment, the workplace, and persons, and to control any spread of radioactive materials.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="segregation">Segregation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#segregation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>A nuclear medicine facility must have separate areas for:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(a) Preparation and storage of radioactive materials.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(b) Injection of patients.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(c) Patients to wait.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(d) Imaging.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(e) Temporary storage of radioactive waste.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Patients containing radioactivity are a source of external radiation → should be spaced apart in the waiting area.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Departmental layout should make use of the "inverse square law" to reduce the effect of background radiation from other patients and sources, particularly in the imaging areas.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="personal-protection">Personal protection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#personal-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Use should be made of distance, shielding, and time.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Staff should only enter areas where there is radioactivity when it is strictly necessary; all procedures must be carried out expeditiously and efficiently.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Departmental local rules must be followed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Some general guidance follows.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Radionuclides are contained in shielded generators or in bottles in lead pots.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Where feasible, bottles and syringes are handled with long-handled forceps (tongs).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Manipulations, such as the labeling of pharmaceuticals and the loading of syringes, are carried out with the arms behind a lead barrier which protects the body and face, and over a tray, lined with absorbent paper, to catch any drips.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Syringes are protected by heavy metal or lead glass sleeves (which can reduce radiation doses by 75%) → &amp; transported in special containers or on a kidney dish.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Before injection, syringes are vented into swabs or closed containers and not into the atmosphere.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lead-rubber aprons are ineffective against the high-energy gamma rays of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To avoid accidental ingestion → waterproof (double-latex) surgical gloves are worn when handing radionuclides.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Cuts and abrasions must be covered first.</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>There must be no eating, drinking, or facial contact.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hands and work surfaces are routinely monitored for radioactive contamination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The air in Radiopharmacies may also be sampled and monitored.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Staff will be monitored for external radiation doses to the body and possibly the hands. They may also be monitored for internal contamination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Swabs are taken from the workstation to monitor for radioactive and bacterial contamination.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hands should be washed regularly at special wash basins. Where necessary, and particularly after spills, decontamination may be carried out. This normally involves the use of water, mild detergents, and swabs, which are then sealed in plastic bags and disposed of as radioactive waste in marked bins.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any use of a nail brush should be gentle; if contamination is obstinate, special detergent solutions may be necessary.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>28</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="patient-protection">Patient protection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Every radionuclide should be checked for activity before administration, using a radionuclide ('well') calibrator.</li>
<li>The patient's identity must be checked against the investigation to be made and the activity to be administered, and this must be recorded.</li>
<li>Particular care should be taken to avoid contamination during oral administrations.</li>
<li>Special circumstances apply for pregnant patients and those with babies they are breastfeeding.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dealing-with-a-radioactive-spill">Dealing with a radioactive spill<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dealing-with-a-radioactive-spill" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the case of a radioactive spill, vomiting, incontinence, etc.:</p>
<ol>
<li>Clear the area of non-essential persons.</li>
<li>Wearing gloves, aprons, and overshoes.</li>
<li>Mop the floor with absorbent pads and seal the swabs in designated plastic bags. If necessary, continue with wet swabs.</li>
<li>Continue until monitoring shows the activity to be at a satisfactorily low level.</li>
<li>If necessary, cordon off the area or cover it with impervious sheeting until sufficient decay has occurred.</li>
<li>Contaminated materials are treated as waste.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disposal-of-radioactive-waste">Disposal of radioactive waste:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disposal-of-radioactive-waste" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These follow the two principles of:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="containment-and-decay-and">Containment and decay; and<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#containment-and-decay-and" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dilution-by-dispersal-to-the-environment">Dilution by dispersal to the environment.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dilution-by-dispersal-to-the-environment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Special rules and authorizations cover the accumulation, storage, and disposal of radioactive waste.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Every hospital is subject to strict limitations on the amount which can be disposed of by each of the following routes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Gaseous waste can be vented to the atmosphere:
In lung ventilation studies, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>133</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{133}\mathrm{Xe}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">133</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Xe</span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{99\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Tc}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span></span></span></span></span> aerosols should be exhausted to the exterior of the building; this is not necessary with the very short-lived <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>81</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{81\mathrm{m}}\mathrm{Kr}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Kr</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aqueous liquid waste → well diluted with water → disposed of via designated sinks or sluices with drains running direct to the foul drain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Solid waste (swabs, syringes, bottles, etc.) → placed in designated sacks for disposal by incineration or, if suitably diluted with ordinary waste, to waste disposal sites.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Old generators are kept in a secure shielded store until they are returned to the manufacturer.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Contaminated clothing and bedding is appropriately bagged and stored in a secure protected area until sufficiently decayed for release to the laundry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Records must be kept, for inspection, of all deliveries, stocks, administration, stored waste, and disposals of waste.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiation-hazards-protection">Radiation Hazards &amp; Protection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-hazards-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ionizing-radiation-interaction-with-tissue">IONIZING RADIATION INTERACTION WITH TISSUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ionizing-radiation-interaction-with-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Absorption of radiation energy in tissue → biological damage (radiation hazards)</li>
<li>If X-ray passes through tissues unabsorbed, no biological effect will take place.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="when-radiation-absorption-takes-place">When radiation absorption takes place:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#when-radiation-absorption-takes-place" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Chemical changes (immediate)</li>
<li>Subsequent molecular damage (seconds or minutes)</li>
<li>Biological damage (hours to decades)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examples-of-radiation-induced-damage">Examples of radiation induced damage:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-radiation-induced-damage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Skin and hands (occurring to radiologists)</li>
<li>Leukemias → seen in patients treated with radiation for ankylosing spondylitis.</li>
<li>Radiation accidents (Hiroshima, Chernobyl)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The current estimates of radiation risk mostly derived from the outcomes of nuclear explosions (esp. 90 000 survivors in Hiroshima &amp; Nagasaki)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-medical-radiation">Types of medical radiation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-medical-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Particles (beta particles, neutrons)</li>
<li>Electromagnetic radiations (X and Gamma rays)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle-sources-of-radiation-in-medicine">Principle sources of radiation in medicine:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-sources-of-radiation-in-medicine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>X-ray</li>
<li>Nuclear medicine</li>
<li>Radiotherapy (including β-emitters, X-rays &amp; others).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effect-of-particulates-radiation">Effect of particulates radiation:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-particulates-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When electrons or β-particles pass through tissue → repeated ionizations &amp; excitations till particle completely loose its energy &amp; comes to rest.</li>
<li>The particles have very tortuous path in the tissue (very light → easily deflected by the negatively charged orbital electrons of tissue atoms).</li>
<li>The total range of interactions is very short (several millimeters)</li>
<li>Electrons &amp; particles radiations are easily deflected by a shield of several millimeters of perspex.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="effect-of-x-and-gamma-rays">Effect of X and Gamma rays<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effect-of-x-and-gamma-rays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>They do not have a maximum depth of penetration because:</p>
<ul>
<li>They undergo progressive attenuation as they go deeper in tissue</li>
<li>Their intensity (energy) decreases all the time (as they get attenuated), but never falls to zero → never give up all their energy completely (unlike electrons).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ionization">IONIZATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ionization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ionization is the causes of majority of radiation immediate chemical changes.</li>
<li>Proteins (e.g. enzymes) and nucleic acids (mainly DNA) are most sensitive for ionization (critical tissues)</li>
<li>Damage occurs in 2 ways:</li>
<li>Direct rupture of a covalent bond of a molecule</li>
<li>Indirectly "more common", by interaction between the molecules and the free radicals (that are produced during ionization of tissue water)</li>
</ul>
<p>Those changes occur in microseconds or less after exposure</p>
<p>How indirect damage happens:</p>
<p>Ionization of water molecule:</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O} +</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mord">+</span></span></span></span></span>  radiation  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mo>−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}^+ +\mathrm{e}^-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9213em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">e</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>This results in a positively charged water ion &amp; a free electron.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9213em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  decomposes  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{OH}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8547em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9213em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  decomposes into hydrogen ion  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and hydroxyl free radical  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{OH}^-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>The OH is highly reactive and powerful OXIDIZING agent to tissues  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  chemical modifications in organic molecules of the tissues.</p>
<p>Damages occur at a variety of levels:</p>
<p>Molecular level (DNA, RNA and enzymes) or
Subcellular level (cell membrane, nuclei, chromosomes) or
Cellular level (cell division inhibition, cell death &amp; malignant transformation)</p>
<p>Cell repair may occur (if enough time for recovery left between irradiation events)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-aa4aca2d.jpeg" alt="img-159.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiation-quantities-and-units">RADIATION QUANTITIES AND UNITS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-quantities-and-units" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-5ea16b06.jpeg" alt="img-160.jpeg"></p>
<p>For each tissue estimate the ABSORBED DOSE (in mSv) given to each tissue or organ
Then multiply it by Radiation Weighting Factor (specific for each radiation), to obtain the EQUIVALENT DOSE in mSv.
Multiply it by Tissue weighting factor to obtain WEIGHTED EQUIVALENT DOSE
Sum the WEIGHTED EQUIVALENT DOSE of all exposed tissues, to obtain the EFFECTIVE DOSE in mSv.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>▹</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangleright</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4653em;"></span><span class="mord">▹</span></span></span></span></span>  Equivalent dose for tissue or organ takes in account of the TYPE of radiation to determine radiation quantity.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>▹</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangleright</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4653em;"></span><span class="mord">▹</span></span></span></span></span>  Radiation weighting factor is indication of the effectiveness of radiation type, compared with that of electrons in inducing cancer at low doses and low dose rates.</p>
<ul>
<li>In X- &amp; Gamma rays,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">W</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">F</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{RWF} = 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">RWF</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>  (both absorbed by 2ry electrons production).</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∴</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\therefore</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mrel amsrm">∴</span></span></span></span></span>  In most medical applications, Absorbed dose = Equivalent dose</p>
<ul>
<li>In high energy neutrons and alpha particles (Heavy particles),  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{RW}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf" style="margin-right: 0.01597em;">RW</span></span></span></span></span></span>  Factor  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= 20</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span></span>  → as their energy is completely deposited in much shorter range.</li>
<li>In low energy neutrons,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold">R</mi><mi mathvariant="bold">W</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{RW}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf" style="margin-right: 0.01597em;">RW</span></span></span></span></span></span>  Factor  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= 5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span></span></span></span></span> .</li>
</ul>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>▹</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\triangleright</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4653em;"></span><span class="mord">▹</span></span></span></span></span>  1Sv = 1 J/kg (unit of equivalent and absorbed doses)
If a person is uniformly irradiated, by X or Gamma rays,</p>
<p>the whole body absorbed dose  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span>  Equivalent dose.</p>
<p>This occurs in occupational exposures &amp; usually expressed in  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mu \mathrm{Sv}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Sv</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="effective-dose">EFFECTIVE DOSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#effective-dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Used to compare the risk from one procedure to the other.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Effective (whole body) dose is calculated to give effective risk (independent on uniformity of exposure of whole body)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  It is calculated by</p>
<p>The sum of (each organ equivalent dose  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">X</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07847em;">X</span></span></span></span></span>  its organ weighted factor wt)</p>
<p>Table 6.3a ICRP (1991) tissue weighting factors</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Tissue</th><th>WT for each tissue</th><th>Σ WT</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Gonads</td><td>0.20</td><td>0.20</td></tr><tr><td>Colon, lung, red bone marrow, stomach</td><td>0.12</td><td>0.48</td></tr><tr><td>Bladder, breast, liver, esophagus, thyroid</td><td>0.05</td><td>0.25</td></tr><tr><td>Bone, skin</td><td>0.01</td><td>0.02</td></tr><tr><td>Remainder - each of 5 organs / tissues</td><td>0.01</td><td>0.05</td></tr><tr><td>Total</td><td></td><td>1.00</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>ICRP = International Commission on Radiological Protection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="somatic-and-genetic-effects-of-ionizing-radiation">SOMATIC AND GENETIC EFFECTS OF IONIZING RADIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somatic-and-genetic-effects-of-ionizing-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genetic">GENETIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genetic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\circ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">∘</span></span></span></span></span>  Occurs in the offspring of the exposed person (due to affection of germinal cells)
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\circ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">∘</span></span></span></span></span>  Difficult to assess.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\circ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">∘</span></span></span></span></span>  Statistically, frequency of occurrence of genetic effect in case of irradiated parents is no much different compared with case of non irradiated parents.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\circ</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4445em;"></span><span class="mord">∘</span></span></span></span></span>  The risk of hereditary ill-health in subsequent children without irradiation is 70000 cases \ a million</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  The risk increase only by 10 extra cases in parents exposed to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \mathrm{mGy}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mGy</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>4</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="somatic">SOMATIC:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#somatic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in exposed person</li>
<li>Divided into: Deterministic effects &amp; Stochastic effects</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="deterministic-effects">DETERMINISTIC EFFECTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deterministic-effects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>They can be measured according to dose, individually considered.</p>
<ul>
<li>Occurs on <strong>high doses</strong> (e.g. radiation accidents) → unlikely in diagnostic radiology.</li>
<li><strong>Threshold dose</strong> applies here. However, may be different from person to another</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Examples:</strong></p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Effect</th><th>Threshold</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>CATARACT</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>One of the highest deterministic risks.</td><td>5 Sv</td></tr><tr><td>CT can give very high eye doses.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>SKIN DAMAGE (erythema and dry desquamation)</td><td>4 Sv</td></tr><tr><td>Seen in interventional radiology</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>BONE MARROW CELL LOSS (aplastic anaemia, not leukaemia)</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>GONADS</td><td>1 Sv → measurable effect.</td></tr><tr><td>4 Sv → sterility</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>MYXOEDEMA (due to affection of thyroid, leading to malfunction)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>In general, <strong>thresholds are greater than 500 mSv</strong> (not common in radiology practice)</li>
<li>Biological changes can't be identified in <strong>less than 50 mSv</strong>.</li>
<li><strong>The amount of radiation damage &amp; Severity of the effect increases with radiation dose</strong> (beyond the threshold),</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Also with:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>The volume of tissue irradiated.</li>
<li>The rate at which dose is given.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Dividing the dose on several events, will eliminate deterministic effect i.e. <strong>NON CUMULATIVE</strong> (except in <strong>the lens</strong>, as it has no repair mechanism, so cataract effect is CUMULATIVE)</li>
<li>A dose given to a single organ (exceeding the threshold), will cause certain effects, but if the SAME dose given to the whole body, effect is different, the effects might not occur.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Lethal Dose:</strong> the dose that will cause 50% of the irradiated persons to die in 30 days from exposure. (MCQ)</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>LD50/30</mtext><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext>&nbsp;Sv&nbsp;whole&nbsp;body&nbsp;dose</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{LD50/30} = 5 \text{ Sv whole body dose}.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">LD50/30</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">&nbsp;Sv&nbsp;whole&nbsp;body&nbsp;dose</span></span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>10 Sv whole body dose → 100% lethal to humans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stochastic-effects-statistical">STOCHASTIC EFFECTS (STATISTICAL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stochastic-effects-statistical" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Of real concern regarding <strong>diagnostic radiology</strong></li>
<li><strong>Probability of occurrence</strong> increases with dose (MCQ) → not severity.</li>
<li><strong>No threshold dose</strong>, thus, cancer may be induced even with small radiation doses</li>
<li>Cancer occurrence takes a <strong>latent period</strong> to occur, ranging from few years (e.g. Leukemia) to up to 40 years in some solid tumors "may be not expressed within lifetime of recipients".</li>
<li><strong>Basal cell carcinoma</strong> is an example of stochastic effects.</li>
<li><strong>Children are more sensitive than adults</strong> "3 times more sensitive → as they have longer years to live, increasing the probability of occurrence of cancer).</li>
</ul>
<p>5</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="probability-coefficient-for-tissue-at-risk">Probability coefficient for tissue at risk<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#probability-coefficient-for-tissue-at-risk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The total risk of inducing a determinant effect in UK population of all age &amp; both sexes which exposed to whole body irradiation of low doses at low dose rate = 2% per Sr whole body equivalent dose = 70 / million /1 mSv.</p>
<p>Each individual organ has probability coefficient for cancer induction → Table 6.1</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="population-exposure-in-uk">Population exposure in UK<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#population-exposure-in-uk" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Natural background radiation in UK (annual per capita value for all radiation sources) = 2.6 mSv (MCQ)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7118c330.jpeg" alt="img-161.jpeg"></p>
<p>The amount of background radiation depends on the place, amount of natural resources, what the food is &amp; local geology.</p>
<ul>
<li>2.2 mSv comes from natural radiation</li>
<li>Radon gas is the largest contributor 1.3 mSv (but can range from negligible to 50 mSv/year)
× Radioactive gas, results from the decay of uranium.
× Emits alpha-particles.</li>
<li>Gamma rays from the ground and buildings 350 μSv</li>
<li>Food and drinks (from natural long lived Radionuclides "mostly ⁴⁰K") 300 μSv</li>
<li>Cosmic radiation (frequent air travelers double their overall dose) 260 μSv</li>
<li>Only 0.4 from artificial sources (including medical)</li>
<li>Medical radiation is the largest share of the artificial radiation (0.37 mSv)</li>
<li>Medical radiation is about 14% of the total background radiation (MCQ)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="in-mcq-take-care">In MCQ, take care:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-mcq-take-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Background radiation = 2.6 mSv
Natural Background radiation = 2.2 mSv
Man-made "Artificial" Background radiation = 0.4 mSv</p>
<p>6</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiation-protection-principles">RADIATION PROTECTION PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-protection-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Proposed by international commission of radiological protection (ICRP).</li>
<li>Composed of 3 fundamental principles: Justification – Optimization – Limitations.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="justification">JUSTIFICATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#justification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The benefit of radiological exposure should be greater than risk</li>
<li>Means that any medical practice must be justified both as general procedure &amp; as regards the individual patient</li>
</ul>
