<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ir-me-r-6-justification-of-individual-medical-exposures">IR(ME)R 6- Justification of Individual Medical Exposures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ir-me-r-6-justification-of-individual-medical-exposures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="no-person-shall-carry-out-a-medical-exposure-unless">No person shall carry out a medical exposure unless -<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#no-person-shall-carry-out-a-medical-exposure-unless" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) It has been justified by the practitioner as showing a sufficient net benefit over risks, as regarding:</p>
<p>i. Objective of exposure.
ii. Total potential diagnostic &amp; therapeutic benefits.
iii. The individual detriment that the exposure may cause.
iv. The efficacy, benefits &amp; risk of alternative techniques "having less exposure".</p>
<p>(b) It has been authorized by the practitioner (or by operator according to the practitioner guidelines).</p>
<p>(c) In the case of a person voluntarily participating in medical or biomedical exposure → approved by a Local Research Ethics Committee; and</p>
<p>(d) In the case of exposures for medico-legal purposes → it complies with the employer's procedures for such exposures.</p>
<p>(e) In the case of a female of childbearing age:</p>
<p>i. Has he enquired whether she is pregnant or breastfeeding.
ii. The practitioner shall justify the urgency of exposure.
iii. Special care is essential for examinations involving the abdominal &amp; pelvic areas.</p>
<p>(f) The practitioner takes account of any data supplied by the referrer to avoid unnecessary exposure.</p>
<ul>
<li>Regarding Justification of exposures:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Some exposures are easier to justify than others.</li>
<li>some are unjustified (e.g. Mammography screening in 20-30 years old well women)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="when-does-a-radiological-procedure-considered-unjustified">When does a radiological procedure considered unjustified?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#when-does-a-radiological-procedure-considered-unjustified" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>If harm from the exposure exceeds its benefit.</li>
<li>If the patient undergoes the same radiological examination recently for the same condition in another hospital → every effort must be done to get the films &amp; reports.</li>
<li>If the diagnosis can be made using other technique (e.g. MRI).</li>
<li>If the procedure won't contribute to the patients management (e.g. Coccydynia)</li>
</ol>
<p>7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="special-cases">Special cases:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-cases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Introducing radiopharmaceutical to a <em>breast feeding woman</em> (breast feeding may need to be interrupted or stopped).</li>
<li>Female patients in the reproductive period of life "pregnant or might be pregnant"</li>
<li>Applies to radiographic examination of any area between the knee &amp; diaphragm and to Radionuclide injection.</li>
<li>This justification follows the "28 day rule" → based on the principle that there is little or no risk to live born child from irradiation during the first 3 weeks of gestation (i.e. before first missed period), except from high-dose procedures (Baenema &amp; Pelviabdominal CT).</li>
<li>Within the first 3 weeks of the gestation, the dose equivalent to a fetus not to exceed 5 mSv.</li>
</ul>
<p>The risk of inducing cancer with this dose is 1/1000, which is same as the natural prevalence of malignancy &lt; 10 years.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-56663b33.jpeg" alt="img-162.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.5 Radiation protection of patients who are or might be pregnant.</p>
<p>OPTIMIZATION</p>
<p>8</p>
<p>For staff and visitors.
Effective Dose should be AS LOW AS REASONBALLY PRACTICABLE (ALARP)</p>
<p>For Patients.
Radiological exposure should be as low as compatible with diagnostic information → achieved by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Reducing number of images (films taken)</li>
<li>Reduce absorbed dose for every exposure</li>
<li>Quality assurance system → including periodic measurement of the patient dose.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 6.4 gives guide for Practical measures for the reduction of patient dose</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 6.4 Practical measures for the reduction of patient dose</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(A) Some dose-saving equipment</td></tr><tr><td>1. Fast screen-film combinations (e.g. rare earth)</td></tr><tr><td>2. Low attenuation (e.g. carbon fiber) materials for cassette fronts, antiscatter grid interspacing, table tops.</td></tr><tr><td>3. Constant potential generators with appropriate kilovoltage</td></tr><tr><td>4. Appropriate beam filtration (minimum 2.5 mm Al for general radiography)</td></tr><tr><td>5. Specialized equipment for mammography and pediatrics</td></tr><tr><td>6. Pulsed and frame-hold (image storage) fluoroscopy equipment.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Digital radiography equipment.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Dose-area product meter to monitor patient exposure.</td></tr><tr><td>(B) Some dose-saving techniques</td></tr><tr><td>1. Use smallest possible field size and good collimation.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Collimate to exclude radiosensitive organs (gonads, breasts, eyes).</td></tr><tr><td>3. When gonads lie outside the primary beam, make distance between the edge of the field and the gonads as large as possible.</td></tr><tr><td>4. Shield breasts, eyes, and gonads unless the area of interest would be masked. Dose to ovary can be halved and that to testes reduced by a factor of 20.</td></tr><tr><td>5. Use largest practicable focus to skin distance: never less than 30 cm, especially in mobile radiography.</td></tr><tr><td>6. Position the patient carefully. Reduce the dose to the female breast and, in skull radiography, to the eye by postero-anterior projection. Minimize the gap between patient and film-screen.</td></tr><tr><td>7. Use compression of patient where possible.</td></tr><tr><td>8. Use non-grid techniques when examining children and small adults.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Keep film reject rate due to all causes down to 5%. Check the factors before exposure. Quality assurance, particularly of automatic processors, is important</td></tr><tr><td>10. In fluoroscopy use the minimal field size and minimal screening time essential for good diagnosis.</td></tr><tr><td>11. Use zoom or small field techniques, which require a higher dose rate, with discretion</td></tr><tr><td>(C) High-risk examinations</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>9</p>
<ol>
<li>Keep pediatric radiation doses to an absolute minimum consistent with adequate diagnosis as children up to the age of 10 years are believed to be 3-4 times more radiosensitive than adults.</li>
<li>In pelvimetry: use MRI or CT scanography where possible; otherwise use fast rare earth screens and carbon fiber components</li>
<li>Mammography is not generally performed on women younger than 50 years unless there is a family history of breast cancer or the patient has related symptoms.</li>
<li>In CT scanning, take the minimum number of slices, position the patient to avoid the eyes and other critical organs; reduce milliamperage if appropriate, e.g. for the chest</li>
<li>Patients who are or might be pregnant; see Fig. 6.5.</li>
<li>Interventional radiology needs care to avoid skin reactions; use pulsed and frame-hold systems: minimize screening times</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IR(ME)R 7- Optimization:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>In relation to all medical exposures except radiotherapeutic procedures, the practitioner and the operator</strong>, shall ensure that doses arising from the exposure are kept as low as reasonably practicable (ALARP)</li>
<li><strong>In relation to exposures for radiotherapeutic purposes</strong>, the practitioner shall ensure that:
i. Exposures of target volumes are individually planned.
ii. Dose to non-target volumes shall is as low as reasonably practicable (ALARP)</li>
<li><strong>for each medical exposure</strong>, the operator shall select equipment and methods to ensure that:
i. Dose of IR to the individual undergoing the exposure is ALARP.
ii. Dose is consistent with the intended diagnostic or therapeutic purpose.
iii. special attention to -
(a) quality assurance;
(b) assessment of patient dose or administered activity; and
(c) adherence to diagnostic reference levels.</li>
<li><strong>For each medical or biomedical research programme</strong>, the employer's procedures shall provide that -</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>the individuals concerned participate voluntarily.</li>
<li>the individuals are informed in advance about the risks of exposure;</li>
<li><strong>if volunteers have no direct medical benefit from the exposure</strong> → the dose constraint set down in the employer's procedures is adhered to.</li>
<li><strong>if volunteers are patients expected to receive a diagnostic or therapeutic benefit</strong> → individual target levels of doses are planned by the practitioner.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>In the case of patients undergoing treatment or diagnosis with radioactive</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>10</p>
<p><strong>medicinal products</strong>, the employer's procedures shall provide written instructions and information to the patient, to consent to the treatment or diagnostic procedure; The instructions and information referred to shall -</p>
<ol>
<li>set out the risks associated with ionising radiation; and</li>
<li>specify how doses resulting from the patient's exposure can be restricted as far as reasonably possible so as to protect persons in contact with the patient;</li>
<li>be provided to the patient prior to the patient leaving the hospital.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>the practitioner and the operator shall pay special attention to</strong> -</li>
</ul>
<p>a) the need to keep doses arising from medico-legal exposures as low as reasonably practicable;
b) medical exposures of children;
c) medical exposures for health screening programme;
d) medical exposures involving high doses to the patient;
e) females in whom pregnancy cannot be excluded and who are undergoing a medical exposure, in particular if abdominal and pelvic regions are involved, taking into account the exposure of both the expectant mother and the unborn child; and
f) females who are breastfeeding and who are undergoing exposures in nuclear medicine, taking into account the exposure of both the female and the child.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The employer shall take steps to ensure that a clinical evaluation of the outcome of each medical exposure is recorded, including factors relevant to patient dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>In the case of fluoroscopy</strong> -</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>(a) no person shall carry out an examination without an image intensification or equivalent technique.
(b) the operator shall ensure that examinations without devices to control the dose rate are limited to justified circumstances; and</p>
<p><strong>IRR (1999), 8- Restriction of exposure</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>It's the duty of the Employer to take all necessary steps to restrict the exposure of his employees and other persons to ionising radiation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Steps for restriction of IR exposure:</strong> -</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>(1) Engineering controls and design features.
(2) The use of safety features and warning devices.
(3) Systems of work.
(4) Provide employees with personal protective equipment (including respiratory protective equipment) &amp; ensure its adequate maintenance &amp; regular testing.
(5) Using dose constraints.
(6) Taking steps to ensure that PPE &amp; system of work are properly used or applied by employee.</p>
<ul>
<li>Radiation employer shall ensure, that -</li>
</ul>
<p>(a) For pregnant employee,</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  after her employer has been notified of the pregnancy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the equivalent dose to the foetus is unlikely to exceed 1mSv during the remainder of the pregnancy; and</p>
<p>(b) For breastfeeding employee,</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  exposure is restricted to prevent bodily contamination.</p>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall ensure that an investigation is carried out when the effective dose of ionising radiation received by any of his employees for the first time in any calendar year exceeds  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15\mathrm{mSv}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mSv</span></span></span></span></span></span>  or as specified in writing in local rules.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="limitation">LIMITATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#limitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Legal dose limits for workers &amp; members of public should ensure:</p>
<ol>
<li>No deterministic effects.</li>
<li>Reasonably low probability of stochastic effect.</li>
</ol>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\times</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">×</span></span></span></span></span>  Limitation of patient dose  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  limits are not appropriate for patient dose, however Reference values indicate levels above which exposure should be reviewed (section 6.7)</p>
<p>See table 6.5 - Dose limits for staff &amp; visitors.
Table 6.5 Current UK dose limits (1985 Regulations)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Staff "classified"</th><th>Dose limit (mSv)</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Trainees aged 16-18 years</td><td>Public, visitors</td></tr><tr><td>Whole body</td><td>20</td><td>6</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>Eyes</td><td>150</td><td>50</td><td>15</td></tr><tr><td>Extremities and other organs</td><td>500</td><td>150</td><td>50</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The annual (whole body) dose limits for workers  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">= 20\mathrm{mSv}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mSv</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>12</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-bee85644.jpeg" alt="img-163.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.4 Radiation protection principles applied to medical diagnostic procedures.</p>
<p>13</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="dose-limitation">Dose limitation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose-limitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regulation-11-irr-1999">Regulation 11 (IRR 1999) -<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation-11-irr-1999" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall ensure that his employees are not exposed to ionising radiation exceeding any dose limit in any calendar year.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schedule-4-regulation-11">SCHEDULE 4-Regulation 11<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-4-regulation-11" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dose-limits-part-1">DOSE LIMITS Part 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dose-limits-part-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="employees-of-18-years-of-age-or-above">Employees of 18 years of age or above<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#employees-of-18-years-of-age-or-above" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Effective dose limit is <strong>20 mSv</strong> in any calendar year.</li>
<li>Equivalent dose limit in a calendar year,</li>
<li>a) for the lens of the eye is <strong>150 mSv</strong>;</li>
<li>b) for the skin is <strong>500 mSv</strong> "applied to the dose averaged over 1cm² regardless of the area exposed";</li>
<li>c) for the hands, forearms, feet and ankles is <strong>500 mSv</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="trainees-aged-under-18-years">Trainees aged under 18 years<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trainees-aged-under-18-years" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Effective dose limit is <strong>6 mSv</strong> in any calendar year.</li>
<li>Equivalent dose limit in a calendar year,</li>
<li>d) for the lens of the eye is <strong>50 mSv</strong>;</li>
<li>e) for the skin is <strong>150 mSv</strong> "applied to the dose averaged over 1cm² regardless of the area exposed";</li>
<li>f) for the hands, forearms, feet and ankles is <strong>150 mSv</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="women-of-reproductive-capacity">Women of reproductive capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#women-of-reproductive-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Equivalent dose limit from external radiation for the abdomen of a woman employee of reproductive capacity → <strong>13 mSv</strong> in any consecutive period of three months.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="other-persons">Other persons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-persons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Any person other than an employee or trainee</strong> including any person below the age of 16 → Effective dose limit is <strong>1 mSv</strong> in any calendar year.</p>
<p><strong>Any person (not being a comforter or carer) who may be exposed to ionising radiation resulting from the medical exposure of another</strong> → the effective dose limit on is <strong>5 mSv</strong> in any period of 5 consecutive calendar years.</p>
<p>&amp; for both:</p>
<ul>
<li>Equivalent dose limit in a calendar year,</li>
<li>g) for the lens of the eye is <strong>15 mSv</strong>;</li>
<li>h) for the skin is <strong>50 mSv</strong> "applied to the dose averaged over 1cm² regardless of the area exposed";</li>
<li>i) for the hands, forearms, feet and ankles is <strong>50 mSv</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="occupational-exposure-of-fertile-woman">Occupational exposure of fertile woman<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#occupational-exposure-of-fertile-woman" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Female staff shouldn't be exposed to more than <strong>1mSv per month</strong></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="occupational-exposure-of-pregnant-woman">Occupational exposure of pregnant woman<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#occupational-exposure-of-pregnant-woman" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>From declaration of pregnancy, a female staff shouldn't receive more than <strong>1 mSv</strong> through out the remainder of pregnancy time.</li>
<li>This would mean a max. dose to fetus = <strong>0.6 mSv</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p>14</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reg-11-2">Reg. 11(2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reg-11-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Where an employer is able to demonstrate in respect of any employee that the dose limit specified above is impracticable (20 mSv in any calendar year for any employee of 18 years of age or above) having regard to the nature of the work undertaken by the employee, the employer may apply the dose limits set out Part II of Schedule4 in respect of that employee.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schedule-4-part-ii">Schedule 4-PART II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-4-part-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-employees-of-18-years-or-above">For employees of 18 years or above:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-employees-of-18-years-or-above" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Effective dose limit is 100 mSv in any 5 consecutive calendar years.</li>
<li>Maximum effective dose of 50 mSv in any single calendar year</li>
<li>Equivalent dose limit in a calendar year,</li>
<li>for the lens of the eye is 150 mSv;</li>
<li>for the skin is 500 mSv "applied to the dose averaged over 1cm² regardless of the area exposed";</li>
<li>for the hands, forearms, feet and ankles is 500 mSv.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="women-of-reproductive-capacity">Women of reproductive capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#women-of-reproductive-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Equivalent dose limit from external radiation for the abdomen of a woman employee of reproductive capacity → 13 mSv in any consecutive period of three months.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="for-employees-under-18-years-it-is-not-allowed-to-use-this-system-of-dose-limits">For employees under 18 years: it is not allowed to use this system of dose limits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#for-employees-under-18-years-it-is-not-allowed-to-use-this-system-of-dose-limits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>However, the employer shall not put this system into effect unless he do the following provisions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Consult the RPA.</li>
<li>Consult &amp; inform in writing any employees who are affected;</li>
<li>Inform in writing the approved dosimetry service; and</li>
<li>Give notice to the Executive at least 28 days before the decision is put into effect giving the reasons for the decision.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>If the Executive is not satisfied that it is impracticable for that employee → require the employer to apply the dose limit specified in Part 1.</li>
<li>Any person who is aggrieved by the decision of the Executive may appeal to the Secretary of State.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="other-important-precautions">Other important precautions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-important-precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Employer shall review the decision to use this system of dose limitation at appropriate intervals → at least once every five years.
if as a result of a review, an employer proposes to revert to a system of annual dose limitation → he shall do the pervious provisions again</li>
<li>The employer shall record the reasons for that decision → keep for 50 years.</li>
<li>If &gt; 20 mSv given in a year → employer must undertake investigations &amp; notify HSE.</li>
</ul>
<p>15</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="n-b-dose-limits-for-fluoroscopy">N.B.: Dose limits for Fluoroscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#n-b-dose-limits-for-fluoroscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>For staff working in fluoroscopy, the D.I.L. "dose investigation level" is:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 6 mSv a year effective dose</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 300 µSv a month under-apron dose</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 5500 µSv a month over-apron dose</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× Hand dose of 7.5 mSv a month</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>For pregnant staff:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 1 mSv during declared term,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 125 µSv a month under-apron</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>× 1500 µSv a month over-apron</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Dose limits are not like a speed limit.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Doses <em>must</em> be as low as is reasonably practicable (ALARP)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dose constraints used in design</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>e.g. 0.3 mSv for members of public,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>5 mSv for comforters and carers (1mSv if pregnant)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Foetus limit: 1 mSv from notification of pregnancy by employee</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Need formal investigation levels for staff</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Do not apply to medical exposures</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In practice, staff members generally receive doses less than 3 mSv/year</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Even interventional radiologists SHOULD NOT exceed 30% of the occupational dose limit/year</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>See figure 6.6 page 162 for the dose distribution among personnel in radiodiagnosis department.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-4cb767e9.jpeg" alt="img-164.jpeg">
Fig. 6.6 Typical dose distributions among personnel in radiodiagnostic imaging departments.</p>
<p>16</p>
<p>× Staff who likely to exceed 30% of any annual dose limits for workers is considered "CLASSIFIED" (e.g. &gt; 6 mSv whole body dose) → Health &amp; Radiation monitoring is statutory.
“ They must subject to regular medical surveillance by an appointed doctor.
“ Monitored by dosimetry services 'approved' by HSE.
“ Their records are kept centrally in the Central Index of Dose Information operated by HSE for 50 years.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>IRR (1999); 20- Designation of classified persons:</strong></p>
<p><strong>Def:</strong> any employees who are likely to receive:</p>
<ol>
<li>Effective dose &gt; 6mSv per year; or</li>
<li>Equivalent dose &gt; 3/10 of any relevant dose limit.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The employer is responsible for such designation &amp; shall inform those employees that they have been so designated.</li>
<li>The employee designated as a classified person must be:-</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>aged 18 years or over; and</li>
<li>fit for the work with ionising radiation as certified by an appointed doctor or employment medical adviser in his health record.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The employer may cease to treat an employee as a classified person only at the end of a calendar year except if -</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>An appointed doctor or employment medical adviser so requires; or</li>
<li>The employee is no longer employed by the same employer or will work in a position which is not likely to result in significant exposure.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Differences between classified and other staff working in controlled areas are outlined in table 6.6 page 166 Farr book</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Table 6.6 Differences between classified and other staff working in controlled areas</strong></p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Classified</th><th>Not classified</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Annual effective dose limit</td><td>20 mSv</td><td>6 mSv</td></tr><tr><td>Personal monitoring</td><td>Required</td><td>Preferable</td></tr><tr><td>Follow 'system of work'</td><td>Preferable</td><td>Required</td></tr><tr><td>Medical surveillance</td><td>Required</td><td>Not required</td></tr><tr><td>Radiation passbook</td><td>Required for 'outside' work</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<hr>
<p><strong>IRR(1999); 24- Medical surveillance</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Who needs medical surveillance:</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Classified persons.</li>
<li>Employee received over-exposure but not classified persons.</li>
<li>Employee seen fit to work in IR under conditions set by the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The employer shall ensure that each of his employees (mentioned above) is under adequate medical surveillance (at least once yearly) by an appointed doctor or employment medical adviser → to determine the fitness of each employee for the work with ionising radiation.</li>
</ul>
<p>17</p>
<ul>
<li>PARTICULARS TO BE CONTAINED IN A HEALTH RECORD:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The employee's → full name; sex; date of birth; address; and National Insurance number;</li>
<li>The date in which the employee's designated as a classified person in present employment;</li>
<li>The nature of the employee's employment;</li>
<li>In the case of a female employee, a statement as to whether she is likely to receive in any consecutive period of three months an equivalent dose of ionising radiation for the abdomen exceeding 13 mSv;</li>
<li>The date of last medical examination;</li>
<li>The type of the last medical examination;</li>
<li>A statement by the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser made as a result of the last medical examination → classifying the employee as fit, fit subject to conditions (which should be specified) or unfit;</li>
<li>The name and signature of the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser in relation to each medical examination;</li>
<li>The name and address of the approved dosimetry service for maintaining the dose record.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The employer shall ensure that:
a) A health record for his employees is made and maintained.
b) That health record is kept until the person attained the age of 75 years &amp; for at least 50 years from the date of the last entry made in it.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The employer shall ensure that there is a valid entry in the health record of each classified employee made by an appointed doctor or employment medical adviser</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An entry in the health record shall be valid for 12 months from the date it was made or until cancelled by an appointed doctor or employment medical adviser by a further entry.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser has certified that employee should not be engaged in work with ionising radiation "unfit" or should only work under conditions he has specified in the health record "fit under conditions":
.: The employer shall not permit that employee to be engaged in the work with ionising radiation except in accordance with this conditions.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If an appointed doctor or employment medical adviser requires to inspect any workplace, the employer shall permit him to do so.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The employer shall make available to the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The summary of the dose record kept by the employer.</li>
<li>Other records as the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser may require.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>If an employee is aggrieved by a decision recorded in the health record by an appointed doctor or employment medical adviser:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Apply to the Executive in writing within 3 months of the date on which he was notified of the decision to be reviewed in accordance with a procedure approved by the Health and Safety Commission.</li>
<li>The result of that review shall be notified to the employee and entered in his health record.</li>
</ol>
<p>18</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="21-dose-assessment-and-recording">21- Dose assessment and recording:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#21-dose-assessment-and-recording" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>“Assessment &amp; recording of all doses of ionising radiation received by employees designated as a classified person:</p>
<ul>
<li>Is the duty of every radiation employer.</li>
<li>Done through arrangements with an approved dosimetry service.</li>
<li>The employer shall provide the approved dosimetry service with such necessary information concerning classified employees.</li>
</ul>
<p>“Duties of approved dosimetry service regarding this is:</p>
<ol>
<li>The making of systematic assessments of the doses using suitable individual measurement for appropriate periods.</li>
<li>The making and maintenance of dose records for each classified person.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Keep the records until the classified person attained the age of 75 years &amp; for at least 50 years;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To provide the employer with:
a) Summaries of the dose records at appropriate intervals.
b) Copies of the dose record of any of his employees when required;
c) Copy of "Termination record" → a record of the information concerning the dose assessment of a classified person who ceases to be an employee of the employer → + send that record to the Executive;
d) A current radiation passbook for outside workers.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To provide the Executive with:
a) Termination record.
b) summaries of all current dose records of the year → within 3 months of the end of each calendar year;
c) copies of any dose records when required</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Make an entry in the dose record and retain the summary of the information used to estimate that dose in case of loss of dosimeter;</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>“An employer shall ensure that each outside worker employed by him is provided with a current individual radiation passbook.</p>
<p>&amp; ensure that the particulars entered in the radiation passbook are kept up-to-date as long as this outside employee works for him.</p>
<p>“PARTICULARS TO BE ENTERED IN THE RADIATION PASSBOOK (Schedule 6):</p>
<ol>
<li>Individual serial number of the passbook.</li>
<li>A statement that the passbook has been approved by the Executive.</li>
<li>Date of issue of the passbook.</li>
<li>The name, telephone number and mark of endorsement of the issuing approved dosimetry service.</li>
<li>The name, address, telephone and telex/fax number of the employer.</li>
<li>Full name, date of birth, gender and national insurance number of the outside worker to whom the passbook has been issued.</li>
<li>Date of the last medical review and the relevant classification in the health record → fit, fit subject to conditions (which shall be specified) or unfit.</li>
</ol>
<p>19</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>The relevant dose limits.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The cumulative dose assessment in mSv for the year to date for the outside worker, external (whole body, organ or tissue) and/or internal as appropriate and the date of the end of the last assessment period.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In respect of services performed by the outside worker -
(a) the name and address of the employer responsible for the controlled area;
(b) the period covered by the performance of the services;
(c) estimated dose information, which shall be -
(i) whole body effective dose in mSv;
(ii) the equivalent dose in mSv to organs and tissues in case of non-uniform exposure; and
(iii) an estimate of the activity taken in or the committed dose in case of internal contamination,.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>"The employer shall keep a copy of the summary of the dose record received from the approved dosimetry service for at least 2 years from the end of the calendar year to which the summary relates.</p>
<p>"The employer shall make available to the classified person at request -</p>
<ol>
<li>a copy of the dose summary record of 2 years preceding the request; and</li>
<li>a copy of the dose record of that person; and</li>
<li>a copy of termination record.</li>
</ol>
<p>HSE Nov. 01:
There has been a number of reported cases where employees have failed to take good care of their dosemeters. Many of these cases involve employees in the Health Services, some of whom have been senior clinicians.</p>
<p>"Non-Classified employees who have been provided with a dosemeter by their employer to ensure compliance with regulation 18 IRR99 have a duty to look after that dosemeter and return it for processing as required. Provided the employer has informed the employees of that duty and is exercising the appropriate level of supervision, employees who persistently fail to wear, look after or return their dosemeters promptly are liable to enforcement action by inspectors up to and including prosecution under Section 7 of the HSW Act 1974. Employers may find statement of this fact useful when dealing with 'errant' staff."</p>
<p>22- Estimated doses and special entries
In case of loss or damage of a dosemeter used to make any individual measurement under regulation 21 (i.e. not practicable to assess the dose received by a classified person over any period)</p>
<ul>
<li>Employer shall make an adequate investigation of:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The circumstances of the case.</li>
<li>A view to estimate the dose received by that person during that period.</li>
</ol>
<p>20</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If there is adequate information to estimate the dose received, Employer shall:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a) Send to the approved dosimetry service a summary of the information used to estimate that dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>b) Arrange for the approved dosimetry service to enter the estimated dose in the dose record of that person.
→ mentioned in the dose record as estimated dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>c) The employer shall not enter the estimated dose in the dose record except after the consent of the Executive if:
i. Recorded cumulative effective dose ≥ 20 mSv in one calendar year.
ii. Recorded cumulative equivalent dose ≥ any relevant dose limit in one calendar year</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>if there is inadequate information to estimate the dose received, Employer shall arrange for the approved dosimetry service to enter a notional dose in the dose record “i.e. proportion of the total annual dose limit for the relevant period”
→ mentioned in the dose record as a national dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In either case, the employer shall</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>a) Inform the classified person of the entry (either estimated or national dose).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>b) Make available at the request of the classified person → a copy of the summary sent to the approved dosimetry service.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>c) Make a report of any investigation → keep a copy for 2 years from the date it was made.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Objections on the estimated dose:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>If employer think the dose received by the classified person is &gt; or &lt; the relevant entry in the dose record → he shall make adequate investigation.</li>
</ul>
<p>But under 2 conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>before 12 month in case of classified person subject only to an annual dose limit.</li>
<li>before 5 yrs in any other case.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>If investigations confirms the belief of the employer, he shall:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Send to the approved dosimetry service a summary of the information used to estimate that dose.</li>
<li>Arrange for the approved dosimetry service to enter the estimated dose in the dose record of that person.
→ mentioned in the dose record as special entry.</li>
<li>Notify the classified person of the change.</li>
<li>Make a report of the investigation → keep a copy for 2 yrs.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If the classified person is aggrieved by this decision → apply to review this decision in writing to the Executive "within 3 months of the date on which he was notified of the decision".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the Executive concludes that -</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(a) The investigation was inadequate; or</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>(b) estimated dose is not reasonable,
The Executive shall direct the employer to re-instate the original entry in the dose record.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>21</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-protection-measures">OTHER PROTECTION MEASURES:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-protection-measures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radiologists and almost all radiology workers ARE NOT CLASSIFIED normally</li>
<li>According to LOCAL RULES, they however supposed to wear personal dosemeters when entering a controlled area</li>
</ul>
<p>N.B. it is not an absolute necessity, this is preferred but not must, but local rules in most places states so, note that the answer of the question:</p>
<p><strong>Radiologist SHOULD wear a dosemeter when entering fluoroscopy room.</strong></p>
<p>The answer is FALSE, because it is not SHOULD, although we all wear them in that case, but still not absolute necessity, if the word used in the question USUALLY, so the answer is TRUE.</p>
<p>&gt; Perhaps that example shows you the degree of sterility of the examination system!!</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="about-personal-monitors">About personal monitors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#about-personal-monitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Personal dosimeters are worn on the trunk, under the lead apron.</li>
<li>Additional monitors MAY BE worn on the forehead or neckband to monitor eye exposure, or fingers to monitor hand doses.</li>
<li>Body monitors are usually worn for 4 weeks</li>
<li>Commonest personal monitoring dosimeters are film badges or TLD.</li>
<li>Electronic dosimeters are used in high dose areas when an indication is needed to monitor at the same time of exposure (ex. Interventional procedures by pregnant radiologist)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="irr-1999-9-personal-protective-equipment">IRR(1999); 9-Personal protective equipment:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-9-personal-protective-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Any personal protective equipment shall comply with the Personal Protective Equipment (EC Directive) Regulations 1992.</li>
<li>Every radiation employer shall provide appropriate accommodation for personal protective equipment when it is not being worn.</li>
</ul>
<p>22</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="statutory-responsibilities-and-organizational-arrangements-for-radiation-protection">STATUTORY RESPONSIBILITIES AND ORGANIZATIONAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR RADIATION PROTECTION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statutory-responsibilities-and-organizational-arrangements-for-radiation-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>IRR1999 aims to Protection of staff and members of public.</li>
<li>IR(ME)R2000 aims to Protection of patients.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arrangements-for-the-management-of-radiation-protection">ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF RADIATION PROTECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrangements-for-the-management-of-radiation-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="irr-1999-13-radiation-protection-adviser">IRR(1999); 13- Radiation protection adviser<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-13-radiation-protection-adviser" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="matters-in-respect-of-which-a-radiation-protection-adviser-must-be-consulted-by-a-radiation-employer">MATTERS IN RESPECT OF WHICH A RADIATION PROTECTION ADVISER MUST BE CONSULTED BY A RADIATION EMPLOYER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#matters-in-respect-of-which-a-radiation-protection-adviser-must-be-consulted-by-a-radiation-employer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Advising to the observance of the Regulations</li>
<li>The implementation of requirements as to controlled and supervised areas.</li>
<li>For new or modified sources of ionising radiation → prior plans for installations and the acceptance into service "in relation to any engineering controls, design features, safety features and warning devices provided to restrict exposure to ionising radiation".</li>
<li>Regular checking of systems of work provided to restrict exposure to ionising radiation.</li>
<li>The regular calibration of equipment provided for monitoring IR levels and the regular checking that such equipment is serviceable and correctly used.</li>
<li>The periodic examination and testing of engineering controls, design features, safety features and warning devices.</li>
<li>Incidents where more than 6 mSv has been received.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>R.P.A. need not be appointed if only:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Very, small amounts of radioactive material (below specified levels)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Very low dose (&lt; 1μSv/h @ 10 cm) x-ray units of a design approved by HSE</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>VDUs with &lt; 1μSv/h @ 10 cm</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>&lt; 30 kV and &lt; 1μSv/h @ 10 cm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There should be a <strong>radiation protection advisor</strong> (RPA) in every radiological facility.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>RPA must have qualification approved by HSE (e.g. RPA2000 certificate).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The radiation employer shall appoint the radiation protection adviser in writing and shall include the advice needed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The radiation employer shall provide RPA with adequate information and facilities.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-information-instruction-and-training">14- Information, instruction and training<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-information-instruction-and-training" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall ensure that -
(1) <strong>his employees</strong> are given appropriate training, information and instruction in the field of radiation protection regarding:-</li>
<li>(a) the risks to health by exposure to ionising radiation;</li>
<li>(b) the precautions; and</li>
<li>(c) the importance of complying with the medical, technical and administrative requirements of these Regulations;</li>
</ul>
<p>23</p>
<p>(2) other persons concerned with the work with ionising radiation are given adequate information to ensure their health and safety; and
(3) female employees:</p>
<ul>
<li>Informed of the risk of ionising radiation to the fetus &amp; a nursing infant.</li>
<li>Informed of the importance of informing the employer in writing as soon as possible
(a) after becoming aware of their pregnancy; or
(b) if they are breast feeding.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>IRMER(11) Training for patient protection:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>No practitioner or operator shall carry out a medical exposure or any practical aspect without having been adequately trained (certificate issued by an institute shall be sufficient proof).</li>
<li>A person can participate in practical aspects of the procedure as part of practical training only under the supervision of adequately trained person.</li>
<li>The employer shall keep an up-to-date training record of all practitioners and operators engaged by him to carry out medical exposures or any practical aspect of such exposures available for inspection by the appropriate authority</li>
<li>Records should show the dates on which training was completed and the nature of the training.</li>
<li>Practitioner or operator employed by other employer → shall supply such records to the new employer upon request.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>PROTECTION OF STAFF &amp; MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC:</strong>
“Legislation is enacted to ensure that individual doses are as low as reasonably practicable (ALARP)
&amp; that people are unlikely to exceed a proportion of the dose limits.</p>
<p><strong>CONTROLLED AREAS:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Required as a further control when inherent shielding of the source (X-ray tube and radiopharmaceutical syringes) is not enough → the area around the shielded source is designated as a controlled area.</li>
<li>Controlled areas have physical boundaries that are able to prevent radiation penetration (above specific level).</li>
<li>Controlled area should be clearly defined boundaries.
This is simple to achieve in an x-ray room but more difficult with mobile X-ray set → where the controlled area is determined by eye as extending for 2 meters around tube.</li>
<li>Every diagnostic X-ray tube produces a large amount of radiation exposure
∴ has to be contained within a controlled area.</li>
<li>In nuclear medicine, area is defined controlled, wherever:</li>
<li>A generator is located, or</li>
<li>There is a syringe containing radiopharmaceutical.</li>
</ul>
<p>24</p>
<ul>
<li>Controlled area should have <strong>restricted access</strong> (to radiation workers &amp; others who work under "written system of work")</li>
<li>"<strong>Written system of work</strong>" organize work within controlled area to ensure that radiology workers can't receive dose &gt; 30% of any dose limit.</li>
<li><strong>Personal protection</strong> should take place within controlled area (e.g. 2.5 mm lead screens, lead rubber aprons and gloves, lead glasses, etc.)</li>
</ul>
<p>N.B. in practice, radiology and nuclear medicine staff receives doses below the public dose limit.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-7947452c.jpeg" alt="img-165.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="part-iv">PART IV<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-iv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="designated-areas">DESIGNATED AREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#designated-areas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="irr-1999-16-designation-of-controlled-or-supervised-areas">IRR(1999); 16- Designation of controlled or supervised areas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-16-designation-of-controlled-or-supervised-areas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall designate as <strong>a controlled area</strong> any area in which -</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Any person who enters or works in the area should follow special procedures to restrict significant exposure to ionising radiation in that area or prevent radiation accidents.</li>
<li>Any person working is likely to receive:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Effective dose &gt; 6 mSv / year.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Equivalent dose &gt; 3/10 of any relevant dose limit (Schedule 4) "for an employee aged 18 years or above".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>also ACOP says if</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>&gt; 7.5 µSv/h averaged over 8 h working day</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>&gt; 75 µSv/h to hands averaged over 8 h working day</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>contamination risk</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>need to keep non-radiation workers out</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>or &gt; 7.5 µSv/h averaged over 1 minute and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>site radiography, or</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>employees untrained in radiation protection enter area (unless radioactivity is dispersed inside a person)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This area should be under complete control of the employer before starting activities which require that area to be designated as a controlled area.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An employer shall designate as <strong>a supervised area</strong> any area which, not designated as a controlled area :-</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>25</p>
<ol>
<li>where it is necessary to keep the conditions of the area under review to determine if the area should be designated as a controlled area; or</li>
<li>Any person working is likely to receive:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Effective dose &gt; 1 mSv / year.</li>
<li>Equivalent dose &gt; 1/10 of any relevant dose limit (Schedule 4) "for an employee aged 18 years or above".</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Any Controlled or Supervised Area should be (as a duty of the employer):</strong>
i. Adequately described in local rules. "N.B. not in the 'System of work'...MCQ"
ii. Physical demarcation of the controlled area, with suitable warning signs.
iii. Display suitable &amp; sufficient signs in suitable positions indicating:</p>
<ul>
<li>The area is a controlled 'or supervised' area.</li>
<li>The nature of the radiation sources in the area.</li>
<li>The risks arising from such sources.
iv. Non-classified workers can only enter under written system of work.</li>
<li>Employer must demonstrate by personal dose monitoring or other means that dose is restricted.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>17- Local rules and radiation protection supervisors:</strong>
<em>Def.:</em> Local interpretation of the legislations that specify the procedures needed to ensure working safely in designated area.
<strong>Local rules must include:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Description of controlled areas.</li>
<li>System of work within controlled areas, which includes:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Restricting access to it.</li>
<li>Specify the need for lead protection.</li>
<li>Staff monitoring.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Dose investigation levels.</li>
<li>RPS name.</li>
<li>Work instruction for unclassified workers.</li>
<li>Back up contingency plan for the department, in case of radiation accidents.
<strong>Local rules can also include:</strong></li>
<li>management and supervision of work</li>
<li>testing and maintenance of safety features</li>
<li>radiation and contamination monitoring</li>
<li>testing of monitors</li>
<li>personal dosimetry</li>
<li>arrangements for pregnant and breast feeding staff</li>
<li>risk assessments</li>
<li>programme to review ALARA</li>
<li>RPA contact.</li>
<li>Every radiation employer shall provide Local Rules for any controlled or supervised area → according to the radiation risk &amp; nature of operations performed.</li>
<li>It should be set down in writing.</li>
<li>New employee get to read local rules &amp; sign to say they have understood.</li>
</ul>
<p>26</p>
<ul>
<li>The radiation employer shall ensure:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Observation of Local rules.</li>
<li>Local rules are followed by employees and other persons who may be affected.</li>
<li>Appoint radiation protection supervisors (RPS) to ensure Local rules compliance with the Regulations.
&amp; mention the names of RPSs in the local rules.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Local rules are A LEGAL DOCUMENT.</strong>
Policed by RPS &amp; Enforced by HSE inspector.</p>
<p><strong>Radiation Protection Supervisor:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Must be appointed “for the purpose of securing compliance of local rules with these Regulations”.</li>
<li>Name must be in Local Rules</li>
<li>It is recommended that RPS</li>
<li>know &amp; understand regulations and local rules</li>
<li>command sufficient authority</li>
<li>understand necessary precautions</li>
<li>know what to do in an emergency</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Requirements of Designated areas</strong></p>
<p><strong>IRR(1999); 19- Monitoring of designated areas</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall monitor the levels of ionising radiation in the controlled &amp; supervised areas through suitable and sufficient equipment.</li>
<li>The monitoring equipments shall be -
a. adequately tested – by a qualified person – before its first use.
b. properly maintained
c. adequately tested and examined at appropriate intervals.</li>
<li>The employer shall make suitable records of the results of the monitoring and of the tests → authorised by a qualified person → &amp; keep the records for at least 2 years.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Employee allowed to enter or remain in Controlled area:</strong>
The employer shall not permit any employee to enter or remain in such an area except:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>An outside worker</strong> → is a classified person who is:
i. Received training required.
ii. Certified fit for the work with ionising radiation.
iii. Subject to individual dose assessment.
iv. Provided with personal protective equipment and trained to use them.
v. Have a radiation passbook issued by approved dosimetry service "which contain their personal details &amp; up-to-date radiation doses" before they enter Controlled area.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The employer shall ensure that <strong>the classified outside worker is:</strong></li>
<li>Subject to arrangements for estimating the dose of IR he receives whilst in the controlled area.</li>
<li>An estimate of the dose received by that worker in that controlled area must be entered into his radiation passbook.</li>
<li>the radiation passbook is made available to that worker upon request</li>
</ul>
<p>27</p>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>If not an outside worker:</strong>
i. Is a classified person.
ii. If not being a classified person → Not permitted to enter or remains in the area, unless the employer can demonstrate, by personal dose monitoring, that the doses are restricted as follows: -
“ in case of employee ≥ 18 years or over → not receive in any calendar year a cumulative dose of IR which require him to be a classified person; or
“ In case of any other person → not receive in any calendar year a dose &gt; any relevant dose limit.
“ The employer shall keep the results of the monitoring or measurements by personal dose monitoring for this non-classified persons for 2 years.
“ Employer shall make that results available to that person on request.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>If there is a significant risk of the spread of radioactive contamination from a controlled area:</strong>
The employer shall make adequate arrangements to restrict the spread of such contamination:</p>
<ol>
<li>provide suitable &amp; sufficient washing and changing facilities for persons who enter or leave any controlled or supervised area;</li>
<li>maintenance of such washing and changing facilities;</li>
<li>prohibit eating, drinking or smoking within controlled area → ↓↓ probability of ingestion of a radioactive substance; and</li>
<li>monitoring contamination of persons, articles or goods leaving a controlled area.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IRR(1999): 35- Approval of dosimetry services:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in accordance with criteria specified by the Executive.</li>
<li>Approval is by a certificate in writing.</li>
<li>The purposes of these services are specified in the certificate.</li>
<li>The Executive may carry out a re-assessment of any approval.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>LEGAL LIABILITIES</strong>
▶ Definition of employer: anyone who uses ionizing radiation in a self-employed capacity, with their own equipment.</p>
<p><strong>Duties of Employer (IRMER2000)</strong>
(1) The employer shall put written procedures "System of work" for medical exposures &amp; ensure that the practitioner and operator are complied with.</p>
<p><strong>SCHEDULE 1</strong>
<strong>Employer's Procedures</strong>
<strong>The written procedures for medical exposures shall include -</strong>
(a) identify the individual to be exposed to ionising radiation;
(b) identify individuals entitled to act as referrer or practitioner or operator (i.e. identify competent staff for specific task);
(c) procedures to be observed in the case of medico-legal exposures;
(d) procedures established by the employer for biomedical and medical research programmes "i.e. no direct medical benefit for the individual";</p>
<p>28</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>(e) procedures for the use of diagnostic reference levels established by the employer for radiodiagnostic examinations;</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(f) assessment of patient dose and administered activity;</td></tr><tr><td>(g) procedures for the carrying out and recording of an evaluation for each medical exposure including factors relevant to patient dose; &amp; review if they are consistently exceeded &amp; take appropriate actions.</td></tr><tr><td>(h) procedures for making enquiries of females of childbearing age to establish whether the individual is or may be pregnant or breastfeeding;</td></tr><tr><td>(i) procedures to ensure that quality assurance programmes are followed;</td></tr><tr><td>(j) procedures for giving information and written instructions for patients undergoing treatment or diagnosis with radioactive material;</td></tr><tr><td>(k) Procedures to ensure that the probability and magnitude of accidental or unintended doses to patients from radiological practices are reduced so far as reasonably practicable.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>(2) Write protocols for every <strong>standard</strong> radiological examination practice for each equipment.</p>
<p>(3) <strong>The employer shall establish -</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>a) Referral criteria, including radiation doses, and ensure that these are available to the referrer;</li>
<li>b) Quality assurance programmes;</li>
<li>c) diagnostic reference levels for radiodiagnostic examinations regard to European diagnostic reference levels where available;</li>
<li>d) Dose constraints for biomedical and medical research programmes.</li>
</ul>
<p>(4) The employer shall take steps to ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>a) no practitioner or operator shall carry out a medical exposure or any practical aspect without having been adequately trained; and</li>
<li>b) practitioners or operators undertakes continuing training for new techniques.</li>
</ul>
<p>(5) <strong>In case of radiation overexposure incident:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>i. Make an immediate preliminary investigation of the incident.</li>
<li>ii. Notify the appropriate authority.</li>
<li>iii. Arrange for a detailed investigation of the circumstances of the exposure.</li>
<li>iv. Arrange for an assessment of the dose received.</li>
</ul>
<p>(6) If diagnostic reference levels are exceeded → undertake appropriate reviews and ensure that corrective action is taken.</p>
<p><strong>Other duties of Employer:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>clinical audit in accordance with national procedures <strong>must</strong> be performed.</li>
<li>Ensure a medical physics expert in areas specified</li>
<li>All employers using ionizing radiation in controlled areas should (i.e. required by law) to appoint RPA to provide advice on practical means of complying the legislations.</li>
<li>Keep an equipment inventory</li>
<li>Limit the amount of equipments.</li>
<li>Legislation lays "<strong>Duty of care</strong>" on Employers → responsibility for ensuring that regulations are followed (through Radiation Protection Committee).</li>
