<p>So, there is a need to <strong>keep dose-rates as low as possible</strong> in the workplace.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Staff working with x-rays can be exposed to three different sources of radiation:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>▶ Direct beam.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>▶ Leakage radiation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>▶ Scatter radiation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Scatter &amp; leakage radiations are collectively known as "<strong>secondary radiation</strong>"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>▶ In nuclear medicine, there are 2 principal sources - the radionuclide before injection and the patient after injection (see Section 5.7).</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sources-of-x-ray-exposure">SOURCES OF X-RAY EXPOSURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources-of-x-ray-exposure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="primary-direct-beam">Primary "Direct" beam<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-direct-beam" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>No-one other than the patient</strong> should be exposed to the direct beam.</li>
<li>Special care is needed in fluoroscopy, overcouch or C-arm tube &amp; mobile radiography.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leakage-radiation">Leakage radiation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leakage-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Leakage radiation is emitted in all directions from the tube housing.</li>
<li>leakage has a higher average energy (&amp; HVL) than the primary beam because of the selective absorption of low energy photons in the housing.</li>
<li>The leakage radiation measured at a distance of <strong>1 m</strong> from the focus for <strong>1 hour</strong> must not be more than <strong>1 mSv</strong>, and is typically <strong>&lt; 0.1 mSv</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="to-protect">To Protect:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-protect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The tube housing incorporates lead shielding → defines the useful beam and absorbs the majority of the off-axis photons.</li>
<li>The cones, diaphragm, and the housing of the light beam diaphragm.</li>
<li>The housing of the image intensifier has a lead equivalent of <strong>2.5 mm</strong>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scattered-radiation">Scattered radiation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scattered-radiation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>X-rays are scattered in <strong>all directions</strong> when the X-ray beam strikes any object, including the patient "a source of scattered rays"</li>
<li>At the x-ray energies used in planar radiography (25-50keV):</li>
<li>Because the intensity of the beam is greatest where it enters the body (and most of the forward scatter will be absorbed in the body)
→ ∴ intensity of <strong>backscatter</strong> from patient is higher than in any other direction.</li>
<li>The average energy (or HVL) of scattered radiation is about the same as the primary beam (remember, low energy x-rays lose vary little energy during Compton scattering), and the intensity or dose-rate due to scatter increases with the size of the primary beam.</li>
</ul>
<p>Typically, the dose-rate due to scattered radiation at 1m from a patient is <strong>&lt; 0.1% of the ESD</strong>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="to-protect">To Protect:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#to-protect" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>48</p>
<ol>
<li>Radiologist &amp; radiographer should be as far away from patient as practicable.</li>
<li>During fluoroscopy → procedures involving lateral views, staffs are advised to stand at the exit side of the patient rather than the side where the beam enters the body</li>
<li>Lead-rubber aprons and curtains, glass screens, etc., should be used.</li>
<li>When injecting contrast in CT:
a) High kV techniques → high side scatter.
b) Avoid the area close to the aperture → highest scatter.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reduction-of-exposure">REDUCTION OF EXPOSURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reduction-of-exposure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="distance">Distance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#distance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The inverse square law affords the cheapest form of protection.
The dose rate from a small (“point”) source will decrease with the square of the distance from it.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>One large step away usually reduces the dose rate four times.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="precautions">Precautions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#precautions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>X-ray rooms must be adequately large.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>No one should stay in the X-ray room or expose to X-ray unnecessarily:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Near the patient in ward radiography.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>During CT warm-up procedures.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Keep as far as possible from the X-ray source, except if necessary:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In ward radiography, the exposure switch has a cable which allows the operator to stand at least 2 m from the patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In fixed equipment → radiographer is not leaving the protective cubicle containing control panel during exposure.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="in-nuclear-medicine">In nuclear medicine:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-nuclear-medicine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Once patients have been injected they become sources of exposure to staff.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Waiting areas are designed to avoid unnecessary exposure to others.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Staff should be able to position and then image the patient with the gamma camera without being unnecessarily exposed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Underconca fluoroscopy units are preferred to overcouch units.
In overcouch unit,</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Staff are closer to the x-ray tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Staff experiences a higher intensity of scattered radiation because of the increased incidence of backscatter from the patient.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="speed-and-time">Speed and time<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#speed-and-time" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The dose delivered to any individual = dose-rate x time</li>
<li>Fast recording media and short screening times → ↓↓ patient &amp; staff dose.</li>
<li>↓↓ time of exposure in interventional procedures &amp; time spend close to nuclear medicine patients after being injected.</li>
<li>In fluoroscopy there is a timer with a maximum setting of 10 min. (exposing the same part of the patient for long times → skin erythema).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="shielding-by-barriers">Shielding by barriers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shielding-by-barriers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The shielding material, its thickness and its geometry with respect to the source are all dependent on the energy of the x-rays, the intensity of the beams, their</li>
</ul>
<p>49</p>
<p>orientation within the room, the expected workload and the level of occupancy of rooms adjacent to the x-ray room.</p>
<ul>
<li>Shielding is most often used to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Absorb leakage radiation from the x-ray tube.</li>
<li>Absorb scattered radiation from the patient.</li>
<li>Absorb primary radiation that has passed through the patient (this shielding is incorporated into the walls and doors of the x-ray room).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Structural shielding is designed to reduce the dose-rate in an area adjacent to the x-ray room to an acceptable level.</li>
</ul>
<p>Acceptable level depends on what the adjacent area is used for. Clearly, frequently occupied areas by other staff and/or the general public will require greater control of the radiation dose-rate than those that act as store rooms etc.</p>
<ul>
<li>Protective barriers should be used when an exposure is made.</li>
</ul>
<p>If this is not practicable, distance and protective clothing should be used.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The protective screen around the control panel protects against scatter only → the primary beam must never point toward it.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The panel is usually made of plywood incorporating 2.5 mm of lead, which reduce the exposure to the public dose limit, without protective clothing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It includes a lead glass window giving a clear view of the patient.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protective-clothing">Protective clothing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protective-clothing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Lead aprons should be worn by anybody who must enter an x-ray room while the beam is on</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Protective clothing does not protect against the direct beam but only attenuated or scattered radiation by the patient.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When palpating, a glove is worn of at least 0.25 mm and preferably 0.35 mm lead equivalent.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>When injecting, the hands must be outside the direct beam.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Standard body aprons:</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cover 75% of the red bone marrow</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Not less than 0.25 mm lead equivalent (which typically transmits only 10% of 90° scatter at standard operating kVp "about 100 kVp").</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In interventional radiology, aprons should cover as large an area as possible and have a front of 0.35 or 0.5 mm lead equivalent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aprons are provided in all X-ray rooms and with each mobile set.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>They must be stored carefully without folding, e.g. draped over a thick rail, to avoid cracking.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>They are examined periodically using X-rays to check for cracks.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Thyroid protection shields → recommended to be worn during fluoroscopic procedures.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lead glass spectacles may be worn during some interventional procedures, or a pull-down lead glass window may be used.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Large drapes of 0.5 mm lead equivalent are used in fluoroscopy</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In gamma imaging → thin lead protection "adequate for X-rays", is</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>50</p>
<p><strong>insufficient.</strong></p>
<p>→ In this case, distance and time are important factors for staff dose reduction when the patient is the source.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="warning-lights-and-signs">Warning lights and signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#warning-lights-and-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="on-the-x-ray-control-panel">On the X-ray control panel<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#on-the-x-ray-control-panel" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A light comes on when the set is switched on.</li>
<li>Another light comes on when the tube is energized, and stays on long enough to be noticed, even if the exposure is brief.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ab41bab7">On each tube housing, in case of double tube controlled by a single control panel → yellow or amber lights come on when the tube is selected.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ab41bab7" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="at-the-entrance-to-the-x-ray-room">At the entrance to the X-ray room:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#at-the-entrance-to-the-x-ray-room" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A <strong>warning sign</strong> to indicate a 'controlled area' due to X-rays.</li>
<li>A <strong>warning light</strong> which comes on during fluoroscopy and when the tube is 'prepared' for radiography.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="in-nuclear-medicine-warning-signs-alone-are-adequate">In nuclear medicine, warning signs alone are adequate.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-nuclear-medicine-warning-signs-alone-are-adequate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Warning lights are <strong>not helpful</strong> as the hazard is effectively present all the time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="protection-of-the-public">Protection of the public<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection-of-the-public" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>× X-ray rooms are shielded "walls, windows &amp; doors" to <strong>reduce the dose in surrounding areas &lt; the levels for 'other persons', i.e. 0.1 mSv per week under normal workloads</strong>.</p>
<p>× The walls which the primary beam can be directed against = "<strong>primary barriers</strong>", while the walls which only protect against scatter and leakage radiation are called "<strong>secondary barriers</strong>".</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-primary-barriers-must-be-more-absorbing-than-secondary-barriers">The primary barriers must be more absorbing than secondary barriers.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-primary-barriers-must-be-more-absorbing-than-secondary-barriers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>For 2ry barriers → <strong>2.5 mm</strong> lead equivalent is satisfactory.</li>
<li>For 1ry barriers "subject to direct beam" → need greater protection.</li>
<li>The protection needed is first calculated in terms of lead.</li>
<li>Then realized as an equivalent combination of other materials.</li>
<li>The following are approximately equal in their protective power for diagnostic X-rays:</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>120 mm of concrete = 12 mm of barium plaster = 1 mm of lead</strong></p>
<p>× Radiopharmacies are similarly protected, and consideration has to be given to visitors in nuclear medicine waiting areas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="supporting-children-during-radiography">Supporting children during radiography<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#supporting-children-during-radiography" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>Restraining and supporting devices</strong> → hold children during radiography.</li>
<li>If this is not practicable, children may be supported by an <strong>accompanying adult "Comforter &amp; Carer"</strong> → but not by a pregnant woman.</li>
<li>× individuals who (other than as part of their profession → not a nurse) knowingly and willingly incur an exposure to ionising radiation to support another person who is undergoing a medical exposure</li>
<li>× Must be aware of the risk of exposure to IR.</li>
<li>× He or she is given instructions how to do so</li>
</ul>
<p>51</p>
<ul>
<li>Positioned outside the beam.</li>
<li>Wears a protective apron or shielded by a barrier.</li>
<li>A direct-reading radiation monitor may provide reassurance.</li>
</ul>
<p>52</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-9-personal-dosimetry-systems">6.9 PERSONAL DOSIMETRY SYSTEMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-9-personal-dosimetry-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radiation dosimeter = any device which is capable of measuring absorbed dose.</li>
<li>In particular the ideal dosimeter must be able to;</li>
</ul>
<p>1 Record doses of different types of radiation (eg x-rays, β particles, positrons etc)
2 Record doses over a wide range of radiation energies (i.e. its response should be the same when measuring 20 keV γ-rays as it should for measuring 511 keV γ-rays).
3 Record doses over a wide range of values (ie it should be able to measure very small and very large doses accurately).
4 Measure doses independent of environmental conditions (temperature, pressure &amp; humidity).
5 Additionally an ideal dosimeter would also be small, lightweight, robust and cheap.</p>
<p>Three different personal dosimetry systems will be described. Their relative advantages or disadvantages are summarized in Table 6.11.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-9-1-film-badges">6.9.1 FILM BADGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-9-1-film-badges" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Most used in diagnostic radiology.</li>
<li>film without screens - same size as a dental film.</li>
<li>It is double coated:</li>
<li>One emulsion is slow → unaffected by normal occupational doses;</li>
<li>The other emulsion is fast → used to assess normal occupational doses.</li>
<li>High (accidental and emergency) doses:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Completely blacken the fast emulsion → radiation dose cannot be assessed.</li>
<li>The slow emulsion → lesser blackening → allows assessment of high dose.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Monitoring films are placed in a plastic cassette or 'badge' which:</li>
<li>Pinned to the clothing.</li>
<li>Carry an identification of the wearer.</li>
<li>Most importantly → incorporates plastic and metal filters to differentiate the radiations received (Fig. 6.9a).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calibration">CALIBRATION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calibration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Each month, films from a single manufacturing batch → similar sensitivities</li>
<li>Stamped with identifying serial numbers (seen through the open window).</li>
<li>A proportion of these are retained in the laboratory as calibration films.</li>
<li>Calibration is by exposure known doses of gamma rays from a long half-life radioactive source, e.g. the 662 keV gamma rays from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>137</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{137}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">137</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>Cs.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="processing">PROCESSING:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#processing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dosemeters are worn for a month → returned to approved dosimetry laboratory</li>
<li>Then, the films are all processed under carefully controlled conditions.</li>
<li>The densities of the calibration films are measured, and a graph is plotted of density of blackening under a lead filter versus dose.</li>
<li>The densities of the badge films are then measured → the received doses are read from the appropriate calibration curve.</li>
</ul>
<p>53</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mechanism">MECHANISM:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The operation of the dosimeter is based on the photochemical reaction, i.e. radiation reacts with the film emulsion which darkens according to dose when developed.</li>
<li>The emulsion contains high atomic number elements "than tissue or air" → ∴ the optical density of the film caused by a given dose of radiation will increase at low energies due to an increase in the number of photoelectric events.</li>
</ul>
<p>∴ The film dosimeter is <strong>energy-dependent</strong>.</p>
<p>For example, diagnostic X-rays produce about 10 times the blackening as the same absorbed dose of gamma rays from diagnostic radionuclides.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-1394ae82.jpeg" alt="img-167.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.9 (a) Personal dosimetry film badge, (b) Exposed films.</p>
<ul>
<li>Film badge is usually exposed to <strong>mixed radiations</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>To identify the various energy components, the film is sandwiched between at least three pairs of filters: (a) 'thick plastic', (b) aluminum, and (c) tin with a thin lead foil (Fig. 6.9a).</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>High energy</th><th>Medium energy</th><th>Low energy</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Thick plastic</td><td>Not attenuated</td><td>Not attenuated</td><td>Somewhat attenuated</td></tr><tr><td>Aluminum</td><td>Not attenuated</td><td>Somewhat attenuated</td><td>Totally attenuated</td></tr><tr><td>Tin with thin lead</td><td>Somewhat attenuated</td><td>Heavily attenuated</td><td>Totally attenuated</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The film badge can also measure <strong>other kinds of ionizing radiations</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To assess the dose of beta rays of various energies → one or more thin plastic filters + the thick one + open window (no filter).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To assess the dose from slow neutrons → an additional filter of cadmium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>interpretation of the badge film:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>By measuring the optical densities of the film under each filter it is possible to estimate <strong>the energy</strong> and <strong>type of radiation</strong> which was responsible for the dose + suitable corrections for the energy dependence.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Because <strong>the characteristic curve of the film is only linear over a limited range of doses</strong> → film badges are only</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>54</p>
<p>able to measure doses from ~0.2 – 1000 mSv "suitable for diagnostic radiology".</p>
<ol>
<li>Pattern of shadows of the three filters → indicate type(s) of radiation (Fig. 6.9b).</li>
<li>The densities under each filter using the relative speed of the film to radiations of different energies, and the calibration curve → Dose of mixed radiations.</li>
<li>A sharp edge to the shadows of the filters → a single exposure to direct rays from one direction;
A blurred edge → scattered rays or multiple small exposures from different directions.
Spots of intense blackening → a radioactive spill (MCQ).</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Adv.: small, lightweight and cheap and forms a permanent dose record.</li>
<li>Disadv.</li>
<li>Used only once.</li>
<li>affected by excessive temperature and humidity.</li>
<li>Lower threshold for hard gamma radiation is 0.15 mSv.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-9-2-thermoluminescent-dosemeters">6.9.2 THERMOLUMINESCENT DOSEMETERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-9-2-thermoluminescent-dosemeters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>More expensive, so less common in radiology than film badges.</li>
<li>Adv.: particularly useful for measuring extremity doses.</li>
<li>TLDs depend on the principle of luminescence &amp; thermoluminescence.</li>
<li>Different forms and materials, ~a small chip of lithium fluoride (3 x 3 mm) mounted in a plastic holder + carries identifying details &amp; pinned to the wearer.</li>
<li>In other forms, TL dosimeters are also used to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Measure patient dose in radiological procedures.</li>
<li>Mounted in rings to measure staff finger doses.</li>
<li>Mounted in sachets, placed on the forehead to estimate eye doses.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The badges are worn for a prescribed period → then, returned to the approved dosimetry laboratory for processing.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism">MECHANISM:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When X- or gamma rays fall on thermoluminescent (TL) material "lithium fluoride" → absorbed → atomic electrons are raised to higher energy levels → the electrons stay indefinitely in their excited state (in 'electron traps'), and the material retains a 'memory' of the radiation exposure.</li>
<li>The greater the dose absorbed, the more electrons are 'trapped'.</li>
<li>TLDs show a linear response over a wide range of doses, unlike film badges.</li>
<li>LiF has an effective atomic number very close to that of soft tissue → the dose recorded by a TLD is very close to the soft tissue dose over a wide range of radiation energies.</li>
<li>TLDs can measure doses across a range of ~0.1 – 2000 mSv.</li>
<li>The response "signal per unit dose" of TLDs shows small variation with energy as compared to film badges.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="processing">PROCESSING:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#processing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The device which heats the chips &amp; measures light output = "TLD reader".</li>
<li>The chip of TL material is inserted in a light-tight chamber → its temperature is raised to 300–400°C at a carefully controlled rate → the trapped electrons leave</li>
</ul>
<p>the traps and fall to their ground state &amp; emit photons of light.</p>
<ul>
<li>Light is collected and measured by a photoelectric device  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  ('glow curve') is drawn  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  the dose is digitized and stored in a computer, together with the glow curve.</li>
<li>The total light energy emitted under the curve is proportional to the dose of X- or gamma rays originally absorbed.</li>
<li>The chip is then annealed "overheated  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>400</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>500</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">400 - 500^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> " to remove any residual stored energy from previous exposure  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  return to original &amp; can be reused.</li>
<li>Calibration is performed as with film dosemeters.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="6-9-3-direct-reading-electronic-dosemeters">6.9.3 DIRECT-READING ELECTRONIC DOSEMETERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-9-3-direct-reading-electronic-dosemeters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Based on Geiger-Muller tubes or single silicon diodes.</li>
<li>Provide effective alarms and immediate dose readings.</li>
<li>Used in areas with real risks of high exposures.</li>
<li>However, these devices have a very poor response to photon energies below around  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80\mathrm{keV} \rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Unable to detect low-energy gamma radiation and diagnostic X-rays.</li>
</ul>
<p>The Siemens electronic personal dosemeter (EPD) overcomes that problem with a linear response to below  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{keV}\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  suitable for radiodiagnostic staff.</p>
<p>Dose range  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Flat response between  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{keV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">keV</span></span></span></span></span></span>  to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\mathrm{MeV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MeV</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-67644b50.jpeg" alt="img-168.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-b7d66202.jpeg" alt="img-169.jpeg"></p>
<ul>
<li>The EPD has achieved approval as a legal personal dosemeter in the UK, Norway, Italy and Germany.</li>
<li>The EPD was developed by Siemens &amp; the UK National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB).</li>
<li>It uses two silicon photodiodes to overcome the energy response limitations of a single detector.</li>
<li>The read-out display gives:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The personal equivalent dose to the body and skin.</li>
<li>Indicate dose rates with or without an alarm feature.</li>
<li>The stored doses  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  record the values in an individual dose record.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The information includes the time when significant dose rates were recorded, which can help in tracing potential incidents.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The sensitivity is 50-200 times greater than that of a TLD, highly appropriate for:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Measuring doses in diagnostic-imaging (low individual doses).</li>
<li>Detect the proposed limits on a proportional monthly basis  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0.15</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(0.15\mathrm{mSy})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">0.15</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mSy</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  for pregnant workers "difficult to assure with either films or a TLD".</li>
</ol>
<p>56</p>
<ul>
<li>A major advantage of such a direct reading dosemeter:
<em>Immediate dose measurement</em> → allow appropriate steps to reduce exposure.</li>
<li>A disadvantage is its initial cost (about £300)
But as its life is expected to be 10 years → the effective monthly cost = TLD or commercial film systems.</li>
<li>The EPD is calibrated for 'life' when manufactured, but an annual check may be needed to comply with legal approval.</li>
<li>The battery only needs to be replaced every 12 months, at which time a calibration check is recommended.</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>Advantages</th><th>Disadvantages</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>film badges</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Relatively cheap</td><td>• Requires dark room and wet processing</td></tr><tr><td>• Permanent record of the exposure</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Wide range of dose (0.2-1000 mSv)</td><td>• Lower threshold for hard gamma radiation is 0.15 mSv</td></tr><tr><td>• Identifies type and energy of exposure</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Easy to identify individual dosemeters</td><td>• Is affected by heat, humidity &amp; chemicals</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Thermoluminescent (TL) personal dosemeters</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Chips can be reused</td><td>• Requires a high capital outlay</td></tr><tr><td>• Wide range of dose (0.1-2000 mSv)</td><td>• No permanent record (other than glow curves)</td></tr><tr><td>• Direct reading of personal dose</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Energy independent within ±10%</td><td>• Cannot distinguish radioactive contamination</td></tr><tr><td>• Compact → suitable for finger dosimetry</td><td>• Requires a filtered badge to provide energy discrimination</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Siemens electronic personal dosemeter (EPD)</strong></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Direct reading and cumulative record storage (up to 16 Sv)</td><td>• Initial cost</td></tr><tr><td>• Flat response: 20 keV to 10 MeV.</td><td>• Linear response to dose</td></tr><tr><td>• Can be 'zeroed' by user without deleting cumulative record</td><td>• Is quite heavy, but weighs less than a hospital 'bleep'</td></tr><tr><td>• Measures personal dose at depth and at the skin directly, to 1 μSv</td><td>• Battery should be renewed each year</td></tr><tr><td>• Audible warning of high dose rates</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>57</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radiation-detectors">RADIATION DETECTORS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-detectors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Detectors may be classified by the type of information produced:</li>
<li><strong>Counters</strong> e.g. Geiger-Mueller (GM) detectors:
Detectors that indicate the no. of interactions occurring in the detector.</li>
<li><strong>Spectrometers</strong> e.g. NaI scintillation detectors:
Detectors yield information about the energy distribution of incident radiation.</li>
<li><strong>Dosimeters:</strong>
Detectors that indicate the net amount of energy deposited in the detector by multiple interactions.</li>
<li>The <em>efficiency (sensitivity)</em> of a detector is a measure of its ability to detect radiation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gas-filled-detectors">Gas-filled detectors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gas-filled-detectors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="types-of-gas-filled-detectors">Types of gas-filled detectors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-gas-filled-detectors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Three types of gas-filled detectors in common use:</li>
<li>Ionization chambers</li>
<li>Proportional counters</li>
<li>Geiger-Mueller (GM) counters</li>
<li>Type determined primarily by the voltage applied between the two electrodes</li>
<li>Ionization chambers have wider range of physical shape (parallel plates, concentric cylinders, etc.)</li>
<li>Proportional counters and GM counters must have thin wire anode</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ionization-chambers">IONIZATION CHAMBERS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ionization-chambers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An ionisation chamber consists of two electrodes separated by air and electronic circuit to measure and display the dose.</li>
<li><strong>Principle:</strong></li>
<li>X-rays and gamma rays → ionisation when interact with air → the ion pairs created will recombine very quickly but this can be prevented by applying a voltage between two electrodes.</li>
<li>The charge is collected by the electrodes to produce an electric current.</li>
<li>The number of ion pairs &amp; current is proportional to the dose of radiation "absorbed dose".</li>
<li>The electrodes can be flat rectangular plates or consist of a single central wire surrounded by a cylinder.</li>
<li>Effective atomic number of air is very close to soft tissue → ∴ the dose recorded by an ionisation chamber is very close to the soft tissue dose over a wide range of radiation energies.</li>
<li>Ionisation chambers are capable of measuring doses over a wide range of values down to as low as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\mu \mathrm{Sv/hr}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Sv/hr</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li><strong>Use:</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Portable dose rate meters for dose surveys within the hospital.</li>
<li>The detectors in most x-ray machine phototimers.</li>
<li>Dose-area product (DAP) meters → allow assessment of patient doses.</li>
</ol>
<p>58</p>
<ul>
<li>N.B.:</li>
<li>Air-filled Ionization Chambers can be used to measure exposure (def.: charge per unit mass of air "C \ kg").</li>
<li>Are not suitable for detection of individual particles "produce small current not sufficient to be measured"</li>
<li>Suitable for radiation dosimetry because the response in air is close to the response of absorbed dose in soft tissue "mean atomic number of air (Z= 7.6) is very close to that of soft tissue (Z= 7.4)"</li>
<li>Ionization chambers don't require highly stabilized voltage supply "output is independent of voltage".</li>
<li>Only voltage high enough to prevent recombination of ions, but not so high to cause amplification by acceleration of electrons &amp; further ionizations"</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="geiger-muller-tube">GEIGER-MULLER TUBE:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#geiger-muller-tube" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>GM counters must contain gases with specific properties</li>
<li>Gas amplification produces billions of ion pairs after an interaction – signal from detector requires little amplification</li>
<li>It detects individual ionization events as electric pulses which can be counted, but the pulse size is independent of energy.</li>
<li>In general, GM survey meters are inefficient detectors of x-rays and gamma rays.</li>
<li>Sometimes, used in dose measurements.</li>
<li>It have got a central wire (anode)</li>
<li>Quenching agent (alcohol or bromide) is added to the counting gas (argon/helium) to prevent the discharge continuing before another pulse is detected.</li>
<li>It has a long dead time of about 300 microsecond (i.e. two interactions must be separated by a finite amount of time if they are to produce distinct signals) → during dead time, no more detections can be made.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scintillation-detectors-tolan">SCINTILLATION DETECTORS: (Tolan)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scintillation-detectors-tolan" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Scintillation detectors consist of a scintillator and a PMT, that converts the light into an electrical signal</li>
<li>Amount of light emitted after an interaction of a photon with the detector &amp; the size of the electronic pulse depends on the energy absorbed.</li>
<li>If the detector is used with pulse height measurement electronics, it can measure the photon energy → can be used to discriminate between different isotopes.</li>
<li>The sensitivity increases with detector size.</li>
<li>Very thin detectors can be used to produce contamination monitors sensitive to beta particles (thicker detector wouldn't be suitable, because β-particles will be absorbed in first few millimeters)</li>
<li>Detectors are usually inorganic crystals. However, organic scintillators are available including liquids used in assay of very low energy β-emitting nuclides (e.g. tritium).</li>
</ul>
<p>59</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="statutory-requirements-and-non-statutory-recommendations">Statutory Requirements and Non-Statutory Recommendations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statutory-requirements-and-non-statutory-recommendations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1- Medicines (Administration of Radioactive Substances) Regulations 1978
2- Radioactive Substances Act 1993</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-medicines-administration-of-radioactive-substances-reg-1978">1- Medicines (Administration of Radioactive Substances) Reg. 1978:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-medicines-administration-of-radioactive-substances-reg-1978" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>“No person shall administer to a human being (otherwise than to himself) any radioactive medicinal product unless he is <strong>doctor or dentist holding a certificate issued by the Health Minister</strong> or a person acting in accordance with the directions of such a doctor or dentist.”</p>
<ul>
<li>In order to assist ministers in the awarding of certificates the <strong>Administration of Radioactive Substances Advisory Committee (ARSAC)</strong> was established.</li>
<li>ARSAC comprises 20 members with a range of professional backgrounds (however, the chairperson is always a clinician) and the certificates they award are referred to as <strong>“ARSAC certificates”</strong>.</li>
<li>ARSAC certificates can be issued for diagnostic, therapeutic and research procedures. Written applications must be supported by the <strong>local RPA</strong>, <strong>radiopharmacist</strong> and <strong>MPE</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="covers">COVERS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#covers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Nuclear medicine scanning</li>
<li>Nuclear medicine therapy</li>
<li>Some pathology test, e.g.</li>
<li>C-14 urea breath test</li>
<li>Co-57 Schilling test</li>
<li>Brachytherapy</li>
<li>☑ interstitial</li>
<li>☑ intracavity</li>
<li>☑ surface applicators</li>
<li>☑ neutron activation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arsac-certificates">ARSAC Certificates:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arsac-certificates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A certificate is awarded if the applicant can demonstrate they have the appropriate training, experience and local scientific support, and is usually only granted to a consultant</li>
<li>Specific to</li>
<li>Practitioner</li>
<li>Radio-pharmaceutical.</li>
<li>Site (i.e. hospital)</li>
<li>Proposed use</li>
<li>Valid for 5 years (or 2 years only for research)</li>
<li>Applicants assessed against “core curriculum”.</li>
</ul>
<p>60</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-radioactive-substances-act-1993-rsa93">2- Radioactive Substances Act 1993 "RSA93":<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-radioactive-substances-act-1993-rsa93" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The Radioactive Substances Act (RSA) mainly concerns nuclear medicine departments.</li>
</ul>
<p>The main points of the RSA are summarized below;</p>
<ul>
<li>Its main function is to control the spread of radioactivity in the environment.</li>
<li>It is enforced by the <strong>Environment Agency (EA)</strong>.</li>
<li>It is concerned with the storage &amp; use of radioactive materials. It also deals with the accumulation and disposal of radioactive waste.</li>
<li>All users of radioactive materials (ie each NHS Trust) must be registered with the Environment Agency.</li>
<li>Registration to keep &amp; use RAS: limits activity &amp; number of sources.</li>
<li>Clear and legible records of all radioactive materials held on the premises must be produced and maintained.</li>
<li>Those users who wish to accumulate and dispose of radioactive waste require authorisation to do so from the EA.</li>
<li>There are legal limits on the amount of radioactive waste that can be accumulated and disposed of each month from the department (this is specified by the Environment Agency).</li>
<li>The user must hold up to date records of all waste disposals.</li>
<li>Lost RAS or radioactive waste must be reported to police &amp; EA.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="part-exemptions">Part Exemptions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-exemptions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>RS (Hospitals) Exemption Order 1990</li>
<li>if disposals small (e.g. &lt; 1 GBq Tc-99m per month to drains, or 500 MBq other radionuclide)</li>
<li>RS (Smoke Detector) Exemption Order 1980</li>
<li>etc.</li>
</ul>
<p>61</p>
<p>ABBREVIATIONS:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>ICRP</th><th>International commission on Radiation Protection.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HSE</td><td>Health &amp; Safety executive</td></tr><tr><td>IRR 99</td><td>Ionising Radiation Regulations 1999</td></tr><tr><td>IR (POPUMET)R 88</td><td>Ionising Radiation (Protection of Patients Undergoing Medical Examination or Treatment) Regulations</td></tr><tr><td>M[ARS]R 78</td><td>The Medicines (Administration of Radioactive Substances) Regulations 1978</td></tr><tr><td>RSA 93</td><td>Radioactive Substances Act 1993</td></tr><tr><td>IRMER 2000</td><td>Ionising Radiation (Medical Exposure) Regulations 2000</td></tr><tr><td>RPS</td><td>Radiation Protection Supervisor.</td></tr><tr><td>HSE</td><td>Health &amp; Service Executive.</td></tr><tr><td>RPA</td><td>Radiation Protection Adviser.</td></tr><tr><td>ACOP</td><td>Approved Code OF Practice</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>21</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hse-nov-01">HSE Nov. 01:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hse-nov-01" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There has been a number of reported cases where employees have failed to take good care of their dosemeters. Many of these cases involve employees in the Health Services, some of whom have been senior clinicians.</p>
<p>"Non-Classified employees who have been provided with a dosemeter by their employer to ensure compliance with regulation18 IRR99 have a duty to look after that dosemeter and return it for processing as required. Provided the employer has informed the employees of that duty and is exercising the appropriate level of supervision, employees who persistently fail to wear, look after or return their dosemeters promptly are liable to enforcement action by inspectors up to and including prosecution under Section 7 of the HSW Act 1974. Employers may find statement of this fact useful when dealing with 'errant' staff."</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="22-estimated-doses-and-special-entries">22- Estimated doses and special entries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#22-estimated-doses-and-special-entries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In case of loss or damage of a dosemeter used to make any individual measurement under regulation 21 (i.e. not practicable to assess the dose received by a classified person over any period)</p>
<ul>
<li>Employer shall make an adequate investigation of:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The circumstances of the case.</li>
<li>A view to estimate the dose received by that person during that period.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If there is adequate information to estimate the dose received, Employer shall:
a) Send to the approved dosimetry service a summary of the information used to estimate that dose.
b) Arrange for the approved dosimetry service to enter the estimated dose in the dose record of that person.
→ mentioned in the dose record as estimated dose.
c) The employer shall not enter the estimated dose in the dose record except after the consent of the Executive if:
i. Recorded cumulative effective dose ≥ 20 mSv in one calendar year.
ii. Recorded cumulative equivalent dose ≥ any relevant dose limit in one calendar year</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>if there is inadequate information to estimate the dose received, Employer shall arrange for the approved dosimetry service to enter a notional dose in the dose record "i.e. proportion of the total annual dose limit for the relevant period"
→ mentioned in the dose record as a national dose.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In either case, the employer shall
a) Inform the classified person of the entry (either estimated or national dose).
b) Make available at the request of the classified person → a copy of the summary sent to the approved dosimetry service.
c) Make a report of any investigation → keep a copy for 2 years from the date it was made.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>22</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="objections-on-the-estimated-dose">Objections on the estimated dose:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objections-on-the-estimated-dose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>If employer think the dose received by the classified person is &gt; or &lt; the relevant entry in the dose record → he shall make <strong>adequate investigation</strong>.</li>
</ul>
<p>But under 2 conditions:</p>
<ol>
<li>before 12 month in case of classified person subject only to an annual dose limit.</li>
<li>before 5 yrs in any other case.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>If investigations confirms the belief of the employer, he shall:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Send to the approved dosimetry service a summary of the information used to estimate that dose.</li>
<li>Arrange for the approved dosimetry service to enter <strong>the estimated dose</strong> in the dose record of that person.
→ mentioned in the dose record as <strong>special entry</strong>.</li>
<li>Notify the classified person of the change.</li>
<li>Make a report of the investigation → keep a copy for 2 yrs.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>If the classified person is aggrieved by this decision → apply to review this decision in writing to the Executive "within 3 months of the date on which he was notified of the decision".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If the Executive concludes that -</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>(a) The investigation was inadequate; or
(b) estimated dose is not reasonable,</p>
<p>The Executive shall direct the employer to re-instate the original entry in the dose record.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="other-protection-measures">OTHER PROTECTION MEASURES:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-protection-measures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Radiologists and almost all radiology workers ARE NOT CLASSIFIED normally</li>
<li>According to <strong>LOCAL RULES</strong>, they however supposed to wear personal dosemeters when entering a controlled area</li>
</ul>
<p>N.B. it is not an absolute necessity, this is preferred but not must, but local rules in most places states so, note that the answer of the question:</p>
<p><strong>Radiologist SHOULD wear a dosemeter when entering fluoroscopy room.</strong></p>
<p>The answer is <strong>FALSE</strong>, because it is not <strong>SHOULD</strong>, although we all wear them in that case, but still not absolute necessity, if the word used in the question <strong>USUALLY</strong>, so the answer is <strong>TRUE</strong>.</p>
<ul>
<li>Perhaps that example shows you the degree of sterility of the examination system!!</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="about-personal-monitors">About personal monitors:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#about-personal-monitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Personal dosimeters are worn on the trunk, under the lead apron.</li>
<li>Additional monitors MAY BE worn on the forehead or neckband to monitor eye exposure, or fingers to monitor hand doses.</li>
<li>Body monitors are usually worn for 4 weeks</li>
<li>Commonest personal monitoring dosimeters are film badges or TLD.</li>
</ol>
<p>23</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Electronic dosimeters are used in high dose areas when an indication is needed to monitor at the same time of exposure (ex. Interventional procedures by pregnant radiologist)</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IRR(1999); 9-Personal protective equipment:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Any personal protective equipment shall comply with the Personal Protective Equipment (EC Directive) Regulations 1992.</li>
<li>Every radiation employer shall provide appropriate accommodation for personal protective equipment when it is not being worn.</li>
</ul>
<p>24</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="statutory-responsibilities-and-organizational-arrangements-for-radiation-protection">STATUTORY RESPONSIBILITIES AND ORGANIZATIONAL ARRANGEMENTS FOR RADIATION PROTECTION:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statutory-responsibilities-and-organizational-arrangements-for-radiation-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>IRR1999 aims to Protection of staff and members of public.</li>
<li>IR(ME)R2000 aims to Protection of patients.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arrangements-for-the-management-of-radiation-protection">ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF RADIATION PROTECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrangements-for-the-management-of-radiation-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
