<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="irr-1999-13-radiation-protection-adviser">IRR(1999); 13- Radiation protection adviser<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-13-radiation-protection-adviser" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="matters-in-respect-of-which-a-radiation-protection-adviser-must-be-consulted-by-a-radiation-employer">MATTERS IN RESPECT OF WHICH A RADIATION PROTECTION ADVISER MUST BE CONSULTED BY A RADIATION EMPLOYER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#matters-in-respect-of-which-a-radiation-protection-adviser-must-be-consulted-by-a-radiation-employer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Advising to the observance of the Regulations</li>
<li>The implementation of requirements as to controlled and supervised areas.</li>
<li>For new or modified sources of ionising radiation → prior plans for installations and the acceptance into service "in relation to any engineering controls, design features, safety features and warning devices provided to restrict exposure to ionising radiation".</li>
<li>Regular checking of systems of work provided to restrict exposure to ionising radiation.</li>
<li>The regular calibration of equipment provided for monitoring IR levels and the regular checking that such equipment is serviceable and correctly used.</li>
<li>The periodic examination and testing of engineering controls, design features, safety features and warning devices.</li>
<li>Incidents where more than 6 mSv has been received.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>R.P.A. need not be appointed if only:</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Very, small amounts of radioactive material (below specified levels)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Very low dose (&lt; 1μSv/h @ 10 cm) x-ray units of a design approved by HSE</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>VDUs with &lt; 1μSv/h @ 10 cm</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>&lt; 30 kV and &lt; 1μSv/h @ 10 cm.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There should be a <strong>radiation protection advisor</strong> (RPA) in every radiological facility.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>RPA must have qualification approved by HSE (e.g. RPA2000 certificate).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The radiation employer shall appoint the radiation protection adviser in writing and shall include the advice needed.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The radiation employer shall provide RPA with adequate information and facilities.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-information-instruction-and-training">14- Information, instruction and training<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-information-instruction-and-training" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall ensure that -
(1) <strong>his employees</strong> are given appropriate training, information and instruction in the field of radiation protection regarding:-</li>
<li>(a) the risks to health by exposure to ionising radiation;</li>
<li>(b) the precautions; and</li>
<li>(c) the importance of complying with the medical, technical and administrative requirements of these Regulations;</li>
</ul>
<p>25</p>
<p>(2) other persons concerned with the work with ionising radiation are given adequate information to ensure their health and safety; and
(3) female employees:</p>
<ul>
<li>Informed of the risk of ionising radiation to the fetus &amp; a nursing infant.</li>
<li>Informed of the importance of informing the employer in writing as soon as possible
(a) after becoming aware of their pregnancy; or
(b) if they are breast feeding.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>IRMER(11) Training for patient protection:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>No practitioner or operator shall carry out a medical exposure or any practical aspect without having been adequately trained (certificate issued by an institute shall be sufficient proof).</li>
<li>A person can participate in practical aspects of the procedure as part of practical training only under the supervision of adequately trained person.</li>
<li>The employer shall keep an up-to-date training record of all practitioners and operators engaged by him to carry out medical exposures or any practical aspect of such exposures available for inspection by the appropriate authority</li>
<li>Records should show the dates on which training was completed and the nature of the training.</li>
<li>Practitioner or operator employed by other employer → shall supply such records to the new employer upon request.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>PROTECTION OF STAFF &amp; MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC:</strong>
“Legislation is enacted to ensure that individual doses are as low as reasonably practicable (ALARP)
&amp; that people are unlikely to exceed a proportion of the dose limits.</p>
<p><strong>CONTROLLED AREAS:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Required as a further control when inherent shielding of the source (X-ray tube and radiopharmaceutical syringes) is not enough → the area around the shielded source is designated as a controlled area.</li>
<li>Controlled areas have physical boundaries that are able to prevent radiation penetration (above specific level).</li>
<li>Controlled area should be clearly defined boundaries.
This is simple to achieve in an x-ray room but more difficult with mobile X-ray set → where the controlled area is determined by eye as extending for 2 meters around tube.</li>
<li>Every diagnostic X-ray tube produces a large amount of radiation exposure
∴ has to be contained within a controlled area.</li>
<li>In nuclear medicine, area is defined controlled, wherever:</li>
<li>A generator is located, or</li>
<li>There is a syringe containing radiopharmaceutical.</li>
</ul>
<p>26</p>
<ul>
<li>Controlled area should have <strong>restricted access</strong> (to radiation workers &amp; others who work under "written system of work")</li>
<li>"<strong>Written system of work</strong>" organize work within controlled area to ensure that radiology workers can't receive dose &gt; 30% of any dose limit.</li>
<li><strong>Personal protection</strong> should take place within controlled area (e.g. 2.5 mm lead screens, lead rubber aprons and gloves, lead glasses, etc.)</li>
</ul>
<p>N.B. in practice, radiology and nuclear medicine staff receives doses below the public dose limit.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251218-312f8e45.jpeg" alt="img-170.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="part-iv">PART IV<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#part-iv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="designated-areas">DESIGNATED AREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#designated-areas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="irr-1999-16-designation-of-controlled-or-supervised-areas">IRR(1999); 16- Designation of controlled or supervised areas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-16-designation-of-controlled-or-supervised-areas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall designate as <strong>a controlled area</strong> any area in which -</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Any person who enters or works in the area should follow special procedures to restrict significant exposure to ionising radiation in that area or prevent radiation accidents.</li>
<li>Any person working is likely to receive:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Effective dose &gt; 6 mSv / year.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Equivalent dose &gt; 3/10 of any relevant dose limit (Schedule 4) "for an employee aged 18 years or above".</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>also ACOP says if</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>&gt; 7.5 µSv/h averaged over 8 h working day</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>&gt; 75 µSv/h to hands averaged over 8 h working day</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>contamination risk</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>need to keep non-radiation workers out</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>or &gt; 7.5 µSv/h averaged over 1 minute and</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>site radiography, or</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>employees untrained in radiation protection enter area (unless radioactivity is dispersed inside a person)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>This area should be under complete control of the employer before starting activities which require that area to be designated as a controlled area.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An employer shall designate as <strong>a supervised area</strong> any area which, not designated as a controlled area :-</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>27</p>
<ol>
<li>where it is necessary to keep the conditions of the area under review to determine if the area should be designated as a controlled area; or</li>
<li>Any person working is likely to receive:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Effective dose &gt; 1 mSv / year.</li>
<li>Equivalent dose &gt; 1/10 of any relevant dose limit (Schedule 4) "for an employee aged 18 years or above".</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Any Controlled or Supervised Area should be (as a duty of the employer):</strong>
i. Adequately described in local rules. "N.B. not in the 'System of work'...MCQ"
ii. Physical demarcation of the controlled area, with suitable warning signs.
iii. Display suitable &amp; sufficient signs in suitable positions indicating:</p>
<ul>
<li>The area is a controlled 'or supervised' area.</li>
<li>The nature of the radiation sources in the area.</li>
<li>The risks arising from such sources.
iv. Non-classified workers can only enter under written system of work.</li>
<li>Employer must demonstrate by personal dose monitoring or other means that dose is restricted.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>17- Local rules and radiation protection supervisors:</strong>
<em>Def.:</em> Local interpretation of the legislations that specify the procedures needed to ensure working safely in designated area.</p>
<ul>
<li>Local rules <em>must</em> include:</li>
<li>Description of controlled areas.</li>
<li>System of work within controlled areas, which includes:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Restricting access to it.</li>
<li>Specify the need for lead protection.</li>
<li>Staff monitoring.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Dose investigation levels.</li>
<li>RPS name.</li>
<li>Work instruction for unclassified workers.</li>
<li>Back up contingency plan for the department, in case of radiation accidents.</li>
<li>Local rules <em>can</em> also include:</li>
<li>management and supervision of work</li>
<li>testing and maintenance of safety features</li>
<li>radiation and contamination monitoring</li>
<li>testing of monitors</li>
<li>personal dosimetry</li>
<li>arrangements for pregnant and breast feeding staff</li>
<li>risk assessments</li>
<li>programme to review ALARA</li>
<li>RPA contact.</li>
<li>Every radiation employer shall provide Local Rules for any controlled or supervised area → according to the radiation risk &amp; nature of operations performed.</li>
<li>It should be set down in writing.</li>
<li>New employee get to read local rules &amp; sign to say they have understood.</li>
</ul>
<p>28</p>
<ul>
<li>The radiation employer shall ensure:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Observation of Local rules.</li>
<li>Local rules are followed by employees and other persons who may be affected.</li>
<li>Appoint radiation protection supervisors (RPS) to ensure Local rules compliance with the Regulations.
&amp; mention the names of RPSs in the local rules.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Local rules are A LEGAL DOCUMENT.</strong>
Policed by RPS &amp; Enforced by HSE inspector.</p>
<p><strong>Radiation Protection Supervisor:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Must be appointed “for the purpose of securing compliance of local rules with these Regulations”.</li>
<li>Name must be in Local Rules</li>
<li>It is recommended that RPS</li>
<li>know &amp; understand regulations and local rules</li>
<li>command sufficient authority</li>
<li>understand necessary precautions</li>
<li>know what to do in an emergency</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Requirements of Designated areas</strong></p>
<p><strong>IRR(1999); 19- Monitoring of designated areas</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Every employer shall monitor the levels of ionising radiation in the controlled &amp; supervised areas through suitable and sufficient equipment.</li>
<li>The monitoring equipments shall be -
a. adequately tested – by a qualified person – before its first use.
b. properly maintained
c. adequately tested and examined at appropriate intervals.</li>
<li>The employer shall make suitable records of the results of the monitoring and of the tests → authorised by a qualified person → &amp; keep the records for at least 2 years.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Employee allowed to enter or remain in Controlled area:</strong>
The employer shall not permit any employee to enter or remain in such an area except:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>An outside worker</strong> → is a classified person who is:
i. Received training required.
ii. Certified fit for the work with ionising radiation.
iii. Subject to individual dose assessment.
iv. Provided with personal protective equipment and trained to use them.
v. Have a radiation passbook issued by approved dosimetry service "which contain their personal details &amp; up-to-date radiation doses" before they enter Controlled area.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The employer shall ensure that <strong>the classified outside worker is:</strong></li>
<li>Subject to arrangements for estimating the dose of IR he receives whilst in the controlled area.</li>
<li>An estimate of the dose received by that worker in that controlled area must be entered into his radiation passbook.</li>
<li>the radiation passbook is made available to that worker upon request</li>
</ul>
<p>29</p>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>If not an outside worker:</strong>
i. Is a classified person.
ii. If not being a classified person → Not permitted to enters or remains in the area, unless the employer can demonstrate, by personal dose monitoring, that the doses are restricted as follows: -
“ in case of employee ≥ 18 years or over → not receive in any calendar year a cumulative dose of IR which require him to be a classified person; or
“ In case of any other person → not receive in any calendar year a dose &gt; any relevant dose limit.
“ The employer shall keep the results of the monitoring or measurements by personal dose monitoring for this non-classified persons for 2 years.
“ Employer shall make that results available to that person on request.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>If there is a significant risk of the spread of radioactive contamination from a controlled area:</strong>
The employer shall make adequate arrangements to restrict the spread of such contamination:</p>
<ol>
<li>provide suitable &amp; sufficient washing and changing facilities for persons who enter or leave any controlled or supervised area;</li>
<li>maintenance of such washing and changing facilities;</li>
<li>prohibit eating, drinking or smoking within controlled area → ↓↓ probability of ingestion of a radioactive substance; and</li>
<li>monitoring contamination of persons, articles or goods leaving a controlled area.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>IRR(1999): 35- Approval of dosimetry services:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Occurs in accordance with criteria specified by the Executive.</li>
<li>Approval is by a certificate in writing.</li>
<li>The purposes of these services are specified in the certificate.</li>
<li>The Executive may carry out a re-assessment of any approval.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>LEGAL LIABILITIES</strong>
▶ Definition of employer: anyone who uses ionizing radiation in a self-employed capacity, with their own equipment.</p>
<p><strong>Duties of Employer (IRMER2000)</strong>
(1) The employer shall put written procedures "System of work" for medical exposures &amp; ensure that the practitioner and operator are complied with.</p>
<p><strong>SCHEDULE 1</strong>
<strong>Employer's Procedures</strong>
<strong>The written procedures for medical exposures shall include -</strong>
(a) identify the individual to be exposed to ionising radiation;
(b) identify individuals entitled to act as referrer or practitioner or operator (i.e. identify competent staff for specific task);
(c) procedures to be observed in the case of medico-legal exposures;
(d) procedures established by the employer for biomedical and medical research programmes "i.e. no direct medical benefit for the individual";</p>
<p>30</p>
<p>(e) procedures for the use of diagnostic reference levels established by the employer for radiodiagnostic examinations;
(f) assessment of patient dose and administered activity;
(g) procedures for the carrying out and recording of an evaluation for each medical exposure including factors relevant to patient dose; &amp; review if they are consistently exceeded &amp; take appropriate actions.
(h) procedures for making enquiries of females of childbearing age to establish whether the individual is or may be pregnant or breastfeeding;
(i) procedures to ensure that quality assurance programmes are followed;
(j) procedures for giving information and written instructions for patients undergoing treatment or diagnosis with radioactive material;
(k) Procedures to ensure that the probability and magnitude of accidental or unintended doses to patients from radiological practices are reduced so far as reasonably practicable.</p>
<p>(2) Write protocols for every <strong>standard</strong> radiological examination practice for each equipment.</p>
<p>(3) <strong>The employer shall establish -</strong>
a) Referral criteria, including radiation doses, and ensure that these are available to the referrer;
b) Quality assurance programmes;
c) diagnostic reference levels for radiodiagnostic examinations regard to European diagnostic reference levels where available;
d) Dose constraints for biomedical and medical research programmes.</p>
<p>(4) The employer shall take steps to ensure that:
a) no practitioner or operator shall carry out a medical exposure or any practical aspect without having been adequately trained; and
b) practitioners or operators undertakes continuing training for new techniques.</p>
<p>(5) <strong>In case of radiation overexposure incident:</strong>
i. Make an immediate preliminary investigation of the incident.
ii. Notify the appropriate authority.
iii. Arrange for a detailed investigation of the circumstances of the exposure.
iv. Arrange for an assessment of the dose received.</p>
<p>(6) If diagnostic reference levels are exceeded → undertake appropriate reviews and ensure that corrective action is taken.</p>
<p><strong>Other duties of Employer:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>clinical audit in accordance with national procedures <strong>must</strong> be performed.</li>
<li>Ensure a medical physics expert in areas specified</li>
<li>All employers using ionizing radiation in controlled areas should (i.e. required by law) to appoint RPA to provide advice on practical means of complying the legislations.</li>
<li>Keep an equipment inventory</li>
<li>Limit the amount of equipments.</li>
<li>Legislation lays "<strong>Duty of care</strong>" on Employers → responsibility for ensuring that regulations are followed (through Radiation Protection Committee).</li>
<li>Local rules are produced by or on behalf of the employer.</li>
<li>Ensuring the requirements to comply the RSA93.</li>
</ol>
<p>31</p>
<p>The employer is on the top of the organization tree "but legal liabilities may be shared with other individuals" see Table 6.7</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="responsibilities-for-radiation-safety">Responsibilities for radiation safety<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-for-radiation-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="radiation-employer">Radiation Employer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radiation-employer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Authorisation of practice.</li>
<li>Notification of specified work.</li>
<li>Prior risk assessment.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="irr-1999-5-authorisation-of-specified-practices">IRR(1999); 5-Authorisation of specified practices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-5-authorisation-of-specified-practices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A radiation employer shall not carry out the following practices, except in with a prior authorisation by <strong>the Executive</strong> in writing, -</li>
<li>(a) the use of electrical equipment intended to produce x-rays -</li>
<li>(b) the use of accelerators, except electron microscopes.</li>
<li>This authorisation may be granted subject to conditions and with or without limit of time and may be revoked in writing at any time.</li>
<li>If the radiation employer attempt to make a material change to the circumstances relating to that authorisation → that change shall also be notified to the Executive.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="irr-1999-6-notification-of-specified-work">IRR(1999); 6- Notification of specified work<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-6-notification-of-specified-work" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A radiation employer shall not for the first time carry out work with ionising radiation unless at least 28 days before commencing that work he has notified the Executive of his intention to carry out that work.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="schedule-1-regulations-6-1-and-13-3">SCHEDULE 1 - Regulations 6(1) and 13(3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-1-regulations-6-1-and-13-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>WORK NOT REQUIRED TO BE NOTIFIED UNDER REGULATION 6</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>(a) where the concentration of activity per unit mass of a radioactive substance does not exceed the concentration specified in column 2 of Part I of Schedule 8;</li>
<li>(b) where the <strong>quantity of radioactive substance</strong> involved does not exceed the quantity specified in column 3 of Part I of Schedule 8;</li>
<li>(c) where apparatus contains radioactive substances in a <strong>quantity exceeding</strong> the values specified but -</li>
<li>the apparatus is of a type approved by the Executive;</li>
<li>the apparatus is constructed in the form of a sealed source;</li>
<li>the apparatus does not under normal operating conditions cause a dose rate of more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mu \mathrm{Sv}\backslash \mathrm{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Sv</span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span></span></span></span></span> at a distance of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> from any accessible surface; and</li>
<li>conditions for the disposal of the apparatus have been specified by the appropriate Agency;</li>
<li>(d) the operation of any electrical apparatus (except those for next point) provided that -</li>
<li>the apparatus is of a type approved by the Executive; and</li>
</ul>
<p>32</p>
<p>“ the apparatus does not under normal operating conditions cause a dose rate of more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mu \mathrm{Sv}\backslash \mathrm{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Sv</span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span></span></span></span></span> at a distance of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> from any accessible surface;</p>
<p>(e) the operation of -
“ any cathode ray tube intended for the display of visual images; or
“ any other electrical apparatus operating at a potential difference not exceeding <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30\mathrm{kV}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kV</span></span></span></span></span></span>,
→ provided that the operation of the tube or apparatus does not under normal operating conditions cause a dose rate of more than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">v</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">\</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mu \mathrm{Sv}\backslash \mathrm{h}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Sv</span></span><span class="mord">\</span><span class="mord mathrm">h</span></span></span></span></span> at a distance of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.1\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">0.1</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> from any accessible surface;</p>
<p>(f) where the work involves material contaminated with radioactive substances resulting from authorised releases which the appropriate Agency has declared not to be subject to further control.</p>
<p>The Employer should provide the Executive with the particulars specified in Schedule 2</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schedule-2-regulation-6-2">SCHEDULE 2 - Regulation 6(2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-2-regulation-6-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars-to-be-provided-in-a-notification-under-regulation-6-2">PARTICULARS TO BE PROVIDED IN A NOTIFICATION UNDER REGULATION 6(2)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-to-be-provided-in-a-notification-under-regulation-6-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) The employer contacts: name, address, telephone or fax number or email address;
b) the address of the premises where or from where the work activity is to be carried out and a telephone or fax number or email address at such premises;
c) whether or not any source is to be used at premises other than the address given; and
d) the nature of the business of the employer;
e) the category of the sources of ionising radiation:
(i) sealed source;
(ii) unsealed radioactive substance;
(iii) electrical equipment;
(iv) an atmosphere containing the short-lived daughters of radon 222;
f) dates of notification and commencement of the work activity.</p>
<p>The Executive may require that radiation employer provide additional particulars of that work → Schedule 3.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="schedule-3-regulation-6-3">SCHEDULE 3 - Regulation 6(3)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#schedule-3-regulation-6-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-particulars-that-the-executive-may-require">ADDITIONAL PARTICULARS THAT THE EXECUTIVE MAY REQUIRE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-particulars-that-the-executive-may-require" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) a description of the work with ionising radiation;
(b) sources of IR " type of electrical equipment or nature of RAS used";
(c) the quantities of any radioactive substance involved in the work;
(d) the identity of any person engaged in the work;
(e) the date of commencement &amp; the duration over which the work is carried on;
(f) the location and description of any premises at which the work is carried out;
(g) the date of termination of the work;
(h) further information on any of the particulars listed in Schedule 2.</p>
<p>33</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">♣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\clubsuit</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8241em; vertical-align: -0.1296em;"></span><span class="mord">♣</span></span></span></span></span> If a radiation employer makes any change that would affect the particulars so notified → he shall notify the Executive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="irr-1999-7-prior-risk-assessment-etc">IRR(1999); 7- Prior risk assessment etc.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-1999-7-prior-risk-assessment-etc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">♣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\clubsuit</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8241em; vertical-align: -0.1296em;"></span><span class="mord">♣</span></span></span></span></span> Before a radiation employer commences a new activity involving work with ionising radiation, he shall make a suitable and sufficient assessment of the risk to any employee and other person for the purpose of identifying the measures he needs to take to restrict the exposure.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">♣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\clubsuit</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8241em; vertical-align: -0.1296em;"></span><span class="mord">♣</span></span></span></span></span> An assessment should -
(a) identify all hazards; and
(b) evaluate the nature and magnitude of the risks to employees and other persons arising from those hazards.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">♣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\clubsuit</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8241em; vertical-align: -0.1296em;"></span><span class="mord">♣</span></span></span></span></span> If the assessment shows that a radiation risk to employees or other persons exists from an identifiable radiation accident, the radiation employer shall take all reasonably practicable steps to -
(a) prevent any accident;
(b) limit the consequences of any such accident which does occur; and
(c) provide employees with the information, instruction and training, and equipments necessary, to restrict their exposure to ionising radiation.
(d) prepare a contingency plan designed to secure the restriction of exposure to ionising radiation and the health and safety of persons who may be affected by such accident</p>
<p>&amp; he shall ensure that:
“a copy of the contingency plan is identified in the local rules;
“any employee under his control who may be involved in the plan has been given suitable and sufficient instructions and where appropriate issued with suitable dosemeters or other devices; and
“Rehearsals of the arrangements in the plan at suitable intervals.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">♣</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\clubsuit</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8241em; vertical-align: -0.1296em;"></span><span class="mord">♣</span></span></span></span></span> Duties of employee:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-responsibilities-for-radiation-safety">I- responsibilities for radiation safety:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-responsibilities-for-radiation-safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(1) Not expose himself or any other person to IR greater than necessary for the purposes of his work.
(2) Shall exercise reasonable care while carrying out his work.
(3) If a personal protective equipment is provided to him, he shall:
(a) Make full and proper use of personal protective equipment.
(b) Report the employer for any defect in personal protective equipment.
(c) Ensure personal protective equipment is returned after use to the accommodation provided for it.
(4) Shall notify his employer of any overexposure, radiation accident or RA substance leakage.
(5) Report equipment defects.</p>
<p>34</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-extra-duties-for-classified-persons">II- Extra-duties for classified persons:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-extra-duties-for-classified-persons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Not to misuse the radiation passbook or falsify any information in it
(2) Comply with the local rules, dose measurements &amp; assessment for classified workers.
(3) Subject to medical surveillance:</p>
<ul>
<li>When required by his employer.</li>
<li>At the cost of the employer &amp; during working hours.</li>
<li>Shall provide the appointed doctor or employment medical adviser with such information concerning his health</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duties-of-the-referrer">Duties of the Referrer:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duties-of-the-referrer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Supply the practitioner with sufficient medical data relevant to the medical exposure to enable the practitioner to decide on whether there is a sufficient net benefit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duties-of-practitioner-operator">Duties of Practitioner &amp; Operator:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duties-of-practitioner-operator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Practitioner</th><th>Operator</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(1) Responsible for the justification of a medical exposure</td><td>(1) Responsible for each and every practical aspect which he carries out.</td></tr><tr><td>(2) Not necessarily a medic – could be a radiographer if specialized in certain procedures.</td><td>(2) In fluoroscopy, ensure AEC used unless other method justified.</td></tr><tr><td>(3) Both shall comply with the employer's procedures.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(4) Must cooperate with other specialists &amp; staff involved in the exposure.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(5) Undergo continuing education or training.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-physics-experts">Medical Physics Experts:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-physics-experts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Employer shall ensure that a medical physics expert is involved in every exposure.</li>
<li>Medical physics experts must have a science degree &amp; experienced in the application of physics to the diagnostic &amp; therapeutic uses of ionising radiation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="duties-of-medical-physics-expert">Duties of medical physics expert:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duties-of-medical-physics-expert" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Give advice on radiation protection concerning medical exposure.
b) <strong>closely involved</strong> in every radiotherapeutic practice other than standardised therapeutic nuclear medicine practices;
c) <strong>available</strong> in standardised therapeutic nuclear medicine practices and in diagnostic nuclear medicine practices;
d) In all other radiological practices → he shall be <strong>involved</strong> for consultation on optimisation, including patient dosimetry and quality assurance.</p>
<p>&gt; Any <strong>new work</strong> or change in work with ionizing radiation should be <strong>notified</strong> to HSE 28 days before starting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="responsibilities-of-hse">Responsibilities of HSE:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-hse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Enforcing IRR.</li>
<li>Have the power to prosecute the employer or individual workers under civil or criminal law.</li>
</ol>
<p>35</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="radioactive-substances-act-93-rsa93">RADIOACTIVE SUBSTANCES ACT 93 (RSA93)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radioactive-substances-act-93-rsa93" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>i. This is a legal document that organizes acquisition, storage, and safe disposal of any radioactive substance. This act controls radioactive substances in the environment
ii. The requirements to comply with this Act are the responsibility of the EMPLOYER.</p>
<hr>
<p>IRR 1999 - PART VI</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="arrangements-for-the-control-of-radioactive-substances-articles-and-equipment">ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE CONTROL OF RADIOACTIVE SUBSTANCES, ARTICLES AND EQUIPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arrangements-for-the-control-of-radioactive-substances-articles-and-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="27-sealed-sources-and-articles-containing-or-embodying-radioactive-substances">27- Sealed sources and articles containing or embodying radioactive substances:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#27-sealed-sources-and-articles-containing-or-embodying-radioactive-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The radiation employer shall ensure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>The radioactive substance used as a source of ionising radiation is in the form of a sealed source.</li>
<li>the design, construction and maintenance of any article containing a radioactive substance, including its bonding, immediate container or other mechanical protection, is such as to prevent the leakage of any radioactive substance -</li>
<li>(a) in the case of a sealed source → so far as is practicable; or</li>
<li>(b) in the case of any other article → so far as is reasonably practicable.</li>
<li>Suitable tests are carried out at suitable intervals to detect leakage of radioactive substances from any article → &amp; make a suitable record of each test &amp; keep for at least 2 years after the article is disposed of or until a further record is made following a subsequent test to that article.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="28-accounting-for-radioactive-substances">28- Accounting for radioactive substances:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#28-accounting-for-radioactive-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every radiation employer shall take steps to account for and keep records of the quantity and location of radioactive substances involved in work with ionising radiation.</li>
<li>Shall keep the records for at least 2 years from the date on which they were made and for at least 2 years from the date of disposal of that radioactive substance.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="29-keeping-and-moving-of-radioactive-substances">29- Keeping and moving of radioactive substances:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#29-keeping-and-moving-of-radioactive-substances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every radiation employer shall ensure that any radioactive substance not in use or being moved, transported or disposed of -</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>is kept in a suitable receptacle; and</li>
<li>is kept in a suitable store.</li>
<li>suitably labelled.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="30-notification-of-certain-occurrences">30- Notification of certain occurrences:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#30-notification-of-certain-occurrences" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the following 2 cases:</p>
<ul>
<li>If a radioactive substance is released into the atmosphere as a gas, aerosol or dust; or spilled (in quantity exceeds the quantity in column 4 of Schedule 8).</li>
<li>If a radioactive substance is lost or stolen "in quantity exceeds the quantity in column 5 of Schedule 8"</li>
</ul>
<p>36</p>
<p>In both cases, a radiation employer shall:</p>
<ol>
<li>Notify the Executive.</li>
<li>Make an immediate investigation → make a report &amp; keep it for at least 50 years (if the problem happened) or for at least 2 years (if investigation shows that the problem didn't actually occur).</li>
</ol>
<p>31- Duties of manufacturers etc. of articles for use in work with ionising radiation</p>
<p>× In the case of articles for use at work with ionising radiation shall be designed and constructed to restrict the exposure of employees and other persons to ionising radiation as far as reasonably practicable.
× Where a person erects or installs an article for use in work with ionising radiation, he shall -</p>
<ol>
<li>Undertake a critical examination to ensure that -
“ the safety features and warning devices operate correctly; and
“ there is sufficient protection for persons from exposure to ionising radiation;</li>
<li>Consult with the radiation protection adviser about the nature and extent of any critical examination and the results of that examination; and</li>
<li>Provide the radiation employer with adequate information about proper use, testing and maintenance of the article.</li>
</ol>
<p>37</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="protection-of-patients-irmer2000">PROTECTION OF PATIENTS (IRMER2000)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#protection-of-patients-irmer2000" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>IRNER2000 is concerned with appropriate use of radiation procedures on patients by properly trained staff</p>
<p>The regulation outline:</p>
<ol>
<li>The core of knowledge = the theoretical knowledge that staff should have (see table 6.8).</li>
<li>It specify the need of practical instruction for all staff.</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Table 6.8 Core of knowledge in the POPUMET regulations</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Nature of ionizing radiation and its interaction with tissue.</td></tr><tr><td>2. Genetic and somatic effects of ionizing radiation and how to assess their risks</td></tr><tr><td>3. The ranges of radiation dose that are given to a patient with a particular procedure, the principal factors which affect the dose and the methods of measuring such doses.</td></tr><tr><td>4. The principles of quality assurance and quality control applied to both equipment and techniques.</td></tr><tr><td>5. The principles of dose limitation and the various means of dose reduction to the patient including protection of the gonads.</td></tr><tr><td>6. The specific requirements of women who are, or who may be, pregnant and also of children.</td></tr><tr><td>7. If applicable, the precautions necessary for handling sealed and unsealed sources.</td></tr><tr><td>8. The organizational arrangements for advice in radiation protection and how to deal with a suspected case of overexposure.</td></tr><tr><td>9. Statutory responsibilities.</td></tr><tr><td>10. In respect of the individual diagnostic and therapeutic procedures which the person intends to use, the clinical value of those procedures in relation to other available techniques used for the same or similar purposes.</td></tr><tr><td>11. The importance of utilizing existing radiological information - films and/or reports - about a patient</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Staff individuals can be divided into:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>individuals clinically directing the exposures e.g. Radiologist:
“Staff members who carry the clinical responsibility.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Staff physically directing the exposure e.g. Radiographer:
“Those who directly irradiate patients.
“if not well-trained → can't work except under supervision of well-trained person (till he complete his training)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Regulation 4 of POPUMET is fundamental to patient protection, it requires: Every medical exposure to be carried out under the direction of a person who is clinically directing the exposure.</p>
<p>a) ensure that only accepted diagnostic practices are used.
b) Ensure selection of procedures &amp; fulfill Justification &amp; Optimization principles:</p>
<p>i. Ensure patient dose is ALARP.
ii. Ensure examination is consistent with requirements for diagnosis.
iii. Ensure particular care of pregnant patients.</p>
<p>38</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="refferrals">REFFERRALS:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#refferrals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The radiologist takes responsibility for clinical direction (So, the request from the clinician is only a request of opinion, the radiologist is having the right to refuse, accept, or tail out a study according to the clinical situation)</li>
<li>The request form – properly filled by clinician – is a legal document.</li>
<li>There should be locally agreed referral criteria set by the employer.</li>
</ul>
<p>The RCR handbook "Making the best use of radiology department" may be used as a basis for referral practice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sharing-responsibilities">Sharing responsibilities:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sharing-responsibilities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Other (non radiologist) medical staff as orthopaedicians, cardiac catheterizators may take responsibility of directing for procedure (physically, or clinically) like in case of C-arm fluoroscopy in Operation Room, or Cathlab.
ii. Any radiographer who continues with a procedure knowing that it is inappropriate, is equally culpable (blamable) in law (i.e. responsible in front of law).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="legal-liability-irr99">Legal liability (IRR99)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#legal-liability-irr99" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>IRR 1999 regulates the responsibility of each, the employer as well as the person who is physically (tech) or clinically (radiologist) directing the study. (Employer, Practitioner and Operator)</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>responsible for enforcing persons clinically or physically directing examinations lies on secretary of State Of Health (who uses health department inspectorate).</li>
<li>There is no umbrella of an employer ??!</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 6.7 Legal liability and inspection</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>LEGISLATION</th><th></th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>IRR8S</td><td>IRR[POPUMET] 88</td><td>M(ARS)R 78</td><td>RSA93</td></tr><tr><td>Area</td><td>X-rays and nuclear medicine</td><td>X-rays and nuclear medicine</td><td>Nuclear medicine</td><td>Nuclear medicine</td></tr><tr><td>Liability</td><td>Employer and employee</td><td>Employer and practitioner</td><td>Employer and practitioner</td><td>Employer</td></tr><tr><td>Inspection</td><td>HSE</td><td>HSE and Government Health Departments</td><td>Departments of Health and of the Environment</td><td>Departments of the Environment</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>39</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="legal-liability-m-ars-regulations">Legal liability (M[ARS] regulations)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#legal-liability-m-ars-regulations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Use of radiopharmaceuticals (diagnostic and therapeutic purpose) is regulated by the M[ARS] in addition to POPUMET.</li>
<li>Procedure should be performed UNDER SUPERVISION OF an ARSAC certificate holder.(MCQ)</li>
<li>Injection may be performed by other staff, but under supervision of ARSAC holder. (Administration of Radioactive Substance Advisory Committee)</li>
<li>Maximum dose to the patient is defined in the certificate.</li>
<li>Everyone who is involved in a procedure (ARSAC holder clinician, or injector, the one physically conducting the procedure) need to be trained under IRR[POPUMET]</li>
<li>Employer is responsible to ensure that clinicians are holding ARSAC.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="regarding-the-arsac-certificates-department-of-health">Regarding the ARSAC certificates "Department of Health"<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regarding-the-arsac-certificates-department-of-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Must be held by the person clinically supervising procedures using RAS.</li>
<li>Authorize certain procedures to be performed by it's holder.</li>
<li>Define max. dose to patients (max. activity to be administrated).</li>
<li>Issued to individual clinicians- for specific procedures- (including research) using specific equipment.</li>
<li>Valid for 5 years (&amp; only 2 years for research purposes).</li>
<li>Needs to be signed by RPA.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="responsibilities-of-arsac-certificate-holder">Responsibilities of ARSAC certificate holder:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#responsibilities-of-arsac-certificate-holder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Gives clinical supervision to procedures using RAS.</li>
<li>Instructing &amp; supervising the person physically directing patients.</li>
<li>Responsible for discharging radioactive patients from hospital:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Depending on max. activity remaining in the body.</li>
<li>Gives specific behavioral instruction or advice to patient (e.g. stop lactation).</li>
<li>RPA should be able to give further advice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="irr-32-equipment-used-for-radiodiagnosis-and-treatment">IRR 32. EQUIPMENT USED FOR RADIODIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#irr-32-equipment-used-for-radiodiagnosis-and-treatment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>"Radiation equipment" means equipment which delivers ionising radiation to the person undergoing a medical exposure and equipment which directly controls the extent of the exposure.</p>
<p>(1) Every employer who controls any equipment which is used for medical exposure shall ensure that such equipment is of such design or construction and is so installed and maintained to be capable of restricting the exposure to ionising radiation of any person undergoing a medical exposure "diagnostic, therapeutic or research" to a compatible extent.</p>
<p>"This includes the use of equipments which directly affects the dose to the patient, e.g. film processors, intensifying screens, radionuclide dose calibrators, etc.</p>
<p>(2) An employer who controls any radiation equipment "installed after the date of these Regulations" shall ensure that it is provided with suitable means for informing its user of the quantity of radiation produced during a radiological procedure.</p>
<p>(3) Every employer shall make arrangements to provide a suitable quality assurance programme for the equipment → to ensure it remains capable of restricting exposure.</p>
<p>40</p>
<p>(4) the quality assurance programme shall provide: -
(a) adequate testing of New equipments before its first use for clinical purposes by an RPA appointed by the employer.
(b) adequate testing of the performance of the equipment at appropriate intervals and after any major maintenance procedure.
(c) measurements at suitable intervals to enable the assessment of doses to persons undergoing medical exposures.</p>
<p>(5) Every employer shall take all steps to monitor &amp; prevent the failure of any equipment which could result in an exposure to ionising radiation greater than intended and to limit the consequences of such failure.</p>
<ul>
<li>To monitor equipment malfunctions "what is accepted to occur from time to time".</li>
<li>There must be systems to detect and to correct for malfunctions.</li>
<li>There should be a log for recording of faults and defects for each X-ray unit.</li>
<li>Deterioration in performance does not necessarily mean that equipment should be withdrawn from use → it may mean that certain procedures should no longer be carried out using that equipment.</li>
<li>The equipment should be properly justified for the new uses.</li>
</ul>
<p>(6) Where a radiation employer suspects or has been informed that an incident may have occurred in which a person while undergoing a medical exposure was exposed to ionising radiation to an extent much greater than intended, as the result of a malfunction of, or defect in, radiation equipment under his control حادث نتيجة عيب بالجهاز, he shall:
i. Make an immediate investigation of the suspected incident.
ii. If that investigation shows that an incident has occurred:</p>
<ul>
<li>Employer shall notify the Executive.</li>
<li>Make or arrange for a detailed investigation of the circumstances of the exposure and an assessment of the dose received.
iii. A radiation employer shall make a report of that investigation and shall -</li>
<li>Immediate investigation report → keep that report for at least 2 years.</li>
<li>Detailed investigation report → keep that report for at least 50 years.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>IRMER 10- Equipment:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The employer shall draw up, keep up-to-date and preserve at each radiological installation an inventory of equipment at that installation.</li>
<li>Employer shall furnish the inventory to the appropriate authority when requested.</li>
<li>The inventory shall contain the following information -</li>
<li>name of manufacturer,</li>
<li>model number,</li>
<li>serial number or other unique identifier,</li>
<li>year of manufacture, and</li>
<li>year of installation.</li>
<li>The employer shall ensure that equipment at each radiological installation is limited to the amount necessary for the proper carrying out of medical exposures at that installation.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="stAppIframeResizerAnchor" data-iframe-height="true" class="st-emotion-cache-1dumvfu eht7o1d9"></div></section></div></div></div><div data-testid="portal" id="portal" class="st-emotion-cache-1q6lfs0 e19n7mk11"></div></div><div class=""></div></div>
  

</body></html>
